Mr. <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>,<br />
Mr. <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>,<br />
Young Gentlemen of the town.<br />
<br />
Alderman <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>, seemingly precise, but a covetous,
lecherous, old Usurer of the city.<br />
<br />
Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span>, a Coxcomb, always in pursuit of
women of great fortunes.<br />
<br />
Mr. <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>, a brisk, conceited, half-witted fellow of
the town.<br />
<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite's</span> Landlord, and his Prentices, Servants,
Waiters, and other Attendants.<br />
<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Christina, Valentine's</span> Mistress.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Lydia, Ranger's</span> Mistress.<br />
<br />
Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant, Gripe's</span> Sister, an affected Widow in
distress for a husband, though still declaiming
against marriage.<br />
<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha, Gripe's</span> Daughter.<br />
<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>, a Match-maker, or precise city bawd.<br />
<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite</span>, an old cheating jill, and bawd to her
Daughter.<br />
<br />
Miss <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite's</span> Daughter.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Isabel, Christina's</span> Woman.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Leonore</span>, Servant to <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>.<br />
<br />
<br />
SCENE&mdash;<span class="smcap">London</span>.</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_11" id="Page_11">[Pg 11]</a></span></p>




<h2><i>LOVE IN A WOOD;<br />
OR,<br />
ST. JAMES'S PARK.</i></h2>


<h3>ACT THE FIRST.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Gripe's</span> <i>House, in the evening.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lady Flip.</i> Not a husband to be had
for money!&mdash;Come, come, I might
have been a better housewife for myself,
as the world goes now, if I had
dealt for an heir with his guardian,
uncle, or mother-in-law; and you are
no better than a chouse, a cheat.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I a cheat, madam!</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I am out of my money, and patience too.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Do not run out of your patience, whatever
you do:&mdash;'tis a necessary virtue for a widow without a
jointure, in truly.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Vile woman! though my fortune be something
wasted, my person's in good repair. If I had not
depended on you, I had had a husband before this time.
When I gave you the last five pounds, did you not promise
I should be married by Christmas?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> And I had kept my promise if you had co-operated.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_12" id="Page_12">[Pg 12]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Co-operated! what should I have done? 'Tis
well known no woman breathing could use more industry
to get her a husband than I have. Has not my
husband's 'scutcheon walked as much ground as the
citizens' signs since the Fire?&mdash;that no quarter of the
town might be ignorant of the widow Flippant.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> 'Tis well known, madam, indeed.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Have I not owned myself (against my stomach)
the relict of a citizen, to credit my fortune?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> 'Tis confessed, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Have I not constantly kept Covent-Garden
church, St. Martin's, the playhouses, Hyde Park, Mulberry
garden,<a name="FNanchor_26_26" id="FNanchor_26_26"></a><a href="#Footnote_26_26" class="fnanchor">[26]</a> and all the other public marts where
widows and maids are exposed?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Far be it from me to think you have an
aversion to a husband. But why, madam, have you
refused so many good offers?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Good offers, Mrs. Joyner! I'll be sworn I
never had an offer since my late husband's.&mdash;If I had an
offer, Mrs. Joyner!&mdash;there's the thing, Mrs. Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Then your frequent and public detestation
of marriage is thought real; and if you have had no
offer, there's the thing, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I cannot deny but I always rail against
marriage;&mdash;which is the widow's way to it certainly.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_13" id="Page_13">[Pg 13]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> 'Tis the desperate way of the desperate
widows, in truly.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Would you have us as tractable as the wenches
that eat oatmeal, and fooled like them too?</p>

<p><i>Mrs Joyn.</i> If nobody were wiser than I, I should think,
since the widow wants the natural allurement which the
virgin has, you ought to give men all other encouragements,
in truly.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Therefore, on the contrary, because the
widow's fortune (whether supposed or real) is her chiefest
bait, the more chary she seems of it, and the more she
withdraws it, the more eagerly the busy gaping fry will
bite. With us widows, husbands are got like bishoprics,
by saying "No:" and I tell you, a young heir is as shy
of a widow as of a rook, to my knowledge.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I can allege nothing against your practice&mdash;but
your ill success; and indeed you must use another
method with Sir Simon Addleplot.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Will he be at your house at the hour?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> He'll be there by ten:&mdash;'tis now nine. I'll
warrant you he will not fail.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I'll warrant you then I will not fail:&mdash;for 'tis
more than time I were sped.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Mr. Dapperwit has not been too busy with
you, I hope?&mdash;Your experience has taught you to prevent
a mischance.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> No, no, my mischance (as you call it) is
greater than that. I have but three months to reckon,
ere I lie down with my port and equipage, and must be
delivered of a woman, a footman, and a coachman:&mdash;for
my coach must down, unless I can get Sir Simon to
draw with me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> He will pair with you exactly if you knew
all. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Ah, Mrs. Joyner, nothing grieves me like the
putting down my coach! For the fine clothes, the fine
lodgings,&mdash;let 'em go; for a lodging is as unnecessary a<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_14" id="Page_14">[Pg 14]</a></span>
thing to a widow that has a coach, as a hat to a man
that has a good peruke. For, as you see about town,
she is most properly at home in her coach:&mdash;she eats,
and drinks, and sleeps in her coach; and for her visits,
she receives them in the playhouse.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Ay, ay, let the men keep lodgings, as you
say, madam, if they will.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter behind, at one door,</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span> <i>and</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span>,
<i>the latter in the dress of a</i> Clerk; <i>at the other,</i>
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Do you think if things had been with me as
they have been, I would ever have housed with this
counter-fashion brother of mine, (who hates a vest as
much as a surplice,) to have my patches assaulted every
day at dinner, my freedom censured, and my visitants shut
out of doors?&mdash;Poor Mr. Dapperwit cannot be admitted.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> He knows him too well to keep his acquaintance.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> He is a censorious rigid fop, and knows
nothing.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> So, so! [<i>Behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Is he here?&mdash;[<i>To</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.]
Nay, with your pardon, madam, I must contradict you
there. He is a prying commonwealth's-man, an implacable
magistrate, a sturdy pillar of his cause, and&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Gripe</span>] But, oh me, is your worship so near then?
if I had thought you heard me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Why, why, Mrs. Joyner, I have said as much
of myself ere now; and without vanity, I profess.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I know your virtue is proof against vainglory;
but the truth to your face looks like flattery in
your worship's servant.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, no; say what you will of me in that kind,
far be it from me to suspect you of flattery.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> In truly, your worship knows yourself, and
knows me, for I am none of those&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_15" id="Page_15">[Pg 15]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Now they are in&mdash;Mrs. Joyner, I'll
go before to your house, you'll be sure to come after me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Immediately.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.]
But as I was saying, I am none of those&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, Mrs. Joyner, you cannot sew pillows under
folks' elbows; you cannot hold a candle to the devil;
you cannot tickle a trout to take him; you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Lord, how well you do know me indeed!&mdash;and
you shall see I know your worship as well. You
cannot backslide from your principles; you cannot be
terrified by the laws; nor bribed to allegiance by office or
preferment; you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Hold, hold, my praise must not interrupt
yours.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> With your worship's pardon, in truly, I
must on.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I am full of your praise, and it will run over.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Nay, sweet sir, you are&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Nay, sweet Mrs. Joyner, you are&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Nay, good your worship, you are&mdash;[<i>Stops
her mouth with his handkerchief.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I say you are&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I must not be rude with your worship.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> You are a nursing mother to the saints;
through you they gather together; through you they
fructify and increase; and through you the child cries
from out of the hand-basket.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Through you virgins are married, or provided
for as well; through you the reprobate's wife is
made a saint; and through you the widow is not disconsolate,
nor misses her husband.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Through you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Indeed you will put me to the blush.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Blushes are badges of imperfection:&mdash;saints
have no shame. You are&mdash;are the flower of matrons,
Mrs. Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You are the pink of courteous aldermen.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_16" id="Page_16">[Pg 16]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> You are the muffler of secrecy.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You are the head-band of justice.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Thank you, sweet Mrs. Joyner: do you think
so indeed? You are&mdash;you are the bonfire of devotion.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You are the bellows of zeal.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> You are the cupboard of charity.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You are the fob of liberality.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> You are the rivet of sanctified love or wedlock.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You are the picklock and dark-lantern of
policy; and, in a word, a conventicle of virtues.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Your servant, your servant, sweet Mrs. Joyner!
you have stopped my mouth.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Your servant, your servant, sweet alderman!
I have nothing to say.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> The half pullet will be cold, sir.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Mrs. Joyner, you shall sup with me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Indeed I am engaged to supper with some
of your man's friends; and I came on purpose to get
leave for him too.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I cannot deny you anything. But I have forgot
to tell you what a kind of fellow my sister's Dapperwit
is: before a full table of the coffee-house sages, he had
the impudence to hold an argument against me in the
defence of vests and protections; and therefore I forbid
him my house; besides, when he came I was forced to
lock up my daughter for fear of him, nay, I think the
poor child herself was afraid of him.&mdash;Come hither, child,
were you not afraid of Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Yes indeed, sir, he is a terrible man.&mdash;Yet I
durst meet with him in a piazza at midnight. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> He shall never come into my doors again.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Shall Mr. Dapperwit never come hither
again then?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, child.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> I am afraid he will.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I warrant thee.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_17" id="Page_17">[Pg 17]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I warrant you then I'll go to him.&mdash;I
am glad of that, for I hate him as much as a bishop.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Thou art no child of mine, if thou dost not
hate bishops and wits.&mdash;Well, Mrs. Joyner, I'll keep you
no longer. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Addleplot</span>.] Jonas, wait on Mrs.
Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Good night to your worship.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> But stay, stay, Mrs. Joyner: have you spoken
with the widow Crossbite about her little daughter, as I
desired?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I will to-morrow early; it shall be the first
thing I'll do after my prayers.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> If Dapperwit should contaminate her!&mdash;I cannot
rest till I have redeemed her from the jaws of that
lion.&mdash;Good night.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Good gentleman.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Ha! ha! ha! Mrs. Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What's the matter, Sir Simon?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;let us make haste to your
house, or I shall burst, faith and troth, to see what fools
you and I make of these people.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I will not rob you of any of the credit;
I am but a feeble instrument, you are an engineer.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Remember what you say now when things
succeed, and do not tell me then,&mdash;I must thank your
wit for all.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> No, in truly, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, I am sure Dapperwit and I have been
partners in many an intrigue, and he uses to serve
me so.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> He is an ill man to intrigue with, as you
call it.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Ay, so are all your wits; a pox! if a man's
understanding be not so public as theirs, he cannot do a
wise action but they go away with the honour of it, if he
be of their acquaintance.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_18" id="Page_18">[Pg 18]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Why do you keep such acquaintance then?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> There is a proverb, Mrs. Joyner, "You may
know him by his company."</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> No, no, to be thought a man of parts, you
must always keep company with a man of less wit than
yourself.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> That's the hardest thing in the world for me
to do, faith and troth.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What, to find a man of less wit than yourself?
Pardon my raillery, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> No, no, I cannot keep company with a fool:&mdash;I
wonder how men of parts can do't, there's something
in't.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> If you could, all your wise actions would
be your own, and your money would be your own too.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, faith and troth, that's true; for your
wits are plaguily given to borrow. They'll borrow of
their wench, coachman, or linkboy, their hire, Mrs.
Joyner; Dapperwit has that trick with a vengeance.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Why will you keep company with him
then, I say? for, to be plain with you, you have followed
him so long, that you are thought but his cully;<a name="FNanchor_27_27" id="FNanchor_27_27"></a><a href="#Footnote_27_27" class="fnanchor">[27]</a> for
every wit has his cully, as every squire his led captain.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I his cully, I his cully, Mrs. Joyner! Lord,
that I should be thought a cully to any wit breathing!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Nay, do not take it so to heart, for the
best wits of the town are but cullies themselves.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> To whom, to whom, to whom, Mrs. Joyner?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> To sempstresses and bawds.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> To your knowledge, Mrs. Joyner.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
There I was with her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> To tailors and vintners, but especially to
the French houses.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> But Dapperwit is a cully to none of them;
for he ticks.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_19" id="Page_19">[Pg 19]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I care not, but I wish you were a cully to
none but me; that's all the hurt I wish you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Thank you, Mrs. Joyner. Well, I will throw
off Dapperwit's acquaintance when I am married, and
will only be a cully to my wife; and that's no more than
the wisest husband of 'em all is.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Then you think you shall carry Mrs.
Martha?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Your hundred guineas are as good as in your
lap.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But I am afraid this double plot of yours
should fail: you would sooner succeed if you only
designed upon Mrs. Martha, or only upon my Lady
Flippant.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, then, you are no woman of intrigue,
faith and troth: 'tis good to have two strings to one's
bow. If Mrs. Martha be coy, I tell the widow I put on
my disguise for her; but if Mrs. Martha be kind to
Jonas, Sir Simon Addleplot will be false to the widow:
which is no more than widows are used to; for a promise
to a widow is as seldom kept as a vow made at sea, as
Dapperwit says.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I am afraid they should discover you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> You have nothing to fear; you have your
twenty guineas in your pocket for helping me into my
service, and if I get into Mrs. Martha's quarters, you
have a hundred more; if into the widow's, fifty:&mdash;happy
go lucky! Will her ladyship be at your house at the
hour?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Then you shall see when I am Sir Simon
Addleplot and myself I'll look like myself; now I am
Jonas, I look like an ass. You never thought Sir Simon
Addleplot could have looked so like an ass by his
ingenuity.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Pardon me, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, do not flatter, faith and troth.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_20" id="Page_20">[Pg 20]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Come let us go, 'tis time.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I will carry the widow to the French house.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> If she will go.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> If she will go! why, did you ever know a
widow refuse a treat? no more than a lawyer a fee, faith
and troth: yet I know too&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">No treat, sweet words, good mien, but sly intrigue</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">That must at length the jilting widow fegue.<a name="FNanchor_28_28" id="FNanchor_28_28"></a><a href="#Footnote_28_28" class="fnanchor">[28]</a> [<i>Exeunt.</i></span><br />
</p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>The French House. A table, wine and
candles.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>, <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Pray, Mr. Ranger, let's have no drinking to-night.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Pray, Mr. Ranger, let's have no Dapperwit
to-night.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, nay, Vincent.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> A pox! I hate his impertinent chat more than he
does the honest Burgundy.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> But why should you force wine upon us? we are
not all of your gusto.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But why should you force your chawed jests,
your damned ends of your mouldy lampoons, and last
year's sonnets, upon us? we are not all of your gusto.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> The wine makes me sick, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Thy rhymes make me spew.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> At repartee already! Come, Vincent. I know
you would rather have him pledge you: here, Dapperwit&mdash;[<i>Gives
him the glass.</i>]&mdash;But why are you so eager to
have him drink always?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_21" id="Page_21">[Pg 21]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Because he is so eager to talk always, and there
is no other way to silence him.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Waiter.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> Here is a gentleman desires to speak with Mr.
Vincent.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I come. [<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span> <i>with</i> Waiter.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He may drink, because he is obliged to the
bottle for all the wit and courage he has; 'tis not free
and natural like yours.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> He has more courage than wit, but wants
neither.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> As a pump gone dry, if you pour no water down
you will get none out, so&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, I bar similes too, to-night.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Why, is not the thought new? don't you
apprehend it?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Yes, yes, but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Well, well, will you comply with his sottishness
too, and hate brisk things in complaisance to the ignorant
dull age? I believe shortly 'twill be as hard to find a
patient friend to communicate one's wit to, as a faithful
friend to communicate one's secret to. Wit has as few
true judges as painting, I see.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> All people pretend to be judges of both.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Ay, they pretend; but set you aside, and one or
two more&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But why, has Vincent neither courage nor wit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He has no courage, because he beat his wench
for giving me <i>les doux yeux</i> once; and no wit, because he
does not comprehend my thoughts; and he is a son of a
whore for his ignorance. I take ignorance worse from
any man than the lie, because 'tis as much as to say I am
no wit.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>.</p>

<p>You need not take any notice, though, to him what I
say.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_22" id="Page_22">[Pg 22]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Ranger, there is a woman below in a coach
would speak with you.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> With me? [<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> This Ranger, Mr. Vincent, is as false to his
friend as his wench.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You have no reason to say so, but because he is
absent.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> 'Tis disobliging to tell a man of his faults to his
face. If he had but your grave parts and manly wit,
I should adore him; but, a pox! he is a mere buffoon, a
jack-pudding, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You are an ungrateful fellow. I have heard him
maintain you had wit, which was more than e'er you
could do for yourself.&mdash;I thought you had owned him
your Mæcenas.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! he cannot but esteem me, 'tis for his
honour; but I cannot but be just for all that&mdash;without
favour or affection. Yet I confess I love him so well,
that I wish he had but the hundredth part of your
courage.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> He has had courage to save you from many a
beating, to my knowledge.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Come, come, I wish the man well, and, next to
you, better than any man! and, I am sorry to say it, he
has not courage to snuff a candle with his fingers.
When he is drunk, indeed, he dares get a clap, or so&mdash;and
swear at a constable.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Detracting fop! when did you see him desert his
friend?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You have a rough kind of a raillery, Mr.
Vincent; but since you will have it, (though I love the
man heartily, I say,) he deserted me once in breaking of
windows, for fear of the constables&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p>But you need not take notice to him of what I tell you;
I hate to put a man to the blush.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_23" id="Page_23">[Pg 23]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I have had just now a visit from my mistress,
who is as jealous of me as a wife of her husband when
she lies in:&mdash;my cousin Lydia,&mdash;you have heard me
speak of her.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But she is more troublesome than a wife that lies
in, because she follows you to your haunts. Why do you
allow her that privilege before her time?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Faith, I may allow her any privilege, and be too
hard for her yet. How do you think I have cheated her
to-night?&mdash;Women are poor credulous creatures, easily
deceived.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> We are poor credulous creatures, when we think
'em so.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Intending a ramble to St. James's Park to-night,
upon some probable hopes of some fresh game I have in
chase, I appointed her to stay at home; with a promise
to come to her within this hour, that she might not spoil
the scent and prevent my sport.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> She'll be even with you when you are married,
I warrant you. In the meantime here's her health,
Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Now had he rather be at the window, writing
her anagram in the glass with his diamond, or biting his
nails in the corner for a fine thought to come and divert
us with at the table.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> No, a pox! I have no wit to-night. I am as
barren and hide-bound as one of your damned scribbling
poets, who are sots in company for all their wit; as a
miser is poor for all his money. How do you like the
thought?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Drink, drink!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Well, I can drink this, because I shall be
reprieved presently.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Who will be so civil to us?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Sir Simon Addleplot:&mdash;I have bespoke him a
supper here, for he treats to-night a new rich mistress.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> That spark, who has his fruitless designs upon<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_24" id="Page_24">[Pg 24]</a></span>
the bed-ridden rich widow, down to the suckling heiress
in her pissing-clout. He was once the sport, but now
the public grievance, of all the fortunes in town; for he
watches them like a younger brother that is afraid to be
mumped of his snip,<a name="FNanchor_29_29" id="FNanchor_29_29"></a><a href="#Footnote_29_29" class="fnanchor">[29]</a> and they cannot steal a marriage,
nor stay their stomachs, but he must know it.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He has now pitched his nets for Gripe's
daughter, the rich scrivener, and serves him as a clerk to
get admission to her; which the watchful fop her father
denies to all others.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I thought you had been nibbling at her once,
under pretence of love to her aunt.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I confess I have the same design yet, and
Addleplot is but my agent, whilst he thinks me his. He
brings me letters constantly from her, and carries mine
back.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Still betraying your best friends!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I cannot in honour but betray him. Let me
perish! the poor young wench is taken with my person,
and would scratch through four walls to come to
me.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> 'Tis a sign she is kept up close indeed.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Betray him! I'll not be traitor to love for any
man.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span> <i>with the</i> Waiter.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Know 'em! you are a saucy Jack-straw to
question me, faith and troth; I know everybody, and
everybody knows me.</p>

<p><i>All.</i> Sir Simon! Sir Simon! Sir Simon!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> And you are a welcome man to everybody.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Now, son of a whore, do I know the gentlemen?&mdash;A
dog! would have had a shilling of me before
he would let me come to you!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> The rogue has been bred at Court, sure.&mdash;Get
you out, sirrah. [<i>Exit</i> Waiter.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_25" id="Page_25">[Pg 25]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> He has been bred at a French-house, where
they are more unreasonable.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Here's to you, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I cannot drink, for I have a mistress within;
though I would not have the people of the house to
know it.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You need not be ashamed of your mistresses, for
they are commonly rich.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> And because she is rich, I would conceal
her; for I never had a rich mistress yet, but one or
other got her from me presently, faith and troth.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But this is an ill place to conceal a mistress in;
every waiter is an intelligencer to your rivals.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I have a trick for that:&mdash;I'll let no waiters
come into the room; I'll lay the cloth myself rather.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But who is your mistress?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Your servant,&mdash;your servant, Mr. Ranger.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Come, will you pledge me?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> No, I'll spare your wine, if you will spare
me Dapperwit's company; I came for that.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You do us a double favour, to take him and
leave the wine.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Come, come, Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Do not go, unless he will suffer us to see his
mistress too. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Come, come, man.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Would you have me so uncivil as to leave my
company?&mdash;they'll take it ill.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I cannot find her talk without thee.&mdash;Pray,
gentlemen, persuade Mr. Dapperwit to go with me.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> We will not hinder him of better company.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Yours is too good to be left rudely.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, gentlemen, I would desire your company
too, if you knew the lady.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> They know her as well as I; you say I know
her not.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> You are not everybody.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_26" id="Page_26">[Pg 26]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Perhaps we do know the lady, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> You do not, you do not: none of you ever
saw her in your lives;&mdash;but if you could be secret, and
civil&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> We have drunk yet but our bottle a-piece.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> But will you be civil, Mr. Vincent?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> He dares not look a woman in the face under
three bottles.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Come along then. But can you be civil,
gentlemen? will you be civil, gentlemen? pray be civil
if you can, and you shall see her.</p>

<p class="center">[<i>Exit, and returns with</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>and</i>
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> How, has he got his jilt here! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> The widow Flippant! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Is this the woman that we never saw! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Does he bring us into company!&mdash;and
Dapperwit one! Though I had married the fool, I thought
to have reserved the wit as well as other ladies. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, look as long as you will, madam, you
will find them civil gentlemen, and good company.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I am not in doubt of their civility, but yours.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You'll never leave snubbing your servants!
Did you not promise to use him kindly?
[<i>Aside to</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>Aside to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.] 'Tis true.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
We wanted no good company, Sir Simon, as long as we
had yours.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> But they wanted good company, therefore I
forced 'em to accept of yours.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> They will not think the company good they
were forced into, certainly.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> A pox! I must be using the words in fashion,
though I never have any luck with 'em. Mrs. Joyner,
help me off.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I suppose, madam, he means the gentlemen
wanted not inclination to your company, but confidence<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_27" id="Page_27">[Pg 27]</a></span>
to desire so great an honour; therefore he
forced 'em.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What makes this bawd here? Sure, mistress, you
bawds should be like the small cards, though at first you
make up a pack, yet, when the play begins, you should
be put out as useless.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Well, well, gibing companion: you would
have the pimps kept in only? you would so?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> What, they are quarrelling!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Pimp and bawd agree now-a-days like doctor
and apothecary.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Try, madam, if they are not civil gentlemen;
talk with 'em, while I go lay the cloth&mdash;no waiter comes
here.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] My mother used to tell me, I should
avoid all occasions of talking before my mistress, because
silence is a sign of love as well as prudence.
[<i>Lays the cloth.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Methinks you look a little yellow on't, Mr.
Dapperwit. I hope you do not censure me because you
find me passing away a night with this fool:&mdash;he is not a
man to be jealous of, sure.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You are not a lady to be jealous of, sure.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> No, certainly.&mdash;But why do you look as if you
were jealous then?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> If I had met you in Whetstone's park,<a name="FNanchor_30_30" id="FNanchor_30_30"></a><a href="#Footnote_30_30" class="fnanchor">[30]</a> with a
drunken foot-soldier, I should not have been jealous of you.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Fy, fy! now you are jealous, certainly; for
people always, when they grow jealous, grow rude:&mdash;but
I can pardon it since it proceeds from love certainly.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_28" id="Page_28">[Pg 28]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I am out of all hopes to be rid of this eternal old
acquaintance: when I jeer her, she thinks herself praised;
now I call her whore in plain English she thinks I am
jealous. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Sweet Mr. Dapperwit, be not so censorious, (I
speak for your sake, not my own,) for jealousy is a great
torment, but my honour cannot suffer certainly.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> No, certainly; but the greatest torment I have
is&mdash;your love.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Alas! sweet Mr. Dapperwit, indeed love is a
torment: but 'tis a sweet torment; but jealousy is a
bitter torment.&mdash;I do not go about to cure you of the
torment of my love.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> 'Tis a sign so.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Come, come, look up, man; is that a rival
to contest with you?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I will contest with no rival, not with my old rival
your coachman; but they have heartily my resignation;
and, to do you a favour, but myself a greater, I will help
to tie the knot you are fumbling for now, betwixt your
cully here and you.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Go, go, I take that kind of jealousy worst of
all, to suspect I would be debauched to beastly matrimony.&mdash;But
who are those gentlemen, pray? are they
men of fortunes, Mrs. Joyner?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I believe so.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Do you believe so, indeed?&mdash;Gentlemen&mdash;[<i>Advancing
towards</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> If the civility we owe to ladies had not controlled
our envy to Mr. Dapperwit, we had interrupted
ere this your private conversation.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Your interruption, sir, had been most civil
and obliging;&mdash;for our discourse was of marriage.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> That is a subject, madam, as grateful as common.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> O fy, fy! are you of that opinion too? I cannot
suffer any to talk of it in my company.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_29" id="Page_29">[Pg 29]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Are you married then, madam?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> No, certainly.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I am sure so much beauty cannot despair of it.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Despair of it!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Only those that are married, or cannot be
married, hate to hear of marriage.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Yet you must know, sir, my aversion to
marriage is such, that you, nor no man breathing, shall
ever persuade me to it.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Cursed be the man should do so rude a thing as
to persuade you to anything against your inclination! I
would not do it for the world, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Come, come, though you seem to be a civil
gentleman, I think you no better than your neighbours.
I do not know a man of you all that will not thrust a
woman up into a corner, and then talk an hour to her
impertinently of marriage.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You would find me another man in a corner, I
assure you, madam; for you should not have a word of
marriage from me, whatsoever you might find in my
actions of it; I hate talking as much as you.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I hate it extremely.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I am your man then, madam; for I find just the
same fault with your sex as you do with ours:&mdash;I ne'er
could have to do with woman in my life, but still she
would be impertinently talking of marriage to me.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Observe that, Mrs. Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Pray, Mr. Ranger, let's go; I had rather drink
with Mr. Vincent, than stay here with you; besides 'tis
Park-time.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.] I come.&mdash;[<i>To</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.]
Since you are a lady that hate marriage, I'll do
you the service to withdraw the company; for those that
hate marriage hate loss of time.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Will you go then, sir? but before you go, sir,
pray tell me is your aversion to marriage real?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> As real as yours.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_30" id="Page_30">[Pg 30]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> If it were no more real than mine&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Your servant, madam. [<i>Turns to go.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> But do you hate marriage certainly?
[<i>Plucks him back.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Certainly.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Come, I cannot believe it: you dissemble it
only because I pretend it.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Do you but pretend it then, madam?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>Aside</i>] I shall discover myself&mdash;[<i>Aloud</i>] I
mean, because I hold against it, you do the same in
complaisance:&mdash;for I have heard say, cunning men think
to bring the coy and untractable women to tameness
as they do some mad people&mdash;by humouring their
frenzies.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I am none of those cunning men, yet have too
much wit to entertain the presumption of designing upon
you.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> 'Twere no such presumption neither.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Come away; 'sdeath! don't you see your
danger?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Those aims are for Sir Simon.&mdash;Good night,
madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Will you needs go, then?&mdash;[<i>To</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon</span>]
The gentlemen are a-going, Sir Simon; will you let 'em?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, madam, if you cannot keep 'em, how
should I?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Stay, sir; because you hate marriage, I'll sing
you a new song against it. [<i>Sings.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">A spouse I do hate,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For either she's false or she's jealous;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">But give us a mate</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who nothing will ask us or tell us.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">She stands on no terms,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nor chaffers, by way of indenture,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">Her love for your farms;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But takes her kind man at a venture.</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_31" id="Page_31">[Pg 31]</a></span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">If all prove not right,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Without an act, process, or warning,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">From wife for a night</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You may be divorced in the morning.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">When parents are slaves,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Their brats cannot be any other;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">Great wits and great braves</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Have always a punk<a name="FNanchor_31_31" id="FNanchor_31_31"></a><a href="#Footnote_31_31" class="fnanchor">[31]</a> to their mother.</span><br />
</p>

<p>Though it be the fashion for women of quality to sing
any song whatever, because the words are not distinguished,
yet I should have blushed to have done it
now, but for you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> The song is edifying, the voice admirable&mdash;and,
once more, I am your servant, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> What, will you go too, Mr Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Pray, Mr. Dapperwit, do not you go too.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I am engaged.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Well, if we cannot have their company, we
will not have their room: ours is a private backroom;
they have paid their reckoning, let's go thither again.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> But pray, sweet Mr. Dapperwit, do not go.
Keep him, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I cannot keep him.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent, Ranger,</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit.</span></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">It is impossible; (the world is so;)</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">One cannot keep one's friend, and mistress too. [<i>Exeunt.</i></span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_32" id="Page_32">[Pg 32]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE SECOND.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>St. James's Park at night.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger, Vincent,</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit.</span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Hang me, if I am not pleased
extremely with this new-fashioned caterwauling,
this mid-night coursing in the
park.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> A man may come after supper
with his three bottles in his head, reel
himself sober, without reproof from his mother, aunt, or
grave relation.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> May bring his bashful wench, and not have her
put out of countenance by the impudent honest women
of the town.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And a man of wit may have the better of the
dumb show of well-trimmed vest or fair peruke:&mdash;no
man's now is whitest.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> And now no woman's modest or proud; for
her blushes are hid, and the rubies on her lips are dyed,
and all sleepy and glimmering eyes have lost their attraction.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> And now a man may carry a bottle under his
arm instead of his hat;&mdash;and no observing spruce fop
will miss the cravat that lies on one's shoulder, or count
the pimples on one's face.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And now the brisk repartee ruins the complaisant
cringe, or wise grimace.&mdash;Something 'twas, we
men of virtue always loved the night.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_33" id="Page_33">[Pg 33]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> O blessed season!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> For good-fellows.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> For lovers.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And for the Muses.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> When I was a boy I loved the night so well, I
had a strong vocation to be a bellman's apprentice.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I, a drawer.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And I, to attend the waits of Westminster, let
me perish!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But why do we not do the duty of this and such
other places;&mdash;walk, censure, and speak ill of all we
meet?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> 'Tis no fault of mine, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Fy, fy! satirical gentlemen, this is not your time;
you cannot distinguish a friend from a fop.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> No matter, no matter; they will deserve amongst
'em the worst we can say.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Who comes here, Dapperwit?
[<i>People walk slowly over the stage.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> By the toss of his head, training of his feet, and
his elbows playing at bo-peep behind his back, it should
be my Lord Easy.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> And who the woman?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> My Lord what-d'ye-call's daughter, that had a
child by&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Dapperwit, hold your tongue.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> How! are you concerned?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Her brother's an honest fellow, and will drink
his glass.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Prithee, Vincent, Dapperwit did not hinder
drinking to-night, though he spake against it; why, then,
should you interrupt his sport?&mdash;Now, let him talk of
anybody.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> So he will,&mdash;till you cut his throat.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Why should you on all occasions thwart him,
contemn him, and maliciously look grave at his jests
only?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_34" id="Page_34">[Pg 34]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Why does he always rail against my friends, then,
and my best friend&mdash;a beer-glass?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Dapperwit, be your own advocate: my game, I
think, is before me there. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> This Ranger, I think, has all the ill qualities of
all your town fops;&mdash;leaving his company for a spruce
lord or a wench.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Nay, if you must rail at your own best friends, I
may forgive you railing at mine.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.&mdash;<i>They walk over the
stage.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> False Ranger, shall I find thee here? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Those are women, are they not? [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Dapper</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> The least seems to be my Lucy, sure. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Faith, I think I dare speak to a woman in the
dark!&mdash;let's try.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> They are persons of quality of my acquaintance;&mdash;hold!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Nay, if they are persons of quality of your
acquaintance, I may be the bolder with 'em.
[<i>The</i> Ladies <i>go off, they follow them.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I come hither to make a discovery to-night.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Of my love to you, certainly; for nobody but
you could have debauched me to the Park, certainly. I
would not return another night, if it were to redeem my
dear husband from his grave.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I believe you:&mdash;but to get another, widow.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Another husband, another husband, foh!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> There does not pass a night here but many a
match is made.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> That a woman of honour should have the
word match in her mouth!&mdash;but I hope, madam, the
fellows do not make honourable love here, do they?
I abominate honourable love, upon my honour.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_35" id="Page_35">[Pg 35]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> If they should make honourable love here, I
know you would prevent 'em.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.&mdash;<i>They walk slowly
towards the</i> Ladies.</p>

<p>But here come two men will inform you what to do.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Do they come?&mdash;are they men certainly?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Prepare for an assault, they'll put you to't.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Will they put us to't certainly? I was never
put to't yet. If they should put us to't, I should drop
down, down, certainly.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I believe, truly, you would not have power to
run away.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Therefore I will not stay the push.&mdash;They
come! they come! oh, the fellows come!
[Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>runs away,</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>follows, and</i>
<span class="smcap">Vincent</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span> <i>after them.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>at the other side, alone.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> So! I am got off clear! I did not run from
the men, but my companion. For all their brags, men
have hardly courage to set upon us when our number is
equal; now they shall see I defy 'em:&mdash;for we women
have always most courage when we are alone. But, a
pox! the lazy rogues come not! or they are drunk and
cannot run. Oh drink! abominable drink! instead of
inflaming love, it quenches it; and for one lover it
encourages, it makes a thousand impotent. Curse on all
wine! even Rhenish wine and sugar&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot,</span> <i>muffled in a cloak.</i></p>

<p>But fortune will not see me want; here comes a single
bully,&mdash;I wish he may stand;&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For now a-nights the jostling nymph is bolder</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Than modern satyr with his cloak o'er shoulder.</span><br />
</p>

<p>Well met, sir. [<i>She puts on her mask.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_36" id="Page_36">[Pg 36]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> How shall I know that, forsooth? Who are
you? do you know me?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Who are you? don't you know me?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Not I, faith and troth!</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I am glad on't; for no man e'er liked a
woman the better for having known her before.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Ay, but then one can't be so free with a new
acquaintance as with an old one; she may deny one the
civility.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Not till you ask her.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> But I am afraid to be denied.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Let me tell you, sir, you cannot disoblige us
women more than in distrusting us.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Pish! what should one ask for, when you
know one's meaning?&mdash;but shall I deal freely with you?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I love, of my life, men should deal freely with
me; there are so few men will deal freely with one&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Are you not a fireship,<a name="FNanchor_32_32" id="FNanchor_32_32"></a><a href="#Footnote_32_32" class="fnanchor">[32]</a> a punk, madam?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Well, sir, I love raillery.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Faith and troth, I do not rally, I deal freely.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> This is the time and place for freedom, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Are you handsome?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Joan's as good as my lady in the dark,
certainly: but men that deal freely never ask questions,
certainly.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> How then! I thought to deal freely, and put
a woman to the question, had been all one.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> But, let me tell you, those that deal freely indeed,
take a woman by&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> What, what, what, what?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> By the hand&mdash;and lead her aside.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Now I understand you; come along then.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter behind</i> Musicians <i>with torches.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> What unmannerly rascals are those that bring<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_37" id="Page_37">[Pg 37]</a></span>
light into the Park? 'twill not be taken well from 'em by
the women, certainly.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Still disappointed!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Oh, the fiddles, the fiddles! I sent for them
hither to oblige the women, not to offend 'em; for I
intend to serenade the whole Park to-night. But my
frolic is not without an intrigue, faith and troth: for I
know the fiddles will call the whole herd of vizard masks
together; and then shall I discover if a strayed mistress
of mine be not amongst 'em, whom I treated to-night at
the French-house; but as soon as the jilt had eat up my
meat and drunk her two bottles, she ran away from me,
and left me alone.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> How! is it he? Addleplot!&mdash;that I could not
know him by his faith and troth! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Now I would understand her tricks; because
I intend to marry her, and should be glad to know what
I must trust to.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> So thou shalt;&mdash;but not yet. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Though I can give a great guess already;
for if I have any intrigue or sense in me, she is as arrant
a jilt as ever pulled pillow from under husband's head,
faith and troth. Moreover she is bow-legged, hopper-hipped,
and, betwixt pomatum and Spanish red, has a
complexion like a Holland cheese, and no more teeth left
than such as give a <i>haut goût</i> to her breath; but she is
rich, faith and troth.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Oh rascal! he has heard somebody
else say all this of me. But I must not discover myself,
lest I should be disappointed of my revenge; for I will
marry him. [<i>The</i> Musicians <i>approaching, exit</i> <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> What, gone!&mdash;come then, strike up, my lads.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Men <i>and</i> Women <i>in vizards&mdash;a Dance, during
which</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span>, <i>for the most part,
stands still in a cloak and vizard; but sometimes goes
about peeping, and examining the</i> Women's <i>clothes&mdash;the
Dance ended, all exeunt.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_38" id="Page_38">[Pg 38]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>, <i>after them</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit.</span></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>.] Nay, if you stay any longer, I
must leave you again. [<i>Going off.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> We have overtaken them at last again. These
are they: they separate too; and that's but a challenge
to us.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Let me perish! ladies&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Nay, good madam, let's unite, now here's the
common enemy upon us.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Damn me! ladies&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Hold, a pox! you are too rough.&mdash;Let me
perish! ladies&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Not for want of breath, gentlemen:&mdash;we'll stay
rather.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> For want of your favour rather, sweet ladies.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] That's Dapperwit, false villain! but
he must not know I am here. If he should, I should
lose his thrice agreeable company, and he would run
from me as fast as from the bailiffs. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>.] What!
you will not talk with 'em, I hope?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Yes, but I will.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Then you are a Park-woman certainly, and
you will take it kindly if I leave you.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> No, you must not leave me.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Then you must leave them.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I'll see if they are worse company than you, first.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Monstrous impudence!&mdash;will you not come?
[<i>Pulls</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Nay, madam, I never suffer any violence to be
used to a woman but what I do myself: she must stay,
and you must not go.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Unhand me, you rude fellow!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Nay, now I am sure you will stay and be kind;
for coyness in a woman is as little sign of true modesty,
as huffing in a man is of true courage.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_39" id="Page_39">[Pg 39]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Use her gently, and speak soft things to her.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Now do I guess I know my coxcomb.&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.] Sir, I am extremely glad I am fallen
into the hands of a gentleman that can speak soft things;
and this is so fine a night to hear soft things in;&mdash;morning,
I should have said.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> It will not be morning, dear madam, till you
pull off your mask.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] That I think was brisk.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Indeed, dear sir, my face would frighten back
the sun.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> With glories more radiant than his own.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
I keep up with her, I think.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But why would you put me to the trouble of
lighting the world, when I thought to have gone to
sleep?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You only can do it, dear madam, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But why would you (of all men) practise treason
against your friend Ph&#339;bus, and depose him for a mere
stranger?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I think she knows me. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But he does not do you justice, I believe; and
you are so positively cock-sure of your wit, you would
refer to a mere stranger your plea to the bay-tree.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> She jeers me, let me perish! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Dapperwit, a little of your aid; for my lady's invincibly
dumb.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Would mine had been so too! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I have used as many arguments to make her
speak, as are requisite to make other women hold their
tongues.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Well, I am ready to change sides.&mdash;Yet before
I go, madam, since the moon consents now I should see
your face, let me desire you to pull off your mask; which
to a handsome lady is a favour, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Truly, sir, I must not be long in debt to you for
the obligation; pray let me hear you recite some of your
verses; which to a wit is a favour, I'm sure.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_40" id="Page_40">[Pg 40]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Madam, it belongs to your sex to be obliged
first; pull off your mask, and I'll pull out my paper.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
Brisk again, of my side.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> 'Twould be in vain, for you would want a candle
now.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I dare not make use again of the lustre
of her face.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>.] I'll wait upon you home then,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Faith, no; I believe it will not be much to our
advantages to bring my face or your poetry to light: for
I hope you have yet a pretty good opinion of my face,
and so have I of your wit. But if you are for proving
your wit, why do not you write a play?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Because 'tis now no more reputation to write a
play, than it is honour to be a knight. Your true wit
despises the title of poet, as much as your true gentleman
the title of knight; for as a man may be a knight and no
gentleman, so a man may be a poet and no wit, let me
perish!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Pray, sir, how are you dignified or distinguished
amongst the rates of wits? and how many rates are
there?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> There are as many degrees of wits as of lawyers:
as there is first your solicitor, then your attorney, then
your pleading-counsel, then your chamber-counsel, and
then your judge; so there is first your court-wit, your
coffee-wit, your poll-wit, or politic-wit, your chamber-wit,
or scribble-wit, and last of all, your judge-wit, or critic.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But are there as many wits as lawyers? Lord,
what will become of us!&mdash;What employment can they
have? how are they known?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> First, your court-wit is a fashionable, insinuating,
flattering, cringing, grimacing fellow&mdash;and has wit enough
to solicit a suit of love; and if he fail, he has malice
enough to ruin the woman with a dull lampoon:&mdash;but he
rails still at the man that is absent, for you must know all
wits rail; and his wit properly lies in combing perukes,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_41" id="Page_41">[Pg 41]</a></span>
matching ribbons, and being severe, as they call it, upon
other people's clothes.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Now, what is the coffee-wit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He is a lying, censorious, gossiping, quibbling
wretch, and sets people together by the ears over that sober
drink, coffee: he is a wit, as he is a commentator, upon
the Gazette; and he rails at the pirates of Algier, the
Grand Signior of Constantinople, and the Christian
Grand Signior.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> What kind of man is your poll-wit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He is a fidgetting, busy, dogmatical, hot-headed
fop, that speaks always in sentences and proverbs, (as
other in similitudes,) and he rails perpetually against the
present government. His wit lies in projects and monopolies,
and penning speeches for young parliament men.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But what is your chamber-wit, or scribble-wit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He is a poring, melancholy, modest sot, ashamed
of the world: he searches all the records of wit, to compile
a breviate of them for the use of players, printers,
booksellers, and sometimes cooks, tobacco-men; he employs
his railing against the ignorance of the age, and all
that have more money than he.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Now your last.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Your judge-wit, or critic, is all these together,
and yet has the wit to be none of them: he can think,
speak, write, as well as the rest, but scorns (himself a
judge) to be judged by posterity: he rails at all the other
classes of wits, and his wit lies in damning all but himself:&mdash;he
is your true wit.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Then, I suspect you are of his form.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I cannot deny it, madam.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Dapperwit, you have been all this time on the
wrong side; for you love to talk all, and here's a lady
would not have hindered you.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! I have been talking too long indeed
here; for wit is lost upon a silly weak woman, as well as
courage. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_42" id="Page_42">[Pg 42]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I have used all common means to move a
woman's tongue and mask; I called her ugly, old, and
old acquaintance, and yet she would not disprove me:&mdash;but
here comes Ranger, let him try what he can do; for,
since my mistress is dogged, I'll go sleep alone. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Ranger! 'tis he indeed: I am sorry he
is here, but glad I discovered him before I went. Yet
he must not discover me, lest I should be prevented
hereafter in finding him out. False Ranger!&mdash;[<i>To</i> Lady
<span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.] Nay, if they bring fresh force upon us,
madam, 'tis time to quit the field.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> What, play with your quarry till it fly from you!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You frighten it away.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Ha! is not one of those ladies in mourning?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> All women are so by this light.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But you might easily discern. Don't you know
her?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> No.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Did you talk with her?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Yes, she is one of your brisk silly baggages.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> 'Tis she, 'tis she!&mdash;I was afraid I saw her before;
let us follow 'em: prithee make haste.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] 'Tis
Lydia. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter, on the other side</i>, <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> Lady
<span class="smcap">Flippant&mdash;Dapperwit</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>following them at a distance.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> They follow us yet, I fear.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> You do not fear it certainly; otherwise you
would not have encouraged them.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> For Heaven's sake, madam, waive your quarrel a
little, and let us pass by your coach, and so on foot to your
acquaintance in the old Pall-mall<a name="FNanchor_33_33" id="FNanchor_33_33"></a><a href="#Footnote_33_33" class="fnanchor">[33]</a>: for I would not be discovered
by the man that came up last to us. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_43" id="Page_43">[Pg 43]</a></span></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Christina's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> For Heaven's sake, undress yourself, madam!
They'll not return to-night: all people have left the Park
an hour ago.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What is't o'clock?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> 'Tis past one.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> It cannot be!</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> I thought that time had only stolen from happy
lovers:&mdash;the disconsolate have nothing to do but to tell
the clock.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I can only keep account with my misfortunes.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> I am glad they are not innumerable.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> And, truly, my undergoing so often your impertinency
is not the least of them.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> I am then more glad, madam, for then they cannot
be great; and it is in my power, it seems, to make
you in part happy, if I could but hold this villainous
tongue of mine: but then let the people of the town hold
their tongues if they will, for I cannot but tell you what
they say.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What do they say?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Faith, madam, I am afraid to tell you, now I
think on't.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Is it so ill?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> O, such base, unworthy things!</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Do they say I was really Clerimont's wench, as he
boasted; and that the ground of the quarrel betwixt
Valentine and him was not Valentine's vindication of my
honour, but Clerimont's jealousy of him?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Worse, worse a thousand times! such villainous
things to the utter ruin of your reputation!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_44" id="Page_44">[Pg 44]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What are they?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Faith, madam, you'll be angry: 'tis the old trick
of lovers to hate their informers, after they have made 'em
such.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I will not be angry.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> They say then, since Mr. Valentine's flying into
France you are grown mad, have put yourself into
mourning, live in a dark room, where you'll see nobody,
nor take any rest day or night, but rave and talk to yourself
perpetually.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Now, what else?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> But the surest sign of your madness is, they say,
because you are desperately resolved (in case my Lord
Clerimont should die of his wounds) to transport yourself
and fortune into France to Mr. Valentine, a man that
has not a groat to return you in exchange.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> All this, hitherto, is true; now to the rest.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Indeed, madam, I have no more to tell you. I
was sorry, I'm sure, to hear so much of any lady of
mine.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Insupportable insolence!</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] This is some revenge for my want of sleep
to-night.&mdash;[<i>Knocking at the door.</i>] So, I hope my old
second is come; 'tis seasonable relief. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Unhappy Valentine! couldst thou but see how
soon thy absence and misfortunes have disbanded all thy
friends, and turned thy slaves all renegadoes, thou sure
wouldst prize my only faithful heart!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant, Lydia</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Hail, faithful shepherdess! but, truly, I had
not kept my word with you, in coming back to-night, if
it had not been for this lady, who has her intrigues too
with the fellows as well as you.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Madam, under my Lady Flippant's protection, I
am confident to beg yours; being just now pursued out
of the Park by a relation of mine, by whom it imports me<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_45" id="Page_45">[Pg 45]</a></span>
extremely not to be discovered:&mdash;[<i>Knocking at the door.</i>]
but I fear he is now at the door.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>, <i>who goes
out.</i>] Let me desire you to deny me to him courageously;&mdash;for
he will hardly believe he can be mistaken in
me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> In such an occasion, where impudence is
requisite, she will serve you as faithfully as you can
wish, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Come, come, madam, do not upbraid her with
her assurance, a qualification that only fits her for a lady's
service. A fine woman of the town can be no more without
a woman that can make an excuse with assurance,
than she can be without a glass, certainly.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> She needs no advocate.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> How can any one alone manage an amorous
intrigue? though the birds are tame, somebody must help
draw the net. If 'twere not for a woman that could make
an excuse with assurance, how should we wheedle, jilt,
trace, discover, countermine, undermine, and blow up the
stinking fellows? which is all the pleasure I receive, or
design by them; for I never admitted a man to my conversation,
but for his punishment, certainly.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Nobody will doubt that, certainly.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Madam, the gentleman will not be mistaken: he
says you are here, he saw you come in; he is your relation,
his name's Ranger, and is come to wait upon you
home. I had much ado to keep him from coming up.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span>.] Madam, for Heaven's sake, help
me! 'tis yet in your power; if but, while I retire into
your dining-room, you will please to personate me, and
own yourself for her he pursued out of the Park: you are
in mourning too, and your stature so much mine it will
not contradict you.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I am sorry, madam, I must dispute any command
of yours. I have made a resolution to see the face<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_46" id="Page_46">[Pg 46]</a></span>
of no man, till an unfortunate friend of mine, now out of
the kingdom, return.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> By that friend, and by the hopes you have to see
him, let me conjure you to keep me from the sight of mine
now. Dear madam, let your charity prevail over you
superstition.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> He comes, he comes, madam!
[<span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>withdraws, and stands unseen at the door.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Ha! this is no Lydia. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What, unworthy defamer, has encouraged you to
offer this insolence?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> She is liker Lydia in her style than her face. I
see I am mistaken; but to tell her I followed her for
another, were an affront rather than an excuse. She's a
glorious creature! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Tell me, sir, whence had you reason for this
your rude pursuit of me, into my lodgings, my chamber?
why should you follow me?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Faith, madam, because you ran away from me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> That was no sign of an acquaintance.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You'll pardon me, madam.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Then, it seems, you mistook me for another,
and the night is your excuse, which blots out all
distinctions. But now you are satisfied in your mistake,
I hope you will seek out your woman in another
place.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Madam, I allow not the excuse you make for me.
If I have offended, I will rather be condemned for my
love, than pardoned for my insensibility.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> How's that? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What do you say?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Though the night had been darker, my heart
would not have suffered me to follow any one but
you:&mdash;he has been too long acquainted with you to
mistake you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_47" id="Page_47">[Pg 47]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> What means this tenderness? he mistook me for
her sure. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What says the gentleman? did you know me
then, sir?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Not I, the devil take me! but I must on
now.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Could you imagine, madam, by the innumerable
crowd of your admirers, you had left any man
free in the town, or ignorant of the power of your beauty?</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I never saw your face before, that I remember.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Ah, madam! you would never regard your
humblest slave; I was till now a modest lover.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Falsest of men! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> My woman said, you came to seek a relation
here, not a mistress.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I must confess, madam, I thought you would
sooner disprove my dissembled error, than admit my
visit, and was resolved to see you.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> 'Tis clear! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Indeed, when I followed you first out of the
Park, I was afraid you might have been a certain relation
of mine, for your statures and habits are the same; but
when you entered here, I was with joy convinced.
Besides, I would not for the world have given her
troublesome love so much encouragement, to have
disturbed my future addresses to you; for the foolish
woman does perpetually torment me to make our relation
nearer; but never more in vain than since I have seen
you, madam.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> How! shall I suffer this? 'tis clear he disappointed
me to-night for her, and made me stay at
home that I might not disappoint him of her company
in the Park. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I am amazed! but let me tell you, sir, if the
lady were here, I would satisfy her the sight of me should
never frustrate her ambitious designs upon her cruel
kinsman.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I wish you could satisfy me. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_48" id="Page_48">[Pg 48]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> If she were here, she would satisfy you she were
not capable of the honour to be taken for you:&mdash;though
in the dark. Faith, my cousin is but a tolerable woman
to a man that had not seen you.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Sure, to my plague, this is the first time you
ever saw me!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Sure, to the plague of my poor heart, 'tis not the
hundredth time I have seen you! For, since the time I
saw you first, you have not been at the Park, playhouse,
Exchange,<a name="FNanchor_34_34" id="FNanchor_34_34"></a><a href="#Footnote_34_34" class="fnanchor">[34]</a> or other public place, but I saw you; for it
was my business to watch and follow.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Pray, when did you see me last at the Park,
playhouse, or Exchange?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Some two, three days, or a week ago.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I have not been this month out of this chamber.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> That is to delude me. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I knew you were mistaken.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You'll pardon a lover's memory, madam.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
A pox! I have hanged myself in my own line.
One would think my perpetual ill-luck in lying should
break me of the quality; but, like a losing gamester, I
am still for pushing on, till none will trust me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Come, sir, you run out of one error into a
greater: you would excuse the rudeness of your mistake,
and intrusion at this hour into my lodgings, with your
gallantry to me,&mdash;more unseasonable and offensive.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, I am in love I see, for I blush and have not
a word to say for myself.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> But, sir, if you will needs play the gallant, pray
leave my house before morning, lest you should be seen<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_49" id="Page_49">[Pg 49]</a></span>
go hence, to the scandal of my honour. Rather than
that should be, I'll call up the house and neighbours to
bear witness I bid you begone.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Since you take a night visit so ill, madam, I will
never wait upon you again but by day. I go, that I may
hope to return; and, for once, I wish you a good night
without me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Good night, for as long as I live.
[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> And good night to my love, I'm sure. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Though I have done you an inconsiderable
service, I assure you, madam, you are not a little obliged
to me.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Pardon me, dear Valentine!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I know not yet whether I am more obliged than
injured: when I do, I assure you, madam, I shall not be
insensible of either.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I fear, madam, you are as liable to mistakes as
your kinsman.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I fear I am more subject to 'em: it may be for
want of sleep, therefore I'll go home.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> My Lady Flippant, good night.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Good night, or rather good morrow, faithful
shepherdess.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I'll wait on you down.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Your coach stays yet, I hope.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Certainly. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<i>The Street before</i> <span class="smcap">Christina's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I was a faithful sentinel: nobody came out, let
me perish!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> No, no, I hunted upon a wrong scent; I thought
I had followed a woman, but found her an angel.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_50" id="Page_50">[Pg 50]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What is her name?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> That you must tell me. What very fine woman
is there lives hereabouts?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Faith, I know not any. She is, I warrant you,
some fine woman of a term's standing or so in the town;
such as seldom appear in public, but in their balconies,
where they stand so constantly, one would think they had
hired no other part of the house.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> And look like the pictures which painters expose
to draw in customers;&mdash;but I must know who she is.
Vincent's lodging is hard by, I'll go and inquire of him,
and lie with him to-night: but if he will not let me, I'll
lie with you, for my lodging is too far off.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Then I will go before, and expect you at mine.
[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Vincent's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>
