<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>in a riding habit, as
newly from a journey.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Your mistress, dear Valentine, will not be more
glad to see you! but my wonder is no less than my
joy, that you would return ere you were informed Clerimont
were out of danger. His surgeons themselves
have not been assured of his recovery till within these
two days.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I feared my mistress, not my life. My life I
could trust again with my old enemy Fortune; but no
longer my mistress in the hands of my greater enemies,
her relations.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Your fear was in the wrong place, then: for
though my Lord Clerimont live, he and his relations may
put you in more danger of your life than your mistress's
relations can of losing her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_51" id="Page_51">[Pg 51]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Would any could secure me her! I would myself
secure my life, for I should value it then.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Come, come; her relations can do you no hurt.
I dare swear, if her mother should but say, "Your hat
did not cock handsomely," she would never ask her
blessing again.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Prithee leave thy fooling, and tell me if, since
my departure, she has given evidences of her love, to
clear those doubts I went away with:&mdash;for as absence is
the bane of common and bastard love, 'tis the vindication
of that which is true and generous.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Nay, if you could ever doubt her love, you deserve
to doubt on; for there is no punishment great enough
for jealousy&mdash;but jealousy.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> You may remember, I told you before my flight
I had quarrelled with the defamer of my mistress, but I
thought I had killed my rival.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But pray give me now the answer which the
suddenness of your flight denied me;&mdash;how could Clerimont
hope to subdue her heart by the assault of her
honour?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Pish! it might be the stratagem of a rival to make
me desist.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> For shame! if 'twere not rather to vindicate her,
than satisfy you, I would not tell you how like a Penelope
she has behaved herself in your absence.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Let me know.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Then know, the next day you went she put herself
in mourning, and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> That might be for Clerimont, thinking him dead,
as all the world besides thought.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Still turning the dagger's point on yourself! hear
me out. I say she put herself into mourning for you&mdash;locked
herself in her chamber this month for you&mdash;shut
out her barking relations for you&mdash;has not seen the sun
or the face of man since she saw you&mdash;thinks and talks
of nothing but you&mdash;sends to me daily to hear of you&mdash;and,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_52" id="Page_52">[Pg 52]</a></span>
and, in short, (I think,) is mad for you. All this I can
swear; for I am to her so near a neighbour, and so inquisitive
a friend for you&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Servant.</p>

<p><i>Serv.</i> Mr. Ranger, sir, is coming up.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> What brings him now? he comes to lie with me.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Who, Ranger?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Yes. Pray retire a little, till I send him off:&mdash;unless
you have a mind to have your arrival published to-morrow
in the coffee houses.
[<span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>retires to the door behind.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> What! not yet a-bed? your man is laying you
to sleep with usquebaugh or brandy; is he not so?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> What punk<a name="FNanchor_35_35" id="FNanchor_35_35"></a><a href="#Footnote_35_35" class="fnanchor">[35]</a> will not be troubled with you to-night,
therefore I am?&mdash;is it not so?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I have been turned out of doors, indeed, just
now, by a woman,&mdash;but such a woman, Vincent!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Yes, yes, your women are always such women!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> A neighbour of yours, and I'm sure the finest
you have.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Prithee do not asperse my neighbourhood with
your acquaintance; 'twould bring a scandal upon an
alley.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, I do not know her; therefore I come to
you.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> 'Twas no wonder she turned you out of doors,
then; and if she had known you, 'twould have been a
wonder she had let you stay. But where does she live?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Five doors off, on the right hand.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Pish! pish!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> What's the matter?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Does she live there, do you say?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_53" id="Page_53">[Pg 53]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Yes; I observed them exactly, that my account
from you might be exact. Do you know who lives there?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Yes, so well, that I know you are mistaken.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Is she not a young lady scarce eighteen, of
extraordinary beauty, her stature next to low, and in
mourning?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> What is this? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> She is; but if you saw her, you broke in at
window.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I chased her home from the Park, indeed, taking
her for another lady who had some claim to my heart, till
she showed a better title to't.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Hah! hah! hah!</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Was she at the Park, then? and have I a new
rival? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> From the Park did you follow her, do you say?&mdash;I
knew you were mistaken.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I tell you I am not.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> If you are sure it was that house, it might be
perhaps her woman stolen to the Park, unknown to her
lady.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> My acquaintance does usually begin with the
maid first, but now 'twas with the mistress, I assure you.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> The mistress!&mdash;I tell you she has not been out
of her doors since Valentine's flight. She is his mistress,&mdash;the
great heiress, Christina.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I tell you then again, I followed that Christina
from the Park home, where I talked with her half an
hour, and intend to see her to morrow again.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Would she talk with him too! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> It cannot be.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Christina do you call her? Faith I am sorry
she is an heiress, lest it should bring the scandal of
interest, and the design of lucre, upon my love.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> No, no, her face and virtues will free you from
that censure. But, however, 'tis not fairly done to rival
your friend Valentine in his absence; and when he is<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_54" id="Page_54">[Pg 54]</a></span>
present you know 'twill be dangerous, by my Lord Clerimont's
example. Faith, if you have seen her, I would
not advise you to attempt it again.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You may be merry, sir, you are not in love;
your advice I come not for, nor will I for your assistance;&mdash;Good
night. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Here's your Penelope! the woman that had not
seen the sun, nor face of man, since my departure! for
it seems she goes out in the night, when the sun is absent,
and faces are not distinguished.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Why! do you believe him?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Should I believe you?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> 'Twere more for your interest, and you would be
less deceived. If you believe him, you must doubt the
chastity of all the fine women in town, and five miles
about.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> His reports of them will little invalidate his
testimony with me.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> He spares not the innocents in bibs and aprons.
I'll secure you, he has made (at best) some gross mistake
concerning Christina, which to-morrow will discover; in
the meantime let us go to sleep.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I will not hinder you, because I cannot enjoy it
myself:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Hunger, Revenge, to sleep are petty foes,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But only Death the jealous eyes can close.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_55" id="Page_55">[Pg 55]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE THIRD.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Good morrow, gossip.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Good morrow;&mdash;but why
up so early, good gossip?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> My care and passionate
concern for you and yours would not
let me rest, in truly.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> For me and mine?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You know we have known one another
long; I think it be some nine-and-thirty years since you
were married.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Nine-and thirty years old, mistress! I'd
have you to know, I am no far-born child; and if the
register had not been burned in the last great fire, alas!&mdash;but
my face needs no register sure; nine-and-thirty years
old, said you?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I said you had been so long married; but,
indeed, you bear your years as well as any she in Pepper-alley.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Nine-and-thirty, mistress!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> This it is; a woman, now-a-days, had
rather you should find her faulty with a man, I warrant
you, than discover her age, I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Marry, and 'tis the greatest secret far.
Tell a miser he is rich, and a woman she is old,&mdash;you<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_56" id="Page_56">[Pg 56]</a></span>
will get no money of him, not kindness of her. To tell
me I was nine-and-thirty&mdash;(I say no more) 'twas un-neighbourly
done of you, mistress.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> My memory confesses my age, it seems, as
much as my face; for I thought&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Pray talk nor think no more of any one's
age; but say what brought you hither so early.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> How does my sweet god-daughter, poor
wretch?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Well, very well.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Ah, sweet creature! Alas! alas!&mdash;I am
sorry for her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Why, what has she done to deserve your
sorrow, or my reprehension?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>, <i>and stands unseen at the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> What, are they talking of me? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> In short, she was seen going into the meeting-house
of the wicked, otherwise called the playhouse,
hand in hand with that vile fellow Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Mr. Dapperwit! let me tell you, if 'twere
not for Master Dapperwit, we might have lived all this
vacation upon green cheese, tripe, and ox cheek. If he
had it, we should not want it; but, poor gentleman! it
often goes hard with him,&mdash;for he's a wit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> So, then, you are the dog to be fed, while
the house is broken up! I say, beware! The sweet bits
you swallow will make your daughter's belly swell,
mistress; and, after all your junkets, there will be a bone
for you to pick, mistress.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Sure, Master Dapperwit is no such manner
of man!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> He is a wit, you say; and what are wits,
but contemners of matrons, seducers, or defamers of
married women, and deflowerers of helpless virgins,
even in the streets, upon the very bulks<a name="FNanchor_36_36" id="FNanchor_36_36"></a><a href="#Footnote_36_36" class="fnanchor">[36]</a>; affronters of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_57" id="Page_57">[Pg 57]</a></span>
midnight magistracy, and breakers of windows? in a
word&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> But he is a little wit, a modest wit, and
they do no such outrageous things as your great wits do.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Nay, I dare say, he will not say himself he
is a little wit if you ask him.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Nay, I cannot hear this with patience.&mdash;[<i>Comes
forward.</i>] With your pardon, mother, you are as much
mistaken as my godmother in Mr. Dapperwit; for he is
as great a wit as any, and in what he speaks or writes as
happy as any. I can assure you, he contemns all your
tearing wits, in comparison of himself.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Alas, poor young wretch! I cannot blame
thee so much as thy mother, for thou art not thyself. His
bewitching madrigals have charmed thee into some
heathenish imp with a hard name.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Nymph, you mean, godmother.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But you, gossip, know what's what. Yesterday,
as I told you, a fine old alderman of the city, seeing
your daughter in so ill hands as Dapperwit's, was
zealously, and in pure charity, bent upon her redemption;
and has sent me to tell you, he will take her into his care
and relieve your necessities, if you think good.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Will he relieve all our necessities?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> All.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Mine, as well as my daughter's?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Well fare his heart!&mdash;D'ye hear, daughter,
Mrs. Joyner has satisfied me clearly; Dapperwit is a vile
fellow, and, in short, you must put an end to that scandalous
familiarity between you.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Leave sweet Mr. Dapperwit!&mdash;oh furious ingratitude!
Was he not the man that gave me my first
Farrendon<a name="FNanchor_37_37" id="FNanchor_37_37"></a><a href="#Footnote_37_37" class="fnanchor">[37]</a> gown, put me out of worsted stockings and
handkerchiefs, taught me to dress, talk, and move
well?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_58" id="Page_58">[Pg 58]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> He has taught you to talk indeed; but,
huswife, I will not have my pleasure disputed.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Nay, indeed, you are too tart with her,
poor sweet soul.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> He taught me to rehearse, too,&mdash;would have
brought me into the playhouse, where I might have had
as good luck as others: I might have had good clothes,
plate, jewels, and things so well about me, that my neighbours,
the little gentlemen's wives of fifteen hundred or
two thousand pounds a year, should have retired into the
country, sick with envy of my prosperity and greatness.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> If you follow your mother's counsel, you
are like to enjoy all you talk of sooner than by Dapperwit's
assistance:&mdash;a poor wretch that goes on tick for the
paper he writes his lampoons on, and the very ale and
coffee that inspire him, as they say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> I am credibly informed so, indeed, Madam
Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Well, I have discharged my conscience;
good morrow to you both. [<i>Exeunt severally.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite's</span> <i>Dining-room.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> This is the cabinet in which I hide my jewel; a
small house, in an obscure, little, retired street, too.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Vulgarly, an alley.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Nay, I hide my mistress with as much care as a
spark of the town does his money from his dun after a
good hand at play; and nothing but you could have
wrought upon me for a sight of her, let me perish.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> My obligation to you is great; do not lessen it
by delays of the favour you promised.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> But do not censure my honour; for if you had
not been in a desperate condition,&mdash;for as one nail must<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_59" id="Page_59">[Pg 59]</a></span>
beat out another, one poison expel another, one fire draw
out another, one fit of drinking cure the sickness of
another,&mdash;so, the surfeit you took last night of Christina's
eyes shall be cured by Lucy's this morning; or as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, I bar more similitudes.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What, in my mistress's lodging? that were as
hard as to bar a young parson in the pulpit, the fifth of
November, railing at the Church of Rome; or as hard as
to put you to bed to Lucy and defend you from touching
her; or as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Or as hard as to make you hold your tongue.&mdash;I
shall not see your mistress, I see.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Miss Lucy! Miss Lucy!&mdash;[<i>Knocks at the door
and returns.</i>]&mdash;The devil take me, if good men (I say no
more) have not been upon their knees to me, to see her,
and you at last must obtain it.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I do not believe you.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> 'Tis such as she; she is beautiful without affectation;
amorous without impertinency; airy and brisk
without impudence; frolic without rudeness; and, in a
word, the justest creature breathing to her assignation.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You praise her as if you had a mind to part with
her; and yet you resolve, I see, to keep her to yourself.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Keep her! poor creature, she cannot leave me;
and rather than leave her, I would leave writing lampoons
or sonnets almost.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Well, I'll leave you with her then.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What, will you go without seeing her?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Rather than stay without seeing her.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Yes, yes, you shall see her; but let me perish if
I have not been offered a hundred guineas for a sight of
her; by&mdash;I say no more.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I understand you now.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] If the
favour be to be purchased, then I'll bid all I have about
me for't.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Fy, fy, Mr. Ranger! you are pleasant, i'faith. Do
you think I would sell the sight of my rarity?&mdash;like those<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_60" id="Page_60">[Pg 60]</a></span>
gentlemen who hang out flags at Charing Cross, or
like&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, then I'm gone again.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What, you take it ill I refuse your money? rather
than that should be, give us it; but take notice I will
borrow it. Now I think on't, Lucy wants a gown and
some knacks.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Here.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> But I must pay it you again: I will not take it
unless you engage your honour I shall pay it you again.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You must pardon me; I will not engage my
honour for such a trifle. Go, fetch her out.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Well, she's a ravishing creature: such eyes and
lips, Mr. Ranger!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Prithee go.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Such neck and breasts, Mr. Ranger!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Again, prithee go.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Such feet, legs, and thighs, Mr. Ranger!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Prithee let me see 'em.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And a mouth no bigger than your ring!&mdash;I need
say no more.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Would thou wert never to speak again!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And then so neat, so sweet a creature in bed,
that, to my knowledge, she does not change her sheets in
half a year.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I thank you for that allay to my impatience.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Miss Lucy! Miss Lucy! Miss!&mdash;[<i>Knocking
at the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Will she not open? I am afraid my pretty miss
is not stirring, and therefore will not admit us. Is she
not gone her walk to Lamb's Conduit?<a name="FNanchor_38_38" id="FNanchor_38_38"></a><a href="#Footnote_38_38" class="fnanchor">[38]</a></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Fy, fy, a quibble next your stomach in a morning!<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_61" id="Page_61">[Pg 61]</a></span>
What if she should hear us? would you lose a
mistress for a quibble? that's more than I could do, let
me perish!&mdash;She's within, I hear her.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But she will not hear you; she's as deaf as if
you were a dun or a constable.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Pish! give her but leave to gape, rub her eyes,
and put on her day pinner; the long patch under the
left eye; awaken the roses on her cheeks with some
Spanish wool, and warrant her breath with some lemon-peel;
the doors fly off the hinges, and she into my arms.
She knows there is as much artifice to keep a victory as
to gain it; and 'tis a sign she values the conquest of my
heart.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I thought her beauty had not stood in need of art.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Beauty's a coward still without the help of art,
and may have the fortune of a conquest but cannot keep
it. Beauty and art can no more be asunder than love
and honour.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Or, to speak more like yourself, wit and judgment.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Don't you hear the door wag yet?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Not a whit.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Miss! miss! 'tis your slave that calls. Come,
all this tricking for him!&mdash;Lend me your comb, Mr.
Ranger.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> No, I am to be preferred to-day, you are to set
me off. You are in possession, I will not lend you arms
to keep me out.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! don't let me be ungrateful; if she has
smugged herself up for me, let me prune and flounce my
peruke a little for her. There's ne'er a young fellow in
the town but will do as much for a mere stranger in the
playhouse.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> A wit's wig has the privilege of being uncombed
in the very playhouse, or in the presence.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> But not in the presence of his mistress; 'tis a
greater neglect of her than himself. Pray lend me your
comb.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_62" id="Page_62">[Pg 62]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I would not have men of wit and courage make
use of every fop's mean arts to keep or gain a mistress.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> But don't you see every day, though a man have
never so much wit and courage, his mistress will revolt
to those fops that wear and comb perukes well. I'll
break off the bargain, and will not receive you my
partner.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Therefore you see I am setting up for myself.
[<i>Combs his peruke.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> She comes, she comes!&mdash;pray, your comb.
[<i>Snatches</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger's</span> <i>comb.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Bargain!&mdash;what, are you offering us to
sale?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! is't she?&mdash;Here take your comb again,
then. [<i>Returns the comb.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Would you sell us? 'tis like you, y'fads.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Sell thee!&mdash;where should we find a chapman?
Go, prithee, mother, call out my dear Miss Lucy.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Your Miss Lucy! I do not wonder you
have the conscience to bargain for us behind our backs,
since you have the impudence to claim a propriety in us
to my face.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> How's this, Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Come, come, this gentleman will not think the
worse of a woman for my acquaintance with her. He has
seen me bring your daughter to the lure with a chiney-orange,
from one side of the playhouse to the other.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> I would have the gentleman and you to
know my daughter is a girl of reputation, though she has
been seen in your company; but is now so sensible of
her past danger, that she is resolved never more to venture
her pitcher to the well, as they say.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> How's that, widow? I wonder at your confidence.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> I wonder at your old impudence, that
where you have had so frequent repulses you should provoke<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_63" id="Page_63">[Pg 63]</a></span>
another, and bring your friend here to witness your
disgrace.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Hark you, widow, a little.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> What, have you mortgaged my daughter to
that gentleman; and now would offer me a snip to join
in the security!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] She overhead me talk of a bargain;&mdash;'twas
unlucky.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Your wrath is grounded upon a
mistake; Miss Lucy herself shall be judge; call her out,
pray.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> She shall not; she will not come to you.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Till I hear it from her own mouth, I cannot
believe it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> You shall hear her say't through the door.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I shall doubt it unless she say it to my face.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Shall we be troubled with you no more
then?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> If she command my death, I cannot disobey her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Come out, child.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>, <i>holding down her head.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Your servant, dearest miss: can you have&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Let me ask her.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> No, I'll ask her.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I'll throw up cross or pile<a name="FNanchor_39_39" id="FNanchor_39_39"></a><a href="#Footnote_39_39" class="fnanchor">[39]</a> who shall ask her.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Can you have the heart to say you will never
more break a cheese-cake with me at New Spring Garden,<a name="FNanchor_40_40" id="FNanchor_40_40"></a><a href="#Footnote_40_40" class="fnanchor">[40]</a> the
Neat-house, or Chelsea? never more sit in my lap at<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_64" id="Page_64">[Pg 64]</a></span>
a new play? never more wear a suit of knots of my
choice? and, last of all, never more pass away an afternoon
with me again in the Green Garret?&mdash;do not forget
the Green Garret.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I wish I had never seen the Green Garret.&mdash;Damn
the Green Garret!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Damn the Green Garret!&mdash;You are strangely
altered!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> 'Tis you are altered.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You have refused Colby's Mulberry-garden, and
the French houses, for the Green Garret; and a little
something in the Green Garret pleased you more than
the best treat the other places could yield; and can you
of a sudden quit the Green Garret?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Since you have a design to pawn me for the
rent, 'tis time to remove my goods.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Thou art extremely mistaken.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Besides, I have heard such strange things of you
this morning.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What things?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I blush to speak 'em.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I know my innocence, therefore take my charge
as a favour. What have I done?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Then know, vile wit, my mother has confessed
just now thou wert false to me, to her too certain
knowledge; and hast forced even her to be false to
me too.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Faults in drink, Lucy, when we are not ourselves,
should not condemn us.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> And now to let me out to hire like a hackney!&mdash;I
tell you my own dear mother shall bargain for me no
more; there are as little as I can bargain for themselves
now-a-days, as well as properer women.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_65" id="Page_65">[Pg 65]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Whispering all this while!&mdash;Beware of his
snares again: come away, child.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Sweet, dear miss&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Bargain for me!&mdash;you have reckoned without
your hostess, as they say. Bargain for me! bargain
for me! [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I must return, then, to treat with you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Treat me no treatings, but take a word for
all. You shall no more dishonour my daughter, nor
molest my lodgings, as you have done at all hours.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Do you intend to change 'em, then, to Bridewell,
or Long's powdering-tub?<a name="FNanchor_41_41" id="FNanchor_41_41"></a><a href="#Footnote_41_41" class="fnanchor">[41]</a></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> No, to a bailiff's house, and then you'll be
so civil, I presume, as not to trouble us.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Here, will you have my comb again, Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! I think women take inconstancy from
me worse than from any man breathing.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Pray, sir, forget me before you write your
next lampoon. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span> <i>in the dress of a</i> Clerk.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ranger</span>
<i>retires to the background.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Have I found you? have I found you in
your by-walks, faith and troth? I am almost out of
breath in following you. Gentlemen when they get into
an alley walk so fast, as if they had more earnest business
there than in the broad streets.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>]&mdash;How came this sot hither? Fortune
has sent him to ease my choler.&mdash;You impudent rascal, who
are you, that dare intrude thus on us? [<i>Strikes him.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Don't you know me, Dapperwit? sure you
know me. [<i>Softly.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_66" id="Page_66">[Pg 66]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Will thou dishonour me with thy acquaintance
too? thou rascally, insolent, pen-and-ink man.
[<i>Strikes him again.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Oh! oh! sure you know me! pray know me.
[<i>Softly.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> By thy saucy familiarity, thou shouldst be a marker
at a tennis-court, a barber, or a slave that fills coffee.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Oh! oh!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What art thou? [<i>Kicks him.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, I must not discover myself to Ranger
for a kick or two. Oh, pray hold, sir: by that you will
know me. [<i>Delivers him a letter.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> How, Sir Simon!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Mum, mum, make no excuses, man; I would
not Ranger should have known me for five hundred&mdash;kicks.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Your disguise is so natural, I protest, it will
excuse me.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I know that, prithee make no excuses, I say.
No ceremony between thee and I, man:&mdash;read the letter.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What, you have not opened it!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Prithee, don't be angry, the seal is a little
cracked: for I could not help kissing Mrs. Martha's
letter. The word is, now or never. Her father she
finds will be abroad all this day, and she longs to see
your friend Sir Simon Addleplot:&mdash;faith 'tis a pretty
jest; while I am with her, and praising myself to her at
no ordinary rate. Let thee and I alone at an intrigue.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Tell her I will not fail to meet her at the place
and time. Have a care of your charge; and manage
your business like yourself, for yourself.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> The gaining Gripe's daughter will make me
support the loss of this young jilt here. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Coming forward.</i>] What fellow's that?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A servant to a friend of mine.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Methinks he something resembles our acquaintance<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_67" id="Page_67">[Pg 67]</a></span>
Sir Simon; but it is no compliment to tell him so:
for that knight is the most egregious coxcomb that ever
played with lady's fan.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> So! thanks to my disguise, I know my
enemies! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> The most incorrigible ass, beyond the reproof of
a kicking rival or a frowning mistress. But, if it be
possible, thou dost use him worse than his mistress or
rival can; thou dost make such a cully of him.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Does he think so too? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Go, friend, go about your business.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Sir
<span class="smcap">Simon</span>.] A pox! you would spoil all, just in the critical
time of projection. He brings me here a summons from
his mistress, to meet her in the evening; will you come
to my wedding?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Don't speak so loud, you'll break poor Lucy's
heart. Poor creature, she cannot leave you; and, rather
than leave her, you would leave writing of lampoons or
sonnets&mdash;almost.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Come, let her go, ungrateful baggage!&mdash;But now
you talk of sonnets, I am no living wit if her love has not
cost me two thousand couplets at least.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But what would you give, now, for a new satire
against women, ready made?&mdash;'Twould be as convenient
to buy satires against women ready made, as it is to buy
cravats ready tied.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Or as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Hey, come away, come away, Mr., or as&mdash;[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Peace, plenty, and pastime be within these
walls!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_68" id="Page_68">[Pg 68]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> 'Tis a small house, you see, and mean
furniture; for no gallants are suffered to come hither.
She might have had ere now as good lodgings as any in
town; her Mortlake<a name="FNanchor_42_42" id="FNanchor_42_42"></a><a href="#Footnote_42_42" class="fnanchor">[42]</a> hangings, great glasses, cabinets,
china, embroidered beds, Persia carpets, gold-plate, and
the like, if she would have put herself forward. But
your worship may please to make 'em remove to a place
fit to receive one of your worship's quality; for this is a
little scandalous, in truly.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, no; I like it well enough:&mdash;I am not
dainty. Besides, privacy, privacy, Mrs. Joyner! I love
privacy in opposition to the wicked, who hate it.
[<i>Looks about.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What do you look for, sir?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Walls have ears; but, besides, I look for a
private place to retire to, in time of need. Oh! here's
one convenient.
[<i>Turns up a hanging, and discovers the slender
provisions of the family.</i>]</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But you see, poor innocent souls, to what
use they put it;&mdash;not to hide gallants.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Temperance is the nurse of chastity.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But your worship may please to mend
their fare; and, when you come, may make them entertain
you better than, you see, they do themselves.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, I am not dainty, as I told you. I abominate
entertainments;&mdash;no entertainments, pray, Mrs.
Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> No! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> There can be no entertainment to me more
luscious and savoury than communion with that little
gentlewoman.&mdash;Will you call her out? I fast till I see
her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_69" id="Page_69">[Pg 69]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But, in truly, your worship, we should have
brought a bottle or two of Rhenish and some Naples
biscuit, to have entertained the young gentlewoman.
'Tis the mode for lovers to treat their mistresses.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Modes! I tell you, Mrs. Joyner, I hate modes
and forms.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You must send for something to entertain
her with.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Again entertaining!&mdash;we will be to each other
a feast.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I shall be ashamed, in truly, your worship.&mdash;Besides,
the young gentlewoman will despise you.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I shall content her, I warrant you; leave it to
me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I am sure you will not content
me, if you will not content her; 'tis as impossible for a
man to love and be a miser, as to love and be wise, as
they say.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> While you talk of treats, you starve my eyes;
I long to see the fair one; fetch her hither.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I am ashamed she should find me so
abominable a liar; I have so praised you to her, and,
above all your virtues, your liberality; which is so great
a virtue, that it often excuses youth, beauty, courage,
wit, or anything.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Pish, pish! 'tis the virtue of fools; every fool
can have it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> And will your worship want it, then? I
told her&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Why would you tell her anything of me? you
know I am a modest man. But come, if you will have
me as extravagant as the wicked, take that and fetch us
a treat, as you call it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Upon my life a groat! what will this purchase?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Two black pots of ale and a cake, at the cellar.&mdash;Come,
the wine has arsenic in't.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_70" id="Page_70">[Pg 70]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, I am mistaken, and my hopes
are abused: I never knew any man so mortified a miser,
that he would deny his lechery anything; I must be even
with thee then another way. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> These useful old women are more exorbitant
and craving in their desires than the young ones in theirs.
These prodigals in white perukes spoil 'em both; and
that's the reason, when the squires come under my
clutches, I make 'em pay for their folly and mine, and
'tis but conscience:&mdash;oh, here comes the fair one at
last!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span> <i>leading in</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>, <i>who hangs backwards
as she enters.</i></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Oh Lord, there's a man, godmother!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Come in, child, thou art so bashful&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> My mother is from home too, I dare not.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> If she were here, she'd teach you better
manners.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I'm afraid she'd be angry.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> To see you so much an ass.&mdash;Come along,
I say.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Nay, speak to her gently; if you won't, I will.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Thank you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Pretty innocent! there is, I see, one left of her
age; what hap have I! Sweet little gentlewoman, come
sit down by me.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I am better bred, I hope, sir.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> You must sit down by me.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I'd rather stand, if you please.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> To please me, you must sit, sweetest.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Not before my godmother, sure.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Wonderment of innocence!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> A poor bashful girl, sir: I'm sorry she is
not better taught.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I am glad she is not taught; I'll teach her
myself.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_71" id="Page_71">[Pg 71]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Are you a dancing-master then, sir? But if I
should be dull, and not move as you would have me, you
would not beat me, sir, I hope?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Beat thee, honeysuckle! I'll use thee thus,
and thus, and thus. [<i>Kisses her.</i>] Ah, Mrs. Joyner,
prithee go fetch our treat now.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> A treat of a groat! I will not wag.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Why don't you go? Here, take more money,
and fetch what you will; take here, half-a-crown.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What will half-a-crown do?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Take a crown then, an angel, a piece;<a name="FNanchor_43_43" id="FNanchor_43_43"></a><a href="#Footnote_43_43" class="fnanchor">[43]</a>&mdash;begone!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> A treat only will not serve my turn; I
must buy the poor wretch there some toys.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> What toys? what? speak quickly.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Pendants, necklaces, fans, ribbons, points,
laces, stockings, gloves&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Hold, hold! before it comes to a gown.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Well remembered, sir; indeed she wants a
gown, for she has but that one to her back. For your
own sake you should give her a new gown, for variety of
dresses rouses desire, and makes an old mistress seem
every day a new one.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> For that reason she shall have no new gown;
for I am naturally constant, and as I am still the same, I
love she should be still the same. But here, take half a
piece for the other things.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Half a piece!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Prithee, begone!&mdash;take t'other piece then&mdash;two
pieces&mdash;three pieces&mdash;five! here, 'tis all I have.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I must have the broad-seal ring too, or I
stir not.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Insatiable woman! will you have that too!
Prithee spare me that, 'twas my grandfather's.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> That's false, he had ne'er a coat.&mdash;So! now
I go; this is but a violent fit, and will not hold. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_72" id="Page_72">[Pg 72]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Oh! whither do you go, godmother? will you
leave me alone?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> The gentleman will not hurt you; you
may venture yourself with him alone.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I think I may, godmother.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.] What! will you lock me in, sir? don't lock
me in, sir. [<span class="smcap">Gripe</span>, <i>fumbling at the door, locks it.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> 'Tis a private lesson, I must teach you, fair.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I don't see your fiddle, sir; where is your little
kit?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I'll show it thee presently, sweetest.&mdash;[<i>Sets a
chair against the door.</i>]&mdash;Necessity, mother of invention!&mdash;Come,
my dearest. [<i>Takes her in his arms.</i></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> What do you mean, sir? don't hurt me, sir,
will you&mdash;Oh! oh! you will kill me! Murder! murder!&mdash;Oh!
oh!&mdash;help! help! oh!</p>

<p class="center"><i>The door is broken open; enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite</span>, <i>and
her</i> Landlord, <i>and his</i> 'Prentice, <i>in aprons.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> What, murder my daughter, villain!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I wish he had murdered me.&mdash;Oh! oh!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> What has he done?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Why would you go out, and leave me alone?
unfortunate woman that I am!</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> How now, what will this end in? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Who brought him in?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> That witch, that treacherous false woman, my
godmother, who has betrayed me, sold me to his lust.&mdash;Oh!
oh!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Have you ravished my daughter, then,
you old goat? ravished my daughter!&mdash;ravished my
daughter! speak, villain.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> By yea and by nay, no such matter.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> A canting rogue, too! Take notice, landlord,
he has ravished my daughter, you see her
all in tears and distraction; and see there the wicked
engine of the filthy execution.&mdash;[<i>Pointing to the chair.</i>]&mdash;Jeremy,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_73" id="Page_73">[Pg 73]</a></span>
call up the neighbours, and the constable,&mdash;False
villain! thou shalt die for it.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Hold! hold!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]&mdash;Nay, I am caught.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Go, go, make haste&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Oh! oh!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Poor wretch!&mdash;Go quickly.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Hold! hold!&mdash;Thou young spawn of the old
serpent! wicked, as I thought thee innocent! wilt thou
say I would have ravished thee?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I will swear you did ravish me.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I thought so, treacherous Eve!&mdash;then I am
gone, I must shift as well as I can.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Oh! oh!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Will none of you call up the neighbours,
and the authority of the alley?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Hold, I'll give you twenty mark<a name="FNanchor_44_44" id="FNanchor_44_44"></a><a href="#Footnote_44_44" class="fnanchor">[44]</a> among you
to let me go.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Villain! nothing shall buy thy life.</p>

<p><i>Land.</i> But stay, Mrs. Crossbite, let me talk with you.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Oh! oh!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Land.</i> Come, sir, I am your friend:&mdash;in a word, I
have appeased her, and she shall be contented with a
little sum.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> What is it? what is it?</p>

<p><i>Land.</i> But five hundred pounds.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> But five hundred pounds!&mdash;hang me then,
hang me rather.</p>

<p><i>Land.</i> You will say I have been your friend.</p>

<p><i>Pren.</i> The constable and neighbours are a-coming.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> How, how; will you not take a hundred?
pray use conscience in your ways.
[<i>Kneels to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> I scorn your money! I will not take a
thousand.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] My enemies are many, and I shall be
a scandal to the faithful, as a laughing-stock to the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_74" id="Page_74">[Pg 74]</a></span>
wicked.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Go, prepare your engines for my
persecution; I'll give you the best security I can.</p>

<p><i>Land.</i> The instruments are drawing in the other room,
if you please to go thither.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Indeed, now I consider, a portion will do
my daughter more good than his death. That would but
publish her shame; money will cover it&mdash;<i>probatum est</i>, as
they say. Let me tell you, sir, 'tis a charitable thing to
give a young maid a portion. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Lydia's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>, <i>attended by</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> 'Tis as hard for a woman to conceal her indignation
from her apostate lover, as to conceal her love
from her faithful servant.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Or almost as hard as it is for the prating
fellows now-a-days to conceal the favours of obliging
ladies.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> If Ranger should come up, (I saw him just now
in the street,) the discovery of my anger to him now
would be as mean as the discovery of my love to him
before.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Though I did so mean a thing as to love a
fellow, I would not do so mean a thing as to confess it,
certainly, by my trouble to part with him. If I confessed
love, it should be before they left me.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> So you would deserve to be left, before you
were. But could you ever do so mean a thing as to
confess love to any?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Yes; but I never did so mean a thing as
really to love any.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> You had once a husband.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_75" id="Page_75">[Pg 75]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Fy! madam, do you think me so ill bred as
to love a husband?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> You had a widow's heart, before you were a
widow, I see.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I should rather make an adventure of my
honour with a gallant for a gown, a new coach, a necklace,
than clap my husband's cheeks for them, or sit in
his lap. I should be as ashamed to be caught in such a
posture with a husband, as a brisk well-bred spark of
the town would be to be caught on his knees at prayers&mdash;unless
to his mistress.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Mr. Ranger, 'twas obligingly done of you.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Indeed, cousin, I had kept my promise with you
last night, but this gentleman knows&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> You mistake me; but you shall not lessen any
favour you do to me. You are going to excuse your not
coming to me last night, when I take it as a particular
obligation, that though you threatened me with a visit,
upon consideration you were so civil as not to trouble
me.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> This is an unlucky morning with me! here's my
eternal persecution, the widow Flippant. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> What, Mr. Dapperwit!
[<span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span> <i>retires to the back of the stage,
followed by</i> <span class="smcap">Lady Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Indeed, cousin, besides my business, another
cause I did not wait on you was, my apprehension you
were gone to the Park, notwithstanding your promise to
the contrary.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Therefore, you went to the Park to visit me
there, notwithstanding your promise to the contrary?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Who, I at the Park! when I had promised to
wait upon you at your lodging! But were you at the
Park, madam?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Who, I at the Park! when I had promised to<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_76" id="Page_76">[Pg 76]</a></span>
wait for you at home! I was no more at the Park than
you were. Were you at the Park?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> The Park had been a dismal desert to me, notwithstanding
all the good company in it, if I had wanted
yours.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Because it has been the constant endeavour
of men to keep women ignorant, they think us
so; but 'tis that increases our inquisitiveness, and makes
us know them ignorant as false. He is as impudent a
dissembler as the widow Flippant, who is making her
importunate addresses in vain, for aught I see.</p>

<p class="center">[Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>comes forward, driving</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>
<i>from one side of the stage to the other.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Dear Mr. Dapperwit! merciful Mr. Dapperwit!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Unmerciful Lady Flippant!</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Will you be satisfied?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Won't you be satisfied?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> That a wit should be jealous; that a wit
should be jealous! there's never a brisk young fellow in
the town, though no wit, Heaven knows, but thinks too
well of himself, to think ill of his wife or mistress. Now,
that a wit should lessen his opinion of himself;&mdash;for
shame!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I promised to bring you off, but I find it enough
to shift for myself&mdash;[<i>Softly, apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> What! out of breath, madam!</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I have been defending our cause, madam;
I have beat him out of the pit. I do so mumble these
prating, censorious fellows they call wits, when I meet
with them.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Her ladyship, indeed, is the only thing in petticoats
I dread. 'Twas well for me there was company in
the room; for I dare no more venture myself with her
alone, than a cully that has been bit dares venture himself
in a tavern with an old rook.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I am the revenger of our sex, certainly.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_77" id="Page_77">[Pg 77]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And the most insatiable one I ever knew,
madam; I dare not stand your fury longer.&mdash;Mr.
Ranger, I will go before and make a new appointment
with your friends that expect you at dinner at the
French-house; 'tis fit business still wait on love.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Do so&mdash;but now I think on't, Sir Thomas goes
out of town this afternoon, and I shall not see him here
again these three months.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Nay, pray take him with you, sir.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> No, sir, you shall not take the gentleman
from his mistress.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.] Do not go
yet, sweet Mr. Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Take him with you, sir; I suppose his business
may be there to borrow or win money, and I ought not
to be his hindrance: for when he has none, he has his
desperate designs upon that little I have;&mdash;for want of
money makes as devout lovers as Christians.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I hope, madam, he offers you no less security
than his liberty.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> His liberty is as poor a pawn to take up money
on as honour. He is like the desperate bankrupts of
this age, who, if they can get people's fortunes into their
hands, care not though they spend them in jail all their
lives.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> And the poor crediting ladies, when they have
parted with their money, must be contented with a
pitiful composition, or starve, for all them.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But widows are commonly so wise as to be sure
their men are solvable before they trust 'em.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Can you blame 'em! I declare I will trust
no man. Pray, do not take it ill, gentlemen: quacks in
their bills, and poets in the titles of their plays, do not
more disappoint us, than gallants with their promises;
but I trust none.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Nay, she's a very Jew in that particular. To
my knowledge, she'll know her man, over and over
again, before she trust him.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_78" id="Page_78">[Pg 78]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Well, my dearest cousin, good-morrow. When
I stay from you so long again, blame me to purpose,
and be extremely angry; for nothing can make me
amends for the loss of your company, but your reprehension
of my absence. I'll take such a chiding as
kindly as Russian wives do beating.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> If you were my husband, I could not take your
absence more kindly than I do.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> And if you were my wife, I would trust you as
much out of my sight as I could, to show my opinion of
your virtue.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> A well-bred gentleman, I warrant.&mdash;Will you
go then, cruel Mr. Dapperwit?
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>, <i>followed by</i>
Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Have I not dissembled well, Leonore?</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> But, madam, to what purpose? why do you not
put him to his trial, and see what he can say for himself?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I am afraid lest my proofs, and his guilt, should
make him desperate, and so contemn that pardon which
he could not hope for.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> 'Tis unjust to condemn him before you hear him.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I will reprieve him till I have more evidence.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> How will you get it?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I will write him a letter in Christina's name,
desiring to meet him; when I shall soon discover if his
love to her be of a longer standing than since last night;
and if it be not, I will not longer trust him with the
vanity to think she gave him the occasion to follow her
home from the Park; so will at once disabuse him and
myself.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> What care the jealous take in making sure of ills
which they, but in imagination, cannot undergo!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Misfortunes are least dreadful when most near:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Tis less to undergo the ill, than fear. [<i>Exeunt.</i></span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_79" id="Page_79">[Pg 79]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FOURTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>, <i>the latter in a blue gown
and nightcap.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What, not well, your worship!
This it is, you will be laying out yourself
beyond your strength. You have
taken a surfeit of the little gentlewoman,
I find. Indeed you should not have been
so immoderate in your embraces; your worship is something
in years, in truly.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Graceless, perfidious woman! what makest
thou here? art thou not afraid to be used like an
informer, since thou hast made me pay thee for
betraying me?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Betray your worship! what do you mean?
I an informer! I scorn your words!</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Woman, I say again, thou art as treacherous as
an informer, and more unreasonable; for he lets us have
something for our money before he disturb us.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Your money, I'm sure, was laid out
faithfully; and I went away because I would not
disturb you.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I had not grudged you the money I gave
you:&mdash;but the five hundred pounds! the five hundred
pounds! Inconscionable, false woman, the five hundred
pounds!&mdash;You cheated, trepanned, robbed me, of the
five hundred pounds!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_80" id="Page_80">[Pg 80]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I cheat you! I rob you!&mdash;well, remember
what you say, you shall answer it before Mr. Doublecap
and the best of&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Oh, impudent woman, speak softly!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I will not speak softly; for innocence is
loud as well as barefaced. Is this your return, after you
have made me a mere drudge to your filthy lusts?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Speak softly; my sister, daughter, and servants,
will hear.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I would have witnesses, to take notice that
you blast my good name, which was as white as a tulip,
and as sweet as the head of your cane, before you
wrought me to the carrying on the work of your fleshly
carnal seekings.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Softly! softly! they are coming in.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> What's the matter, brother?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Nothing, nothing, sister, only the godly woman
is fallen into a fit of zeal against the enormous transgressions
of the age. Go! go! you do not love to hear
vanity reproved; pray begone!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Pray stay, madam, that you may know&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> [<i>Aside to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.] Hold! hold! here are
five guineas for thee,&mdash;pray say nothing.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Sister,
pray begone, I say.&mdash;[<i>Exeunt</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>and</i>
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.] Would you prejudice your own reputation
to injure mine?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Would you prejudice your own soul to
wrong my repute, in truly? [<i>Pretends to weep.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Pray have me in excuse. Indeed, I thought
you had a share of the five hundred pounds, because you
took away my seal-ring; which they made me send,
together with a note to my cash-keeper for five hundred
pounds. Besides, I thought none but you knew it was
my wonted token to send for money by.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> 'Tis unlucky I should forget it, and leave<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_81" id="Page_81">[Pg 81]</a></span>
it on the table!&mdash;But oh the harlotry! did she make that
use of it then? 'twas no wonder you did not stay till I
came back.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I stayed till the money released me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Have they the money, then? five hundred
pounds!</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Too certain.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> They told me not a word of it; and have
you no way to retrieve it?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Not any.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I am glad of it.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Is there
no law but against saints?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I will not for five hundred pounds publish my
transgression myself, lest I should be thought to glory
in't: though, I must confess, 'twould tempt a man to
conform to public praying and sinning, since 'tis so
chargeable to pray and sin in private.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But are you resolved to give off a loser?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> How shall I help it?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Nay, I'll see you shall have what the young
jade has, for your money; I'll make 'em use some
conscience, however.&mdash;Take a man's money for nothing!</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Thou sayest honestly, indeed. And shall I
have my pennyworths out of the little gentlewoman for
all this?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I'll be engaged body for body for her, and
you shall take the forfeiture on me else.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, no, I'll rather take your word, Mrs.
Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Go in and dress yourself smug, and leave
the rest to me.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No man breathing would give-off a loser, as she
says. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_82" id="Page_82">[Pg 82]</a></span></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>Another Room in the same.</i></h4>

<p class="center">Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span> <i>discovered sitting at a desk
writing as a</i> Clerk, Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>jogging him.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> 'Tis a lord's mortgage, and therefore requires
the more haste:&mdash;pray do not jog me, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Dull rascal! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> They cannot stay for money as other folks.
If you will not let me make an end on't, I shall lose my
expedition-fee.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> There are some clerks would have understood
me before this. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, pray be quiet, madam; if you squeeze
me so to the wall, I cannot write.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] 'Tis much for the honour of the
gentlemen of this age, that we persons of quality are
forced to descend to the importuning of a clerk, a butler,
coachman, or footman; while the rogues are as dull of
apprehension, too, as an unfledged country squire amongst
his mother's maids! [<i>Jogs him again.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Again! Let me tell you, madam, familiarity
breeds contempt: you'll never leave till you have made
me saucy.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I would I could see that.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I vow and swear then, get you gone! or I'll
add a black patch or two to those on your face.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
I shall have no time to get Mrs. Martha out, for her.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Will you, sir, will you! [<i>Jogs him again.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I must have a plot for her, she is a
coy woman.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] I vow and swear if you pass this
crevice,<a name="FNanchor_45_45" id="FNanchor_45_45"></a><a href="#Footnote_45_45" class="fnanchor">[45]</a> I'll kiss you in plain English.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I would I could see that!&mdash;do you defy me!
[<i>Steps to him&mdash;he kisses her.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] How's this! I vow and swear, she<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_83" id="Page_83">[Pg 83]</a></span>
kisses as tamely as Mrs. Ticklish, and with her mouth
open too.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I thought you would have been ashamed to
have done so to your master's own sister!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I hope you'll be quiet now, madam?</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Nay, I'll be revenged of you sure.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> If you come again, I shall do more to you
than that.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I'll pursue my plot and try if she be
honest.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> You do more to me than that! nay, if you'll
do more to me than that&mdash;[<i>She
throws down his ink and runs out, he following her.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I must visit my young clients in the meantime.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon</span>, <i>holding up his hands.</i></p>

<p>What's the matter, Sir Simon?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Lord! who would have thought it?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What ails you, Sir Simon?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I have made such a discovery, Mrs. Joyner!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> What is't?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Such a one that makes me at once glad and
sorry; I am sorry my Lady Flippant is naught, but I'm
glad I know it:&mdash;thanks still to my disguise.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Fy! fy!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, this hand can tell&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> But how?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> She threw down my ink-glass, and ran away
into the next room; I followed her, and, in revenge,
threw her down upon the bed:&mdash;but, in short, all that I
could do to her would not make her squeak.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> She was out of breath, man, she was out of
breath.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Ah, Mrs. Joyner, say no more, say no more
of that!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_84" id="Page_84">[Pg 84]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> You rude, unmannerly rascal!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You see she complains now.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I know why, Mrs. Joyner, I know why.
[<i>Aside to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I'll have you turned out of the house; you are
not fit for my brother's service.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Not for yours, you mean, madam. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I'll go and acquaint my brother&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> [<i>Aside to</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.] Hold, hold,
madam, speak not so loud:&mdash;'tis Sir Simon Addleplot,
your lover, who has taken this disguise on purpose to be
near you, and to watch and supplant his rival.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> What a beast was I, I could not discover it!
you have undone me! why would you not tell me sooner
of it? [<i>Aside to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I thought he had been discernible enough.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> I protest, I knew him not; for I must confess
to you, my eyes are none of the best since I have used
the last new wash of mercury-water.&mdash;What will he think
of me!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Let me alone with him.&mdash;[<i>To</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon</span>.]
Come, come, did you think you could disguise yourself
from my lady's knowledge? she knew you, man, or else
you had ne'er had those liberties. Alas, poor lady, she
cannot resist you!</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> 'Tis my weakness.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> How's this!&mdash;but here comes my master.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Come, Mrs. Joyner, are you ready to go?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I am ever ready when your worship
commands.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Brother, if you go to t'other end of the town,
you'll set me down near the playhouse?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> The playhouse! do you think I will be seen
near the playhouse?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_85" id="Page_85">[Pg 85]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> You shall set me down in Lincoln's-inn-fields,
then? for I have earnest business there.&mdash;[<i>Apart to</i> Sir
<span class="smcap">Simon</span>.] When I come home again, I'll laugh at you
soundly, Sir Simon.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Has Joyner betrayed me then! 'tis time to
look to my hits. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Martha, be sure you stay within now. If you
go out, you shall never come into my doors again.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> No, I will not, sir; I'll ne'er come into
your doors again, if once I should go out.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> 'Tis well said, girl.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>, <i>and</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> 'Twas prettily said: I understand you, they
are dull, and have no intrigue in 'em. But dear sweet
Mrs. Martha, 'tis time we were gone; you have stole
away your scarfs and hood from your maid, I hope?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Nay, I am ready, but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Come, come, Sir Simon Addleplot, poor
gentleman, is an impatient man, to my knowledge.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Well, my venture is great, I'm sure, for a
man I know not. But pray, Jonas, do not deceive me;
is he so fine a gentleman, as you say he is?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Pish! pish! he is the&mdash;gentleman of the
town, faith and troth.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> But may I take your word, Jonas?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> 'Tis not my word, 'tis the word of all the
town.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Excuse me, Jonas, for that:&mdash;I never heard
any speak well of him but Mr. Dapperwit and you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> That's because he has been a rival to all
men, and a gallant to all ladies. Rivals and deserted
mistresses never speak well of a man.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Has he been so general in his amours? his
kindness is not to be valued then.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> The more by you; because 'tis for you he
deserts all the rest, faith and troth.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You plead better for him than he could for<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_86" id="Page_86">[Pg 86]</a></span>
himself, I believe; for, indeed, they say he is no better
than an idiot.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Then, believe me, madam&mdash;for nobody knows
him better than I&mdash;he has as much wit, courage, and as
good a mien to the full, as I have.&mdash;He an idiot!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> The common gull; so perspicuous a fop, the
women find him out:&mdash;for none of 'em will marry him.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> You may see, now, how he and you are
abused. For that he is not married, is a sign of his wit;
and for being perspicuous, 'tis false; he is as mysterious
as a new parliament-man, or a young statesman newly
taken from a coffee-house or tennis-court.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> But is it a sign of his wit because he is
not married?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Yes, yes; your women of the town ravish
your fops: there's not one about the town unmarried that
has anything.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> It may be then he has spent his estate.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] How unluckily guessed!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
If he had, he has a head can retrieve it again.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Besides, they say he has the modish distemper.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> He can cure it with the best French chirurgeon
in town.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Has his practice on himself been so much?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Come, come.&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Fame, like deserted jilt, does still belie men;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who doubts her man, must be advised by Hymen;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For he knows best of any how to try men.&nbsp; [<i>Exeunt.</i></span><br />
</p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<i>The old Pall Mall.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Now the Lucys have renounced us, hey for the
Christinas! She cannot use me worse than your honourable
mistress did you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_87" id="Page_87">[Pg 87]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! some young heir or another has promised
her marriage. There are so many fools in the
world, 'tis impossible for a man of wit to keep his wench
from being a lady, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But have you no other acquaintance that sticks
to her vocation, in spite of temptations of honour or
filthy lucre? I declare, I make honourable love merely
out of necessity, as your rooks play on the square rather
than not play at all.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span> <i>masked, with a letter in her hand.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Come, the devil will not lose a gamester: here's
ready money for you, push freely.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Thou art as well met as if by assignation.
[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> And you are as well met as if you were the man
I looked for.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Kind rogue!</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> Sweet sir!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Come, I am thy prisoner, (without more words,)
show but thy warrant. [<i>Goes to pull off her mask.</i></p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> You mistake, sir; here is my pass.
[<i>Gives him the letter.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> A letter! and directed to me!</p>

<p>[<i>Reads.</i>] "I cannot put up the injuries and affronts
you did me last night;"&mdash;a challenge, upon my life!
and by such a messenger!&mdash;"therefore conjure you by
your honour, at eight o'clock precisely, this evening, to
send your man to St. James's gate, to wait for me with a
chair, to conduct me to what place you shall think
most fit, for the giving of satisfaction to the injured&mdash;Christina."</p>

<p>Christina! I am amazed! What is it o'clock, Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> It wants not half an hour of eight.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.] Go then back, my pretty
herald, and tell my fair enemy the service she designs<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_88" id="Page_88">[Pg 88]</a></span>
my man is only fit for my friend here; whose faith and
honour she may be secure of. He shall immediately go
wait for her at St James's gate, whilst I go to prepare a
place for our rencounter, and myself to die at her feet.
[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.] Dapperwit, dear Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What lucky surprisal's this?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Prithee ask no questions, till I have more leisure
and less astonishment. I know you will not deny to be
an instrument in my happiness.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> No, let me perish! I take as much pleasure to
bring lovers together as an old woman; or as a bankrupt
gamester loves to look on, though he has no advantage
by the play; or as a bully that fights not himself, yet
takes pleasure to set people together by the ears, or as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> 'Sdeath! is this a time for similitudes?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You have made me miscarry of a good thought
now, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Go presently to St. James's gate, where you are
to expect the coming of a lady ('tis Christina), accompanied
by that woman you saw e'en now. She will
permit you to put her into a chair, and then conduct her
to my lodging; while I go before to remove some spies,
and prepare it for her reception.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Your lodging? had you not better carry her to
Vincent's? 'tis hard by; and there a vizard mask has as
free egress and regress as at the playhouse.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Faith, though it be not very prudent, yet she
shall come thither in my vindication; for he would not
believe I had seen her last night.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> To have a fine woman, and not tell on't as you
say, Mr. Ranger&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Go, and bring her to Vincent's lodging; there
I'll expect you. [<i>Exeunt severally.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_89" id="Page_89">[Pg 89]</a></span></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<i>The Street before</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> This is the door, madam; here Mr. Vincent
lodges.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> 'Tis no matter, we will pass it by; lest the
people of our lodgings should watch us. But if he
should not be here now!</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Who, Mr. Valentine, madam? I warrant you
my intelligencer dares not fail me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Did he come last night, said he?</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Last night late.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> And not see me yet! nay, not send to me!&mdash;'tis
false, he is not come,&mdash;I wish he were not. I know
not which I should take more unkindly from him, exposing
his life to his revengeful enemies, or being almost
four-and-twenty hours so near me, and not let me
know't.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> A lover's dangers are the only secrets kept from
his mistress; he came not to you because he would not
purchase his happiness with your fear and apprehensions.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Nay, he is come, I see, since you are come
about again of his side.</p>

<p><i>Isa.</i> Will you go in, madam, and disprove me, if you
can? 'tis better than standing in the street.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> We'll go a little further first, and return.
[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE V.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Vincent's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I told you I had sent my man to Christina's this
morning, to inquire of her maid, (who seldom denies him
a secret,) if her lady had been at the Park last night;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_90" id="Page_90">[Pg 90]</a></span>
which she peremptorily answered to the contrary, and
assured him she had not stirred out since your departure.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Will not chambermaids lie, Vincent?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Will not Ranger lie, Valentine?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> The circumstances of his story proved it true.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Do you think so old a master in the faculty as
he will want the varnish of probability for his lies?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Do you think a woman, having the advantage of
her sex, and education under such a mistress, will want
impudence to disavow a truth that might be prejudicial
to that mistress?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But if both testimonies are fallible, why will you
needs believe his? we are apter to believe the things we
would have, than those we would not.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> My ill luck has taught me to credit my misfortunes
and doubt my happiness.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But fortune we know is inconstant.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> And all of her sex.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Will you judge of fortune by your experience,
and not do your mistress the same justice? Go see her,
and satisfy yourself and her; for if she be innocent, consider
how culpable you are, not only in your censures of
her, but in not seeing her since your coming.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> If she be innocent, I should be afraid to surprise
her, for her sake; if false, I should be afraid to surprise
her for my own.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> To be jealous and not inquisitive is as hard as to
love extremely and not to be something jealous.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Inquisitiveness as seldom cures jealousy, as
drinking in a fever quenches the thirst.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> If she were at the Park last night, 'tis probable
she'll not miss this. Go watch her house, see who goes
out, who in; while I, in the meantime, search out
Ranger: who, I'll pawn my life, upon more discourse
shall avow his mistake.&mdash;Here he is; go in:&mdash;how
luckily is he come!
[<span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>retires to the door behind.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_91" id="Page_91">[Pg 91]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p>Ranger, you have prevented me: I was going to look
you out, between the scenes at the playhouse, the coffee-house,
tennis-court, or Gifford's.<a name="FNanchor_46_46" id="FNanchor_46_46"></a><a href="#Footnote_46_46" class="fnanchor">[46]</a></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Do you want a pretence to go to a bawdy-house?&mdash;but
I have other visits to make.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I forget. I should rather have sought you in
