Christina's lodgings, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Well, well, I'm just come to tell you that
Christina&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Proves not, by daylight, the kind lady you
followed last night out of the Park.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I have better news for you, to my thinking.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> What is't?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Not that I have been in Christina's lodging
this morning; but that she'll be presently here in your
lodging with me.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin. [Retiring, and speaking softly to</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.]
You see now, his report was a jest, a mere jest.&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.] Well, must my lodging be your vaulting-school<a name="FNanchor_47_47" id="FNanchor_47_47"></a><a href="#Footnote_47_47" class="fnanchor">[47]</a>
still? thou hast appointed a wench to come
hither, I find.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> A wench! you seemed to have more reverence
for Christina last night.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Now you talk of Christina, prithee tell me what
was the meaning of thy last night's romance of Christina?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You shall know the meaning of all when Christina
comes: she'll be here presently.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Who will? Christina?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Yes, Christina.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_92" id="Page_92">[Pg 92]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Incredulous envy! thou art as envious as an
impotent lecher at a wedding.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Thou art either mad, or as vain as a Frenchman
newly returned home from a campaign, or obliging
England.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Thou art as envious as a rival; but if thou art
mine, there's that will make you desist; [<i>gives him a
letter</i>] and if you are not my rival, entrusting you with
such a secret will, I know, oblige you to keep it, and
assist me against all other interests.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Do you think I take your secret as an obligation?
don't I know, lovers, travellers, and poets, will give
money to be heard? But what's the paper? a lampoon
upon Christina, hatched last night betwixt squire Dapperwit
and you, because her maid used you scurvily?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> No, 'tis only a letter from her, to show my company
was not so disgustful to her last night, but that she
desires it again to-day.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> A letter from her! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> A letter from Christina! [<i>Reads.</i>]&mdash;Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, 'tis pleasant.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You mistake, I laugh at you, not the letter.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I am like the winning gamester, so pleased with
my luck, I will not quarrel with any who calls me a fool
for't.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Is this the style of a woman of honour?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> It may be, for ought you know; I'm sure 'tis
well if your female correspondents can read.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I must confess I have none of the little letters,
half name or title, like your Spanish Epistles Dedicatory;
but that a man so frequent in honourable intrigues as
you are, should not know the summons of an impudent
common woman, from that of a person of honour!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Christina is so much a person of honour she'll
own what she has writ when she comes.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But will she come hither indeed?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Immediately. You'll excuse my liberty with you;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_93" id="Page_93">[Pg 93]</a></span>
I could not conceal such a happiness from such a friend
as you, lest you should have taken it unkindly.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Faith, you have obliged me indeed; for you and
others would often have made me believe your honourable
intrigues, but never did me the honour to convince
me of 'em before.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You are merry, I find, yet.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> When you are happy I cannot be otherwise.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] But I lose time; I should lay a little
parson in ambush, that lives hard by, in case Christina
should be impatient to be revenged of her friends, as it
often happens with a discontented heiress. Women,
like old soldiers, more nimbly execute than they resolve.
[<i>Going out.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> What now! you will not disappoint a woman of
Christina's quality?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I'll be here before she comes, I warrant you.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I do believe you truly!&mdash;What think you,
Valentine?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> [<i>Coming forward.</i>] I think, since she has the
courage to challenge him, she'll have the honour of being
first in the field.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Fy, your opinion of her must be as bad, as
Ranger's of himself is good, to think she would write to
him. I long till his bona-roba<a name="FNanchor_48_48" id="FNanchor_48_48"></a><a href="#Footnote_48_48" class="fnanchor">[48]</a> comes, that you may be
both disabused.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> And I have not patience to stay her coming, lest
you should be disabused.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Here she is, i'faith; I'm glad she's come.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> And I'm sorry. But I will to my post again, lest
she should say she came to me. [<i>Retires as before.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] By heavens, Christina herself! 'tis she!
[<span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>pulls off her mask.</i></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> 'Tis she:&mdash;cursed be these eyes! more cursed<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_94" id="Page_94">[Pg 94]</a></span>
than when they first betrayed me to that false bewitching
face. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> You may wonder, sir, to see me here&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I must confess I do.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> But the confidence your friend has in you is the
cause of mine; and yet some blushes it does cost me to
come to seek a man.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Modest creature! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> How am I deceived! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Where is he, sir? why does he not appear, to
keep me in countenance? pray call him, sir; 'tis something
hard if he should know I'm here.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I hardly can myself believe you are here,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> If my visit be troublesome or unseasonable, 'tis
your friend's fault; I designed it not to you, sir. Pray
call him out, that he may excuse it, and take it on himself,
together with my shame.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> How impatient she is! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Or do you delay the happiness I ask, to make
it more welcome? I have stayed too long for it already,
and cannot more desire it. Dear sir, call him out.
Where is he? above, or here within? I'll snatch the
favour which you will not give.&mdash;[<i>Goes to the door and discovers</i>
<span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.] What! Do you hide yourself for
shame?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> [<i>Coming forward.</i>] I must confess I do.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> To see me come hither&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I acknowledge it. [<span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>offers to go out.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Before you came to me? But whither do you
go? come, I can forgive you.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> But I cannot forgive you.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Whither do you go? you need not forge a
quarrel to prevent mine to you: nor need you try if I
would follow you, you know I will;&mdash;I have, you see.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> That impudence should look so like innocence!
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_95" id="Page_95">[Pg 95]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Whither would you go? why would you go?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> To call your servant to you.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> She is here; what would you have with her?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I mean your lover,&mdash;the man you came to meet.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Oh heavens! what lover? what man? I came
to see no man but you, whom I had too long lost.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> You could not know that I was here.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Ask her; 'twas she that told me.
[<i>Points to</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How could she know?</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> That you shall know hereafter.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> No, you thought me too far out of the way to
disturb your assignation; and I assure you, madam, 'twas
my ill-fortune, not my design: and that it may appear so,
I do withdraw, as in all good breeding and civility I am
obliged; for sure your wished-for lover's coming.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What do you mean? are you a-weary of that
title?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I am ashamed of it, since it grows common.
[<i>Going out.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Nay, you will not, shall not go.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> My stay might give him jealousy, and so do you
injury, and him the greatest in the world: heavens forbid!
I would not make a man jealous; for though you
call a thousand vows, and oaths, and tears to witness (as
you safely may), that you have not the least of love for
me, yet if he ever knew how I have loved you, sure he
would not, could not believe you.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I do confess, your riddle is too hard for me to
solve; therefore you are obliged to do't yourself.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I wish it were capable of any other interpretation
than what you know already.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Is this that generous good Valentine? who has
disguised him so? [<i>Weeps.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Nay, I must withhold you then. [<i>Stops</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>
<i>going out.</i>] Methinks she should be innocent; her
tongue, and eyes, together with that flood that swells 'em,
do vindicate her heart.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_96" id="Page_96">[Pg 96]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> They show but their long practice of dissimulation.
[<i>Going out.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Come back: I hear Ranger coming up: stay but
till he comes.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Do you think I have the patience of an alderman?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You may go out this way, when you will, by the
back-stairs; but stay a little, till&mdash;Oh, here he comes.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>. <i>Upon his entrance</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span>
<i>puts on her mask.</i></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> My revenge will now detain me.
[<span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>retires again.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>]&mdash;What, come already! where is
Dapperwit?&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] The blessing's double that comes quickly;
I did not yet expect you here, otherwise I had not done
myself the injury to be absent. But I hope, madam, I
have not made you stay long for me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I have not staid at all for you.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I am glad of it, madam.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>.] Is not this that troublesome
stranger who last night followed the lady into my
lodgings?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] 'Tis he.
[<i>Removing from him to the other side.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Why does she remove so disdainfully
from me?&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] I find you take it ill I was not at
your coming here, madam.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Indeed I do not; you are mistaken, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Confirm me by a smile then, madam; remove
that cloud, which makes me apprehend foul weather.
[<i>Goes to take off her mask.</i>]&mdash;Mr. Vincent, pray retire;
'tis you keep on the lady's mask, and no displeasure
which she has for me.&mdash;Yet, madam, you need not distrust
his honour or his faith.&mdash;But do not keep the lady
under constraint; pray leave us a little, Master Vincent.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> You must not leave us, sir; would you leave
me with a stranger?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_97" id="Page_97">[Pg 97]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How's that! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I've done amiss, I find, to bring her
hither.&mdash;Madam, I understand you&mdash;[<i>Apart
to</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span>.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Sir, I do not understand you.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You would not be known to Mr. Vincent.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> 'Tis your acquaintance I would avoid.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Dull brute that I was, to bring her
hither!&mdash;I have found my error, madam; give me but a
new appointment, where I may meet you by and by, and
straight I will withdraw as if I knew you not. [<i>Softly to her.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Why, do you know me?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I must not own it.&mdash;No, madam, but&mdash;[<i>Offers
to whisper.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Whispering, sir, argues an old acquaintance;
but I have not the vanity to be thought of yours, and resolve
you shall never have the disparagement of mine.&mdash;Mr.
Vincent, pray let us go in here.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> How's this! I am undone, I see; but if I let her
go thus, I shall be an eternal laughing-stock to Vincent.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Do you not know him, madam? I thought you
had come hither on purpose to meet him.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> To meet him!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> By your own appointment.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> What strange infatuation does delude you all?
you know, he said he did not know me.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You writ to him; he has your letter.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Then, you know my name sure? yet you confessed
but now you knew me not.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I must confess your anger has disguised you
more than your mask: for I thought to have met a
kinder Christina here.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Heavens! how could he know me in
this place? he watched me hither sure; or is there any
other of my name.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] That you may no longer<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_98" id="Page_98">[Pg 98]</a></span>
mistake me for your Christina, I'll pull off that which
soothes your error. [<i>Pulls off her mask.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Take but t'other vizard off too, (I mean your
anger,) and I'll swear you are the same, and only Christina
which I wished, and thought, to meet here.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> How could you think to meet me here?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Gives her the letter.</i>] By virtue of this your commission;
which now, I see, was meant a real challenge:
for you look as if you would fight with me.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> The paper is a stranger to me; I never writ it.
You are abused.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Christina is a person of honour, and will own
what she has written, Ranger.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So! the comedy begins; I shall be
laughed at sufficiently if I do not justify myself; I must
set my impudence to hers. She is resolved to deny all,
I see, and I have lost all hope of her.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Come, faith, Ranger&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You will deny too, madam, that I followed you
last night from the Park to your lodging, where I staid
with you till morning? you never saw me before, I
warrant.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> That you rudely intruded last night into my
lodging, I cannot deny; but I wonder you have the
confidence to brag of it: sure you will not of your
reception?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I never was so ill-bred as to brag of my reception
in a lady's chamber; not a word of that, madam.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] How! If he lies, I revenge her; if it I
be true, I revenge myself.
[<span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>draws his sword, which</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>,
<i>seeing, thrusts him back, and shuts the door
upon him before he is discovered by</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>, <i>stopping at the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> What do I see! Christina with him! a counterplot
to mine, to make me and it ridiculous. 'Tis true,
I find, they have been long acquainted, and I long<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_99" id="Page_99">[Pg 99]</a></span>
abused; but since she intends a triumph, in spite, as well
as shame, (not emulation,) I retire. She deserves no
envy, who will be shortly in my condition; his natural
inconstancy will prove my best revenge on her&mdash;on both.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Christina's going away again;&mdash;what's the
matter?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> What do you mean?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I scarce had paid the chairmen, and was coming
up after her, but I met her on the stairs, in as much haste
as if she had been frightened.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Who do you talk of?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Christina, whom I took up in a chair just now at
St. James's gate.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Thou art mad! here she is, this is Christina.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I must confess I did not see her face; but I am
sure the lady is gone that I brought just now.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I tell you again this is she: did you bring two?</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I came in no chair, had no guide but my woman
there.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> When did you bring your lady, Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Even now, just now.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> This lady has been here half-an-hour.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> He knows not what he says, he is mad: you are
all so; I am so too.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> 'Tis the best excuse you can make for yourself,
and by owning your mistake you'll show you are come to
yourself. I myself saw your woman at the door, who but
looked in, and then immediately went down again;&mdash;as
your friend Dapperwit too affirms.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> You had best follow her that looked for you;
and I'll go seek out him I came to see.&mdash;Mr. Vincent,
pray let me in here.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> 'Tis very fine! wondrous fine!
[<span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>goes out a little, and returns.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_100" id="Page_100">[Pg 100]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Oh! he is gone! Mr. Vincent, follow him; he
were yet more severe to me in endangering his life, than
in his censures against me. You know the power of his
enemies is great as their malice;&mdash;just Heaven preserve
him from them, and me from this ill or unlucky man!
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Christina, Isabel</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> 'Tis well&mdash;nay, certainly, I shall never be master
of my senses more: but why dost thou help to distract
me too?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> My astonishment was as great as yours to see
her go away again; I would have stayed her if I could.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Yet again talking of a woman you met going
out, when I talk of Christina!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I talk of Christina too.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> She went out just now; the woman you found
me with was she.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> That was not the Christina I brought just now.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You brought her almost half an hour ago;&mdash;'sdeath,
will you give me the lie?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A lady disappointed by her gallant, the night
before her journey, could not be more touchy with her
maid or husband, than you are with me now after your
disappointment; but if you thank me so, I'll go serve
myself hereafter. For aught I know, I have disappointed
Mrs. Martha for you, and may lose thirty thousand
pounds by the bargain. Farewell! a raving lover is fit
for solitude. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Lydia, triumph! I now am thine again. Of
intrigues, honourable or dishonourable, and all sorts of
rambling, I take my leave; when we are giddy, 'tis time
to stand still. Why should we be so fond of the by-paths
of love, where we are still waylaid with surprises, trepans,
dangers, and murdering disappointments?&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Just as at blindman's buff we run at all,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Whilst those that lead us laugh to see us fall;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And when we think we hold the lady fast,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">We find it but her scarf, or veil, at last. [<i>Exit.</i></span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_101" id="Page_101">[Pg 101]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FIFTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>St. James's Park.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span> <i>and</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span>, <i>the latter
leading</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> At length you see I have
freed the captive lady for her longing
knight, Mr. Dapperwit:&mdash;who brings
off a plot cleverly now?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I wish our poets were half
so good at it.&mdash;Mrs. Martha, a thousand
welcomes!
[<span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span> <i>kisses and embraces</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Hold, hold, sir: your joy is a little too
familiar, faith and troth!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Will you not let me salute Mrs. Martha?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> What, Jonas, do you think I do not know
good breeding? must I be taught by you?</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I would have kept the maidenhead of your
lips for your sweet knight, Mrs. Martha, that's all; I
dare swear you never kissed any man before but your
father.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> My sweet knight, if he will be knight of
mine, must be contented with what he finds, as well as
other knights.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> So smart already, faith and troth!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Dear Mr. Dapperwit I am overjoyed to see
you; but I thank honest Jonas for't.
[<i>She hugs</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_102" id="Page_102">[Pg 102]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] How she hugs him!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Poor Mr. Dapperwit, I thought I should
never have seen you again; but I thank honest Jonas
there&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Do not thank me, Mrs. Martha, any more
than I thank you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> I would not be ungrateful, Jonas.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Then reserve your kindness only for your
worthy, noble, brave, heroic knight, who loves you only,
and only deserves your kindness.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> I will show my kindness to my worthy,
brave, heroic knight, in being kind to his friend, his dear
friend, who helped him to me. [<i>Hugs</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span> <i>again.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> But, Mistress Martha, he is not to help him
always; though he helps him to be married, he is not to
help him when he is married.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> What, Mr. Dapperwit, will you love my
worthy knight less after marriage than before? that were
against the custom; for marriage gets a man friends,
instead of losing those he has.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I will ever be his servant and yours, dear
madam; do not doubt me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> I do not, sweet dear Mr. Dapperwit; but
I should not have seen you these two days if it had not
been for honest Jonas there&mdash;[<i>She kisses</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.] For shame! though
she be young and foolish, do not you wrong me to my
face.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Would you have me so ill bred as to repulse her
innocent kindness?&mdash;what a thing it is to want wit!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] A pox! I must make haste to discover
myself, or I shall discover what I would not discover;
but if I should discover myself in this habit, 'twould not
be to my advantage. But I'll go, put on my own clothes,
and look like a knight.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Well, Mrs. Martha, I'll
go seek out your knight: are you not impatient to see
him?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_103" id="Page_103">[Pg 103]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Wives must be obedient; let him take his
own time.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Can you trust yourself a turn or two with
Master Dapperwit?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Yes, yes, Jonas&mdash;as long as you will.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] But I would not trust you with him,
if I could help it.&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">So married wight sees what he dares not blame;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And cannot budge for fear, nor stay for shame. [<i>Exit.</i></span><br />
</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I am glad he is gone, that I may laugh. 'Tis
such a miracle of fops, that his conversation should be
pleasant to me, even when it hindered me of yours.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Indeed, I'm glad he is gone too, as pleasant
as he is.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I know why, I know why, sweet Mrs. Martha.
I warrant you, you had rather have the parson's company
than his?&mdash;now you are out of your father's house, 'tis
time to leave being a hypocrite.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Well, for the jest's sake, to disappoint my
knight, I would not care if I disappointed myself of a
ladyship.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Come, I will not keep you on the tenters; I
know you have a mind to make sure of me: I have a
little chaplain (I wish he were a bishop or one of the
friars) to perfect our revenge upon that zealous Jew, your
father.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Do not speak ill of my father; he has been
your friend, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> My friend!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> His hard usage of me conspired with your
good mien and wit, and to avoid slavery unto him, I stoop
to your yoke.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I will be obliged to your father for nothing but a
portion; nor to you for your love; 'twas due to my
merit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You show yourself Sir Simon's original; if
'twere not for that vanity&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_104" id="Page_104">[Pg 104]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I should be no wit&mdash;'tis the badge of my calling;
for you can no more find a man of wit without vanity
than a fine woman without affectation: but let us go
before the knight comes again.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Let us go before my father comes; he soon
will have the intelligence.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Stay, let me think a little. [<i>Pauses.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> What are you thinking of? you should
have thought before this time, or I should have thought
rather.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Peace! peace!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> What are you thinking of?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I am thinking what a wit without vanity is like.
He is like&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You do not think we are in a public place,
and may be surprised and prevented by my father's
scouts!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What! would you have me lose my thought?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You would rather lose your mistress, it
seems.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> He is like&mdash;I think I am a sot to-night, let me
perish.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Nay, if you are so in love with your
thought&mdash;[<i>Offers to go.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Are you so impatient to be my wife?&mdash;He is like&mdash;he
is like&mdash;a picture without shadows, or&mdash;or&mdash;a face
without patches&mdash;or a diamond without a foil. These
are new thoughts now, these are new!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You are wedded already to your thoughts,
I see;&mdash;good night.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Madam, do not take it ill:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For loss of happy thought there's no amends;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For his new jest true wit will lose old friends.</span><br />
</p>

<p>That's new again,&mdash;the thought's new. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_105" id="Page_105">[Pg 105]</a></span></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>Another part of the same.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>, <i>leading</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>; Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span> <i>and</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Crossbite</span> <i>following.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Mrs. Joyner, I can conform to this mode of
public walking by moonlight, because one is not known.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Why, are you ashamed of your company?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, pretty one; because in the dark, or as it
were in the dark, there is no envy nor scandal. I would
neither lose you nor my reputation.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Your reputation! indeed, your worship,
'tis well known there are as grave men as your worship;
nay, men in office too, that adjourn their cares and
businesses, to come and unbend themselves at night
here, with a little vizard-mask.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I do believe it, Mrs. Joyner.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Ay, godmother, and carries and treats her at
Mulberry-garden.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Nay, does not only treat her, but gives her
his whole gleaning of that day.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> They may, they may, Mrs. Crossbite; they
take above six in the hundred.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Nay, there are those of so much worth and
honour and love, that they'll take it from their wives and
children to give it to their misses; now your worship has
no wife, and but one child.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Still for my edification! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> That's true, indeed; for I know a great
lady that cannot follow her husband abroad to his haunts,
because her Ferrandine is so ragged and greasy, whilst
his mistress is as fine as fi'pence, in embroidered satins.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Politicly done of him indeed! If the truth
were known, he is a statesman by that, umph&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Truly, your women of quality are very
troublesome to their husbands: I have heard 'em complain,
they will allow them no separate maintenance,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_106" id="Page_106">[Pg 106]</a></span>
though the honourable jilts themselves will not marry
without it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Come, come, mistress; sometimes 'tis the
craft of those gentlemen to complain of their wives'
expenses to excuse their own narrowness to their misses;
but your daughter has a gallant that can make no excuse.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> So, Mrs. Joyner!&mdash;my friend, Mrs. Joyner&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> I hope, indeed, he'll give my daughter no
cause to dun him; for, poor wretch! she is as modest as
her mother.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I profess, I believe it.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> But I have the boldness to ask him for a treat.&mdash;Come,
gallant, we must walk towards the Mulberry-garden.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> So!&mdash;I am afraid, little mistress, the rooms are
all taken up by this time.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Will you shame yourself again?
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> If the rooms be full we'll have an arbour.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> At this time of night!&mdash;besides, the waiters
will ne'er come near you.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> They will be observant of good customers, as we
shall be. Come along.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Indeed, and verily, little mistress, I would go,
but that I should be forsworn if I did.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> That's so pitiful an excuse!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> In truth, I have forsworn the place ever since
I was pawned there for a reckoning.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> You have broken many an oath for the good old
cause, and will you boggle at one for your poor little
miss? Come along.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span> <i>behind.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Unfortunate lady that I am! I have left the
herd on purpose to be chased, and have wandered this
hour here; but the Park affords not so much as a satyr
for me, and (that's strange!) no Burgundy man or<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_107" id="Page_107">[Pg 107]</a></span>
drunken scourer will reel my way. The rag-women, and
cinder-women, have better luck than I.&mdash;But who are
these? if this mongrel light does not deceive me, 'tis my
brother,&mdash;'tis he:&mdash;there's Joyner, too, and two other
women. I'll follow 'em. It must be he, for this world
hath nothing like him;&mdash;I know not what the devil may
be in the other. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<i>Another part of the same.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot</span>, <i>in fine clothes</i>, <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>
<i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>, <i>unseen by him at the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Well, after all my seeking, I can find those I
would not find; I'm sure 'twas old Gripe, and Joyner
with him, and the widow followed. He would not have
been here, but to have sought his daughter, sure; but
vigilant Dapperwit has spied them too, and has, no doubt,
secured her from him.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> And you. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> The rogue is as good at hiding, as I am at
stealing, a mistress. 'Tis a vain, conceited fellow, yet I
think 'tis an honest fellow:&mdash;but, again, he is a damnable
whoring fellow; and what opportunity this air and darkness
may incline 'em to, Heaven knows; for I have heard
the rogue say himself, a lady will no more show her
modesty in the dark than a Spaniard his courage.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, if you are there, my true friend, I'll
forgive your hearkening, if you'll forgive my censures.&mdash;I
speak to you, dear Madam Martha; dear, dear&mdash;behold
your worthy knight&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> That's far from neighbours.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Is come to reap the fruit of his labours.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> I cannot see the knight; well, but I'm
sure I hear Jonas.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_108" id="Page_108">[Pg 108]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I am no Jonas, Mrs. Martha.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> The night is not so dark, nor the peruke
so big, but I can discern Jonas.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Faith and troth, I am the very Sir Simon
Addleplot that is to marry you; the same Dapperwit
solicited you for; ask him else, my name is not Jonas.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You think my youth and simplicity capable
of this cheat; but let me tell you, Jonas, 'tis not your
borrowed clothes and titles shall make me marry my
father's man.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Borrowed title! I'll be sworn I bought it of
my laundress, who was a court-laundress; but, indeed,
my clothes I have not paid for; therefore, in that sense,
they are borrowed.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Prithee, Jonas, let the jest end, or I shall
be presently in earnest.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Pray, be in earnest, and let us go; the parson
and supper stay for us, and I am a knight in
earnest.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You a knight! insolent, saucy fool.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> The devil take me, Mrs. Martha, if I am not
a knight now! a knight-baronet too! A man ought, I
see, to carry his patent in his pocket when he goes to be
married; 'tis more necessary than a licence. I am a
knight indeed and indeed now, Mrs. Martha.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Indeed and indeed, the trick will not pass,
Jonas.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Poor wretch! she's afraid she shall not be a
lady.&mdash;Come, come, discover the intrigue, Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> You need not discover the intrigue, 'tis
apparent already. Unworthy Mr. Dapperwit, after my
confidence reposed in you, could you be so little generous
as to betray me to my father's man? but I'll be even
with you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Do not accuse him, poor man! before you
hear him.&mdash;Tell her the intrigue, man.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! she will not believe us.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_109" id="Page_109">[Pg 109]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Will you not excuse yourself? but I must
not let it rest so.&mdash;Know, then, Mrs. Martha&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Come, I forgive thee before thy confession,
Jonas; you never had had the confidence to have designed
this cheat upon me but from Mr. Dapperwit's
encouragement&mdash;'twas his plot.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Nay, do not do me that wrong, madam.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> But since he has trepanned me out of my
father's house, he is like to keep me as long as I live;
and so good night, Jonas.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Hold, hold, what d'ye mean both? prithee
tell her I am Sir Simon, and no Jonas.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> A pox! she will not believe us, I tell you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I have provided a supper and parson at
Mulberry-garden, and invited all my friends I could meet
in the Park.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Nay, rather than they shall be disappointed,
there shall be a bride and bridegroom to entertain 'em;
Mrs. Martha and I will go thither presently.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Why, shall she be your bride?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> You see she will have it so.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Will you make Dapperwit your husband?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Rather than my father's man.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Oh, the devil!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Nay, come along, Jonas, you shall make
one at the wedding, since you helped to contrive it.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Will you cheat yourself, for fear of being
cheated?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> I am desperate now.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Wilt thou let her do so ill a thing, Dapperwit,
as to marry thee? open her eyes, prithee, and tell her I
am a true knight.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> 'Twould be in vain, by my life! you have carried
yourself so like a natural clerk&mdash;and so adieu, good
Jonas. [<i>Exeunt</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> What! ruined by my own plot, like an old
cavalier! yet like him, too, I will plot on still, a plot of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_110" id="Page_110">[Pg 110]</a></span>
prevention. So! I have it&mdash;her father was here even
now, I'm sure; well&mdash;I'll go tell her father of her, that I
will!</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And punish so her folly and his treachery:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Revenge is sweet, and makes amends for lechery.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exit.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<i>Another part of the same.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I wish I had not come hither to-night, Leonore.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> Why did you, madam, if the place be so disagreeable
to you?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> We cannot help visiting the place often where we
have lost anything we value: I lost Ranger here last night.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> You thought you had lost him before, a great
while ago; and therefore you ought to be the less
troubled.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But 'twas here I missed him first, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> Come, madam, let not the loss vex you; he is
not worth the looking after.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> It cannot but vex me yet, if I lost him by my
own fault.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> You had but too much care to keep him.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> It often happens, indeed, that too much care is
as bad as negligence; but I had rather be robbed than
lose what I have carelessly.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> But, I believe you would hang the thief if you
could.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Not if I could have my own again.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> I see you would be too merciful.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I wish I were tried.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> But, madam, if you please, we will waive the discourse;
for people seldom (I suppose) talk with pleasure
of their real losses.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_111" id="Page_111">[Pg 111]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> 'Tis better than to ruminate on them; mine, I'm
sure, will not out of head nor heart.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> Grief is so far from retrieving a loss, that it makes
it greater; but the way to lessen it is by a comparison
with others' losses. Here are ladies in the Park of your
acquaintance, I doubt not, can compare with you; pray,
madam, let us walk and find 'em out.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> 'Tis the resentment, you say, makes the loss
great or little; and then, I'm sure, there is none like
mine: however, go on. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE V.&mdash;<i>Another part of the same.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I am glad I have found you, for now I am prepared
to lead you out of the dark and all your trouble: I
have good news.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> You are as unmerciful as the physician who with
new arts keeps his miserable patient alive and in hopes,
when he knows the disease is incurable.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> And you, like the melancholy patient, mistrust
and hate your physician, because he will not comply
with your despair: but I'll cure your jealousy now.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> You know, all diseases grow worse by relapses.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Trust me once more.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Well, you may try your experiments upon me.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Just as I shut the door upon you, the woman
Ranger expected came up stairs; but finding another
woman in discourse with him, went down again; I
suppose, as jealous of him, as you of Christina.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How does it appear she came to Ranger?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Thus: Dapperwit came up after he had brought
her, just then, in a chair from St. James's by Ranger's
appointment; and it is certain your Christina came
to you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_112" id="Page_112">[Pg 112]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How can that be? for she knew not I was in the
kingdom.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> My man confesses, when I sent him to inquire of
her woman about her lady's being here in the Park last
night, he told her you were come; and she, it seems,
told her mistress.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] That might be.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] But did not
Christina confess, Ranger was in her lodging last night?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> By intrusion, which she had more particularly informed
me of, if her apprehensions of your danger had
not posted me after you; she not having yet (as I
suppose) heard of Clerimont's recovery. I left her, poor
creature! at home, distracted with a thousand fears for
your life and love.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Her love, I'm sure, has cost me more fears than
my life; yet that little danger is not past (as you think)
till the great one be over.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Open but your eyes, and the fantastic goblin's
vanished, and all your idle fears will turn to shame; for
jealousy is the basest cowardice.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I had rather, indeed, blush for myself than her.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I'm sure you will have more reason. But is not
that Ranger there?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>, <i>followed by</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Isabel</span>;
<i>after them</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I think it is.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I suppose his friend Dapperwit is not far off; I
will examine them both before you, and not leave you so
much as the shadow of doubt: Ranger's astonishment at
my lodging confessed his mistake.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> His astonishment might proceed from Christina's
unexpected strangeness to him.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> He shall satisfy you now himself to the contrary,
I warrant you; have but patience.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I had rather, indeed, he should satisfy my doubts
than my revenge; therefore I can have patience.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_113" id="Page_113">[Pg 113]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> But what women are those that follow him?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Stay a little&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Lydia, Lydia&mdash;poor Lydia!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> If she be my rival, 'tis some comfort yet to see
her follow him, rather than he her. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> But if you follow them a little longer, for your
comfort you shall see them go hand in hand.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Sir! sir!&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Leo.</i> She calls to him already.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But he does not hear, you see; let us go a little
nearer.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Sure it is Ranger!</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> As sure as the woman that follows him closest is
Christina.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> For shame! talk not of Christina; I left her just
now at home, surrounded with so many fears and griefs
she could not stir.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> She is come, it may be, to divert them here in
the Park; I'm sure 'tis she.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> When the moon, at this instant, scarce affords
light enough to distinguish a man from a tree, how can
you know her?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How can you know Ranger, then?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> I heard him speak.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> So you may her too, I'll secure you, if you will
draw but a little nearer; she came, doubtless, to no
other end but to speak with him: observe&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.] Sir, I have followed you hitherto;
but now, I must desire you to follow me out of the company;
for I would not be overheard nor disturbed.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Ha! is not this Christina's voice? it is, I am
sure; I cannot be deceived now.&mdash;Dear madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> It is she indeed. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Is it so?</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Come, sir&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Nay, I'll follow you too, though not invited.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_114" id="Page_114">[Pg 114]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I must not, cannot stay behind. [<i>Aside.</i>
[<i>They all go off together hastily.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Christina, Isabel</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>on the
other side.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Come along, sir.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> So! I must stick to her when all is done; her
new servant has lost her in the crowd, she has gone too
fast for him; so much my revenge is swifter than his
love. Now shall I not only have the deserted lover's
revenge, of disappointing her of her new man, but an
opportunity infallibly at once to discover her falseness,
and confront her impudence. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Pray come along, sir, I am in haste.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> So eager, indeed!&mdash;I wish that cloud may yet
withhold the moon, that this false woman may not discover
me before I do her. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Here no one can hear us, and I'm sure we cannot
see one another.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> 'Sdeath! what have I giddily run myself upon?
'Tis rather a trial of myself than her;&mdash;I cannot undergo
it. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Come nearer, sir.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Hell and vengeance! I cannot suffer it&mdash;I
cannot. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Come, come; yet nearer,&mdash;pray come
nearer.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> It is impossible! I cannot hold! I must discover
myself, rather than her infamy. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> You are conscious, it seems, of the wrong you
have done me, and are ashamed, though in the dark.
[<i>Speaks, walking slowly.</i></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How's this! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I'm glad to find it so; for all my business with
you is, to show you your late mistakes, and force a confession
from you of those unmannerly injuries you have
done me.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_115" id="Page_115">[Pg 115]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> What! I think she's honest; or does she know
me?&mdash;sure she cannot. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> First, your intrusion, last night, into my lodging;
which, I suppose, has begot your other gross mistakes.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> No, she takes me for Ranger, I see again. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> You are to know, then, (since needs you must,)
it was not me you followed last night to my lodging from
the Park, but some kinswoman of yours, it seems, whose
fear of being discovered by you prevailed with me to
personate her, while she withdrew, our habits and our
statures being much alike; which I did with as much
difficulty, as she used importunity to make me; and all
this my Lady Flippant can witness, who was then with
your cousin.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I am glad to hear this. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Now, what your claim to me, at Mr. Vincent's
lodging, meant; the letter and promises you unworthily,
or erroneously, laid to my charge, you must explain to
me and others, or&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How's this! I hope I shall discover no guilt but my
own:&mdash;she would not speak in threats to a lover. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Was it because you found me in Mr. Vincent's
lodgings you took a liberty to use me like one of your
common visitants? but know, I came no more to Mr.
Vincent than you. Yet, I confess, my visit was intended
to a man&mdash;a brave man, till you made him use a woman
ill; worthy the love of a princess, till you made him
censure mine; good as angels, till you made him
unjust:&mdash;why, in the name of honour, would you do't?</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> How happily am I disappointed!&mdash;poor injured
Christina! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> He would have sought me out first, if you had
not made him fly from me. Our mutual love, confirmed
by a contract, made our hearts inseparable, till you
rudely, if not maliciously, thrust in upon us, and broke
the close and happy knot: I had lost him before for a
month, now for ever. [<i>Weeps.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_116" id="Page_116">[Pg 116]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> My joy and pity makes me as mute as my shame;
yet I must discover myself. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> Your silence is a confession of your guilt.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> I own it. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> But that will not serve my turn; for straight
you must go clear yourself and me to him you have
injured in me! if he has not made too much haste from
me to be found again. You must, I say; for he is a
man that will have satisfaction; and in satisfying him,
you do me.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Then he is satisfied.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> How! is it you? then I am not satisfied.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Will you be worse than your word?</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I gave it not to you.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Come, dear Christina, the jealous, like the
drunkard, has his punishment with his offence.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Valentine! Mr. Valentine!</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Vincent!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Where have you been all this while?
[<span class="smcap">Valentine</span> <i>holds</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span> <i>by the hand; who
seems to struggle to get from him.</i></p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Here with my injured Christina.</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> She's behind with Ranger, who is forced to speak
all the tender things himself; for she affords him not a
word.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Pish! pish! Vincent; who is blind now? who
deceived now?</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> You are; for I'm sure Christina is with him.
Come back and see.
[<i>They go out on one side, and return on the other.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>, <i>followed by</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lydia</span>.] Still mocked! still abused! did
you not bid me follow you where we might not be disturbed
or overheard?&mdash;and now not allow me a word!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_117" id="Page_117">[Pg 117]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Did you hear him? [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Yes, yes, peace. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Disowning your letter and me at Mr. Vincent's
lodging, declaring you came to meet another there, and
not me, with a great deal of such affronting unkindness,
might be reasonable enough, because you would not
entrust Vincent with our love; but now, when nobody
sees us nor hears us, why this unseasonable shyness?</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> It seems she did not expect him there, but had
appointed to meet another:&mdash;I wish it were so. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> I have not patience!&mdash;do you design thus to
revenge my intrusion into your lodging last night? sure
if you had then been displeased with my company, you
would not have invited yourself to't again by a letter? or
is this a punishment for bringing you to a house so near
your own, where, it seems, you were known too? I do
confess it was a fault; but make me suffer any penance
but your silence, because it is the certain mark of a
mistress's lasting displeasure.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> My&mdash;is not yet come. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Not yet a word! you did not use me so unkindly
last night, when you chid me out of your house, and with
indignation bid me begone. Now, you bid me follow
you, and yet will have nothing to say to me; and I am
more deceived this day and night than I was last night;&mdash;when,
I must confess, I followed you for another&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> I'm glad to hear that. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> One that would have used me better; whose
love I have ungratefully abused for yours; yet from no
other reason but my natural inconstancy.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Poor
Lydia! Lydia!</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> He muttered my name sure; and with a sigh.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But as last night by following (as I thought) her,
I found you, so this night, by following you in vain, I do
resolve, if I can find her again, to keep her for ever.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Now I am obliged, and brought into debt, by his<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_118" id="Page_118">[Pg 118]</a></span>
inconstancy:&mdash;faith, now cannot I hold out any longer;
I must discover myself. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But, madam, because I intend to see you no
more, I'll take my leave of you for good and all; since
you will not speak, I'll try if you will squeak.
[<i>Goes to throw her down, she squeaks.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Mr. Ranger! Mr. Ranger!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> Fy! Fy! you need not ravish Christina sure,
that loves you so.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Is it she! Lydia all this while!&mdash;how am I
gulled! and Vincent in the plot too! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Now, false Ranger!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Now, false Christina too!&mdash;you thought I did
not know you now, because I offered you such an unusual
civility.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> You knew me!&mdash;I warrant you knew, too, that
I was the Christina you followed out of the Park last
night! that I was the Christina that writ the letter
too!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Certainly, therefore I would have taken my
revenge, you see, for your tricks.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Is not this the same woman that took refuge in
your house last night, madam? [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Christina</span>.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> The very same.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> What, Mr. Ranger, we have chopped, and
changed, and hid our Christinas so long and often, that
at last we have drawn each of us our own?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Mr. Valentine in England!&mdash;the truth on't is,
you have juggled together, and drawn without my knowledge;
but since she will have it so, she shall wear me
for good and all now. [<i>Goes to take her by the hand.</i></p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Come not near me.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, you need not be afraid I would ravish you,
now I know you.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> And yet, Leonore, I think 'tis but justice to
pardon the fault I made him commit?
[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Leonore</span>, <span class="smcap">Ranger</span> <i>listens.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_119" id="Page_119">[Pg 119]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You consider it right, cousin; for indeed you
are but merciful to yourself in it.</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> Yet, if I would be rigorous, though I made a blot,
your oversight has lost the game.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> But 'twas rash woman's play, cousin, and ought
not to be played again, let me tell you.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Who's there? who's there?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Dapperwit.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Mr. Ranger, I am glad I have met with you, for
I have left my bride just now in the house at Mulberry-garden,
to come and pick up some of my friends in the
Park here to sup with us.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Your bride! are you married then? where is
your bride?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Here at Mulberry-garden, I say, where you, these
ladies and gentlemen, shall all be welcome, if you will
afford me the honour of your company.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> With all our hearts:&mdash;but who have you married?
Lucy?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What! do you think I would marry a wench? I
have married an heiress worth thirty thousand pounds,
let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Vin.</i> An heiress worth thirty thousand pounds!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Mr. Vincent, your servant; you here too?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Nay, we are more of your acquaintance here, I
think.&mdash;Go, we'll follow you, for if you have not dismissed
your parson, perhaps we may make him more work.
[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE VI.&mdash;<i>The Dining-room in Mulberry-garden House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Simon Addleplot, Gripe</span>, Lady <span class="smcap">Flippant</span>,
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Martha</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Crossbite</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> 'Tis as I told you, sir, you see.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_120" id="Page_120">[Pg 120]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Oh, graceless babe! married to a wit! an idle,
loitering, slandering, foul-mouthed, beggarly wit! Oh
that my child should ever live to marry a wit!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Indeed, your worship had better seen her
fairly buried, as they say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> If my daughter there should have done so,
I would not have given her a groat.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Marry a wit!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Mrs. Joyner, do not let me lose the widow
too:&mdash;for if you do, (betwixt friends,) I and my small
annuity are both blown up: it will follow my estate.
[<i>Aside to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> I warrant you. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Let us make sure of Sir Simon to-night, or&mdash;[<i>Aside
to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Joyner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> You need not fear it.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Like the
lawyers, while my clients endeavour to cheat one another,
I in justice cheat 'em both.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Marry a wit!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Dapperwit, Ranger, Lydia, Valentine, Christina</span>,
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent. Dapperwit</span> <i>stops them, and
they stand all behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What, is he here! Lucy and her mother! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Tell me how thou camest to marry a wit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Pray be not angry, sir, and I'll give you a
good reason.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Reason for marrying a wit!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Mar.</i> Indeed, I found myself six months gone
with child, and saw no hopes of your getting me a
husband, or else I had not married a wit, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Joyn.</i> Then you were the wit.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Had you that reason? nay, then&mdash;&mdash;[<i>Holding
up his hands.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> How's that! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Who would have thought, Dapperwit, you would
have married a wench?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_121" id="Page_121">[Pg 121]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Ranger</span>.]&mdash;Well, thirty thousand pounds
will make me amends; I have known my betters wink,
and fall on for five or six.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span> <i>and the rest.</i>]
What! you are come, sir, to give me joy? you Mrs. Lucy,
you and you? well, unbid guests are doubly welcome.&mdash;Sir
Simon, I made bold to invite these ladies and gentlemen.&mdash;For
you must know, Mr. Ranger, this worthy Sir
Simon does not only give me my wedding supper, but
my mistress too; and is, as it were, my father.</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> Then I am, as it were, a grandfather to your
new wife's <i>Hans en kelder</i>;<a name="FNanchor_49_49" id="FNanchor_49_49"></a><a href="#Footnote_49_49" class="fnanchor">[49]</a> to which you are but, as it
were, a father! there's for you again, sir&mdash;ha, ha!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Vincent</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Fools sometimes say unhappy things, if we would
mind 'em; but&mdash;what! melancholy at your daughter's
wedding, sir?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> How deplorable is my condition!</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Nay, if you will rob me of my wench, sir, can
you blame me for robbing you of your daughter? I
cannot be without a woman.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> My daughter, my reputation, and my money
gone!&mdash;but the last is dearest to me. Yet at once I
may retrieve that, and be revenged for the loss of the
other: and all this by marrying Lucy here: I shall get
my five hundred pounds again, and get heirs to exclude
my daughter and frustrate Dapperwit; besides, 'tis agreed
on all hands, 'tis cheaper keeping a wife than a wench.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> If you are so melancholy, sir, we will have the
fiddles and a dance to divert you; come!</p>

<p class="center"><i>A Dance.</i></p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Indeed, you have put me so upon a merry pin,
that I resolve to marry too.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Nay, if my brother come to marrying once,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_122" id="Page_122">[Pg 122]</a></span>
I may too; I swore I would, when he did, little
thinking&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> I take you at your word, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Flip.</i> Well, but if I had thought you would have
been so quick with me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Where is your parson?</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> What! you would not revenge yourself upon the
parson?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> No, I would have the parson revenge me upon
you; he should marry me.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I am glad you are so frolic, sir; but who would
you marry?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> That innocent lady. [<i>Pointing to</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> That innocent lady!</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> Nay, I am impatient, Mrs. Joyner; pray fetch
him up if he be yet in the house.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> We were not married here:&mdash;but you cannot be
in earnest.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> You'll find it so; since you have robbed me of
my housekeeper, I must get another.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> Why, she was my wench!</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I'll make her honest then.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Cros.</i> Upon my repute he never saw her before:&mdash;but
will your worship marry my daughter then?</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I promise her and you, before all this good
company, to-morrow I will make her my wife.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> How!</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Our ladies, sir, I suppose, expect the same
promise from us. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Valentine</span>.</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> They may be sure of us without a promise; but
let us (if we can) obtain theirs, to be sure of them.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> But will you marry her to-morrow?&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gripe</span>.</p>

<p><i>Gripe.</i> I will, verily.</p>

<p><i>Dap.</i> I am undone then! ruined, let me perish!</p>

<p><i>Sir Sim.</i> No, you may hire a little room in Covent
Garden, and set up a coffee-house:&mdash;you and your wife
will be sure of the wits' custom.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_123" id="Page_123">[Pg 123]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dap.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Abused by him I have abused!&mdash;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Fortune our foe we cannot overwit;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">By none but thee our projects are cross-bit.</span><br />
</p>

<p><i>Val.</i> Come, dear madam, what, yet angry?&mdash;jealousy
sure is much more pardonable before marriage than after
it; but to-morrow, by the help of the parson, you'll put
me out of all my fears.</p>

<p><i>Chris.</i> I am afraid then you would give me my revenge,
and make me jealous of you; and I had rather suspect
your faith than you should mine.</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> Cousin Lydia, I had rather suspect your faith
too, than you should mine; therefore let us e'en marry
to-morrow, that I may have my turn of watching, dogging,
standing under the window, at the door, behind the
hanging, or&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lyd.</i> But if I could be desperate now and give you up
my liberty, could you find in your heart to quit all other
engagements, and voluntarily turn yourself over to one
woman, and she a wife too? could you away with the
insupportable bondage of matrimony?</p>

<p><i>Ran.</i> You talk of matrimony as irreverently as my
Lady Flippant: the bondage of matrimony! no&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The end of marriage now is liberty.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And two are bound&mdash;to set each other free.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_124" id="Page_124">[Pg 124]</a></span></p>




<h3>EPILOGUE</h3>

<h4>SPOKEN BY DAPPERWIT.<a name="FNanchor_50_50" id="FNanchor_50_50"></a><a href="#Footnote_50_50" class="fnanchor">[50]</a></h4>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Now my brisk brothers of the pit, you'll say</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">I'm come to speak a good word for the play;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But gallants, let me perish! if I do,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For I have wit and judgment, just like you;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Wit never partial, judgment free and bold,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For fear or friendship never bought or sold,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nor by good-nature e'er to be cajoled.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Good-nature in a critic were a crime,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Like mercy in a judge, and renders him</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Guilty of all those faults he does forgive,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Besides, if thief from gallows you reprieve,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He'll cut your throat; so poet saved from shame,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In damned lampoon will murder your good name.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet in true spite to him and to his play,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Good faith, you should not rail at them to-day</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But to be more his foe, seem most his friend,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And so maliciously the play commend;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">That he may be betrayed to writing on,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And poet let him be,&mdash;to be undone.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="full" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_125" id="Page_125">[Pg 125]</a></span></p>




<h2><a name="THE_GENTLEMAN" id="THE_GENTLEMAN"><i>THE
GENTLEMAN DANCING-MASTER.</i></a></h2>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 8.5em;">"Non satis est risu diducere rictum</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Auditorus: et est quædam tamen his quoque virtus."<a name="FNanchor_51_51" id="FNanchor_51_51"></a><a href="#Footnote_51_51" class="fnanchor">[51]</a>&mdash;<span class="smcap">Horat.</span></span><br />
<br /></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_126" id="Page_126">[Pg 126]</a></span></p>

<p>If we may trust the author's statement to
Pope, this admirable comedy was written
when Wycherley was twenty-one years of
age, in the year 1661-2. It is impossible
to fix with certainty the date of its first
performance. The Duke's Company,
then under the management of the widow of Sir William
Davenant, opened its new theatre in Dorset Gardens, near
Salisbury Court, on the 9th of November, 1671, with a performance
of Dryden's <i>Sir Martin Mar-all</i>, and Wycherley's
"Prologue to the City" points to the production of his play
in the new theatre shortly after its opening. Genest states,
on the authority of Downes, that "<i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i>
was the third new play acted at this theatre, and
that several of the old stock plays were acted between each
of the new ones." <i>Sir Martin Mar-all</i>, having been three
times performed, was succeeded by Etherege's <i>Love in a
Tub</i>, which, after two representations, gave place to a new
piece, Crowne's tragedy of <i>Charles the Eighth</i>. This was
played six times in succession, and was followed, probably
after an interval devoted to stock pieces, by a second
novelty, an adaptation by Ravenscroft from Molière, entitled
<i>The Citizen turn'd Gentleman, or Mamamouchi</i>, which ran
for nine days together. <i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i>
was then acted, probably after another short interval, and
must therefore have been produced either in December, 1671,
or in January, 1672. Genest, in fact, places it first on his
list of plays performed at the Dorset Gardens Theatre
during the year 1672, although, in his list for the preceding
year, immediately after <i>The Citizen turn'd Gentleman</i>, he
mentions Lord Orrery's comedy of <i>Mr. Anthony</i> as "nearly
certain" to have been brought out in the season of 1671-2.
But this, again, was a new piece, making the third produced
at Dorset Gardens, without including <i>The Gentleman
Dancing-Master</i>, and must consequently have been brought
forward later than Wycherley's play. Of <i>The Gentleman
Dancing-Master</i> Genest observes that "it was not much
liked, and was acted only six times."</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_127" id="Page_127">[Pg 127]</a></span></p>

<p>But it is by no means clear that the first performance at
Dorset Gardens was the actual first performance of our
comedy. The opening verses of the prologue, indeed, seem
to imply a previous and unsuccessful performance, probably
by the same company, at their old theatre in Portugal
Street, Lincoln's Inn Fields. This, at least, as it seems to
me, is the most obvious interpretation of the following
lines:</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">"Our author (like us) finding 'twould scarce do</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At t'other end o' th' town, is come to you;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And, <i>since 'tis his last trial,</i> has that wit</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To throw himself on a substantial pit."</span><br />
</p>

<p>The presumption, therefore, is strongly in favour of 1671 as
the year in which <i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i> was first
brought upon the stage. It was published, without a
dedication or the names of the actors, in 1673. The remarks
about "packing to sea" in the epilogue, which, like the
prologue, was written for the production, or rather, as we
may suppose, the revival of the piece at the theatre in
Dorset Gardens, refer, questionless, to the impending war
with the Dutch, against whom the formal declaration of war
was issued on the 17th of March, 1672.</p>

<p>The incident upon which the plot turns is borrowed from
Calderon's comedy, <i>El Maestro de Danzar</i>, but a brief
review of the corresponding scenes in that drama will prove
how trifling was Wycherley's obligation to the great Spanish
poet. Leonor, the heroine of the piece, is enjoying a stolen
interview with her lover, Don Enrique, in an apartment of
her father's house in Valencia. Meanwhile, lest their voices
should be overheard, Ines, Leonor's maid, stations herself
without the chamber, singing and accompanying herself with
the guitar. She presently enters, declaring that an instrument
so out of tune will attract suspicion, and Don Enrique
takes up the guitar for the purpose of tuning it. At this
juncture the father, Don Diego, appears suddenly upon the
scene. In reply to his questioning, Leonor explains that,
dancing being little in fashion at the Court, she had formerly
neglected that accomplishment; but that, finding herself, on
that account, looked down upon in Valencia, where dancing
was all the mode, she had engaged a master, who had but just
taken up the guitar which her maid had brought him, when
her father entered. This explanation proving satisfactory to<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_128" id="Page_128">[Pg 128]</a></span>
Don Diego, he seats himself, and desires that the lesson
may proceed. But here a new difficulty arises, for Don
Enrique owns, in an "aside" to his mistress, that he understands
little or nothing of dancing. The lady, however, is
equal to the occasion, and, affecting diffidence, tells her
father that he must wait until she has taken a few lessons.
He, nevertheless, insisting, Don Enrique takes again the
guitar, and, under pretence of tuning it, screws up the string
until it snaps, declaring then that the strings are worn, and
that the instrument is broken. Leonor now suggests that
the maestro shall carry away the guitar, to get it set in order,
and shall come again on the morrow or in the evening; and
Don Diego, acquiescing, bids him neglect not to return,
trusting him for the payment. Don Enrique responding
that he will not fail, although he has many lessons to give,
the old cavalier dismisses him with a "Vaya con Dios." In
a later scene Don Enrique is again with Leonor, of whom
he has conceived unjust suspicions, and is bestowing upon
her the full benefit of his jealousy, when Ines announces the
approach of Don Diego, and the lover, at his mistress's
earnest appeal, again takes up the guitar, and pretends to be
giving her a lesson. The father inquires after his daughter's
improvement, and again insists on seeing her dance, a mock
performance this time actually ensuing. And again, in another
scene, the lovers, similarly interrupted, have recourse to a
similar method of diverting Don Diego's suspicions.</p>

<p>In these few incidents, and in the name of Don Diego,
which our author has employed as the adopted appellation
of his Spain-loving Englishman, are to be found the only
points of resemblance between the two plays. The merits
of the one lie in a direction totally diverse from that in
which the excellencies of the other are to be sought.
Wycherley's play is fairly overflowing with wit and mirth,
qualities in which the Spanish drama is somewhat deficient.
On the other hand, the English play affords no counterpart
to the high moral tone and exalted passion which are distinguishing
characteristics of Calderon's comedy.</p>

<p><i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i> is constructed with
greater simplicity and unity of action than <i>Love in a Wood</i>,
and, although less powerfully written than <i>The Country
Wife</i>, it is also far less exceptionable, and more uniformly
pleasing.</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_129" id="Page_129">[Pg 129]</a></span></p>




<h3>PROLOGUE
TO THE CITY</h3>

<h5>NEWLY AFTER THE REMOVAL OF THE DUKE'S COMPANY FROM
LINCOLN'S-INN-FIELDS TO THEIR NEW THEATRE NEAR
SALISBURY-COURT.</h5>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our author (like us) finding 'twould scarce do</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At t'other end o' th' town, is come to you;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And, since 'tis his last trial, has that wit</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To throw himself on a substantial pit;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Where needy wit or critic dare not come,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Lest neighbour i' the cloak, with looks so grum,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Should prove a dun;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Where punk in vizor dare not rant and tear</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To put us out, since Bridewell is so near:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In short, we shall be heard, be understood,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">If not, shall be admired, and that's as good.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For you to senseless plays have still been kind,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, where no sense was, you a jest would find:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And never was it heard of, that the city</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Did ever take occasion to be witty</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Upon dull poet, or stiff player's action,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But still with claps opposed the hissing faction.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But if you hissed, 'twas at the pit, not stage;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">So, with the poet, damned the damning age,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And still, we know, are ready to engage</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Against the flouting, ticking gentry, who</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Citizen, player, poet, would undo:&mdash;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The poet! no, unless by commendation,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For on the 'Change wits have no reputation:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And rather than be branded for a wit,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He with you able men would credit get.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_130" id="Page_130">[Pg 130]</a></span></p>




<h3>DRAMATIS PERSONÆ</h3>

<p>
Mr. <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>,<br />
Mr. <span class="smcap">Martin</span>,<br />
Young Gentlemen of the town, and friends.<br />
<br />
