Mr. <span class="smcap">Paris</span>, or Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris</span>, a vain coxcomb, and
rich city heir, newly returned from France, and mightily
affected with the French language and fashions.<br />
<br />
Mr. <span class="smcap">James Formal</span>, or Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>, an old rich Spanish
merchant, newly returned home, much affected with the
habit and customs of Spain, and Uncle to <span class="smcap">Paris</span>.<br />
<br />
A little Blackamoor, Lackey to <span class="smcap">Formal</span>.<br />
<br />
A Parson.<br />
<br />
A French Scullion.<br />
<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>, <span class="smcap">Formal's</span> Daughter.<br />
<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>, <span class="smcap">Formal's</span> Sister, an impertinent precise old
woman.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Prue</span>, <span class="smcap">Hippolita's</span> Maid.<br />
<br />
A Lady.<br />
<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Flirt</span>,<br />
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Flounce</span>,<br />
Two common Women of the town.<br />
<br />
Servants, Waiter, and Attendants.<br />
<br />
<br />
SCENE&mdash;<span class="smcap">London</span>.</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_131" id="Page_131">[Pg 131]</a></span></p>




<h2><i>THE
GENTLEMAN DANCING-MASTER.</i></h2>

<h3>ACT THE FIRST.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;Don <span class="smcap">Diego's</span> <i>House, in the evening.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> To confine a woman just in her
rambling age! take away her liberty at
the very time she should use it! O barbarous
aunt! O unnatural father! to
shut up a poor girl at fourteen, and hinder
her budding! All things are ripened by
the sun:&mdash;to shut up a poor girl at fourteen!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> 'Tis true, miss, two poor young creatures as
we are!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Not suffered to see a play in a twelve-month!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nor go to Punchinello,<a name="FNanchor_52_52" id="FNanchor_52_52"></a><a href="#Footnote_52_52" class="fnanchor">[52]</a> nor Paradise!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nor to take a ramble to the Park nor Mulberry-garden!<a name="FNanchor_53_53" id="FNanchor_53_53"></a><a href="#Footnote_53_53" class="fnanchor">[53]</a>&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_132" id="Page_132">[Pg 132]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nor to Totnam-court, nor Islington!<a name="FNanchor_54_54" id="FNanchor_54_54"></a><a href="#Footnote_54_54" class="fnanchor">[54]</a>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nor to eat a syllabub in New Spring garden<a name="FNanchor_55_55" id="FNanchor_55_55"></a><a href="#Footnote_55_55" class="fnanchor">[55]</a> with
a cousin!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nor to drink a pint of wine with a friend at the
Prince in the Sun!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nor to hear a fiddle in good company!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nor to hear the organs and tongs at the Gun in
Moorfields!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, not suffered to go to church, because the
men are sometimes there!&mdash;Little did I think I should
ever have longed to go to church.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Or I either;&mdash;but between two maids&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nor see a man!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nor come near a man!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nor hear of a man!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> No, miss; but to be denied a man! and to
have no use at all of a man!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Hold, hold!&mdash;your resentment is as much
greater than mine, as your experience has been greater.
But all this while, what do we make of my cousin, my
husband elect, as my aunt says? We have had his
company these three days; is he no man?</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> No, faith, he's but a monsieur. But you'll
resolve yourself that question within these three days; for
by that time he'll be your husband, if your father come
to-night&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Or if I provide not myself with another in the
mean time: for fathers seldom choose well; and I will
no more take my father's choice in a husband, than I a
would in a gown, or a suit of knots. So that if that
cousin of mine were not an ill-contrived, ugly, freakish
fool, in being my father's choice I should hate him.
Besides, he has almost made me out of love with mirth
and good-humour; for he debases it as much as a jack-pudding,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_133" id="Page_133">[Pg 133]</a></span>
and civility and good breeding more than a
city dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> What! won't you marry him then, madam?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Would'st thou have me marry a fool, an idiot?</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Lord! 'tis a sign you have been kept up indeed,
and know little of the world, to refuse a man for a
husband only because he's a fool! Methinks he's a
pretty apish kind of a gentleman, like other gentlemen,
and handsome enough to lie with in the dark, when
husbands take their privileges; and for the day-times,
you may take the privilege of a wife.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Excellent governess! you do understand the
world, I see.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Then you should be guided by me.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Art thou in earnest then, damned jade?&mdash;would'st
thou have me marry him?&mdash;Well, there are more poor
young women undone, and married to filthy fellows by
the treachery and evil counsel of chambermaids, than by
the obstinacy and covetousness of parents.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Does not your father come on purpose out of
Spain to marry you to him? Can you release yourself
from your aunt or father any other way? Have you a
mind to be shut up as long as you live? For my part,
though you can hold out upon the lime from the walls
here, salt, old shoes, and oatmeal, I cannot live so: I
must confess my patience is worn out.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Alas, alas, poor Prue! your stomach lies another
way: I will take pity of you, and get me a husband very
suddenly, who may have a servant at your service. But
rather than marry my cousin, I will be a nun in the new
protestant nunnery they talk of; where, they say, there
will be no hopes of coming near a man.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> But you can marry nobody but your cousin,
miss: your father you expect to-night; and be certain
his Spanish policy and wariness, which has kept you up
so close ever since you came from Hackney school, will
make sure of you within a day or two at farthest.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_134" id="Page_134">[Pg 134]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Then 'tis time to think how to prevent him&mdash;stay&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> In vain, vain, miss!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> If we knew but any man, any man, though he
were but a little handsomer than the devil, so that he
were a gentleman!</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> What if you did know any man? if you had an
opportunity, could you have confidence to speak to a
man first? but if you could, how could you come to him,
or he to you? nay, how could you send to him? for
though you could write, which your father in his Spanish
prudence would never permit you to learn, who should
carry the letter?&mdash;But we need not be concerned for that,
since we know not to whom to send it.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Stay&mdash;it must be so&mdash;I'll try however&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Serviteur! serviteur! la cousine;</i> I come to
give the <i>bon soir</i>, as the French say.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O, cousin! you know him; the fine gentleman
they talk of so much in town.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> What! will you talk to him of any man else?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I know all the <i>beau monde, cousine</i>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Master&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Monsieur Taileur, Monsieur Esmit, Monsieur&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> These are Frenchmen&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, non</i>; voud you have me say Mr. Taylor,
Mr. Smith? Fi! fi! <i>tête non!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But don't you know the brave gentleman they
talk so much of in town?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Who? Monsieur Gerrard?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What kind of man is that Mr. Gerrard? and
then I'll tell you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why&mdash;he is truly a pretty man, a pretty man&mdash;a
pretty so so&mdash;kind of man, for an Englishman.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> How a pretty man?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why, he is conveniently tall&mdash;but&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_135" id="Page_135">[Pg 135]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But what?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And not ill-shaped&mdash;but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But what?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And handsome, as 'tis thought, but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But! what are your exceptions to him?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I can't tell you, because they are innumerable,
innumerable, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Has he wit?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, they say, he's witty, brave, and <i>de bel
humeur</i>, and well-bred, with all that&mdash;but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But what? does he want judgment?</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, non</i>: they say he has good sense and judgment;
but it is according to the account Englis&mdash;for&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> For what?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> For, <i>jarni!</i> if I think it.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why?&mdash;why his tailor lives within Ludgate&mdash;his
<i>valet de chambre</i> is no Frenchman&mdash;and he has been
seen at noon-day to go into an English eating-house&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Say you so, cousin!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Then for being well-bred, you shall judge:&mdash;First,
he can't dance a step, nor sing a French song, nor
swear a French oate, nor use the polite French word in
his conversation; and in fine, can't play at hombre&mdash;but
speaks base good Englis, with the commune home-bred
pronunciation; and in fine, to say no more, he
never carries a snuff-box about with him.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And yet this man has been abroad as much as
any man, and does not make the least show of it, but a
little in his mien, not at all in his discour, <i>jarni!</i> He
never talks so much as of St. Peter's church at Rome,
the Escurial, or Madrid; nay, not so much as of Henry
IV., of Pont-neuf, Paris, and the new Louvre, nor of the
Grand Roi.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Tis for his commendation, if he does not talk of
his travels.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_136" id="Page_136">[Pg 136]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh! auh!&mdash;<i>cousine</i>&mdash;he is conscious to himself
of his wants, because he is very envious; for he cannot
endure me.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] He shall be my man then for that.&mdash;Ay,
ay! 'tis the same, Prue.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] No, I know he can't
endure you, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How do you know it&mdash;who never stir out? <i>tête
non!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well&mdash;dear cousin,&mdash;if you will promise me
never to tell my aunt, I'll tell you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I won't, I won't, <i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nor to be concerned yourself, so as to make a
quarrel of it.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, non</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Upon the word of a gentleman?</p>

<p><i>Mons. Foi de chevalier</i>, I will not quarrel.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Lord, miss! I wonder you won't believe him
without more ado.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Then he has the hatred of a rival for you.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Malepeste!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You know my chamber is backward, and has a
door into the gallery which looks into the back yard of a
tavern, whence Mr. Gerrard once spying me at the
window, has often since attempted to come in at that
window by the help of the leads of a low building adjoining;
and, indeed, 'twas as much as my maid and I could
do to keep him out.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Ah, le coquin!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But nothing is stronger than aversion; for I hate
him perfectly, even as much as I love you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> I believe so, faith!&mdash;but what design have we
now on foot? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> This discovery is an argument, sure, of my love
to you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, say no more, cousin, I doubt not your
amour for me, because I doubt not your judgment.
But what's to be done with this fanfaron?&mdash;I know<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_137" id="Page_137">[Pg 137]</a></span>
where he eats to-night&mdash;I'll go find him out, <i>ventre
bleu!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O, my dear cousin, you will not make a quarrel
of it? I thought what your promise would come to!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Would you have a man of honour&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Keep his promise?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And lose his mistress?&mdash;That were not for my
honour, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Cousin, though you do me the injury to think I
could be false, do not do yourself the injury to think any
one could be false to you. Will you be afraid of losing
your mistress? To show such a fear to your rival, were
for his honour, and not for yours, sure.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, cousin, I'd have you know I was never
afraid of losing my mistress in earnest.&mdash;Let me see the
man can get my mistress from me, <i>jarni!</i>&mdash;But he that
loves must seem a little jealous.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Not to his rival: those that have jealousy hide it
from their rivals.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But there are some who say, jealousy is no
more to be hid than a cough:&mdash;but it should never be
discovered in me, if I had it, because it is not French at
all&mdash;<i>ventre bleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, you should rally your rival, and rather make
a jest of your quarrel to him; and that, I suppose, is
French too.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> 'Tis so, 'tis so, <i>cousine</i>; 'tis the veritable French
method; for your Englis, for want of wit, drive every
thing to a serious grum quarrel, and then would make
a jest on't, when 'tis too late, when they can't laugh,
<i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes, yes, I would have you rally him soundly:
do not spare him a jot.&mdash;But shall you see him to-night?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes; pray be sure to see him for the jest's sake.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I will&mdash;for I love a jest as well as any <i>bel esprit</i>
of 'em all&mdash;da!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_138" id="Page_138">[Pg 138]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ay, and rally him soundly; be sure you rally him
soundly, and tell him just thus:&mdash;that the lady he has so
long courted, from the great window of the Ship tavern,
is to be your wife to-morrow, unless he come at his
wonted hour of six in the morning to her window to
forbid the banns; for 'tis the first and last time of asking;
and if he come not, let him for ever hereafter stay away,
and hold his tongue.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! a ver good jest, <i>tête bleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> And if the fool should come again, I would tell
him his own, I warrant you, cousin. My gentleman
should be satisfied for good and all, I'd secure him.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Bon, bon.</i></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Well, well, young mistress; you were not at
Hackney school for nothing, I see; nor taken away for
nothing.&mdash;A woman may soon be too old, but is never
too young to shift for herself. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! <i>cousine</i>, dou art a merry grig, <i>ma
foi!</i>&mdash;I long to be with Gerrard; and I am the best at
improving a jest&mdash;I shall have such divertisement to-night,
<i>tête bleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> He'll deny, may be, at first, that he ever courted
any such lady.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, I am sure he'll be ashamed of it, I shall
make him look so sillily, <i>tête non!</i>&mdash;I long to find him
out.&mdash;Adieu, adieu, <i>la cousine</i>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Shall you be sure to find him?</p>

<p><i>Mons. Indubitablement</i>, I'll search the town over, but
I'll find him: ha! ha! ha!&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Monsieur</span>, <i>and
returns.</i>]&mdash;But I'm afraid, <i>cousine</i>, if I should tell him
you are to be my wife to-morrow, he would not come:
now, I am for having him come for the jest's sake,
<i>ventre!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So am I, cousin, for having him come too for the
jest's sake.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, well, leave it to me:&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_139" id="Page_139">[Pg 139]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What's all this giggling here?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Hey! do you tinke we'll tell you? no, fait, I
warrant you, <i>tête non!</i>&mdash;ha! ha! ha!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My cousin is overjoyed, I suppose, that my father
is to come to-night.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I am afraid he will not come to-night:&mdash;but
you'll stay and see, nephew?</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, non</i>: I am to sup at t'other end of the
town to-night&mdash;La, la, la&mdash;Ra, ra, ra&mdash;[<i>Exit, singing.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I wish the French levity of this young man
may agree with your father's Spanish gravity.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Just as your crabbed old age and my youth
agree.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Well, malapert, I know you hate me,
because I have been the guardian of your reputation:
but your husband may thank me one day.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> If he be not a fool, he would rather be obliged to
me for my virtue than to you, since, at long run, he must,
whether he will or no.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> So, so!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, now I think on't, I'd have you to know, the
poor man, whosoe'er he is, will have little cause to thank
you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No; for I never lived so wicked a life as I have
done this twelvemonth, since I have not seen a man.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> How, how! if you have not seen a man,
how could you be wicked? how could you do any ill?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, I have done no ill; but I have paid it with
thinking.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> O that's no hurt! to think, is no hurt:&mdash;ancient,
grave, and godly, cannot help thoughts.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I warrant, you have had 'em yourself, aunt?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes, yes, when I cannot sleep.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ha! ha!&mdash;I believe it. But know, I have had<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_140" id="Page_140">[Pg 140]</a></span>
those thoughts sleeping and waking; for I have dreamt
of a man.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No matter, no matter, so that it was but
a dream: I have dreamt myself. For you must know,
widows are mightily given to dream; insomuch that a
dream is waggishly called "the Widow's Comfort."</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But I did not only dream&mdash;[<i>Sighs.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> How, how! did you more than dream?
speak, young harlotry! confess; did you more than
dream? How could you do more than dream in this
house? speak, confess!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, I will then. Indeed, aunt, I did not
only dream, but I was pleased with my dream when I
awaked.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Oh, is that all?&mdash;Nay, if a dream only will
please you, you are a modest young woman still: but
have a care of a vision.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ay; but to be delighted when we wake with a
naughty dream, is a sin, aunt; and I am so very
scrupulous, that I would as soon consent to a naughty
man as to a naughty dream.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I do believe you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I am for going into the throng of temptations.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> There I believe you again.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> And making myself so familiar with them, that I
would not be concerned for 'em a whit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> There I do not believe you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> And would take all the innocent liberty of the
town:&mdash;to tattle to your men under a vizard in the playhouses,
and meet 'em at night in masquerade.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> There I do believe you again; I know you
would be masquerading: but worse would come on't, as
it has done to others who have been in a masquerade,
and are now virgins but in masquerade, and will not be
their own women again as long as they live. The
children of this age must be wise children indeed if they
know their fathers, since their mothers themselves cannot<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_141" id="Page_141">[Pg 141]</a></span>
inform 'em! O, the fatal liberty of this masquerading
age! when I was a young woman&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Come, come, do not blaspheme this masquerading
age, like an ill-bred city-dame, whose husband is half
broke by living in Covent-garden, or who has been
turned out of the Temple or Lincoln's-Inn upon a
masquerading night. By what I've heard, 'tis a pleasant,
well-bred, complaisant, free, frolic, good-natured, pretty
age: and if you do not like it, leave it to us that do.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Lord, how impudently you talk, niece!
I'm sure I remember when I was a maid&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Can you remember it, reverend aunt?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes, modest niece,&mdash;that a raw young
thing, though almost at woman's estate, (that was then at
thirty or thirty-five years of age,) would not so much as
have looked upon a man&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Above her father's butler or coachman.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Still taking me up! Well, thou art a mad
girl; and so good night. We may go to bed; for I
suppose now your father will not come to-night. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I'm sorry for it; for I long to see him.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
But I lie: I had rather see Gerrard here; and
yet I know not how I shall like him. If he has wit, he
will come; and if he has none, he would not be welcome.
[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>The French House.&mdash;A table, bottles, and
candles.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mr. <span class="smcap">Gerrard, Martin</span>, <i>and</i> Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> 'Tis ver veritable, <i>jarni!</i> what the French say
of you Englis: you use the debauch so much, it cannot
have with you the French operation; you are never
enjoyee. But come, let us for once be <i>infiniment gaillard</i>,
and sing a French sonnet.
[<i>Sings,&mdash;"La bouteille, la bouteille, glou, glou."</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_142" id="Page_142">[Pg 142]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.] What a melodious fop it is!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh! you have no complaisance.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, we can't sing; but we'll drink to you the
lady's health, whom (you say) I have so long courted at
her window.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, there is your complaisance: all your Englis
complaisance is pledging complaisance, <i>ventre!</i>&mdash;But if
I do you reason here, [<i>Takes the glass.</i>]&mdash;will you do me
reason to a little French <i>chanson à boire</i> I shall begin to
you?&mdash;[<i>Sings.</i>] <i>"La bouteille, la bouteille&mdash;"</i></p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.] I had rather keep company with
a set of wide-mouthed, drunken cathedral choristers.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, sir, drink; and he shall do you reason to
your French song, since you stand upon't.&mdash;Sing him
"Arthur of Bradley," or "I am the Duke of Norfolk."</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh! <i>tête bleu!</i>&mdash;an Englis catch! fy! fy!
<i>ventre!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> He can sing no damned French song.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nor can I drink the damned Englis wine.
[<i>Sets down the glass.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, to that lady's health, who has commanded
me to wait upon her to-morrow at her window, which
looks (you say) into the inward yard of the Ship tavern,
near the end of what-d'ye-call't street.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay; do you not know her? not you! <i>vert
bleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But, pray repeat again what she said.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why, she said she is to be married to-morrow to
a person of honour, a brave gentleman, that shall be
nameless, and so, and so forth.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Little does he
think who 'tis!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And what else?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> That if you make not your appearance before
her window to-morrow at your wonted hour of six in the
morning, to forbid the banns, you must for ever hereafter
stay away and hold your tongue; for 'tis the first and last
time of asking.&mdash;Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_143" id="Page_143">[Pg 143]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> 'Tis all a riddle to me: I should be unwilling to
be fooled by this coxcomb. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I won't tell him all she said, lest he should not
go: I would fain have him go for the jest's sake&mdash;Ha!
ha! ha! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Her name is, you say, Hippolita, daughter to a
rich Spanish merchant.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, you don't know her, not you! <i>à d'autre,
à d'autre, ma foi!</i>&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, I will be an easy fool for once.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> By all means go.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, by all means go&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] To be caught in a fool's trap&mdash;I'll
venture it.&mdash;[<i>Drinks to him.</i>] Come, 'tis her health.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And to your good reception&mdash;<i>tête bleu!</i>&mdash;ha!
ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, monsieur, I'll say this for thee, thou hast
made the best use of three months at Paris as ever
English squire did.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Considering I was in a dam Englis pension
too.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Yet you have conversed with some French, I
see; footmen, I suppose, at the fencing-school? I judge
it by your oaths.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> French footmen! well, well, I had rather have
the conversation of a French footman than of an Englis
'squire; there's for you, da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> I beg your pardon, monsieur; I did not think
the French footmen had been so much your friends.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, yes, I warrant they have obliged him at Paris
much more than any of their masters did. Well, there
shall be no more said against the French footmen.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, de grace!</i>&mdash;you are always turning the
nation <i>Française</i> into ridicule, dat nation so accomplie,
dat nation which you imitate so, dat in the conclusion,
you butte turn yourself into ridicule, <i>ma foi!</i> If you are
for de raillery, abuse the Dutch, why not abuse the Dutch?<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_144" id="Page_144">[Pg 144]</a></span>
<i>les gros villains, pendards</i>, insolents; but here in your
England, <i>ma foi!</i>&mdash;you have more honeur, respecte, and
estimation for de Dushe swabber, who come to cheat
your nation, den for de Franch footman, who come to
oblige your nation.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Our nation! then you disown it for yours, it
seems.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well! wat of dat? are you the disobligee by
dat?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, monsieur, far from it; you could not oblige
us, nor your country, any other way than by disowning
it.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> It is de brutal country, which abuse de France,
and reverence de Dushe; I will maintain, sustain, and
justifie, dat one little Franch footman have more honeur,
courage, and generosity, more good blood in his vaines,
an mush more good manners an civility den all de State-General
together, <i>jarni!</i>&mdash;Dey are only wise and valiant
wen dey are drunkee.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> That is, always.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But dey are never honest wen dey are drunkee;
dey are de only rogue in de varlde who are not honeste
when dey are drunk&mdash;<i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I find you are well acquainted with them,
monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, I have made the toure of Holland, but
it was <i>en poste</i>, dere was no staying for me, <i>tête non!</i>&mdash;for
de gentleman can no more live dere den de toad in
Ir'land, <i>ma foi!</i> for I did not see on' chevalier in de
whole countree: alway, you know, de rebel hate de gens
de quality. Besides, I had made sufficient observation of
the <i>canaille barbare</i> de first nightee of my arrival at
Amsterdamme: I did visit, you must know, one of de
principal of de State-General, to whom I had recommendation
from England, and did find his excellence
weighing soap, <i>jarni!</i>&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Weighing soap!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_145" id="Page_145">[Pg 145]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Weighing soap, <i>ma foi!</i> for he was a wholesale
chandeleer; and his lady was taking de tale of chandels
wid her own witer hands, <i>ma foi!</i> and de young lady,
his excellence daughter, stringing harring, stringing
harring, <i>jarni!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> So!&mdash;and what were his sons doing?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Augh&mdash;his son (for he had but one) was making
the tour of France, Espagne, Italy, and Germany, in a
coach and six; or rader, now I tink on't, gone of an
embassy hider to dere master Cromwell, whom dey did
love and fear, because he was someting de greater rebel.
But now I talk of de <i>rebelle</i>, none but the rebel can love
the <i>rebelle</i>. And so much for you and your friend the
Dushe; I'll say no more, and pray do you say no more
of my friend de Franch, not so mush as of my friend de
Franch footman&mdash;da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, no;&mdash;but, monsieur, now give me leave to
admire thee, that in three months at Paris you could
renounce your language, drinking, and your country, (for
which we are not angry with you,) as I said, and come
home so perfect a Frenchman, that the draymen of your
father's own brewhouse would be ready to knock thee on
the head.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Vel, vel, my father was a merchant of his own
beer, as the <i>noblesse</i> of Franch of their own wine.&mdash;But
I can forgive you that raillery, that bob,<a name="FNanchor_56_56" id="FNanchor_56_56"></a><a href="#Footnote_56_56" class="fnanchor">[56]</a> since
you say I have the eyre <i>Français</i>:&mdash;but have I the
eyre <i>Français</i>?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> As much as any French footman of 'em all.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And do I speak agreeable ill Englis enough?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Very ill.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Véritablement?</i></p>

<p><i>Ger. Véritablement.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> For you must know, 'tis as ill breeding now to
speak good Englis as to write good Englis, good sense,
or a good hand.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_146" id="Page_146">[Pg 146]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But, indeed, methinks you are not slovenly
enough for a Frenchman.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Slovenly! you mean negligent?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, I mean slovenly.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Then I will be more slovenly.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> You know, to be a perfect Frenchman, you must
never be silent, never sit still, and never be clean.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> But you have forgot one main qualification of a
true Frenchman, he should never be sound, that is, be
very pocky too.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Oh! if dat be all, I am very pocky; pocky
enough, <i>jarni!</i> that is the only French qualification may
be had without going to Paris, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Waiter.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> Here are a couple of ladies coming up to you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> To us!&mdash;did you appoint any to come hither,
Martin?</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Not I.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nor you, monsieur?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nor I.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Sirrah, tell your master, if he cannot protect us
from the constable, and these midnight coursers, 'tis not
a house for us.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Tell 'em you have nobody in the house, and
shut the doors.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> They'll not be satisfied with that, they'll break
open the door. They searched last night all over the
house for my Lord Fisk, and Sir Jeffery Jantee, who
were fain to hide themselves in the bar under my
mistress's chair and petticoats.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Wat, do the women hunt out the men so now?</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Ay, ay, things are altered since you went to
Paris; there's hardly a young man in town dares be
known of his lodging for 'em.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Bailiffs, pursuivants, or a city constable, are
modest people in comparison of them.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_147" id="Page_147">[Pg 147]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> And we are not so much afraid to be taken up
by the watch as by the tearing midnight ramblers, or
huzza women.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Jarni!</i> ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Where are they? I hope they are gone again.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> No, sir, they are below at the stair-foot, only
swearing at their coachman.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, you rogue, they are in fee with you
waiters, and no gentleman can come hither, but they
have the intelligence straight.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> Intelligence from us, sir! they should never
come here, if we could help it. I am sure we wish 'em
choked when we see them come in; for they bring such
good stomachs from St James's Park, or rambling about
in the streets, that we poor waiters have not a bit left;
'tis well if we can keep our money in our pockets for 'em.
I am sure I have paid seventeen and sixpence in half-crowns
for coach-hire at several times for a little damned
tearing lady, and when I asked her for it again one
morning in her chamber, she bid me pay myself, for she
had no money; but I wanted the courage of a gentleman;
besides, the lord that kept her was a good
customer to our house and my friend, and I made a
conscience of wronging him.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> A man of honour!</p>

<p><i>Mons. Vert</i> and <i>bleu!</i> pleasant, pleasant, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Go, go, sirrah, shut the door, I hear 'em coming
up.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> Indeed I dare not; they'll kick me down stairs,
if I should.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Go, you rascal, I say.
[<i>The</i> Waiter <i>shuts the door, 'tis thrust open
again.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Flounce</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Flirt</span> <i>in vizards, striking the</i>
Waiter, <i>and come up to the table.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Flounce and Flirt, upon my<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_148" id="Page_148">[Pg 148]</a></span>
life!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Ladies, I am sorry you have no volunteers in
your service; this is mere pressing, and argues a great
necessity you have for men.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> You need not be afraid, sir; we will use no
violence to you; you are not fit for our service: we
know you.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> The hot service you have been in formerly
makes you unfit for ours now; besides, you begin to be
something too old for us; we are for the brisk huzzas of
seventeen or eighteen.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nay, faith, I am not too old yet; but an old
acquaintance will make any man old:&mdash;besides, to tell
you the truth, you are come a little too early for me, for
I am not drunk yet. But there are your brisk young
men, who are always drunk, and, perhaps, have the
happiness not to know you.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> The happiness not to know us!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> The happiness not to know us!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Be not angry, ladies; 'tis rather happiness to
have pleasure to come than to have it past, and therefore
these gentlemen are happy in not knowing you.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> I'd have you to know, I do know the ladies too,
and I will not lose the honour of the ladies' acquaintance
for anything.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Not for the pleasure of beginning an acquaintance
with us, as Mr. Gerrard says: but it is the general
vanity of you town fops to lay claim to all good acquaintance
and persons of honour; you cannot let a woman
pass in the Mall at midnight, but, damn you, you know
her straight, you know her;&mdash;but you would be damned
before you would say so much for one in a mercer's
shop.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> He has spoken it in a French-house, where he
has very good credit, and I dare swear you may make
him eat his words.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> She does want a gown, indeed; she is in her
<i>déshabillé</i>. This <i>déshabillé</i> is a great mode in England;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_149" id="Page_149">[Pg 149]</a></span>
the women love the <i>déshabillé</i> as well as the men, <i>ma
foi!</i> [<i>Peeping under her scarf.</i></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Well, if we should stay and sup with you, I
warrant you would be bragging of it to-morrow amongst
your comrades, that you had the company of two women
of quality at the French-house, and name us.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Pleasant jilts! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, upon our honours, we would not brag of
your company.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Upon your honours?</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> No, faith.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Come, we will venture to sit down then: yet I
know the vanity of you men; you could not contain
yourselves from bragging.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, no; you women now-a-days have found out the
pleasure of bragging, and will allow it the men no longer.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Therefore, indeed, we dare not stay to sup with
you; for you would be sure to tell on't.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And we are young men who stand upon our
reputations.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> You are very pleasant, gentlemen.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> For my part I am to be married shortly, and
know 'twould quickly come to my mistress's ear.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And for my part I must go visit to-morrow
betimes a new city mistress; and you know they are as
inquisitive as precise in the city.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Come, come; pray leave this fooling; sit down
again, and let us bespeak supper.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, faith, I dare not.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Besides, we have supped.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> No matter, we only desire you should look on
while we eat, and put the glass about, or so.
[<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Martin</span> <i>offer to go.</i></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Pray, stay.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Upon my life I dare not.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Upon our honours we will not tell, if you are in
earnest.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_150" id="Page_150">[Pg 150]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Pshaw! pshaw!&mdash;I know the vanity of you
women; you could not contain yourselves from bragging.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Ma foi!</i> is it certain? ha! ha! ha!&mdash;Hark
you, madam, can't you fare well but you must cry roast-meat?</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You spoil your trade by bragging of your gains;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The silent sow (madam) does eat most grains.&mdash;da&mdash;</span><br />
</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Your servant, monsieur fop.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Nay, faith, do not go, we will no more tell&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Than you would of a clap, if you had it; dat's
the only secret you can keep, <i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> I am glad we are rid of these jilts.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And we have taken a very ridiculous occasion.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Wat! must we leave the lady then? dis is dam
civility Englis, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Nay, sir, you have too much of the French air,
to have so little honour and good breeding.
[<i>Pulling him back.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Dee you tinke so then, sweet madam, I have
mush of de French eyre?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> More than any Frenchman breathing.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, you are the curtoise dame; <i>morbleu!</i> I
shall stay then, if you think so. Monsieur Gerrard, you
will be certain to see the lady to-morrow? pray not
forget, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, no, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> You will go then?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I will go on a fool's errand for once.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Martin</span>.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> What will you eat, sir?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Wat you please, madam.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> D'ye hear, waiter? then some young partridge.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> What else, madam?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Some ruffs.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> What else, madam?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Some young pheasants.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> What else, madam?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_151" id="Page_151">[Pg 151]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Some young rabbits; I love rabbits.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> What else, madam?</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Stay&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mans.</i> Dis Englis waiter wit his "Wat else, madam,"
will ruin me, <i>tête non!</i> [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> What else, madam?</p>

<p><i>Mans.</i> "Wat else, madam," agen!&mdash;call up the French
waiter.</p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> What else, madam?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Again!&mdash;call up the French waiter or <i>cuisinier,
mort! tête! ventre! vite!</i>&mdash;Auh, madam, the stupidity
of the Englis waiter! I hate the Englis waiter, <i>ma foi!</i>
[<i>Exit</i> Waiter.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Be not in passion, dear monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I kiss your hand, <i>obligeante</i> madam.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter a French</i> Scullion.</p>

<p><i>Cher Pierrot, serviteur, serviteur.</i>&mdash;[<i>Kisses the</i> Scullion.]&mdash;<i>Or-ça
à manger.</i></p>

<p><i>Scull. En voulez-vous</i> de cram schiquin?</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Scull.</i> De partrish, de faysan, de quailles?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] This <i>bougre</i> vil ruine me too; but he
speak wit dat <i>bel</i> eyre and grace, I cannot bid him hold
his tongue, <i>ventre! C'est assez, Pierrot, va-t'en.</i>
[<i>Exit</i> Scullion, <i>and returns.</i></p>

<p><i>Scull.</i> And de litel plate de&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons. Jarni! va-t'en.</i> [<i>Exit</i> Scullion, <i>and returns.</i></p>

<p><i>Scull.</i> And de litel plate de&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons. De grace</i>, go dy way. [<i>Exit</i> Scullion, <i>and returns.</i></p>

<p><i>Scull.</i> And de litel de&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons. De fromage de Brie, va-t'en!</i>&mdash;go, go.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> What's that? cheese that stinks?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, be sure it stinke extremente. <i>Pierrot,
va-t'en;</i> but stay till I drink dy health:&mdash;here's to dat
pretty fellow's health, madam.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_152" id="Page_152">[Pg 152]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Must we drink the scullion's health?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, you will not be <i>désobligeante</i>, madam; he
is the <i>cuisinier</i> for a king, nay, for a cardinal or French
abbot. [<i>Drinks. Exit</i> Scullion.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> But how shall we divertise ourselves till supper
be ready?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Can we have better <i>divertissement</i> than this
gentleman?</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> But I think we had better carry the gentleman
home with us, and because it is already late, sup at home,
and divertise the gentleman at cards, till it be ready.&mdash;D'ye
hear, waiter? let it be brought, when 'tis ready, to
my lodging hard by, in Mustard-Alley, at the sign of the
Crooked-billet.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> At the Crooked-billet!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Come, sir, come.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Morbleu!</i> I have take the vow (since my last
clap) never to go again to the <i>bourdel</i>.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> What is the <i>bourdel</i>?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How call you the name of your house?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> The Crooked-billet.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, no, the&mdash;bawdy-house, <i>vert</i> and <i>bleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> How, our lodging! we'd have you to know&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, <i>morbleu!</i> I would not know it; de
Crooked-billet, ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Come, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Besides, if I go wit you to the <i>bourdel</i>, you will
tell, <i>morbleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> Fy! fy! come along.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Beside, I am to be married within these two
days; if you should tell now&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Come, come along, we will not tell.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But you will promise then to have the care of my
honour? pray, good madam, have de care of my honour,
pray have de care of my honour. Will you have care of
my honour? pray have de care of my honour, and do
not tell if you can help it; pray, dear madam, do not
tell. [<i>Kneels to them.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_153" id="Page_153">[Pg 153]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> I would not tell for fear of losing you, my love
for you will make me secret.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why, do you love me?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Indeed I cannot help telling you now, what my
modesty ought to conceal, but my eyes would disclose it
too:&mdash;I have a passion for you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> A passion for me!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> An extreme passion, dear sir; you are so
French, so mightily French, so agreeable French&mdash;but
I'll tell you more of my heart at home: come along.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But is your pation sincere?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> The truest in the world.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well then, I'll venture my body with thee for
one night.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> For one night! don't you believe that; and so
you would leave me to-morrow? but I love you so, I
cannot part with you, you must keep me for good and
all, if you will have me. I can't leave you for my heart.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! keep, <i>jarni!</i> de whore Englis have
notinge but keepe, keepe in dere mouths now-a-days,
<i>tête non!</i>&mdash;Formerly 'twas enoughe to keep de shild,
<i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Nay, I will be kept, else&mdash;but, come, we'll talk
on't at home.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Umh&mdash;so, so, ver vel; de amour of de whore
does alway end in keep, ha! keep, <i>ma foi!</i> keep, ha!&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The punk that entertains you wit her passion,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Is like kind host who makes the invitation,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At your own cost, to his <i>fort bonne collation.</i></span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_154" id="Page_154">[Pg 154]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE SECOND.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;Don <span class="smcap">Diego's</span> <i>House in the morning.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>in a Spanish habit, and</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Have you had a Spanish care of the
honour of my family? that is to say,
have you kept my daughter close in
my absence, as I directed?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I have sir, but it was
as much as I could do.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I knew that; for 'twas as much as I could do to
keep up her mother;&mdash;I that have been in Spain, look
you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay 'tis a hard task to keep up an Englishwoman.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> As hard as it is for those who are not kept up to
be honest, look you, <i>con licencia</i>, sister.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> How now, brother! I am sure my husband
never kept me up.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I knew that, therefore I cried <i>con licencia</i>, sister,
as the Spaniards have it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> But you Spaniards are too censorious,
brother.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You Englishwomen, sister, give us too much
cause, look you;&mdash;but you are sure my daughter has not
seen a man since my departure?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, not so much as a churchman.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_155" id="Page_155">[Pg 155]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> As a churchman! <i>voto!</i> I thank you for that;
not a churchman! not a churchman!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, not so much as a churchman; but
of any, one would think one might trust a churchman.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, we are bold enough in trusting them with our
souls, I'll never trust them with the body of my daughter,
look you, <i>guarda!</i> You see what comes of trusting
churchmen here in England; and 'tis because the women
govern the families, that chaplains are so much in
fashion. Trust a churchman!&mdash;trust a coward with your
honour, a fool with your secret, a gamester with your
purse, as soon as a priest with your wife or daughter;
look you, <i>guarda!</i> I am no fool, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, I know you are a wise man, brother.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why, sister, I have been fifteen years in Spain
for it, at several times, look you: now in Spain, he is
wise enough that is grave, politic enough that says little,
and honourable enough that is jealous; and though I say
it, that should not say it, I am as grave, grum, and
jealous, as any Spaniard breathing.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I know you are, brother.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> And will be a Spaniard in everything still, and
will not conform, not I, to their ill-favoured English
customs, for I will wear my Spanish habit still, I will
stroke my Spanish whiskers still, and I will eat my
Spanish <i>olio</i> still; and my daughter shall go a maid to
her husband's bed, let the English custom be what 'twill:
I would fain see any finical, cunning, insinuating monsieur
of the age, debauch, or steal away my daughter.
But, well, has she seen my cousin? how long has he
been in England?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> These three days.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> And she has seen him, has she? I was
contented he should see her, intending him for her
husband; but she has seen nobody else upon your
certain knowledge?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_156" id="Page_156">[Pg 156]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, no, alas! how should she? 'tis impossible
she should.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Where is her chamber? pray let me see her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> You'll find her, poor creature, asleep, I
warrant you: or, if awake, thinking no hurt, nor of your
coming this morning.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Let us go to her, I long to see her, poor
innocent wretch. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita, Gerrard</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span> <i>at a distance.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Am I not come upon your own summons,
madam? and yet receive me so?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My summons, sir! no, I assure you; and if you
do not like your reception, I cannot help it; for I am
not used to receive men, I'd have you to know.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> She is beautiful beyond all things I ever saw.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I like him extremely! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, fairest, why do you frown?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Because I am angry.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I am come on purpose to please you, then; do
not receive me so unkindly.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I tell you, I do not use to receive men.&mdash;There
has not been a man in the house before, but my cousin,
this twelvemonth, I'd have you to know.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Then you ought to bid me the more welcome,
I'd have you to know.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What! do you mock me too? I know I am but
a home-bred simple girl! but I thought you gallants of
the town had been better bred than to mock a poor girl
in her father's own house. I have heard, indeed, 'tis a
part of good breeding to mock people behind their
backs, but not to their faces.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_157" id="Page_157">[Pg 157]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Pretty creature! she has not only the
beauty, but the innocency of an angel.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.]
Mock you, dear miss! no, I only repeated the words because
they were yours, sweet miss; what we like we imitate.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> "Dear miss! sweet miss!" how came you and I
so well acquainted? this is one of your confident tricks,
too, as I have been told; you'll be acquainted with a
woman in the time you can help her over a bench in the
playhouse, or to her coach. But I need not wonder at
your confidence, since you could come in at the great
gallery window, just now. But, pray, who shall pay for
the glass you have broken?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Pretty creature! your father might have made
the window bigger then, since he has so fine a
daughter, and will not allow people to come in at the
door to her.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> A pleasant man!&mdash;well, 'tis harder playing the
hypocrite with him, I see, than with my aunt or father;
and if dissimulation were not very natural to a woman, I'm
sure I could not use it at this time: but the mask of
simplicity and innocency is as useful to an intriguing
woman as the mask of religion to a statesman, they say.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Why do you look away, dearest miss?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Because you quarrelled with me just now for
frowning upon you, and I cannot help it, if I look upon
you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> O! let me see that face at any rate.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Would you have me frown upon you? for I shall
be sure to do't.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, I'll stand fair: you have done your worst
to my heart already.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Now I dare not look upon him, lest I should not
be able to keep my word. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, I am ready:&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] and yet I am afraid
of her frowns.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.] Come, look, Ih&mdash;am
ready, Ih&mdash;am ready.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_158" id="Page_158">[Pg 158]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But I am not ready. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Turn, dear miss, come, Ih&mdash;am ready.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Are you ready then? I'll look. [<i>Turns upon
him.</i>]&mdash;No, faith, I cannot frown upon him, if I should
be hanged. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Dear miss, I thank you, that look has no
terror in't.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, I cannot frown for my heart for blushing, I
don't use to look upon men, you must know.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> If it were possible anything could, those blushes
would add to her beauty: well, bashfulness is the only
out-of-fashioned thing that is agreeable. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ih&mdash;h&mdash;like this man strangely, I was going to
say loved him. Courage then, Hippolita! make use of
the only opportunity thou canst have to enfranchise
thyself. Women formerly (they say) never knew how to
make use of their time till it was past; but let it not be
said so of a young woman of this age.&mdash;My damned aunt
will be stirring presently:&mdash;well, then, courage, I say,
Hippolita!&mdash;thou art full fourteen years old,&mdash;shift for
thyself. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> So! I have looked upon her so long, till I am
grown bashful too. Love and modesty come together
like money and covetousness, and the more we have, the
less we can show it. I dare not look her in the face now,
nor speak a word. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What, sir, methinks you look away now!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Because you would not look upon me, miss.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, I hope you can't look me in the face, since
you have done so rude a thing as to come in at the
window upon me. Come, come, when once we women
find the men bashful, then we take heart. Now I can
look upon you as long as you will; let's see if you can
frown upon me now.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Lovely innocency! no, you may swear I can't
frown upon you, miss.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So! I knew you were ashamed of what you have<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_159" id="Page_159">[Pg 159]</a></span>
done. Well, since you are ashamed, and because you
did not come of your own head, but were sent by my
cousin, you say&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Which I wonder at. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> For all these reasons, I do forgive you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> In token of your forgiveness then, dearest miss,
let me have the honour to kiss your hand.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, there 'tis; you men are like our little
shock dogs:<a name="FNanchor_57_57" id="FNanchor_57_57"></a><a href="#Footnote_57_57" class="fnanchor">[57]</a> if we don't keep you off from us, but use you
a little kindly, you grow so fiddling and so troublesome,
there is no enduring you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> O dear miss! if I am like your shock-dog, let it
be in his privileges.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why, I'd have you know he does not lie with
me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> 'Twas well guessed, miss, for one so innocent.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, I always kick him off from the bed, and
never will let him come near it; for of late, indeed, (I do
not know what's the reason,) I don't much care for my
shock-dog, nor my babies.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> O then, miss, I may have hopes! for after the
shock-dog and the babies, 'tis the man's turn to be
beloved.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why, could you be so good-natured as to come
after my shock-dog in my love? it may be, indeed,
rather than after one of your brother men.</p>

<p><i>Ger</i> Hah, ha, ha! poor creature! a wonder of innocency!
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But I see you are humble, because you would
kiss my hand.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, I am ambitious therefore.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, all this fooling but loses time, I
must make better use of it. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.] I could let
you kiss my hand, but then I'm afraid you would take
hold of me and carry me away.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Indeed I would not.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_160" id="Page_160">[Pg 160]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Come, I know you would.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Truly I would not.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You would! you would! I know you would.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I'll swear I wo' not&mdash;by&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, don't swear, for you'll be the apter to do it
then. [<i>Aside.</i>] I would not have him forswear it neither;&mdash;he
does not like me, sure, well enough to carry me
away.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Dear miss, let me kiss your hand.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I am sure you would carry me away if I should.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Be not afraid of it.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Nay, I am afraid of the contrary.&mdash;Either
he dislikes me, and therefore will not be troubled
with me, or what is as bad, he loves me and is dull, or
fearful to displease me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Trust me, sweetest! I can use no violence to
you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, I am sure you would carry me away; what
should you come in at the window for, if you did not
mean to steal me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> If I should endeavour it, you might cry out, and I
should be prevented.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Dull, dull man of the town! are all like
thee? He is as dull as a country squire at questions and
commands.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.] No, if I should cry out never
so loud, this is quite at the further end of the house, and
there nobody could hear me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I will not give you the occasion, dearest.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, I will quicken thy sense, if it be
possible.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.] Nay, I know you come to
steal me away; because I am an heiress, and have twelve
hundred pounds a year, lately left me by my mother's
brother, which my father cannot meddle with, and which
is the chiefest reason (I suppose) why he keeps me up so
close.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Ha!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So!&mdash;this has made him consider. O money!<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_161" id="Page_161">[Pg 161]</a></span>
powerful money! how the ugly, old, crooked, straight,
handsome young women are beholding to thee! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Twelve hundred pounds a year!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Besides, I have been told my fortune, and the
woman said I should be stolen away, because she says
'tis the fate of heiresses to be stolen away.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Twelve hundred pounds a-year!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, more, she described the man to me that
was to do it, and he was as like you as could be. Have
you any brothers?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Not any; 'twas I, I warrant you, sweetest.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So, he understands himself now. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, madam, since 'twas foretold you, what
do you think on't? 'tis in vain, you know, to resist
fate.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I do know, indeed, they say 'tis to no purpose:
besides, the woman that told me my fortune, or you,
have bewitched me&mdash;Ih&mdash;think. [<i>Sighs.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> My soul! my life! 'tis you have charms powerful
as numberless, especially those of your innocency
irresistible, and do surprise the wariest heart. Such mine
was, while I could call it mine, but now 'tis yours for
ever.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, well, get you gone then. I'll keep it safe
for your sake.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nay, you must go with me, sweetest.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, I see you will part with the jewel; but
you will have the keeping of the cabinet to which you
commit it.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, come, my dearest, let us be gone: Fortune
as well as women must be taken in the humour.</p>

<p class="center"><i>As they are going out</i>, <span class="smcap">Prue</span> <i>runs hastily to them.</i></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> O miss, miss! your father, it seems, is just now
arrived, and is here coming in upon you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My father.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_162" id="Page_162">[Pg 162]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> My daughter and a man!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> A man! a man in the house!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Ha! what mean these?&mdash;a Spaniard!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What shall I do? Stay&mdash;Nay, pray stir not from
me; but lead me about, as if you led me a corant.<a name="FNanchor_58_58" id="FNanchor_58_58"></a><a href="#Footnote_58_58" class="fnanchor">[58]</a>
[<i>Leads her about.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Is this your government, sister? and this your
innocent charge, that hath not seen the face of a man
this twelvemonth? <i>en hora mala!</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> O, sure, it is not a man! it cannot be a
man! [<i>Puts on her spectacles.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> It cannot be a man! if he be not a man, he's a
devil. He has her lovingly by the hand too, <i>valgame el
cielo!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Do not seem to mind them, but dance on, or
lead me about still.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> What d'ye mean by it? [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Hey, they are frolic, a-dancing!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Indeed, they are dancing, I think.&mdash;Why,
niece!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, hold a little: I'll make 'em dance in the
devil's name; but it shall not be <i>la gallarda</i>.
[<i>Draws his sword.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> O niece! why niece!
[Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span> <i>holds him.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Do you hear her? what do you mean?
[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Take no notice of them; but walk about still,
and sing a little, sing a corant.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I can't sing: but I'll hum, if you will.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Are you so merry? well I'll be with you: <i>en
hora mala!</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> O niece, niece! why niece! oh&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_163" id="Page_163">[Pg 163]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why, daughter, my dainty daughter! My shame!
my ruin! my plague!
[<i>Struggling, gets from</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>, <i>goes towards
them with his sword drawn.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Mind him not, but dance and sing on.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> A pretty time to dance and sing, indeed, when I
have a Spaniard with a naked Toledo at my tail! No,
pray excuse me, miss, from fooling any longer.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Turning about.</i>] O, my father, my father!
poor father! you are welcome; pray give me your
blessing.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> My blessing, <i>en hora mala!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What! am I not your daughter, sir?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> My daughter! <i>mi mal! mi muerte!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My name's Hippolita, sir: I don't own your
Spanish names. But, pray father, why do you frighten
one so? you know I don't love to see a sword: what do
you mean to do with that ugly thing out?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I'll show you. <i>Traidor! ladron de mi honra!</i>
thou diest. [<i>Runs at</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Not if I can help it, good Don. But by the
names you give me, I find you mistake your man: I
suppose some Spaniard has affronted you. [<i>Draws.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> None but thee, <i>ladron!</i> and thou diest for't.
[<i>Fight.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Oh! oh! oh!&mdash;help! help! help!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O&mdash;what, will you kill my poor dancing-master?
[<i>Kneels.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> A dancing-master! he's a fencing-master rather,
I think. But is he your dancing-master? umph&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> So much wit and innocency were never together
before. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Is he a dancing-master? [<i>Pausing.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Is he a dancing-master? He does not
look like a dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Pish!&mdash;you don't know a dancing-master: you
have not seen one these threescore years, I warrant.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_164" id="Page_164">[Pg 164]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No matter: but he does not look like a
dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, nay, dancing-masters look like gentlemen
enough, sister: but he's no dancing-master, by drawing
a sword so briskly. Those tripping outsides of gentlemen
are like gentlemen enough in everything but in
drawing a sword; and since he is a gentleman, he shall
die by mine. [<i>They fight again.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Oh! hold! hold!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Hold! hold!&mdash;Pray, brother, let's talk with
him a little first; I warrant you I shall trap him; and if
he confesses, you may kill him; but those that confess,
they say, ought to be hanged&mdash;Let's see&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Poor Hippolita! I wish I had not had this
occasion of admiring thy wit; I have increased my love,
whilst I have lost my hopes; the common fate of poor
lovers. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Come, you are guilty, by that hanging
down of your head. Speak: are you a dancing-master?
Speak, speak; a dancing-master?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, forsooth, I am a dancing-master; ay, ay&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How does it appear?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why, there is his fiddle, there upon the table,
father.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, busybody, but it is not:&mdash;that is my
nephew's fiddle.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why, he lent it to my cousin: I tell you it is
his.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, it may be, indeed; he might lend it
to him for aught I know.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, ay: but ask him, sister, if he be a dancing-master,
where.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Pray, brother, let me alone with him, I
know what to ask him, sure.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, will you be wiser than I? nay, then stand
away. Come, if you are a dancing-master, where's your
school? <i>Donde? donde?</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_165" id="Page_165">[Pg 165]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Why, he'll say, may be, he has ne'er a one.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Who asked you, nimble chaps? So you have put
an excuse in his head.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Indeed, sir, 'tis no excuse: I have no school.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Well; but who sent you? how came you
hither?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> There I am puzzled indeed. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> How came you hither, I say? how&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Why, how, how should I come hither?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, how should he come hither? Upon his legs.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> So, so! now you have put an excuse in his
head too, that you have, so you have; but stay&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, with your favour, mistress, I'll ask him now.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Y'facks, but you shan't! I'll ask him, and
ask you no favour, that I will.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Y'fackins, but you shan't ask him! if you go
there too, look you, you prattle-box you, I'll ask him.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I will ask him, I say!&mdash;come!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Where?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Mine's a shrewd question.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Mine's as shrewd as yours.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, then, we shall have it.&mdash;Come, answer me;
where's your lodging? come, come, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> A shrewd question, indeed! at the Surgeons'-arms,
I warrant you; for 'tis spring-time, you
know.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Must you make lies for him?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> But come, sir; what's your name?&mdash;answer
me to that; come.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> His name! why, 'tis an easy matter to tell you a
false name, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> So! must you teach him to cheat us?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why did you say my questions were not shrewd
questions, then?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> And why would you not let me ask him
the question, then? Brother, brother, ever while you live,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_166" id="Page_166">[Pg 166]</a></span>
for all your Spanish wisdom, let an old woman make discoveries:
the young fellows cannot cheat us in anything,
I'd have you to know. Set your old woman still to
grope out an intrigue, because, you know, the mother
found her daughter in the oven. A word to the wise,
brother.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, leave this tattling: he has dishonoured
my family, debauched my daughter; and what
if he could excuse himself? The Spanish proverb says,
excuses neither satisfy creditors nor the injured. The
wounds of honour must have blood and wounds, <i>St. Jago
para mi!</i>
[<i>Kisses the cross of his sword, and runs at</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O hold, dear father! and I'll confess all.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> She will not, sure, after all. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My cousin sent him; because, as he said,
he would have me recover my dancing a little before
our wedding, having made a vow he would never marry a
wife who could not dance a corant. I am sure I was
unwilling; but he would have him come, saying I was to
be his wife as soon as you came, and therefore expected
obedience from me.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Indeed, the venture is most his, and the shame
would be most his; for I know here in England, 'tis not
the custom for the father to be much concerned what the
daughter does; but I will be a Spaniard still.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Did not you hear him say last night he would
send me one this morning?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, not I, sure. If I had, he had never
come here.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, aunt, you grow old I see; your memory
fails you very much. Did not you hear him, Prue, say
he would send him to me?</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Yes, I'll be sworn did I.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Look you there, aunt.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I wonder I should not remember it.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, you are a doting old fool.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_167" id="Page_167">[Pg 167]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> So! So! the fault will be mine now. But
pray, mistress, how did he come in? I am sure I had the
keys of the doors, which, till your father came in, were
not opened to-day.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> He came in just after my father, I suppose.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> It might be, indeed, while the porters
brought in the things, and I was talking with you.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> O, might he so, forsooth! you are a brave
governante! Look you, you a duenna, <i>voto!</i>&mdash;and not
know who comes in and out!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut</i> So! 'tis my fault, I know.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Your maid was in the room with you; was she
not, child?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes, indeed, and indeed, father, all the while.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, child, I am satisfied then.&mdash;But I hope he
does not use the dancing-master's tricks, of squeezing
your hands, setting your legs and feet, by handling your
thighs and seeing your legs.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, indeed, father: I'd give him a box on the
ear if he should.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Poor innocent!&mdash;Well, I am contented you
should learn to dance, since, for aught I know, you shall
be married to-morrow, or the next day at farthest: by
that time you may recover a corant&mdash;a saraband I would
say.<a name="FNanchor_59_59" id="FNanchor_59_59"></a><a href="#Footnote_59_59" class="fnanchor">[59]</a> And since your cousin, too, will have a dancing
wife, it shall be so; and I'll see you dance myself. You
shall be my charge these two days, and then I dare venture
you in the hand of any dancing-master, even a saucy
French dancing-master, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Well, have a care, though; for this man is
not dressed like a dancing master.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Go, go, you dote; are they not (for the most
part) better dressed and prouder than many a good
gentleman? you would be wiser than I, would you,
<i>cuerno</i>?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Well, I say only, look to't, look to't.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_168" id="Page_168">[Pg 168]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Hey, hey! Come, friend, to your business;
teach her her lesson over again; let's see.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Come, master.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, let's see your English method; I
understand something of dancing myself&mdash;come.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Come, master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I shall betray you yet, dearest miss; for I know
not a step: I could never dance. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, child.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed I'm ashamed, father.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You must not be ashamed, child; you'll never
dance well if you are ashamed.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, I can't help it, father.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, I say, go to't.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed I can't, father, before you: 'tis my first
lesson, and I shall do it so ill.&mdash;Pray, good father, go
into the next room for this once; and the next time
my master comes, you shall see I shall be confident
enough.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Poor, foolish, innocent creature!&mdash;Well, well, I
will, child. Who but a Spanish kind of a father could
have so innocent a daughter in England?&mdash;Well, I would
fain see any one steal or debauch my daughter from
me.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, won't you go, father?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Yes, yes, I go, child: we will all go but your
maid.&mdash;You can dance before your maid?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes, yes, father: a maid at most times with her
mistress is nobody. [<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> He peeps yet at the door.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, father, you peep; indeed you must not see
me. When we have done, you shall come in.
[<i>She pulls the door to.</i></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Indeed, little mistress, like the young kitten,
you see you played with your prey till you had almost
lost it.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_169" id="Page_169">[Pg 169]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Tis true, a good old mouser like you had taken
it up, and run away with it presently.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Let me adore you, dearest miss, and give you&mdash;[<i>Going
to embrace her.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, no embracing, good master! that ought to
be the last lesson you are to teach me, I have heard.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Though an aftergame be the more tedious and
dangerous, 'tis won, miss, with the more honour and
pleasure: for all that, I repent we were put to't. The
coming in of your father, as he did, was the most unlucky
thing that ever befel me.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What then, you think I would have gone with
you?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes; and you will go with me yet, I hope.&mdash;Courage,
miss! we have yet an opportunity; and the
gallery-window is yet open.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, no; if I went, I would go for good and all:
but now my father will soon come in again, and may
quickly overtake us. Besides, now I think on't, you are
a stranger to me; I know not where you live, nor
whither you might carry me. For aught I know, you
might be a spirit, and carry me to Barbadoes.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, dear miss, I would carry you to court, the
playhouses, and Hyde-park&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, I know 'tis the trick of all you that spirit
women away, to speak 'em mighty fair at first: but
when you have got 'em in your clutches, you carry 'em
into Yorkshire, Wales, or Cornwall, which is as bad as to
Barbadoes; and rather than be served so, I would be a
prisoner in London still as I am.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I see the air of this town, without the pleasures
of it, is enough to infect women with an aversion for the
country. Well, miss, since it seems you have some
diffidence in me, give me leave to visit you as your
dancing-master, now you have honoured me with the
character; and under that I may have your father's
permission to see you, till you may better know me<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_170" id="Page_170">[Pg 170]</a></span>
and my heart, and have a better opportunity to reward
it.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I am afraid to know your heart would require a
great deal of time; and my father intends to marry me
very suddenly to my cousin, who sent you hither.</p>

<p><i>Get.</i> Pray, sweet miss, let us make the better use of
our time if it be short. But how shall we do with that
cousin of yours in the mean time? we must needs charm
him.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Leave that to me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But (what's worse) how shall I be able to act
a dancing-master, who ever wanted inclination and
patience to learn myself?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> A dancing-school in half an hour will furnish
you with terms of the art. Besides, Love (as I have
