heard say) supplies his scholars with all sorts of capacities
they have need of, in spite of nature:&mdash;but what has love
to do with you?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Love, indeed, has made a grave gouty statesmen
fight duels, the soldier fly from his colours, a pedant a
fine gentlemen, nay, and the very lawyer a poet; and,
therefore, may make me a dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> If he were your master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I'm sure, dearest miss, there is nothing else
which I cannot do for you already; and, therefore, may
hope to succeed in that.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, have you done?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O, my father again!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, now let us see you dance.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed I am not perfect yet: pray excuse me
till the next time my master comes. But when must he
come again, father?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Let me see&mdash;friend, you must needs come after
dinner again, and then at night again, and so three times
to-morrow too. If she be not married to-morrow, (which<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_171" id="Page_171">[Pg 171]</a></span>
I am to consider of,) she will dance a corant in twice or
thrice teaching more; will she not? for 'tis but a twelvemonth
since she came from Hackney-school.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> We will lose no time, I warrant you, sir, if she be
to be married to-morrow.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> True, I think she may be married to-morrow;
therefore, I would not have you lose any time, look you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> You need not caution me, I warrant you, sir.&mdash;Sweet
scholar, your humble servant: I will not fail you
immediately after dinner.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, no, pray do not; and I will not fail to satisfy
you very well, look you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> He does not doubt his reward, father, for his
pains. If you should not, I would make that good to
him.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, let us go in to your aunt: I must talk
with you both together, child.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I follow you, sir.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>and</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Here's the gentlewoman o' th' next house come
to see you, mistress.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] She's come, as if she came expressly to
sing the new song she sung last night. I must hear it;
for 'tis to my purpose now.&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady.</p>

<p>Madam, your servant: I dreamt all night of the song
you sung last; the new song against delays in love,
Pray, let's hear it again.</p>

<p><i>Lady.</i> [<i>Sings.</i>]</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Since we poor slavish women know</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">Our men we cannot pick and choose,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To him we like why say we no,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">And both our time and lover lose?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">With feigned repulses and delays</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">A lover's appetite we pall;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And if too long the gallant stays,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">His stomach's gone for good and all,</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_172" id="Page_172">[Pg 172]</a></span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Or our impatient amorous guest</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">Unknown to us away may steal,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And rather than stay for a feast,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">Take up with some coarse ready meal</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">When opportunity is kind,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">Let prudent women be so too;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And if the man be to your mind,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">Till needs you must, ne'er let him go.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The match soon made is happy still,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">For only love has there to do.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Let no one marry 'gainst her will,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">But stand off when her parents woo,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And only to their suits be coy:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">For she whom jointure can obtain,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To let a fop her bed enjoy,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">Is but a lawful wench for gain.</span><br />
</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Your father calls for you, miss.
[<i>Steps to the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I come, I come; I must be obedient as long as
I am with him. [<i>Pausing.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our parents who restrain our liberty,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">But take the course to make us sooner free,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Though all we gain be but new slavery;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 3em;">We leave our fathers, and to husbands flee.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_173" id="Page_173">[Pg 173]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE THIRD.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;Don <span class="smcap">Diego's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris, Hippolita</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Serviteur, serviteur, la cousine.</i>
Your maid told me she watched at the
stair-foot for my coming; because you
had a mind to speak wit me before I
saw your fader, it seem.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I would so, indeed, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Or-ça! or-ça!</i> I know your affair. It is to tell
me wat recreation you ade with Monsieur Gerrard.
But did he come? I was afrait he would not come.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes, yes, he did come.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;and were you not infiniment
divertisee and please? Confess.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I was indeed, cousin, I was very well pleased.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I do tinke so. I did tinke to come and be
divertisee myself this morning with the sight of his reception:
but I did rancounter last night wit dam company
dat keep me up so late, I could not rise in de morning,
<i>malepeste de putains!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, we wanted you here mightily, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> To elpe you to laugh: for if I adde been here,
I had made such recreation wit dat coxcomb Gerrard!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, cousin, you need not have any subject
property to make one laugh, you are so pleasant yourself;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_174" id="Page_174">[Pg 174]</a></span>
and when you are but alone, you would make one
burst.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Am I so happy, cousin, then, in the <i>bon</i> quality
of making people laugh?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Mighty happy, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Mons. De grace?</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, <i>sans vanité</i>, I observe, wheresoe'er I
come, I make everybody merry; <i>sans vanité</i>&mdash;da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I do believe you do.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, as I marche in de street, I can make de
dull apprenty laugh and sneer.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> This fool, I see, is as apt as an ill poet to mistake
the contempt and scorn of people for applause and
admiration. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ah, cousin, you see what it is to have been in
France! Before I went into France, I could get nobody
to laugh at me, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No? truly, cousin, I think you deserved it before;
but you are improved, indeed, by going into
France.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, the French education make us <i>propre
à tout</i>. Beside, cousin, you must know, to play the
fool is the science in France, and I didde go to the
Italian academy at Paris thrice a-week to learn to play
de fool of Signior Scaramouche,<a name="FNanchor_60_60" id="FNanchor_60_60"></a><a href="#Footnote_60_60" class="fnanchor">[60]</a> who is the most
excellent personage in the world for dat noble science.
Angel is a dam English fool to him.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Methinks, now, Angel is a very good fool.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Naugh, naugh, Nokes is a better fool; but
indeed the Englis are not fit to be fools: here are ver<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_175" id="Page_175">[Pg 175]</a></span>
few good fools. 'Tis true, you have many a young
cavalier who go over into France to learn to be de
buffoon; but for all dat, dey return but <i>mauvais</i> buffoon,
<i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I'm sure, cousin, you have lost no time there.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, <i>le brave</i> Scaramouche!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But is it a science in France, cousin? and is
there an academy for fooling? sure none go to it but
players.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Dey are comedians dat are de <i>maîtres</i>; but all
the <i>beau monde</i> go to learn, as they do here of Angel and
Nokes. For if you did go abroad into company, you
would find the best almost of de nation conning in all
places the lessons which dey have learned of the fools
dere <i>maîtres</i>, Nokes and Angel.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Yes, yes, dey are de <i>gens de qualité</i> that practise
dat science most, and the most <i>ambitieux</i>; for fools and
buffoons have been always most welcome to courts, and
desired in all companies. Auh, to be de fool, de buffoon,
is to be de great personage.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Fools have fortune, they say, indeed.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> So say old Senèque.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, cousin, not to make you proud, you are
the greatest fool in England, I am sure.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, non, de grace; non:</i> Nokes de comedian
is a pretty man, a pretty man for a comedian, da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You are modest, cousin.&mdash;But lest my father
should come in presently, which he will do as soon as he
knows you are here, I must give you a caution, which 'tis
fit you should have before you see him.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Vell, vell, cousin, vat is dat?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You must know, then (as commonly the conclusion
of all mirth is sad), after I had a good while
pleased myself in jesting, and leading the poor gentleman
you sent into a fool's paradise, and almost made him
believe I would go away with him, my father, coming<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_176" id="Page_176">[Pg 176]</a></span>
home this morning, came in upon us, and caught him
with me.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Malepeste!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> And drew his sword upon him, and would have
killed him; for you know my father's Spanish fierceness
and jealousy.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But how did he come off then, <i>tête non?</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> In short, I was fain to bring him off by saying he
was my dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! ver good jeste.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I was unwilling to have the poor man killed, you
know, for our foolish frolic with him: but then, upon my
aunt's and father's inquiry, how he came in, and who sent
him, I was forced to say you did, desiring I should be
able to dance a corant before our wedding.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> A ver good jest&mdash;da&mdash;still better as better.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Now, all that I am to desire of you is, to own
you sent him, that I may not be caught in a lie.</p>

<p><i>Mons</i> Yes, yes, a ver good jest: Gerrard a <i>maître de
danse!</i> ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, the jest is like to be better yet; for my
father himself has obliged him now to come and teach
me: so that now he must take the dancing-master upon
him, and come three or four times to me before our
wedding, lest my father, if he should come no more,
should be suspicious I had told him a lie. And, for
aught I know, if he should know, or but guess he were
not a dancing-master, in his Spanish strictness and
punctilios of honour, he might kill me as the shame and
stain of his honour and family, which he talks of so
much. Now, you know the jealous cruel fathers in
Spain serve their poor innocent daughters often so; and
he is more than a Spaniard.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Non, non,</i> fear noting; I warrant you, he shall
come as often as you will to de house; and your father
shall never know who he is till we are married. But
then I'll tell him all for the jest's sake.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_177" id="Page_177">[Pg 177]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But will you keep my counsel, dear cousin, till
we are married?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Poor dear fool! I warrant thee, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, what a fool am I indeed! for you would not
have me killed. You love me too well, sure, to be an
instrument of my death.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>, <i>walking gravely, a</i> Black boy <i>behind
him; and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p>But here comes my father, remember.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I would no more tell him of it than I would tell
you if I had been with a wench, <i>jarni!</i> [<i>Aside.</i>]&mdash;She's
afraid to be killed, poor wretch, and he's a capricious,
jealous fop enough to do't:&mdash;but here he comes.&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.] I'll keep thy counsel, I warrant thee, my
dear soul, <i>mon petit c&#339;ur.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Peace! peace! my father's coming this way.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, but by his march he won't be near enough
to hear us this half hour, ha! ha! ha!
[Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>walks leisurely round</i> Monsieur, <i>surveying
him, and shrugging up his shoulders,
whilst</i> Monsieur <i>makes legs and faces aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Is that thing my cousin, sister?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> 'Tis he, sir.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Cousin, I am sorry to see you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Is that a Spanish compliment?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> So much disguised, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Oh! is it out at last, <i>ventre?</i>&mdash;[<i>To</i>
Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.]&mdash;<i>Serviteur, serviteur, à monsieur mon oncle;</i>
and I am glad to see you here within doors, most
Spanish <i>oncle</i>, ha! ha! ha! but I should be sorry to see
you in the streets, <i>tête non!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why so?&mdash;would you be ashamed of me, hah&mdash;<i>voto
á St. Jago!</i> would you? hauh&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay; it may be you would be ashamed yourself,
<i>monsieur mon oncle</i>, of the great train you would get to
wait upon your Spanish hose, puh&mdash;the boys would<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_178" id="Page_178">[Pg 178]</a></span>
follow you, and hoot at you&mdash;<i>vert</i> and <i>bleu!</i> pardon my
Franch <i>franchise, monsieur mon oncle.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> We shall have sport anon, betwixt these two
contraries. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Dost thou call me "monsieur?" <i>voto á St. Jago!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, I did not call you Monsieur Voto á St.
Jago! Sir, I know you are my uncle, Mr. James Formal&mdash;da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> But I can hardly know you are my cousin, Mr.
Nathaniel Paris.&mdash;But call me, sir, Don Diego henceforward,
look you, and no monsieur. Call me monsieur!
<i>guarda!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I confess my error, sir; for none but a blind
man would call you monsieur, ha! ha!&mdash;But, pray, do
not call me neder Paris, but de Paris, de Paris, (<i>s'il vous
plait,</i>) Monsieur de Paris. Call me monsieur, and
welcome, da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Monsieur de Pantaloons then, <i>voto</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Monsieur de Pantaloons! a pretty name, a
pretty name, <i>ma foi!</i> da&mdash;<i>bien trouvé</i> de Pantaloons!
how much better den your de la Fountaines, de la
Rivieres, de la Roches, and all the <i>de's</i> in France&mdash;da&mdash;well;
but have you not the admiration for my
pantaloon, Don Diego, <i>mon oncle?</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I am astonished at them, <i>verdaderamente</i>, they
are wonderfully ridiculous.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Redicule! redicule! ah&mdash;'tis well you are my
uncle, da&mdash;redicule! ha&mdash;is dere any ting in the universe
so <i>gentil</i> as de pantaloons? any ting so <i>ravissant</i> as de
pantaloons? Auh&mdash;I could kneel down and varship
a pair of <i>gentil</i> pantaloons. Vat, vat, you would have me
have de admiration for dis outward skin of your thigh,
which you call Spanish hose, fi! fi! fi!&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Dost thou deride my Spanish hose, young man,
hauh?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> In comparison of pantaloon, I do undervalue
'em indeed, Don Diego, <i>mon oncle</i>, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_179" id="Page_179">[Pg 179]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Thou art then a <i>gabacho<a name="FNanchor_61_61" id="FNanchor_61_61"></a><a href="#Footnote_61_61" class="fnanchor">[61]</a> de mal gusto</i>, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> You may call me vat you vill, <i>oncle</i> Don
Diego; but I must needs say, your Spanish hose are
scurvy hose, ugly hose, lousy hose, and stinking hose.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Do not provoke me, <i>borracho!</i>
[<i>Puts his hand to his sword.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Indeet, as for lousy, I recant dat epithete, for
dere is scarce room in 'em for dat little animal, ha! ha!
ha! but for stinking hose, dat epithete may stand; for
how can they choose but stink, since they are so
<i>furieusement</i> close to your Spanish tail, da?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ha! ha! ridiculous! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Do not provoke me, I say, <i>en hora mala!</i>
[<i>Seems to draw.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, <i>oncle</i>, I am sorry you are in de pation;
but I must live and die for de pantaloon against de
Spanish hose, da.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You are a rash young man; and while you wear
pantaloons, you are beneath my passion, <i>voto</i>&mdash;auh&mdash;they
make thee look and waddle (with all those gewgaw
ribbons) like a great, old, fat, slovenly water dog.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And your Spanish hose, and your nose in the
air, make you look like a great, grizzled, long Irish greyhound
reaching a crust off from a high shelf, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Don. Bueno! bueno!</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What, have you a mind to ruin yourself
and break off the match?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pshaw&mdash;wat do you tell me of the matche! d'ye
tinke I will not vindicate pantaloons, <i>morbleu!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, he is a lost young man, I see, and
desperately far gone in the epidemic malady of our
nation, the affectation of the worst of French vanities:
but I must be wiser than him, as I am a Spaniard.
Look you, Don Diego, and endeavour to reclaim him by<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_180" id="Page_180">[Pg 180]</a></span>
art and fair means, look you, Don Diego; if not, he
shall never marry my daughter, look you, Don
Diego, though he be my own sister's son, and has two
thousand five hundred seventy-three pounds sterling,
twelve shillings and twopence a year pennyrent, <i>seguramente!</i>&mdash;[<i>To</i>
Monsieur.] Come, young man, since you
are so obstinate, we will refer our difference to arbitration;
your mistress, my daughter, shall be umpire betwixt us,
concerning Spanish hose and pantaloons.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pantaloons and Spanish hose, <i>s'il vous plait</i>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Your mistress is the fittest judge of your dress, sure.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I know ver vel dat most of the <i>jeunesse</i> of
England will not change de ribband upon de crevat
without de consultation of dere <i>maîtresse</i>; but I am no
<i>Anglais</i>, da&mdash;nor shall I make de reference of my dress
to any in the universe, da&mdash;I judge by any in England!
<i>tête non!</i> I would not be judge by any English looking-glass,
<i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Be not <i>positivo</i>, young man.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, pray refer it, cousin, pray do.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Non, non, your servant, your servant, aunt.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> But, pray, be not so positive. Come hither,
daughter, tell me which is best.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, father, you have kept me in universal
ignorance, I know nothing.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And do you tink I shall refer an affair of that
consequence to a poor young ting who have not seen the
vorld, da? I am wiser than so, <i>voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, in short, if you will not be wiser, and leave
off your French dress, stammering, and tricks, look you,
you shall be a fool, and go without my daughter, <i>voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! must I leave off my jantee French
accoutrements, and speak base Englis too, or not marry
my cousin, <i>mon oncle</i> Don Diego? Do not break
off the match, do not; for know, I will not leave off my
pantaloon and French pronuntiation for ne'er a cousin in
England't, da.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_181" id="Page_181">[Pg 181]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I tell you again, he that marries my daughter
shall at least look like a wise man, for he shall wear the
Spanish habit; I am a Spanish <i>positivo</i>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ver vel! ver vel! and I am a French <i>positivo</i>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Then I am <i>definitivo</i>; and if you do not go
immediately into your chamber, and put on a Spanish
habit, I have brought over on purpose for your wedding-clothes,
and put off all these French fopperies and
<i>vanidades</i>, with all your grimaces, agreeables, adorables,
<i>ma fois</i>, and <i>jarnis</i>; I swear you shall never marry my
daughter (and by an oath by Spaniard never broken) by
my whiskers and snuff-box!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> O hold! do not swear, uncle, for I love your
daughter <i>furieusement</i>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> If you love her, you'll obey me.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, wat will become of me! but have the
consideration. Must I leave off all the Franch <i>beautés</i>,
graces, and embellisments, bote of my person, and
language?
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>,
<i>laughing.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I will have it so.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I am ruinne den, undonne. Have some consideration
for me, for dere is not de least ribbon of my
<i>garniture</i> but is as dear to me as your daughter, <i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Then, you do not deserve her; and for that
reason I will be satisfied you love her better, or you shall
not have her, for I am <i>positivo</i>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Vill you break mine arte? Pray have de consideration
for me.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I say again, you shall be dressed before night
from top to toe in the Spanish habit, or you shall never
marry my daughter, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> If you will not have de consideration for me,
have de consideration for your daughter; for she have
de passionate <i>amour</i> for me, and like me in dis habite
bettre den in yours, da.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_182" id="Page_182">[Pg 182]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What I have said I have said, and I am <i>un
positivo</i>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Will you not so mush as allow me one little
French oate?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, you shall look like a Spaniard, but speak
and swear like an Englishman, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons. Hélas! hélas!</i> den I shall take my leave, <i>mort!
tête! ventre! jarni! tête bleu! ventre bleu! ma foi!</i> certes!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> [<i>Calls at the door.</i>] Pedro, Sanchez, wait upon
this <i>cavaliero</i> into his chamber with those things I ordered
you to take out of the trunks.&mdash;I would have you a little
accustomed to your clothes before your wedding; for, if
you comply with me, you shall marry my daughter to-morrow,
look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Adieu then, dear pantaloon! dear belte! dear
sword! dear peruke! and dear <i>chapeau retroussé</i>, and
dear shoe, <i>jarni!</i> adieu! adieu! adieu! <i>Hélas!
hélas! hélas!</i> will you have yet no pity?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I am a Spanish <i>positivo</i>, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And more cruel than de Spanish inquisitiono,
to compel a man to a habit against his conscience;
<i>hélas! hélas! hélas!</i> [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span> <i>with</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Here's the dancing-master, shall I call my
mistress, sir?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Yes.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.] O, you are as punctual
as a Spaniard: I love your punctual men; nay, I think
'tis before your time something.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nay, I am resolved your daughter, sir, shall lose
no time by my fault.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> So, so, 'tis well.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I were a very unworthy man, if I should not be
punctual with her, sir.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You speak honestly, very honestly, friend; and
I believe a very honest man, though a dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I am very glad you think me so, sir.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_183" id="Page_183">[Pg 183]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, you are but a young man, are you married
yet?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, sir; but I hope I shall, sir, very suddenly,
if things hit right.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, the old folks her friends are wary, and
cannot agree with you so soon as the daughter can?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, sir, the father hinders it a little at present;
but the daughter, I hope, is resolved, and then we shall
do well enough.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! you do not steal her, according to the
laudable custom of some of your brother dancing-masters?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, no, sir; steal her, sir! steal her! you are
pleased to be merry, sir, ha! ha! ha!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I cannot
but laugh at that question.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, sir, methinks you are pleased to be merry,
but you say the father does not consent?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Not yet, sir; but 'twill be no matter whether he
does or no.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Was she one of your scholars? if she were, 'tis a
hundred to ten but you steal her.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I shall not be able to hold laughing.
[<i>Laughs.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, nay, I find by your laughing you steal her:
she was your scholar; was she not?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, sir, she was the first I ever had, and may be
the last too; for she has a fortune (if I can get her) will
keep me from teaching to dance any more.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> So, so, then she is your scholar still it seems,
and she has a good portion; I'm glad on't; nay, I knew
you stole her.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] My laughing may give him suspicions,
yet I cannot hold. [<i>Laughs.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! you laugh, I warrant, to think how the
young baggage and you will mump the poor old father!
but if all her dependence for a fortune be upon the
father, he may chance to mump you both and spoil the
jest.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_184" id="Page_184">[Pg 184]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I hope it will not be in his power, sir, ha! ha!
ha!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I shall laugh too much anon.&mdash;[<i>To</i> Don
<span class="smcap">Diego</span>.] Pray, sir, be pleased to call for your daughter, I
am impatient till she comes, for time was never more
precious with me, and with her too; it ought to be so,
sure, since you say she is to be married to-morrow.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> She ought to bestir her, as you say, indeed. Wuh,
daughter! daughter! Prue! Hippolita! come away,
child, why do you stay so long? [<i>Calls at the door.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita, Prue</span>, <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Your servant, master; indeed I am ashamed you
have stayed for me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> O, good madam, 'tis my duty; I know you came
as soon as you could.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I knew my father was with you, therefore I did
not make altogether so much haste as I might; but if
you had been alone, nothing should have kept me from
you. I would not have been so rude as to have made
you stay a minute for me, I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, fiddle faddle, what a deal of ceremony
there is betwixt your dancing-master and you, <i>cuerno!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Lord, sir! I hope you'll allow me to show my
respect to my master, for I have a great respect for my
master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And I am very proud of my scholar, and am a
very great honourer of my scholar.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, friend, about your business, and
honour the king.&mdash;[<i>To</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.] Your dancing-masters
and barbers are such finical, smooth-tongued,
tattling fellows; and if you set 'em once a-talking, they'll
ne'er a-done, no more than when you set 'em a-fiddling:
indeed, all that deal with fiddles are given to impertinency.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Well, well, this is an impertinent fellow,
without being a dancing-master. He is no more a
dancing-master than I am a maid.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_185" id="Page_185">[Pg 185]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! will you still be wiser than I? <i>voto!</i>&mdash;Come,
come, about with my daughter, man.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> So he would, I warrant you, if your worship
would let him alone.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How now, Mrs. Nimblechaps!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, though I have got a little canting at the
dancing-school since I was here, yet I do all so bunglingly,
he'll discover me. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Try.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come take my hand,
master.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Look you, brother, the impudent harlotry
gives him her hand.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Can he dance with her without holding her by
the hand?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Here, take my hand, master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I wish it were for good and all. [<i>Aside to her.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You dancing-masters are always so hasty, so
nimble.</p>

<p><i>Don. Voto á St. Jago!</i> not that I see; about with her,
man.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Indeed, sir, I cannot about with her as I would
do, unless you will please to go out a little, sir; for I see
she is bashful still before you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Hey, hey, more fooling yet! come, come, about,
about with her.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, indeed, father, I am ashamed, and cannot
help it.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> But you shall help it, for I will not stir. Move
her, I say.&mdash;Begin, hussy, move when he'll have you.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> I cannot but laugh at that, ha! ha! ha! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.] Come, then, madam, since
it must be so, let us try; but I shall discover all.&mdash;One,
two, and coupee.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, d'ye see how he squeezes her hand,
brother! O the lewd villain!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, move, I say, and mind her not.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, three, four, and turn round.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_186" id="Page_186">[Pg 186]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> D'ye see again? he took her by the bare
arm.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, move on, she's mad.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, and a coupee.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, one, two, and turn out your toes.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> There, there, he pinched her by the thigh:
will you suffer it?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, three, and fall back.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Fall back, fall back, back; some of you are forward
enough to back.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Back, madam.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Fall back, when he bids you, hussy.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> How! how! fall back, fall back! marry,
but she shall not fall back when he bids her.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I say she shall.&mdash;Huswife, come.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> She will, she will, I warrant you, sir, if you won't
be angry with her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Do you know what he means by that now?
You a Spaniard!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How's that? I not a Spaniard! say such a
word again&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come forward, madam, three steps again.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> See, see, she squeezes his hand now: O
the debauched harlotry!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> So, so, mind her not; she moves forward pretty
well; but you must move as well backward as forward,
or you'll never do anything to purpose.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Do you know what you say, brother,
yourself, now? are you at your beastliness before your
young daughter?</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How now, mistress, are you so merry?&mdash;Is this
your staid maid as you call her, sister Impertinent?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I have not much to say to you, miss; but I shall
not have an opportunity to do it, unless we can get your
father out. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, about again with her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_187" id="Page_187">[Pg 187]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Look you there, she squeezes his hand
hard again.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, and indeed, father, my aunt puts
me quite out: I cannot dance while she looks on
for my heart, she makes me ashamed and afraid together.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Indeed, if you would please to take her out, sir, I
am sure I should make my scholar do better, than when
you are present, sir. Pray, sir, be pleased for this time
to take her away; for the next time, I hope I shall
order it so, we shall trouble neither of you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, no, brother, stir not, they have a mind
to be left alone. Come, there's a beastly trick in't; he's
no dancing-master, I tell you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Damned jade! she'll discover us.
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, will you teach me? nay, then I will go
out, and you shall go out too, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I will not go out, look you.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, thou art a censorious wicked
woman, and you shall disturb them no longer.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What! will you bawd for your daughter?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, ay; come go out, out, out.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I will not go out, I will not go out; my
conscience will not suffer me, for I know by experience
what will follow.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I warrant you, sir, we'll make good use of our
time when you are gone.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Do you hear him again? don't you know
what he means?
[<i>Exit</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>thrusting</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span> <i>out.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Tis very well!&mdash;you are a fine gentleman to
abuse my poor father so.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> 'Tis but by your example, miss.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, I am his daughter, and may make the
bolder with him, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And I am his son-in-law, that shall be; and<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_188" id="Page_188">[Pg 188]</a></span>
therefore may claim my privilege too of making bold
with him, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Methinks you should be contented in making
bold with his daughter (for you have made very bold
with her) sure.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I hope I shall make bolder with her yet.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I do not doubt your confidence, for you are a
dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Why, miss, I hope you would not have me a fine,
senseless, whining, modest lover; for modesty in a man
is as ill as the want of it in a woman.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I thank you for that, sir, now you have made
bold with me indeed; but if I am such a confident piece,
I am sure you made me so: if you had not had the
confidence to come in at the window, I had not had the
confidence to look upon a man: I am sure I could not
look upon a man before.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But that I humbly conceive, sweet miss, was
your father's fault, because you had not a man to look
upon. But, dearest miss, I do not think you confident,
you are only innocent; for that which would be called
confidence, nay impudence, in a woman of years, is called
innocency in one of your age; and the more impudent you
appear, the more innocent you are thought.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Say you so? has youth such privileges? I do not
wonder then, most women seem impudent, since it is to
be thought younger than they are, it seems. But indeed,
master, you are as great an encourager of impudence, I
see, as if you were a dancing-master in good earnest.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, yes, a young thing may do anything; may
leap out of the window and go away with her dancing
master, if she please.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So, so, the use follows the doctrine very suddenly.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, dearest, pray let us make the use we should
of it; lest your father should make too bold with us, and
come in before we would have him.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, old relations are apt to take that ill-bred<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_189" id="Page_189">[Pg 189]</a></span>
freedom of pressing into young company at unseasonable
hours.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, dear miss, let me tell you how I have designed
matters; for in talking of anything else we lose
time and opportunity. People abroad indeed say, the
English women are the worst in the world in using an
opportunity, they love tittle-tattle and ceremony.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Tis because, I warrant, opportunities are not so
scarce here as abroad, they have more here than they
can use; but let people abroad say what they will of
English women, because they do not know 'em, but what
say people at home?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Pretty innocent! ha! ha! ha!&mdash;Well, I say you
will not make use of your opportunity.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I say, you have no reason to say so yet.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well then, anon at nine of the clock at night I'll
try you: for I have already bespoke a parson, and have
taken up the three back-rooms of the tavern, which front
upon the gallery-window, that nobody may see us escape;
and I have appointed (precisely betwixt eight and nine of
the clock when it is dark) a coach and six to wait at the
tavern-door for us.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> A coach and six! a coach and six, do you say?
nay, then I see you are resolved to carry me away; for a
coach and six, though there were not a man but the
coachman with it, would carry away any young girl of my
age in England:&mdash;a coach and six!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Then you will be sure to be ready to go with me?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What young woman of the town could ever say
no to a coach and six, unless it were going into the
country?&mdash;A coach and six! 'tis not in the power of
fourteen years old to resist it.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> You will be sure to be ready?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You are sure 'tis a coach and six?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I warrant you, miss.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I warrant you then they'll carry us merrily away:&mdash;a
coach and six!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_190" id="Page_190">[Pg 190]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But have you charmed your cousin the monsieur
(as you said you would) that he in the mean time say
nothing to prevent us?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I warrant you.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>; Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span> <i>pressing in after
him.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I will come in.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, I hope by this time you have given her full
instructions; you have told her what and how to do,
you have done all.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> We have just done indeed, sir.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ay, sir, we have just done, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> And I fear just undone, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> D'ye hear that damned witch?
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, leave your censorious prating; thou hast
been a false, right woman thyself in thy youth, I warrant
you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I right! I right! I scorn your words, I'd
have you to know, and 'tis well known. I right! no,
'tis your dainty minx, that Jillflirt, your daughter here,
that is right; do you see how her handkerchief is
ruffled, and what a heat she's in?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> She has been dancing.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Ay, ay, Adam and Eve's dance, or the
beginning of the world; d'ye see how she pants?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> She has not been used to motion.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Motion! motion! motion d'ye call it? no
indeed, I kept her from motion till now: motion with a
vengeance!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You put the poor bashful girl to the blush, you
see, hold your peace.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> 'Tis her guilt, not her modesty, marry!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, mind her not, child.&mdash;Come,
master, let me see her dance now the whole dance
roundly together; come, sing to her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_191" id="Page_191">[Pg 191]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Faith; we shall be discovered after all; you
know I cannot sing a note, miss. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, man.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, father, my master's in haste now; pray
let it alone till anon at night, when, you say, he is to
come again, and then you shall see me dance it to the
violin; pray stay till then, father.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I will not be put off so; come, begin.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Pray, father.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, sing to her; come, begin.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Pray, sir, excuse me till anon, I am in some
haste.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I say, begin, I will not excuse you: come, take
her by the hand, and about with her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I say, he shall not take her by the hand,
he shall touch her no more; while I am here, there
shall be no more squeezing and tickling her palm. Good
Mr. Dancing-master, stand off. [<i>Thrusts</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>away.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Get you out, Mrs. Impertinence.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.]
Take her by the hand, I say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Stand off, I say. He shall not touch her,
he has touched her too much already.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> If patience were not a Spanish virtue, I would
lay it aside now: I say, let 'em dance.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I say, they shall not dance.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Pray, father, since you see my aunt's obstinacy,
let us alone till anon, when you may keep her out.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well then, friend, do not fail to come.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, if he fail me at last&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Be sure you come, for she's to be married to-morrow:&mdash;do
you know it?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, yes, sir.&mdash;Sweet scholar, your humble
servant, till night; and think in the mean time of the
instructions I have given you, that you may be the
readier when I come.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, girl, be sure you do,&mdash;and do you be sure
to come.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_192" id="Page_192">[Pg 192]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> You need not be so concerned, he'll be
sure to come I warrant you; but if I could help it, he
should never set foot again in the house.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You would frighten the poor dancing-master
from the house,&mdash;but be sure you come for all her.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, sir.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] But this jade will pay me
when I am gone.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Hold, hold, sir, I must let you out, and I
wish I could keep you out. He a dancing-master! he's
a chouse, a cheat, a mere cheat, and that you'll find.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I find any man a cheat! I cheated by any man!
I scorn your words.&mdash;I that have so much Spanish care,
circumspection, and prudence, cheated by a man! Do
you think I, who have been in Spain, look you, and have
kept up my daughter a twelve month, for fear of being
cheated of her, look you? I cheated of her!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Well, say no more.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego, Hippolita</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>,
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, old Formality, if you had not kept up your
daughter, I am sure I had never cheated you of her.</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The wary fool is by his care betrayed,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">As cuckolds by their jealousy are made.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_193" id="Page_193">[Pg 193]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FOURTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris</span> <i>without a peruke, with a
Spanish hat, a Spanish doublet, stockings, and shoes,
but in pantaloons, a waist-belt, and a Spanish dagger
in it, and a cravat about his neck.</i>&mdash;<span class="smcap">Hippolita</span> <i>and</i>
<span class="smcap">Prue</span> <i>behind laughing.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> To see wat a fool love do make
of one, <i>jarni!</i> It do metamorphose
de brave man in de beast, de sot, de
animal.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, you may laugh, 'tis ver
vell, I am become as ridicule for you as can be, <i>morbleu!</i>
I have deform myself into a ugly Spaniard.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why, do you call this disguising yourself like a
Spaniard, while you wear pantaloons still, and the
cravat?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But is here not the double doublet, and the
Spanish dagger <i>aussi</i>?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But 'tis as long as the French sword, and worn
like it. But where's your Spanish beard, the thing of
most consequence?</p>

<p><i>Mons. Jarni!</i> do you tink beards are as easy to be
had as in the playhouses? non; but if here be no the
ugly long Spanish beard, here are, I am certain, the ugly
long Spanish ear.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> That's very true, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh de ingrate, dat de woman is! wen we<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_194" id="Page_194">[Pg 194]</a></span>
poor men are your gallants, you laugh at us yourselves,
and wen we are your husband, you make all the world
laugh at us, <i>jarni!</i>&mdash;Love, dam love, it makes the man
more ridicule, than poverty, poetry, or a new title of
honour, <i>jarni!</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! at your <i>jarnis</i> still? <i>voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why, <i>oncle</i>, you are at your <i>votos</i> still.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, I'll allow you to be at your <i>votos</i> too, but
not to make the incongruous match of Spanish doublet,
and French pantaloons.
[<i>Holding his hat before his pantaloons.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, pray, dear <i>oncle</i>, let me unite France and
Spain; 'tis the mode of France now, <i>jarni, voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, I see I must pronounce: I told you, if you
were not dressed in the Spanish habit to-night, you
should not marry my daughter to-morrow, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well! am I not <i>habillé</i> in de Spanish habit?
my doublet, ear and hat, leg and feet, are Spanish, that
dey are.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I told you I was a Spanish <i>positivo, voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Will you not spare my pantaloon! begar, I
will give you one little finger to excuse my pantaloon, da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I have said, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, <i>cher</i> pantaloons! Speak for my pantaloons,
cousin. My poor pantaloons are as dear to me as
de scarf to de countree capitane, or de new-made officer:
therefore have de compassion for my pantaloons, Don
Diego, <i>mon oncle. Hélas! hélas! hélas!</i> [<i>Kneels.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I have said, look you, your dress must be
Spanish, and your language English: I am <i>un positivo</i>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And must speak base good English too! Ah!
<i>la pitié! hélas!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> It must be done; and I will see this great
change ere it be dark, <i>voto!</i>&mdash;Your time is not long;
look to't, look you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_195" id="Page_195">[Pg 195]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons. Hélas! hélas! hélas!</i> dat <i>Espagne</i> should conquer
<i>la France</i> in England! <i>Hélas! hélas! hélas!</i> [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You see what pains I take to make him the
more agreeable to you, daughter.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But indeed, and indeed, father, you wash the
blackamoor white, in endeavouring to make a Spaniard
of a monsieur, nay, an English monsieur too; consider
that, father: for when once they have taken the French
<i>plie</i> (as they call it) they are never to be made so much
as Englishmen again, I have heard say.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! I warrant you are like the rest of the
young silly baggages of England, that like nothing but
what is French? You would not have him reformed,
you would have a monsieur to your husband, would you,
<i>cuerno</i>?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, indeed, father, I would not have a monsieur
to my husband; not I indeed: and I am sure you'll
never make my cousin otherwise.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You can't, you can't indeed, father: and you
have sworn, you know, he shall never have me, if he does
not leave off his monsieurship. Now, as I told you, 'tis
as hard for him to cease being a monsieur, as 'tis for you
to break a Spanish oath; so that I am not in any great
danger of having a monsieur to my husband.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, but you shall have him for your husband,
look you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Then you will break your Spanish oath.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, I will break him of his French tricks; and
you shall have him for your husband, <i>cuerno!</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed and indeed, father, I shall not have him.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Indeed you shall, daughter.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, you shall see, father.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> No, I warrant you, she will not have him,
she'll have her dancing-master rather: I know her meaning,
I understand her.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Thou malicious foolish woman! you understand<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_196" id="Page_196">[Pg 196]</a></span>
her!&mdash;But I do understand her; she says, I will not
break my oath, nor he his French customs; so, through
our difference, she thinks she shall not have him: but
she shall.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But I shan't.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I know she will not have him, because she hates him.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I tell you, if she does hate him, 'tis a sign she
will have him for her husband; for 'tis not one of a thousand
that marries the man she loves, look you. Besides,
'tis all one whether she loves him now or not; for as soon
as she's married, she'd be sure to hate him. That's the
reason we wise Spaniards are jealous, and only expect,
nay, will be sure our wives shall fear us, look you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Pray, good father and aunt, do not dispute about
nothing; for I am sure he will never be my husband to
hate.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I am of your opinion, indeed; I understand
you. I can see as far as another.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You! you cannot see so much as through your
spectacles!&mdash;But I understand her: 'tis her mere desire
to marriage makes her say she shall not have him; for
your poor young things, when they are once in the teens,
think they shall never be married.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, father, think you what you will; but I know
what I think.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris</span> <i>in the Spanish habit entire,
only with a cravat, and followed by the little</i> Blackamoor
<i>with a golilla</i><a name="FNanchor_62_62" id="FNanchor_62_62"></a><a href="#Footnote_62_62" class="fnanchor">[62]</a> <i>in his hand.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, did not I tell you, you should have him?
look you there, he has complied with me, and is a perfect
Spaniard.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay! ay! I am ugly rogue enough now, sure,
for my cousin. But 'tis your father's fault, cousin, that<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_197" id="Page_197">[Pg 197]</a></span>
you han't the handsomest, best-dressed man in the nation;
a man <i>bien mis</i>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Yet again at your French! and a cravat on still!
<i>voto á St. Jago!</i> off, off, with it!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, I will ever hereafter speak clownish good
English, do but spare me my cravat.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I am <i>un positivo</i>, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Let me not put on that Spanish yoke, but spare
me my cravat; for I love cravat <i>furieusement</i>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Again at your <i>furieusements!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Indeed I have forgot myself: but have some
mercy. [<i>Kneels.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Off, off, off with it, I say! Come, refuse the <i>ornamento</i>
principal of the Spanish habit!
[<i>Takes him by the cravat, pulls it off, and the</i>
Black <i>puts on the golilla.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Will you have no mercy, no pity? alas! alas!
alas! Oh! I had rather put on the English pillory, than
that Spanish <i>golilla</i>, for 'twill be all a case I'm sure:
for when I go abroad, I shall soon have a crowd of boys
about me, peppering me with rotten eggs and turnips.
<i>Hélas! hélas!</i> [Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>puts on the golilla.</i></p>

<p><i>Don. Hélas</i>, again!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Alas! alas! alas!</p>

<p>
<i>Hip.</i> I shall die!&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;}<br />
<span style="margin-left: 8em;">} Ha! ha! ha!</span><br />
<i>Prue.</i> I shall burst! }<br />
</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay! ay! you see what I am come to for your
sake, cousin: and, uncle, pray take notice how ridiculous
I am grown to my cousin, that loves me above all the
world: she can no more forbear laughing at me, I vow
and swear, than if I were as arrant a Spaniard as yourself.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Be a Spaniard like me, and ne'er think people
laugh at you: there was never a Spaniard that thought
any one laughed at him. But what! do you laugh at a
<i>golilla</i>, baggage? Come, sirrah black, now do you teach
him to walk with the <i>verdadero gesto, gracia,</i> and <i>gravidad</i>
of a true Castilian.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_198" id="Page_198">[Pg 198]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Must I have my dancing-master too?&mdash;Come,
little master, then, lead on.
[<i>The</i> Black <i>struts about the stage,</i> Monsieur
<i>follows him, imitating awkwardly all he does.</i></p>

<p><i>Don. Malo! malo!</i> with your hat on your poll, as it
it hung upon a pin!&mdash;the French and English wear their
hats as if their horns would not suffer 'em to come over
their foreheads, <i>voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> 'Tis true, there are some well-bred gentlemen
have so much reverence for their peruke, that they would
refuse to be grandees of your Spain for fear of putting on
their hats, I vow and swear!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, black, teach him now to make a Spanish
leg.<a name="FNanchor_63_63" id="FNanchor_63_63"></a><a href="#Footnote_63_63" class="fnanchor">[63]</a></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! your Spanish leg is an English
courtesy, I vow and swear, hah! hah! hah!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, the hood does not make the monk; the ass
was an ass still, though he had the lion's skin on. This
will be a light French fool, in spite of the grave Spanish
habit, look you.&mdash;But, black, do what you can; make
the most of him; walk him about.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Here are the people, sir, you sent to speak
about provisions for the wedding; and here are
clothes brought home too, mistress.
[<i>Goes to the door and returns.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, I come.&mdash;Black, do what you can with
him; walk him about.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Indeed, uncle, if I were as you, I would not
have the grave Spanish habit so travestied: I shall disgrace
it, and my little black master too, I vow and swear.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Learn, learn of him; improve yourself by him&mdash;and
do you walk him, walk him about soundly.&mdash;Come,
sister, and daughter, I must have your judgments, though
I shall not need 'em, look you.&mdash;Walk him, see you walk
him.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego, Hippolita</span>, <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_199" id="Page_199">[Pg 199]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons. Jarni!</i> he does not only make a Spaniard of
me, but a Spanish jennet, in giving me to his lackey to
walk.&mdash;But come along, little master.
[<i>The</i> Black <i>instructs</i> Monsieur <i>on one side of
the stage</i>, <span class="smcap">Prue</span> <i>standing on the other.</i></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> O the unfortunate condition of us poor chambermaids!
who have all the carking and caring, the watching
and sitting up, the trouble and danger of our mistresses'
intrigues, whilst they go away with all the
pleasure! And if they can get their man in a corner, 'tis
well enough; they ne'er think of the poor watchful
chambermaid, who sits knocking her heels in the cold,
for want of better exercise, in some melancholy lobby or
entry, when she could employ her time every whit as
well as her mistress, for all her quality, if she were but
put to't. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Black.</i> Hold up your head, hold up your head sir:&mdash;a
stooping Spaniard, <i>malo!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> True, a Spaniard scorns to look upon the
ground.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> We can shift for our mistresses, and not for
ourselves. Mine has got a handsome proper young man,
and is just going to make the most of him; whilst I must
be left in the lurch here with a couple of ugly little blackamoor
boys in bonnets, and an old withered Spanish
eunuch; not a servant else in the house, nor have I
hopes of any comfortable society at all. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Black.</i> Now let me see you make your visit-leg, thus.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Auh, <i>tête non!</i>&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Black.</i> What! a Spaniard, and laugh aloud! No, if
you laugh, thus only&mdash;so&mdash;Now your salutation in the
street, as you pass by your acquaintance; look you, thus&mdash;if
to a woman, thus&mdash;putting your hat upon your
heart; if to a man, thus, with a nod&mdash;so&mdash;but frown a
little more, frown:&mdash;but if to a woman you would be very
ceremonious to, thus&mdash;so&mdash;your neck nearer your
shoulder&mdash;so&mdash;Now, if you would speak contemptibly of any man,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_200" id="Page_200">[Pg 200]</a></span>
or thing, do thus with your hand&mdash;so&mdash;and shrug up your
shoulders till they hide your ears.&mdash;[Monsieur <i>imitating
the</i> Black.] Now walk again.
[<i>The</i> Black <i>and</i> Monsieur <i>walk off the stage.</i></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> All my hopes are in that coxcomb there: I must
take up with my mistress's leavings, though we chambermaids
are wont to be beforehand with them. But he is
the dullest, modestest fool, for a frenchified fool, as ever I
saw; for nobody could be more coming to him than I
have been, though I say it, and yet I am ne'er the
nearer. I have stolen away his handkerchief, and told
him of it; and yet he would never so much as struggle
with me to get it again: I have pulled off his peruke,
untied his ribbons, and have been very bold with him:
yet he would never be so with me: nay, I have pinched
him, punched him and tickled him; and yet he would
never do the like for me.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter the</i> Black <i>and</i> Monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Black.</i> Nay, thus, thus, sir.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> And to make my person more acceptable to
him, I have used art, as they say; for every night since
he came, I have worn the forehead-piece of bees-wax and
hog's-grease, and every morning washed with butter-milk
and wild tansy; and have put on every day for his only
sake my Sunday's bowdy<a name="FNanchor_64_64" id="FNanchor_64_64"></a><a href="#Footnote_64_64" class="fnanchor">[64]</a> stockings, and have new-chalked
my shoes, as constantly as the morning came: nay,
I have taken occasion to garter my stockings before him,
as if unawares of him; for a good leg and foot, with good
shoes and stockings, are very provoking, as they say;
but the devil a bit would he be provoked.&mdash;But I must
think of a way. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Black.</i> Thus, thus.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_201" id="Page_201">[Pg 201]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> What, so! Well, well, I have lessons enough for
this time, little master; I will have no more, lest the
multiplicity of them make me forget them, da.&mdash;Prue, art
thou there and so pensive? what art thou thinking of?</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Indeed, I am ashamed to tell your worship.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> What, ashamed! wert thou thinking then of my
beastliness? ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nay, then I am forced to tell your worship in my
own vindication.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come then.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> But indeed, your worship&mdash;I'm ashamed, that I
am, though it was nothing but a dream I had of your
sweet worship last night.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Of my sweet worship! I warrant it was a sweet
dream then:&mdash;what was it? ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nay, indeed, I have told your worship enough
already; you may guess the rest.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I cannot guess; ha! ha! ha! What should it
be? prithee let's know the rest.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Would you have me so impudent?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Impudent! ha! ha! ha! Nay, prithee tell me;
for I can't guess, da&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nay, 'tis always so, for want of the men's guessing
the poor women are forced to be impudent:&mdash;but I
am still ashamed.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I will know it; speak.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Why then, methought last night you came up
into my chamber in your shirt when I was in bed; and
that you might easily do, for I have ne'er a lock to my
door.&mdash;Now I warrant I am as red as my petticoat.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, thou'rt as yellow as e'er thou wert.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Yellow, sir!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay: but let's hear the dream out.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Why, can't you guess the rest now?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, not I, I vow and swear: come, let's hear.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> But can't you guess, in earnest?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Not I, the devil eat me!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_202" id="Page_202">[Pg 202]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Not guess yet! why then, methought you came
to bed to me.&mdash;Now am I as red as my petticoat again.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;well, and what then? ha! ha!
ha!</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nay, now I know by your worship's laughing
you guess what you did. I'm sure I cried out, and
waked all in tears, with these words in my mouth&mdash;"You
have undone me! you have undone me! your worship
has undone me!"</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;but you waked, and found it
was but a dream.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Indeed it was so lively, I know not whether
'twas a dream, or no.&mdash;But if you were not there, I'll
undertake you may come when you will, and do anything
to me you will, I sleep so fast.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, no; I don't believe that.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Indeed you may, your worship&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> It cannot be.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Insensible beast! he will not understand me
yet; and one would think I speak plain enough. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, but, Prue, what art thou thinking of?</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Of the dream, whether it were a dream or no.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> 'Twas a dream, I warrant thee.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Was it? I am hugeous glad it was a dream.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, it was a dream: and I am hugeous glad
it was a dream too.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> But now I have told your worship my door has
neither lock nor latch to it, if you should be so naughty
as to come one night, and prove the dream true&mdash;I am so
afraid on't.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ne'er fear it:&mdash;dreams go by the contraries.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Then, by that I should come into your worship's
chamber, and come to bed to your worship.&mdash;Now am I
as red as my petticoat again, I warrant.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, thou art no redder than a brick unburnt,
Prue.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> But if I should do such a trick in my sleep,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_203" id="Page_203">[Pg 203]</a></span>
your worship would not censure a poor harmless maid, I
hope?&mdash;for I am apt to walk in my sleep.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, then, Prue, because thou shalt not shame
thyself, poor wench, I'll be sure to lock my door every
night fast.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So! so! this way I find will not do:&mdash;I
must come roundly and downright to the business, like
other women, or&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> O, the dancing-master!</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Dear sir, I have something to say to you in your
ear, which I am ashamed to speak aloud.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Another time, another time, Prue. But now
go call your mistress to her dancing-master. Go, go.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nay, pray hear me, sir, first.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Another time, another time, Prue; prithee
begone.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Nay, I beseech your worship hear me.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No; prithee begone.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Nay, I am e'en well enough served for
not speaking my mind when I had an opportunity.&mdash;Well,
I must be playing the modest woman, forsooth! a
woman's hypocrisy in this case does only deceive herself.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> O, the brave dancing master! the fine dancing-master!
Your servant, your servant.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Your servant sir: I protest I did not know you
at first&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I am afraid this fool should spoil all,
notwithstanding Hippolita's care and management; yet
I ought to trust her:&mdash;but a secret is more safe with a
treacherous knave than a talkative fool.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come, sir, you must know a little brother
dancing-master of yours&mdash;walking master I should have
said; for he teaches me to walk and make legs, by-the-bye.
Pray, know him, sir; salute him, sir.&mdash;You Christian
dancing-masters are so proud.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_204" id="Page_204">[Pg 204]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But, monsieur, what strange metamorphosis is
this? You look like a Spaniard, and talk like an
Englishman again, which I thought had been impossible.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nothing impossible to love: I must do't, or
lose my mistress, your pretty scholar; for 'tis I am to
have her. You may remember I told you she was
to be married to a great man, a man of honour and
quality.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But does she enjoin you to this severe penance?&mdash;such
I am sure it is to you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, no: 'tis by the compulsion of the starched
fop her father, who is so arrant a Spaniard, he would kill
you and his daughter, if he knew who you were: therefore
have a special care to dissemble well.
[<i>Draws him aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Dear Gerrard&mdash;Go, little master, and call my
cousin: tell her her dancing-master is here. [<i>Exit the</i>
Black]&mdash;I say, dear Gerrard, faith, I'm obliged to you for
the trouble you have had. When I sent you, I intended a
jest indeed; but did not think it would have been so
dangerous a jest: therefore pray forgive me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I do, do heartily forgive you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But can you forgive me for sending you at first,
like a fool as I was? 'Twas ill done of me: can you
forgive me?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, yes, I do forgive you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, thou art a generous man, I vow and
swear, to come and take upon you all this trouble,
danger, and shame, to be thought a paltry dancing-master;
and all this to preserve a lady's honour and life,
who intended to abuse you. But I take the obligation
upon me.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Pish! pish! you are not obliged to me at all.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Faith, but I am strangely obliged to you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Faith, but you are not.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I vow and swear but I am.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_205" id="Page_205">[Pg 205]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I swear you are not.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, thou art so generous a dancing-master, ha!
ha! ha!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego, Hippolita</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>, <i>and</i>
<span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You shall not come in, sister.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I will come in.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You will not be civil.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I'm sure they will not be civil, if I do not
come in:&mdash;I must, I will.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, honest friend, you are very punctual, which
is a rare virtue in a dancing-master; I take notice of it,
and will remember it; I will, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> So, silly, damned, politic Spanish uncle!&mdash;ha!
ha! ha! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> My fine scholar, sir, there, shall never have
reason, as I have told you, sir, to say I am not a
punctual man; for I am more her servant than to any
scholar I ever had.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well said, i'faith!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Thou dost make a
pretty fool of him, I vow and swear. But I wonder
people can be made such fools of:&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, master, I thank you; and I hope I shall be
a grateful, kind scholar to you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! cunning little jilt, what a fool she
makes of him too! I wonder people can be made such
fools of, I vow and swear:&mdash;ha! ha! ha! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, it shall go hard but I'll be a grateful, kind
scholar to you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> As kind as ever your mother was to your
father, I warrant.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How! again with your senseless suspicions.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pish! pish! aunt&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Ha! ha! ha!
she's a fool another way: she thinks she loves him, ha!
ha! ha! Lord! that people should be such fools!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Come, come, I cannot but speak: I tell you,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_206" id="Page_206">[Pg 206]</a></span>
beware in time; for he is no dancing-master, but some
debauched person who will mump you of your daughter.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Will you be wiser than I still? Mump me of my
daughter! I would I could see any one mump me of my
daughter.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> And mump you of your mistress too,
young Spaniard.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! will you be wiser than I too,
<i>voto</i>? Mump me of my mistress! I would I could see
any one mump me of my mistress.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.] I am afraid this damned old aunt
should discover us, I vow and swear: be careful therefore
and resolute.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> He! he does not go about his business
like a dancing-master. He'll ne'er teach her to dance;
but he'll teach her no goodness soon enough, I warrant.&mdash;He
a dancing-master!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, the devil eat me if he be not the best
dancing-master in England now!&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.] Was not that well said, cousin? was it
not? for he's a gentleman dancing-master, you know.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You know him, cousin, very well? cousin, you
sent him to my daughter?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Yes, yes, uncle:&mdash;know him!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] We'll
ne'er be discovered, I warrant, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> But will you be made a fool of too?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, aunt, ne'er trouble yourself.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, friend, about your business; about with
my daughter.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, pray, father, be pleased to go out a little,
and let us practise awhile, and then you shall see me
dance the whole dance to the violin.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Tittle tattle! more fooling still!&mdash;Did not you
say, when your master was here last, I should see you
dance to the violin when he came again?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So I did, father: but let me practise a little first
before, that I may be perfect. Besides, my aunt is here,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_207" id="Page_207">[Pg 207]</a></span>
and she will put me out; you know I cannot dance
before her.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Fiddle faddle!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] They're afraid to be discovered by
Gerrard's bungling, I see.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come, come, uncle
turn out! let 'em practise.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I won't, <i>voto á St. Jago!</i> what a fooling's here.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come, come, let 'em practise: turn out, turn
out, uncle.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why can't she practise it before me?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come, dancers and singers are sometimes
humoursome; besides, 'twill be more grateful to you to
see it danced all at once to the violin. Come, turn out,
turn out, I say.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What a fooling's here still among you, <i>voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> So, there he is with you, <i>voto!</i>&mdash;Turn out, turn
out; I vow and swear you shall turn out.
[<i>Takes him by the shoulder.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, shall I see her dance it to the violin at
last?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, yes, sir; what do you think I teach her for?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Go, go, turn out.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.] And
you too, aunt.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Seriously, nephew, I shall not budge;
royally, I shall not.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Royally, you must, aunt: come.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Pray hear me, nephew.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I will not hear you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> 'Tis for your sake I stay: I must not
suffer you to be wronged.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come, no wheedling, aunt: come away.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> That slippery fellow will do't.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Let him do't.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Indeed he will do't; royally he will.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, let him do't, royally.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> He will wrong you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, let him, I say; I have a mind to be<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_208" id="Page_208">[Pg 208]</a></span>
wronged: what's that to you? I will be wronged, if you
go there too, I vow and swear.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> You shall not be wronged.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I will.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> You shall not.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What's the matter? won't she be ruled?&mdash;Come,
come away; you shall not disturb 'em.
[Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>and</i> Monsieur <i>try to thrust</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Caution</span> <i>out.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> D'ye see how they laugh at you both?&mdash;Well,
go to; the troth-telling Trojan gentlewoman of old
was ne'er believed till the town was taken, rummaged,
and ransacked. Even, even so&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! turn out&mdash;[<i>Exeunt</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>
<i>and</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.]&mdash;Lord, that people should be such
arrant cuddens!<a name="FNanchor_65_65" id="FNanchor_65_65"></a><a href="#Footnote_65_65" class="fnanchor">[65]</a> ha! ha! ha! But I may stay, may I not?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, no; I'd have you go out and hold the door,
cousin; or else my father will come in again before his
time.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I will, I will then, sweet cousin.&mdash;'Tis well
thought on; that was well thought on, indeed, for me to
hold the door.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But be sure you keep him out, cousin, till we
knock.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I warrant you, cousin.&mdash;Lord, that people
should be made such fools of! Ha! ha! ha! [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> So, so:&mdash;to make him hold the door, while I
steal his mistress, is not unpleasant.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ay, but would you do so ill a thing, so treacherous
a thing? Faith 'tis not well.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Faith, I can't help it, since 'tis for your sake.&mdash;Come,
sweetest, is not this our way into the gallery?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes; but it goes against my conscience to be accessory
to so ill a thing.&mdash;You say you do it for my sake?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_209" id="Page_209">[Pg 209]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Alas, poor miss! 'tis not against your conscience,
but against your modesty, you think, to do it frankly.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, if it be against my modesty, too, I can't do
it indeed.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, come, miss, let us make haste:&mdash;all's ready.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, faith, I can't satisfy my scruple.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, dearest, this is not a time for scruples
nor modesty.&mdash;Modesty between lovers is as impertinent
as ceremony between friends; and modesty is now as
unseasonable as on the wedding night.&mdash;Come away, my
dearest.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Whither?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nay, sure we have lost too much time already.
Is that a proper question now? If you would know,
come along; for I have all ready.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But I am not ready.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Truly, miss, we shall have your father come in
upon us, and prevent us again, as he did in the morning.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Twas well for me he did:&mdash;for, on my conscience,
if he had not come in, I had gone clear away with you
when I was in the humour.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, dearest, you would frighten me, as if you
were not yet in the same humour.&mdash;Come, come away;
the coach and six is ready.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Tis too late to take the air, and I am not ready.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> You were ready in the morning.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ay, so I was.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come, come, miss:&mdash;indeed the jest begins to be
none.</p>
