<p><i>Hip.</i> What! I warrant you think me in jest then?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> In jest, certainly; but it begins to be troublesome.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But, sir, you could believe I was in earnest in the
morning, when I but seemed to be ready to go with you;
and why won't you believe me now when I declare to the
contrary?&mdash;I take it unkindly, that the longer I am
acquainted with you, you should have the less confidence
in me.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_210" id="Page_210">[Pg 210]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> For Heaven's sake, miss, lose no more time thus;
your father will come in upon us, as he did&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Let him if he will.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> He'll hinder our design.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No, he will not; for mine is to stay here now.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Are you in earnest?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You'll find it so.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> How! why, you confessed but now you would
have gone with me in the morning.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I was in the humour then.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And I hope you are in the same still; you cannot
change so soon.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Why, is it not a whole day ago?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> What! are you not a day in the same humour?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Lord! that you who know the town, they say,
should think any woman could be a whole day together
in a humour!&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Hey! this begins to be pleasant.&mdash;What! won't
you go with me then after all?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No indeed, sir, I desire to be excused.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Then you have abused me all this while?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> It may be so.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Could all that so natural innocency be dissembled?&mdash;faith,
it could not, dearest miss.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Faith, it was, dear master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Was it, faith?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Methinks you might believe me without an oath.
You saw I could dissemble with my father, why should
you think I could not with you?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> So young a wheedle!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ay, a mere damned jade I am.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And I have been abused, you say?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> 'Tis well you can believe it at last.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> And I must never hope for you?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Would you have me abuse you again?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Then you will not go with me?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No: but, for your comfort, your loss will not be<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_211" id="Page_211">[Pg 211]</a></span>
great; and that you may not resent it, for once I'll be
ingenuous, and disabuse you.&mdash;I am no heiress, as I told
you, to twelve hundred pounds a-year; I was only a
lying jade then.&mdash;Now will you part with me willingly, I
doubt not.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I wish I could. [<i>Sighs.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Come, now I find 'tis your turn to dissemble:&mdash;but
men use to dissemble for money; will you dissemble
for nothing?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> 'Tis too late for me to dissemble.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Don't you dissemble, faith?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nay, this is too cruel.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What! would you take me without the twelve
hundred pounds a-year? would you be such a fool as to
steal a woman with nothing?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I'll convince you; for you shall go with me:&mdash;and
since you are twelve hundred pounds a-year the
lighter, you'll be the easier carried away.
[<i>He takes her in his arms, she struggles.</i></p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> What! he takes her way against her will:&mdash;I
find I must knock for my master then. [<i>She knocks.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My father! my father is here!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Prevented again! [<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>sets her down again.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, you have done I hope now, friend, for
good and all?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, yes; we have done for good and all
indeed.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How now!&mdash;you seem to be out of humour,
friend.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, so I am; I can't help it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> He's a dissembler in his very throat,
brother.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Pray do not carry things so as to discover yourself,
if it be but for my sake, good master.
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_212" id="Page_212">[Pg 212]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> She is grown impudent. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> See, see, they whisper, brother!&mdash;to steal
a kiss under a whisper!&mdash;O the harlotry!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What's the matter, friend?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I say, for my sake be in humour, and do not discover
yourself, but be as patient as a dancing-master still.
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, she is whispering to him indeed! What's
the matter? I will know it, friend, look you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Will you know it?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Yes, I will know it.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Why, if you will know it then, she would not do
as I would have her; and whispered me to desire me not
to discover it to you.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, hussy, would you not do as he'd have you?
I'll make you do as he'd have you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I wish you would.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> 'Tis a lie; she'll do all he'll have her do,
and more too, to my knowledge.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, tell me what 'twas then she would not do&mdash;come,
do it, hussy, or&mdash;Come, take her by the hand,
friend. Come, begin:&mdash;let's see if she will not do anything
now I'm here!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Come, pray be in humour, master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I cannot dissemble like you.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, she can't dissemble already, can she?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes, but she can: but 'tis with you she
dissembles: for they are not fallen out, as we think. For
I'll be sworn I saw her just now give him the languishing
eye, as they call it, that is, the whiting's eye, of old called
the sheep's eye:&mdash;I'll be sworn I saw it with these two
eyes; that I did.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You'll betray us; have a care, good master.
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Hold your peace, I say, silly woman!&mdash;but does
she dissemble already?&mdash;how do you mean?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> She pretends she can't do what she should do;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_213" id="Page_213">[Pg 213]</a></span>
and that she is not in humour.&mdash;The common excuse of
women for not doing what they should do.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, I'll put her in humour.&mdash;Dance, I say.&mdash;Come,
about with her, master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I am in a pretty humour to dance.&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.] I cannot fool any longer, since you have
fooled me.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You would not be so ungenerous as to betray the
woman that hated you! I do not do that yet. For
Heaven's sake! for this once be more obedient to my
desires than your passion. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! is she humoursome still?&mdash;but methinks
you look yourself as if you were in an ill-humour:&mdash;but
about with her.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I am in no good dancing humour, indeed.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, how goes the dancing forward?&mdash;What,
my aunt here to disturb 'em again?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come! come! [<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>leads her about.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I say, stand off;&mdash;thou shall not come
near. Avoid, Satan! as they say.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, then we shall have it:&mdash;nephew, hold her
a little, that she may not disturb 'em.&mdash;Come, now away
with her.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, and a coupee.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Fooled and
abused&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Wilt thou lay violent hands upon thy own
natural aunt, wretch? [<i>To</i> Monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, about with her.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, three, four, and turn round&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] by
such a piece of innocency!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Dost thou see, fool, how he squeezes her
hand? [<i>To</i> Monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> That won't do, aunt.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Pray, master, have patience, and let's mind our
business.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_214" id="Page_214">[Pg 214]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why did you anger him then, hussy, look you?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Do you see how she smiles in his face,
and squeezes his hand now? [<i>To</i> Monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Your servant, aunt.&mdash;That won't do, I say.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Have patience, master.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I am become her sport!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] One,
two, three&mdash;Death! hell! and the devil!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, they are three indeed!&mdash;But pray have
patience.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Do you see how she leers upon him, and
clings to him? Can you suffer it? [<i>To</i> Monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, three, and a slur.&mdash;Can you be so unconcerned
after all?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! is she unconcerned?&mdash;Hussy, mind your
business.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, three, and turn round;&mdash;one, two, fall
back&mdash;hell and damnation!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, people fall back indeed into hell and damnation,
Heaven knows!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> One, two, three, and your honour.&mdash;I can fool no
longer!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nor will I be withheld any longer, like a
poor hen in her pen, while the kite is carrying away her
chicken before her face.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What, have you done?&mdash;Well then, let's see her
dance it now to the violin.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, let's see her dance it to the violin.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Another time, another time.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Don't you believe that, friend:&mdash;these dancing-masters
make no bones of breaking their words. Did
not you promise just now, I should see her dance it to
the violin? and that I will too, before I stir.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Let monsieur play then while I dance with her&mdash;she
can't dance alone.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I can't play at all; I'm but a learner:&mdash;but if
you'll play, I'll dance with her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_215" id="Page_215">[Pg 215]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I can't play neither.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! a dancing-master, and not play!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Ay, you see what a dancing-master he is.
'Tis as I told you, I warrant.&mdash;A dancing-master, and
not play upon the fiddle!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O you have betrayed us all! If you confess that,
you undo us for ever. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I cannot play;&mdash;what would you have me say?
[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I vow and swear we are all undone if you cannot
play. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! are you a dancing-master, and cannot
play? Umph&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> He is only out of humour, sir.&mdash;Here, master, I
know you will play for me yet;&mdash;for he has an excellent
hand. [<i>She offers</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>the violin.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, that he has.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] At giving a box on the ear.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Why does he not play, then?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Here, master, pray play for my sake.
[<i>Gives</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>the violin.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> What would you have me do with it?&mdash;I cannot
play a stroke. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> No! stay&mdash;then seem to tune it, and break the
strings. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Come then.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Next to the devil's, the
invention of women! They'll no more want an excuse to
cheat a father with, than an opportunity to abuse a husband.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
But what do you give me such a damned
fiddle with rotten strings, for?
[<i>Winds up the strings till they break, and throws
the violin on the ground.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Hey-day! the dancing-master is frantic.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! That people should be made
such fools of! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> He broke the strings on purpose, because
he could not play.&mdash;You are blind, brother.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_216" id="Page_216">[Pg 216]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! will you see further than I, look you?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But pray, master, why in such haste?
[<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>offers to go.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Because you have done with me.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> But don't you intend to come to-morrow, again?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Your daughter does not desire it.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No matter; I do; I must be your paymaster, I'm
sure. I would have you come betimes too; not only to
make her perfect, but since you have so good a hand upon
the violin, to play your part with half-a-dozen of musicians
more, whom I would have you bring with you: for we
will have a very merry wedding, though a very private
one.&mdash;You'll be sure to come?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Your daughter does not desire it.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, baggage, you shall desire it of him;
he is your master.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> My father will have me desire it of you, it seems.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But you'll make a fool of me again if I should
come; would you not?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> If I should tell you so, you'd be sure not to come.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, she shall not make a fool of you,
upon my word. I'll secure you, she shall do what you
will have her.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! So, so, silly Don. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But, madam, will you have me come?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I'd have you to know, for my part, I care not
whether you come or no:&mdash;there are other dancing-masters
to be had:&mdash;it is my father's request to you. All
that I have to say to you is a little good advice, which,
because I will not shame you, I'll give you in private.
[<i>Whispers</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What! will you let her whisper with him
too?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, if you find fault with it, they shall whisper,
though I did not like it before:&mdash;I'll ha' nobody wiser
than myself. But do you think, if 'twere any hurt, she
would whisper it to him before us?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_217" id="Page_217">[Pg 217]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> If it be no hurt, why does she not speak
aloud?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Because she says she will not put the man out of
countenance.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Hey-day! put a dancing-master out of
countenance!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You say he is no dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes, for his impudence he may be a
dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, well, let her whisper before me as much as
she will to-night, since she is to be married to-morrow;&mdash;especially
since her husband (that shall be) stands by
consenting too.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, let 'em whisper, as you say, as much as
they will before we marry.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] She's making more
sport with him, I warrant.&mdash;But I wonder how people can
be fooled so.&mdash;Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, a penny for the secret, daughter.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, father, you shall have it for nothing to-morrow.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Well, friend, you will not fail to come?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, no, sir.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Yet I am a fool if I do.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> And be sure you bring the fiddlers with you, as I
bid you.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes, be sure you bring the fiddlers with you, as I
bid you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> So, so: he'll fiddle your daughter out of the
house.&mdash;Must you have fiddles, with a fiddle faddle?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Lord! that people should be made such fools
of! Ha! ha! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego, Hippolita</span>, Monsieur,
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger</i>.</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Fortune we sooner may than woman trust:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To her confiding gallant she is just;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But falser woman only him deceives,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who to her tongue and eyes most credit gives.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_218" id="Page_218">[Pg 218]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FIFTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Monsieur de <span class="smcap">Paris</span> <i>and the</i> Black, <i>stalking over
the stage; to them</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Good morrow to thee, noble
dancing-master:&mdash;ha! ha! ha! your
little black brother here, my master, I
see, is the more diligent man of the
two. But why do you come so late?&mdash;What!
you begin to neglect your
scholar, do you?&mdash;Little black master, <i>con licencia</i>, pray
get you out of the room.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Black.] What! out of
humour, man! a dancing-master should be like his fiddle,
always in tune. Come, my cousin has made an ass of
thee; what then? I know it.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Does he know it! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But prithee don't be angry: 'twas agreed upon
betwixt us, before I sent you, to make a fool of thee;&mdash;ha!
ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Was it so?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I knew you would be apt to entertain vain
hopes from the summons of a lady: but, faith, the
design was but to make a fool of thee, as you find.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> 'Tis very well.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But indeed I did not think the jest would have
lasted so long, and that my cousin would have made a
dancing-master of you, ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> The fool has reason, I find, and I am the coxcomb
while I thought him so. [<i>Aside</i>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_219" id="Page_219">[Pg 219]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come, I see you are uneasy, and the jest of
being a dancing-master grows tedious to you:&mdash;but have
a little patience; the parson is sent for, and when once
my cousin and I are married, my uncle may know who
you are.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I am certainly abused. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Listening.</i>] What do you say?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Merely fooled! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why do you doubt it? ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Can it be? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pish! pish! she told me yesterday as soon as
you were gone, that she had led you into a fool's paradise,
and made you believe she would go away with you&mdash;ha!
ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Did she so?&mdash;I am no longer to doubt it then.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, she makes a mere fool of thee, I vow
and swear; but don't be concerned, there's hardly a man
of a thousand but has been made a fool of by some
woman or other.&mdash;I have been made a fool of myself,
man, by the women; I have, I vow and swear I
have.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, you have, I believe it, for you are a coxcomb.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Lord! you need not be so touchy with one; I
tell you but the truth, for your good; for though she
does, I would not fool you any longer; but prithee don't
be troubled at what can't be helped. Women are made
on purpose to fool men: when they are children, they
fool their fathers; and when they have taken their leaves
of their hanging sleeves, they fool their gallants or
dancing masters,&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Hark you, sir! to be fooled by a woman, you
say, is not to be helped; but I will not be fooled by a
fool.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> You show your English breeding now; an
English rival is so dull and brutish as not to understand<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_220" id="Page_220">[Pg 220]</a></span>
raillery; but what is spoken in your passion I'll take no
notice of, for I am your friend, and would not have you
my rival to make yourself ridiculous.&mdash;Come, prithee,
prithee, don't be so concerned; for, as I was saying,
women first fool their fathers, then their gallants, and
then their husbands; so that it will be my turn to be
fooled too (for your comfort); and when they come to
be widows, they would fool the devil, I vow and swear.&mdash;Come,
come, dear Gerrard, prithee don't be out of
humour, and look so sillily.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Prithee do not talk so sillily.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, faith, I am resolved to beat you out of
this ill-humour.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Faith, I am afraid I shall first beat you into an
ill-humour.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! that thou shouldst be gulled so
by a little gipsy, who left off her bib but yesterday!&mdash;faith
I can't but laugh at thee.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Faith, then I shall make your mirth (as being
too violent) conclude in some little misfortune to you.
The fool begins to be tyrannical.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! poor angry dancing-master!
prithee match my Spanish pumps and legs with one of
your best and newest sarabands; ha! ha! ha! come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I will match your Spanish ear, thus, sir, and
make you dance thus. [<i>Strikes and kicks him.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! sa! sa! sa! then I'll make you dance
thus.
[Monsieur <i>draws his sword and runs at him,
but</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>drawing, he retires.</i></p>

<p>Hold! hold a little!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] A desperate disappointed
lover will cut his own throat, then sure he will make
nothing of cutting his rival's throat.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Consideration is an enemy to fighting; if you
have a mind to revenge yourself, your sword's in your
hand.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pray, sir, hold your peace; I'll ne'er take my<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_221" id="Page_221">[Pg 221]</a></span>
rival's counsel, be't what 'twill. I know what you would
be at; you are disappointed of your mistress, and could
hang yourself, and therefore will not fear hanging. But
I am a successful lover, and need neither hang for you
nor my mistress: nay, if I should kill you, I know I
should do you a kindness; therefore e'en live, to die
daily with envy of my happiness. But if you will needs
die, kill yourself, and be damned for me, I vow and swear.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But won't you fight for your mistress?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I tell you, you shall not have the honour to be
killed for her: besides I will not be hit in the teeth by
her as long as I live, with the great love you had for her.
Women speak well of their dead husbands; what will
they do of their dead gallants?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But if you will not fight for her, you shall dance
for her, since you desired me to teach you to dance too;&mdash;I'll
teach you to dance thus&mdash;[<i>Strikes
his sword at his legs,</i> Monsieur <i>leaps.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, if it be for the sake of my mistress, there's
nothing I will refuse to do.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Nay, you must dance on.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, for my mistress, and sing too, la, la, la,
ra, la.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What! swords drawn betwixt you two! what's
the matter?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Is she here?&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come, put up
your sword; you see this is no place for us; but the
devil eat me if you shall not eat my sword, but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What's the matter, cousin?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nothing, nothing, cousin, but your presence is
a sanctuary for my greatest enemy, or else, <i>tête non!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What, you have not hurt my cousin, sir, I hope?
[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> How! she's concerned for him! nay, then I
need not doubt, my fears are true. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_222" id="Page_222">[Pg 222]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> What was that you said, cousin? hurt me!&mdash;ha!
ha! ha! hurt me!&mdash;if any man hurt me, he must
do it basely; he shall ne'er do it when my sword's
drawn, sa! sa! sa!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Because you will ne'er draw your sword, perhaps.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Scurvily guessed.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] You ladies
may say anything; but, cousin, pray do not you talk of
swords and fighting; meddle with your guitar, and
talk of dancing with your dancing-master there, ha!
ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But I am afraid you have hurt my master,
cousin:&mdash;he says nothing; can he draw his breath?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, 'tis you have hurt your master, cousin, in
the very heart, cousin, and therefore he would hurt me;
for love is a disease makes people as malicious as the
plague does.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, poor master, something does ail you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, nay, cousin, faith don't abuse him any
longer; he's an honest gentleman, and has been long of
my acquaintance, and a man of tolerable sense, to take
him out of his love; but prithee, cousin, don't drive the
jest too far for my sake.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> He counsels you well, pleasant, cunning, jilting
miss, for his sake; for if I am your divertisement,
it shall be at his cost, since he's your gallant in favour.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I don't understand you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But I do, a pox take him! and the custom
that so orders it, forsooth! that if a lady abuse or affront
a man, presently the gallant must be beaten; nay, what's
more unreasonable, if a woman abuse her husband, the
poor cuckold must bear the shame as well as the injury.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But what's the matter, master? what was it you
said?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I say, pleasant, cunning, jilting lady, though you
make him a cuckold, it will not be revenge enough for
me upon him for marrying you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_223" id="Page_223">[Pg 223]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> How! my surly, huffing, jealous, senseless, saucy
master?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, nay, faith, give losers leave to speak,
losers of mistresses especially, ha! ha! ha! Besides,
your anger is too great a favour for him; I scorn to
honour him with mine you see.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I tell you, my saucy master, my cousin shall
never be made that monstrous thing you mention, by
me.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Thank you, I vow and swear, cousin; no, no, I
never thought I should.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Sure you marry him by the sage maxim of your
sex, which is, wittols make the best husbands, that is,
cuckolds.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Indeed, master, whatsoever you think, I would
sooner choose you for that purpose than him.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ha! ha! ha! there she was with him, i'faith;&mdash;I
thank you for that, cousin, I vow and swear.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, he shall thank me for that too:&mdash;but how
came you two to quarrel? I thought, cousin, you had had
more wit than to quarrel, or more kindness for me than
to quarrel here. What if my father, hearing the bustle,
should have come in? he would have soon discovered
our false dancing-master (for passion unmasks every
man), and then the result of your quarrel had been my
ruin.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, you had both felt his desperate deadly
daunting dagger:&mdash;there are your d's for you!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Go, go presently, therefore, and hinder my father
from coming in, whilst I put my master into a better
humour, that we may not be discovered, to the prevention
of our wedding, or worse when he comes; go, go.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, well, I will, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Be sure you let him not come in this good
while.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, no, I warrant you.&mdash;[<i>Goes out and returns.</i>]&mdash;But
if he should come before I would have him, I'll<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_224" id="Page_224">[Pg 224]</a></span>
come before him, and cough and hawk soundly, that you
may not be surprised. Won't that do well, cousin?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Very well, pray begone.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Monsieur.]
Well, master, since I find you are quarrelsome and
melancholy, and would have taken me away without a
portion, three infallible signs of a true lover, faith here's
my hand now in earnest, to lead me a dance as long as I
live.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> How's this! you surprise me as much, as when
first I found so much beauty and wit in company with so
much innocency. But, dearest, I would be assured of
what you say, and yet dare not ask the question. You
h&mdash;&mdash;do not abuse me again? You h&mdash;&mdash;will fool me
no more sure?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Yes, but I will sure.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> How? nay, I was afraid on't.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> For, I say, you are to be my husband, and you
say husbands must be wittols, and some strange things to
boot.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Well, I will take my fortune.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> But have a care, rash man.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I will venture.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> At your peril; remember I wished you to have a
care: forewarned, fore-armed.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Indeed now, that's fair; for most men are fore-armed
before they are warned.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Plain dealing is some kind of honesty however,
and few women would have said so much.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> None but those who would delight in a husband's
jealousy, as the proof of his love and her honour.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Hold, sir, let us have a good understanding
betwixt one another at first, that we may be long friends.
I differ from you in the point; for a husband's jealousy,
which cunning men would pass upon their wives for a
compliment, is the worst can be made 'em; for indeed it
is a compliment to their beauty, but an affront to their
honour.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_225" id="Page_225">[Pg 225]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> But madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So that upon the whole matter I conclude,
jealousy in a gallant is humble true love, and the height
of respect, and only an undervaluing of himself to overvalue
her; but in a husband 'tis arrant sauciness,
cowardice, and ill-breeding, and not to be suffered.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> I stand corrected, gracious miss.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, but have you brought the gentlemen
fiddlers with you, as I desired?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> They are below.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Are they armed well?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Yes, they have instruments too that are not of
wood; but what will you do with them?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What did you think I intended to do with
them? when I whispered you to bring gentlemen of your
acquaintance instead of fiddlers, as my father desired you
to bring, pray what did you think I intended?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Faith, e'en to make fools of the gentlemen
fiddlers, as you had done of your gentleman dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I intended 'em for our guard and defence against
my father's Spanish and Guinea force, when we were to
make our retreat from hence; and to help us to take the
keys from my aunt, who has been the watchful porter
of this house this twelve-month; and this design (if your
heart do not fail you) we will put in execution as soon as
you have given your friends below instructions.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Are you sure your heart will stand right still?
You flinched last night, when I little expected it, I am
sure.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> The time last night was not so proper for us as
now, for reasons I will give you. But besides that, I
confess I had a mind to try whether your interest did
not sway you more than your love; whether the twelve
hundred pounds a-year I told you of had not made a
greater impression in your heart than Hippolita: but
finding it otherwise&mdash;yet hold, perhaps upon consideration<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_226" id="Page_226">[Pg 226]</a></span>
you are grown wiser; can you yet, as I said, be so
desperate, so out of fashion, as to steal a woman with
nothing?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> With you I can want nothing, nor can be made
by anything more rich or happy.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Think well again; can you take me without the
twelve hundred pounds a-year,&mdash;the twelve hundred
pounds a-year?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Indeed, miss, now you begin to be unkind again,
and use me worse than e'er you did.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Well, though you are so modest a gentleman as
to suffer a wife to be put upon you with nothing, I have
more conscience than to do it. I have the twelve
hundred pounds a-year out of my father's power, which
is yours, and I am sorry it is not the Indies to mend
your bargain.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Dear miss, you but increase my fears, and not
my wealth. Pray let us make haste away; I desire but
to be secure of you:&mdash;come, what are you thinking
of?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> I am thinking if some little, filching, inquisitive
poet should get my story, and represent it to the stage,
what those ladies who are never precise but at a play
would say of me now;&mdash;that I were a confident, coming
piece, I warrant, and they would damn the poor poet for
libelling the sex. But sure, though I give myself and
fortune away frankly, without the consent of my friends,
my confidence is less than theirs who stand off only for
separate maintenance.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> They would be widows before their time, have a
husband and no husband:&mdash;but let us begone, lest fortune
should recant my happiness, now you are fixed, my
dearest miss. [<i>He kisses her hand.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Monsieur, <i>coughing, followed by</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Oh, here's my father!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How now, sir!&mdash;What, kissing her hand! what<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_227" id="Page_227">[Pg 227]</a></span>
means that, friend, ha?&mdash;Daughter, ha! do you permit
this insolence, ha? <i>voto á mi honra!</i></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> We are prevented again. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Ha! ha! ha! you are so full of your Spanish
jealousy, father; why, you must know he is a city
dancing-master, and they, forsooth, think it fine to kiss
the hand at the honour before the corant.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, ay, ay, uncle, don't you know that?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Go to, go to, you are an easy French fool;
there's more in it than so, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I vow and swear there's nothing more in't, if
you'll believe one.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.]
Did not I cough and hawk? a jealous, prudent husband
could not cough and hawk louder at the approach of his
wife's chamber in visiting time, and yet you would not
hear me. He'll make now ado about nothing, and you'll
be discovered both.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Umph, umph,&mdash;no, no, I see it plain, he is no
dancing-master: now I have found it out, and I think I
can see as far into matters as another: I have found it
now, look you.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> My fear was prophetical. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span>.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> What shall we do?&mdash;nay, pray, sir, do not
stir yet. [<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>offers to go out with her.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What's the matter, brother? what's the
matter?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I have found it out, sister, I have found it out,
sister; this villain here is no dancing-master&mdash;but a dishonourer
of my house and daughter; I caught him
kissing her hand.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pish! pish! you are a strange Spanish kind of
an uncle, that you are.&mdash;A dishonourer of your daughter,
because he kissed her hand! pray how could he honour
her more? he kissed her hand, you see, while he was
making his honour to her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_228" id="Page_228">[Pg 228]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You are an unthinking, shallow French fop,
<i>voto!</i>&mdash;But I tell you, sister, I have thought of it, and
have found it out; he is no dancing-master, sister. Do
you remember the whispering last night? I have found
out the meaning of that too; and I tell you, sister, he's
no dancing-master, I have found it out.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> You found it out! marry come up, did
not I tell you always he was no dancing-master?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You tell me! you silly woman, what then? what
of that?&mdash;You tell me! d'ye think I heeded what you
told me? but I tell you now I have found it out.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I say I found it out.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I say 'tis false, gossip, I found him out.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I say I found him out first, say you what
you will.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Sister, mum, not such a word again, <i>guarda!</i>&mdash;You
found him out!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I must submit, or dissemble like other
prudent women, or&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, come, sister, take it from me, he is no
dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> O yes, he is a dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> What! will you be wiser than I every way?&mdash;remember
the whispering, I say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, he thinks I speak in earnest,
then I'll fit him still.&mdash;[<i>To</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.] But what do
you talk of their whispering! they would not whisper any
ill before us, sure.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Will you still be an idiot, a dolt, and see
nothing?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Lord! you'll be wiser than all the world, will
you? are we not all against you? pshaw! pshaw! I ne'er
saw such a <i>donissimo</i> as you are, I vow and swear.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, sister, he's no dancing-master; for now I
think on't too, he could not play upon the fiddle.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Pish! pish! what dancing-master can play
upon a fiddle without strings?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_229" id="Page_229">[Pg 229]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Again, I tell you he broke them on purpose, because
he could not play; I have found it out now, sister.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, you see farther than I, brother.
[<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span> <i>offers to lead her out.</i></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> For Heaven's sake stir not yet.
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Besides, if you remember, they were perpetually
putting me out of the room; that was, sister, because
they had a mind to be alone, I have found that out too:&mdash;now,
sister, look you, he is no dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> But has he not given her a lesson often
before you?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Ay, but sister, he did not go about his business
like a dancing-master; but go, go down to the door,
somebody rings. [<i>Exit</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I vow and swear, uncle, he is a dancing-master;
pray be appeased.&mdash;Lord! d'ye think I'd tell
you a lie?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> If it prove to be a lie, and you do not confess it,
though you are my next heir after my daughter, I will
disown thee as much as I do her, for thy folly and
treachery to thyself, as well as me.&mdash;You may have her,
but never my estate, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! I must look to my hits then. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Look to't.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Then I had best confess all, before he
discover all, which he will soon do.&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Parson.</p>

<p>O here's the parson too! he won't be in choler, nor
brandish toledo before the parson sure?&mdash;[<i>To</i> Don
<span class="smcap">Diego</span>.] Well, uncle, I must confess, rather than lose
your favour, he is no dancing-master.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No!</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> What! has the fool betrayed us then at last, nay,
then 'tis time to be gone; come away, miss. [<i>Going out.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Nay, sir, if you pass this way, my toledo will
pass that way, look you. [<i>Thrusts at him with his sword.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_230" id="Page_230">[Pg 230]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> O hold, Mr. Gerrard!&mdash;Hold father!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I tell you, uncle, he's an honest gentleman,
means no hurt, and came hither but upon a frolic of
mine and your daughter's. [<i>Stops</i> Don <span class="smcap">Diego</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don. Ladron! traidor!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I tell you all's but a jest, a mere jest, I vow
and swear.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> A jest!&mdash;jest with my honour, <i>voto!</i> ha! no
family to dishonour but the grave, wise, noble, honourable,
illustrious, puissant, and right worshipful family of
the Formals!&mdash;Nay, I am contented to reprieve you, till
you know who you have dishonoured, and convict you of
the greatness of your crime before you die. We are
descended, look you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, pray, uncle, hear me.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I say, we are descended&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> 'Tis no matter for that.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> And my great, great, great-grandfather was&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, well, I have something to say more to
the purpose.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> My great, great, great-grandfather, I say, was&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, a pinmaker in&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> But he was a gentleman for all that, fop, for he
was a sergeant to a company of the trainbands; and my
great-great-grandfather was&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Was his son, what then? won't you let me clear
this gentleman?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> He was, he was&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> He was a felt-maker, his son a wine-cooper,
your father a vintner, and so you came to be a Canary
merchant.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> But we were still gentlemen, for our coat was, as
the heralds say&mdash;was&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Was! your sign was the Three Tuns, and the
field Canary; now let me tell you, this honest gentleman&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Now, that you should dare to dishonour this<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_231" id="Page_231">[Pg 231]</a></span>
family!&mdash;by the graves of my ancestors in Great St.
Helen's church&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Yard.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Thou shalt die for't, <i>ladron!</i> [<i>Runs at</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Hold, hold, uncle, are you mad?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Oh! oh!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay then, by your own Spanish rules of honour
(though he be my rival), I must help him; [<i>Draws his
sword.</i>] since I brought him into danger.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Sure
he will not show his valour upon his nephew and son-in-law,
otherwise I should be afraid of showing mine.&mdash;Here,
Mr. Gerrard, go in here, nay, you shall go in, Mr.
Gerrard, I'll secure you all; and, parson, do you go in
too with 'em, for I see you are afraid of a sword and the
other world, though you talk of it so familiarly, and make
it so fine a place.
[<i>Opens a door, and thrusts</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard, Hippolita</span>,
Parson, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span> <i>in, then shuts it,
and guards it with his sword.</i></p>

<p><i>Don. Tu quoque, Brute!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, now, uncle, you must understand reason.&mdash;What,
you are not only a Don, but you are a Don
Quixote too, I vow and swear!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Thou spot, sploach<a name="FNanchor_66_66" id="FNanchor_66_66"></a><a href="#Footnote_66_66" class="fnanchor">[66]</a> of my family and blood! I
will have his blood, look you.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pray, good Spanish uncle, have but patience to
hear me. Suppose&mdash;I say, suppose he had done, done,
done the feat to your daughter.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How! done the feat! done the feat: done the
feat! <i>en hora mala!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I say, suppose, suppose&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Suppose!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> I say, suppose he had, for I do but suppose it;
well, I am ready to marry her, however. Now marriage
is as good a solder for cracked female honour as blood;
and can't you suffer the shame but for a quarter of an hour,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_232" id="Page_232">[Pg 232]</a></span>
till the parson has married us? and then if there be any
shame, it becomes mine; for here in England, the father
has nothing to do with the daughter's business, honour,
what d'ye call't, when once she's married, d'ye see.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> England! what d'ye tell me of England? I'll be
a Spaniard still, <i>voto á mi honra!</i> and I will be revenged.&mdash;Pedro!
Juan! Sanchez! [<i>Calls at the door.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Caution</span>, <i>followed by</i> <span class="smcap">Flirt</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Flounce</span>,
<i>in vizard masks.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> What's the matter, brother?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Pedro! Sanchez! Juan!&mdash;but who are these,
sister? are they not men in women's clothes? what make
they here?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> They are relations, they say, of my cousin's,
who pressed in when I let in the parson; they say my
cousin invited 'em to his wedding.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Two of my relations!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Ha! they are
my cousins indeed of the other night; a pox take 'em!&mdash;but
that's no curse for 'em; a plague take 'em then!&mdash;but
how came they here?</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Now must I have witnesses too of the
dishonour of my family; it were Spanish prudence to
despatch 'em away out of the house, before I begin my
revenge. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Flirt</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Flounce</span>.] What are you? what
make you here? who would you speak with?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> With monsieur.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Here he is.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Now will these jades discredit me, and spoil my
match just in the coupling minute. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Do you know 'em?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Yes, sir, sure, I know 'em.242
&mdash;[<i>Aside to them.</i>]
Pray, ladies, say as I say, or you will spoil my wedding,
for I am just going to be married; and if my uncle or
mistress should know who you are, it might break off the
match.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> We come on purpose to break the match.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_233" id="Page_233">[Pg 233]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Why, d'ye think to marry, and leave us so in
the lurch?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> What do the jades mean? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, who are they? what would they have?
If they come to the wedding, ladies, I assure you there
will be none to-day here.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> They won't trouble you, sir; they are going
again.&mdash;Ladies, you hear what my uncle says; I know
you won't trouble him.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I wish I were well rid
of 'em.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> You shall not think to put us off so. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Who are they? what are their names?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> We are, sir&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, for Heaven's sake don't tell who you are,
for you will undo me, and spoil my match infallibly.
[<i>Aside to them.</i></p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> We care not, 'tis our business to spoil matches.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> You need not, for I believe married men are
your best customers, for greedy bachelors take up with
their wives.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Come, pray ladies, if you have no business here,
be pleased to retire; for few of us are in humour to be
so civil to you as you may deserve.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Ay, prithee, dear jades, get you gone.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> We will not stir.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Who are they, I say, fool? and why don't they
go?</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> We are, sir&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Hold! hold!&mdash;They are persons of honour and
quality, and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> We are no persons of honour and quality, sir,
we are&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> They are modest ladies, and being in a kind of
disguise, will not own their quality.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> We modest ladies!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why, sometimes you are in the humour to pass<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_234" id="Page_234">[Pg 234]</a></span>
for women of honour and quality; prithee, dear jades,
let your modesty and greatness come upon you now.
[<i>Aside to them.</i></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Come, sir, not to delude you, as he would have
us, we are&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Hold! hold!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> The other night at the French-house&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Hold, I say!&mdash;'Tis even true as Gerrard says,
the women will tell, I see.</p>

<p><i>Flou.</i> If you would have her silent, stop her mouth
with that ring.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Will that do't? here, here&mdash;'Tis worth one
hundred and fifty pounds.&mdash;[<i>Takes off his ring and gives
it her.</i>] But I must not lose my match, I must not lose
a trout for a fly.&mdash;That men should live to hire women
to silence!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard, Hippolita</span>, Parson, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Oh, are you come again.
[<i>Draws his sword and runs at them</i>, Monsieur
<i>holds him.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Oh! hold! hold! uncle!&mdash;What, are you mad,
Gerrard, to expose yourself to a new danger? why would
you come out yet?</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> Because our danger now is over, I thank the
parson there. And now we must beg&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Hippolita</span> <i>kneel.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, faith, uncle, forgive him now, since he asks
you forgiveness upon his knees, and my poor cousin too.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> You are mistaken, cousin; we ask him blessing,
and you forgiveness.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How, how, how! what do you talk of blessing?
what, do you ask your father blessing and he ask me
forgiveness? but why should he ask me forgiveness?</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Because he asks my father's blessing.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Pish! pish! I don't understand you, I vow and
swear.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_235" id="Page_235">[Pg 235]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> The parson will expound it to you, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Hey! what say you to it, parson?</p>

<p><i>Par.</i> They are married, sir.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Married!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Married! so, I told you what 'twould
come to.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> You told us!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nay, she is setting up for the reputation of a
witch.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Married!&mdash;Juan, Sanchez, Pedro, arm! arm!
arm!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> A witch! a witch!</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> Nay, indeed, father, now we are married, you
had better call the fiddlers.&mdash;Call 'em, Prue, quickly.
[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Prue</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Who do you say, married, man?</p>

<p><i>Par.</i> Was I not sent for on purpose to marry 'em?
why should you wonder at it?</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> No, no, you were to marry me, man, to her; I
knew there was a mistake in't somehow; you were merely
mistaken, therefore you must do your business over again
for me now.&mdash;The parson was mistaken, uncle, it seems,
ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> I suppose five or six guineas made him
make the mistake, which will not be rectified now,
nephew. They'll marry all that come near 'em, and, for
a guinea or two, care not what mischief they do, nephew.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Married!&mdash;Pedro! Sanchez!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! and must she be his wife then for ever
and ever? have I held the door then for this, like a fool
as I was?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes, indeed!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Have I worn <i>golilla</i> here for this? little breeches
for this?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes, truly.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> And put on the Spanish honour with the habit,
in defending my rival? nay then, I'll have another turn<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_236" id="Page_236">[Pg 236]</a></span>
of honour in revenge. Come, uncle, I'm of your side
now, sa! sa! sa! but let's stay for our force; Sanchez,
Juan, Pedro, arm! arm! arm!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter two</i> Blacks <i>and a</i> Spaniard, <i>followed by</i> <span class="smcap">Prue,
Martin</span>, <i>and five other gentlemen-like</i> Fiddlers.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Murder the villain! kill him!
[<i>Running all upon</i> <span class="smcap">Gerrard</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> Hold! hold! sir!</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How now! who sent for you, friends?</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> We fiddlers, sir, often come unsent for.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> And you are often kicked down stairs for't too.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> No, sir, our company was never kicked, I think.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Fiddlers, and not kicked! then to preserve your
virgin honour, get you down stairs quickly; for we are
not at present disposed much for mirth, <i>voto!</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> [<i>Peeping.</i>] A pox! is it you, is it you, Martin?&mdash;Nay,
uncle, then 'tis in vain; for they won't be kicked down
stairs, to my knowledge. They are gentlemen fiddlers,
forsooth! A pox on all gentlemen fiddlers and gentlemen
dancing-masters! say I.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How! ha! [<i>Pausing.</i></p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, Flirt, now I am a match for thee: now I
may keep you.&mdash;And there's little difference betwixt
keeping a wench and marriage; only marriage is a little
the cheaper; but the other is the more honourable now,
<i>vert</i> and <i>bleu!</i> Nay, now I may swear a French oath
too. Come, come, I am thine; let us strike up the bargain:
thine, according to the honourable institution of
keeping.&mdash;Come.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Nay, hold, sir; two words to the bargain; first,
I have ne'er a lawyer here to draw articles and settlements.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! is the world come to that? A man cannot
keep a wench without articles and settlements! Nay,
then 'tis e'en as bad as marriage, indeed, and there's no
difference betwixt a wife and a wench.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_237" id="Page_237">[Pg 237]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Only in cohabitation; for the first article shall
be against cohabitation:&mdash;we mistresses suffer no cohabitation.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Nor wives neither now.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then separate maintenance, in case you should
take a wife, or I a new friend.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How! that too! then you are every whit as bad
as a wife.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then my house in town and yours in the
country, if you will.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> A mere wife!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then my coach apart, as well as my bed apart.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> As bad as a wife still!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> But take notice, I will have no little, dirty,
second-hand chariot new furbished, but a large, sociable,
well-painted coach; nor will I keep it till it be as well
known as myself, and it come to be called Flirt-coach;
nor will I have such pitiful horses as cannot carry me
every night to the Park; for I will not miss a night in the
Park, I'd have you to know.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> 'Tis very well: you must have your great, gilt,
fine painted coaches. I'm sure they are grown so
common already amongst you, that ladies of quality
begin to take up with hackneys again, <i>jarni!</i>&mdash;But what
else?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then, that you do not think I will be served by
a little dirty boy in a bonnet, but a couple of handsome,
lusty, cleanly footmen, fit to serve ladies of quality, and
do their business as they should do.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> What then?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then, that you never grow jealous of them.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Why, will you make so much of them?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> I delight to be kind to my servants.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Well, is this all?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> No.&mdash;Then, that when you come to my house,
you never presume to touch a key, lift up a latch, or
thrust a door, without knocking beforehand: and that<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_238" id="Page_238">[Pg 238]</a></span>
you ask no questions, if you see a stray piece of plate,
cabinet, or looking-glass, in my house.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Just a wife in everything.&mdash;But what else?</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then, that you take no acquaintance with me
abroad, nor bring me home any when you are drunk,
whom you will not be willing to see there when you are
sober.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> But what allowance? let's come to the main
business; the money.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Stay, let me think: first for advance-money, five
hundred pounds for pins.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> A very wife!</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then you must take the lease of my house, and
furnish it as becomes one of my quality; for don't you
think we'll take up with your old Queen Elizabeth
furniture, as your wives do.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Indeed there she is least like a wife, as she
says.</p>

<p><i>Flirt.</i> Then for house-keeping, servants' wages, clothes,
and the rest, I'll be contented with a thousand pounds a
year present maintenance, and but three hundred pounds
a year separate maintenance for my life, when your love
grows cold. But I am contented with a thousand pounds
a year, because for pendants, neck-laces, and all sorts of
jewels, and such trifles, nay, and some plate, I will shift
myself as I can; make shifts, which you shall not take
any notice of.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> A thousand pounds a year! what will wenching
come to? Time was a man might have fared as well at
a much cheaper rate, and a lady of one's affections, instead
of a house, would have been contented with a little
chamber, three pair of stairs backward, with a little closet
or ladder to't; and instead of variety of new gowns and
rich petticoats, with her <i>deshabillé</i>, or flame-colour gown
called Indian, and slippers of the same, would have been
contented for a twelvemonth; and instead of visits and
gadding to plays, would have entertained herself at home<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_239" id="Page_239">[Pg 239]</a></span>
with "St. George for England," "The Knight of the
Sun," or "The Practice of Piety;" and instead of sending
her wine and meat from the French-houses, would
have been contented, if you had given her, poor wretch,
but credit at the next chandler's and chequered cellar;<a name="FNanchor_67_67" id="FNanchor_67_67"></a><a href="#Footnote_67_67" class="fnanchor">[67]</a>
and then, instead of a coach, would have been well satisfied
to have gone out and taken the air for three or four
hours in the evening in the balcony, poor soul. Well,
Flirt, however, we'll agree:&mdash;'tis but three hundred
pounds a year separate maintenance, you say, when I am
weary of thee and the charge.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>]&mdash;Robbed of my honour, my daughter,
and my revenge too! O my dear honour! Nothing
vexes me, but that the world should say I had not
Spanish policy enough to keep my daughter from being
debauched from me. But methinks my Spanish policy
might help me yet. I have it&mdash;so&mdash;I will cheat 'em all;
for I will declare I understood the whole plot and contrivance,
and connived at it, finding my cousin a fool, and
not answering my expectation. Well, but then if I
approve of the match, I must give this mock-dancing-master
my estate, especially since half he would have in
right of my daughter, and in spite of me. Well, I am resolved
to turn the cheat upon themselves, and give them
my consent and estate.</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> Come, come, ne'er be troubled, uncle: 'twas a
combination, you see, of all these heads and your
daughter's, you know what I mean, uncle, not to be
thwarted or governed by all the Spanish policy in Christendom.
I'm sure my French policy would not have
governed her; so since I have 'scaped her, I am glad I
have 'scaped her, <i>jarni!</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Come, brother, you are wiser than I, you
see: ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> No, you think you are wiser than I now, in<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_240" id="Page_240">[Pg 240]</a></span>
earnest: but know, while I was thought a gull, I gulled
you all, and made them and you think I knew nothing of
the contrivance. Confess, did not you think verily that
I knew nothing of it, and that I was a gull?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Yes indeed, brother, I did think verily you
were a gull.</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> How's this? [<i>Listening.</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> Alas, alas! all the sputter I made was but to
make this young man, my cousin, believe, when the thing
should be effected, that it was not with my connivance or
consent; but since he is so well satisfied, I own it. For
do you think I would ever have suffered her to marry a
monsieur, a monsieur? <i>guarda!</i>&mdash;besides, it had been
but a beastly incestuous kind of a match, <i>voto!</i>&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, then I see, brother, you are wiser than
I indeed.</p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> So, so.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Caut.</i> Nay, young man, you have danced a fair
dance for yourself, royally; and now you may go jig it
together till you are both weary. And though you were
so eager to have him, Mrs. Minx, you'll soon have your
bellyful of him, let me tell you, mistress.</p>

<p><i>Prue.</i> Ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Mons.</i> How, uncle! what was't you said? Nay, if I
had your Spanish policy against me, it was no wonder I
missed of my aim, <i>ma foi!</i></p>

<p><i>Don.</i> I was resolved too my daughter should not marry
a coward, therefore made the more the more ado to try
you, sir. But I find you are a brisk man of honour, firm
stiff Spanish honour; and that you may see I deceived
you all along, and you not me, ay, and am able to deceive
you still, for I know now you think that I will give you
little or nothing with my daughter, like other fathers,
since you have married her without my consent&mdash;but, I
say, I'll deceive you now; for you shall have the most
part of my estate in present, and the rest at my death.&mdash;There's
for you: I think I have deceived you now, look you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_241" id="Page_241">[Pg 241]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ger.</i> No, indeed, sir, you have not deceived me; for
I never suspected your love to your daughter, nor your
generosity.</p>

<p><i>Don.</i> How, sir! have a care of saying I have not deceived
you, lest I deceive you another way, <i>guarda!</i>&mdash;Pray,
gentlemen, do not think any man could deceive me,
look you; that any man could steal my daughter, look
you, without my connivance:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The less we speak, the more we think;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And he sees most, that seems to wink.</span><br />
</p>

<p><i>Hip.</i> So, so, now I could give you my blessing, father;
now you are a good complaisant father, indeed:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">When children marry, parents should obey,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Since love claims more obedience far than they.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>




<hr class="chap" />
<h3>EPILOGUE</h3>

<h4>SPOKEN BY FLIRT.</h4>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The ladies first I am to compliment,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Whom (if he could) the poet would content,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But to their pleasure then they must consent;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Most spoil their sport still by their modesty,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And when they should be pleased, cry out, "O fy!"</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And the least smutty jest will ne'er pass by.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But city damsel ne'er had confidence</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At smutty play to take the least offence,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But mercy shows, to show her innocence,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet lest the merchants' daughters should to-day</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Be scandalised, not at our harmless play,</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_242" id="Page_242">[Pg 242]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">But our Hippolita, since she's like one</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Of us bold flirts of t'other end o' th' town;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our poet sending to you (though unknown)</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">His best respects by me, does frankly own</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The character to be unnatural;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Hippolita is not like you at all:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You, while your lovers court you, still look grum,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And far from wooing, when they woo, cry mum;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And if some of you e'er were stol'n away,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Your portion's fault 'twas only, I dare say.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Thus much for him the poet bid me speak;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Now to the men I my own mind will break.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You good men o' th' Exchange, on whom alone</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">We must depend, when sparks to sea are gone;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Into the pit already you are come,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Tis but a step more to our tiring-room;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Where none of us but will be wondrous sweet</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Upon an able love of Lombard-street.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You we had rather see between our scenes,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Than spendthrift fops with better clothes and miens;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Instead of laced coats, belts, and pantaloons,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Your velvet jumps,<a name="FNanchor_68_68" id="FNanchor_68_68"></a><a href="#Footnote_68_68" class="fnanchor">[68]</a> gold chains, and grave fur gowns,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Instead of periwigs, and broad cocked hats,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Your satin caps, small cuffs, and vast cravats.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For you are fair and square in all your dealings,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You never cheat your doxies with gilt shillings;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You ne'er will break our windows; then you are</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Fit to make love, while our huzzas make war;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And since all gentlemen must pack to sea,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our gallants and our judges you must be!</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">We, therefore, and our poet, do submit,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To all the camlet cloaks now i' the pit.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="full" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_243" id="Page_243">[Pg 243]</a></span></p>




<h2><a name="THE_COUNTRY_WIFE" id="THE_COUNTRY_WIFE"><i>THE COUNTRY WIFE.</i></a></h2>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Indignor quidquam reprehendi, non quia crasse</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Compositum illepideve putetur, sed quia nuper:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nec veniam antiquis, sed honorem et præmia posci.<a name="FNanchor_69_69" id="FNanchor_69_69"></a><a href="#Footnote_69_69" class="fnanchor">[69]</a></span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 19em;"><span class="smcap">Horat.</span></span><br /><br /><br />
</p>



<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_244" id="Page_244">[Pg 244]</a></span></p>




<p><i>The Country Wife</i> was written,
according to its author's own statement,
about the year 1671 or 1672. Its production
upon the stage was subsequent to
that of <i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i>,
to which allusion is made in the prologue,
and antecedent to that of the earlier-written
<i>Plain Dealer</i>, in the second act of which the author
inserted some critical observations upon <i>The Country Wife</i>.
The first performance of <i>The Plain Dealer</i>, as will afterwards
appear, admits not of a later date than that of March, or the
very beginning of April, 1674; it follows then that <i>The
Country Wife</i> was brought forward some time between the
early spring of 1672 and that of 1674. It was acted by the
King's Company, established during these two years at the
theatre in Portugal Street, Lincoln's Inn Fields, and was
published in the year 1675.</p>

<p>If we can overlook the immorality which, in this play, is
more offensive and pronounced than in any of Wycherley's
other dramas, we shall find in <i>The Country Wife</i> a brilliantly
written and skilfully constructed comedy, superior to either
of the preceding dramas from the same pen, and surpassed,
among comedies of the Restoration, only by its author's own
masterpiece, <i>The Plain Dealer</i>. The plot of <i>The Country
Wife</i> is partly based upon two comedies by Molière&mdash;<i>L'Ecole
des Femmes</i> and <i>L'Ecole des Maris</i>. From the former of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_245" id="Page_245">[Pg 245]</a></span>
these Wycherley derived his conception of the jealous man
who keeps under close restraint a young and ignorant woman,
with the vain hope of thereby securing her fidelity to him.
Agnes's innocent confessions to Arnolphe of her lover's
stratagems and her own esteem for him find a counterpart in
the Country Wife's frankness on a similar occasion, but
beyond these points of coincidence there is little resemblance
between the two plays. From <i>L'Ecole des Maris</i>, again,
Wycherley has borrowed one or two incidents: the imprisoned
girl's device of making her would-be husband (in
the English play, her actual husband) the bearer of a letter
to her gallant, and the trick by which Isabella causes her
tyrant, under the impression that she is another woman, to
consign her with his own hands to his rival.</p>

<p>Steele has published, in the <i>Tatler</i> of April 16, 1709, a
very just criticism upon this play, which, as it cannot fail to
interest the reader, I venture to subjoin.</p>

<blockquote>

<p>"Will's Coffee-house, April 14.</p>

<p>"This evening the Comedy, called <i>The Country Wife</i>, was
acted in Drury Lane, for the benefit of Mrs. Bignell. The
part which gives name to the Play was performed by herself.
Through the whole action she made a very pretty figure, and
exactly entered into the nature of the part. Her husband,
in the Drama, is represented to be one of those debauchees
who run through the vices of the town, and believe, when
they think fit, they can marry and settle at their ease. His
own knowledge of the iniquity of the age makes him choose
a wife wholly ignorant of it, and place his security in her
want of skill to abuse him. The Poet, on many occasions,
where the propriety of the character will admit of it, insinuates
that there is no defence against vice but the contempt of
it: and has, in the natural ideas of an untainted innocent,
shown the gradual steps to ruin and destruction which persons
of condition run into, without the help of a good education
to form their conduct. The torment of a jealous coxcomb,
which arises from his own false maxims, and the
aggravation of his pain by the very words in which he sees
her innocence, makes a very pleasant and instructive satire.
The character of Horner, and the design of it, is a good
representation of the age in which that Comedy was written:<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_246" id="Page_246">[Pg 246]</a></span>
at which time love and wenching were the business of life,
and the gallant manner of pursuing women was the best
recommendation at Court. To this only it is to be imputed
that a Gentleman of Mr. Wycherley's character and sense
condescends to represent the insults done to the honour of
the bed without just reproof; but to have drawn a man of
probity with regard to such considerations had been a
monster, and a Poet had at that time discovered his want of
knowing the manners of the Court he lived in, by a virtuous
character in his fine gentleman, as he would show his
ignorance by drawing a vicious one to please the present
audience."</p></blockquote>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_247" id="Page_247">[Pg 247]</a></span></p>




<h3>PROLOGUE</h3>

<h4>SPOKEN BY MR. HART.<a name="FNanchor_70_70" id="FNanchor_70_70"></a><a href="#Footnote_70_70" class="fnanchor">[70]</a></h4>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Poets, like cudgelled bullies, never do</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At first or second blow submit to you;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But will provoke you still, and ne'er have done,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Till you are weary first with laying on.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The late so baffled scribbler of this day,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Though he stands trembling, bids me boldly say,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">What we before most plays are used to do,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For poets out of fear first draw on you;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In a fierce prologue the still pit defy,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And, ere you speak, like Castril<a name="FNanchor_71_71" id="FNanchor_71_71"></a><a href="#Footnote_71_71" class="fnanchor">[71]</a> give the lie.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But though our Bayes's battles oft I've fought,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And with bruised knuckles their dear conquests bought;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, never yet feared odds upon the stage,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In prologue dare not hector with the age;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But would take quarter from your saving hands,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Though Bayes within all yielding countermands,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Says, you confederate wits no quarter give,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Therefore his play shan't ask your leave to live.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Well, let the vain rash fop, by huffing so,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Think to obtain the better terms of you;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But we, the actors, humbly will submit,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Now, and at any time, to a full pit;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, often we anticipate your rage,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And murder poets for you on our stage:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">We set no guards upon our tiring-room,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But when with dying colours there you come,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">We patiently, you see, give up to you</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our poets, virgins, nay, our matrons too.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_248" id="Page_248">[Pg 248]</a></span></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_249" id="Page_249">[Pg 249]</a></span></p>




<h2><i>THE COUNTRY WIFE.</i></h2>

<h3>ACT THE FIRST.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Horner's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>, <i>and</i> Quack <i>following him at a distance.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] A quack is as fit for a
pimp, as a midwife for a bawd; they
are still but in their way, both helpers
of nature.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Well, my dear
doctor, hast thou done what I desired?</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> I have undone you for ever
with the women, and reported you throughout the whole
town as bad as an eunuch, with as much trouble as if
I had made you one in earnest.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But have you told all the midwives you know,
the orange wenches at the playhouses, the city husbands,
and old fumbling keepers of this end of the town? for
they'll be the readiest to report it.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> I have told all the chambermaids, waiting-women,
tire-women, and old women of my acquaintance;
nay, and whispered it as a secret to 'em, and to the
whisperers of Whitehall; so that you need not doubt
'twill spread, and you will be as odious to the handsome
young women, as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> As the small-pox. Well&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_250" id="Page_250">[Pg 250]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> And to the married women of this end of the
town, as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> As the great one; nay, as their own husbands.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> And to the city dames, as aniseed Robin, of
filthy and contemptible memory; and they will frighten
their children with your name, especially their females.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And cry, Horner's coming to carry you away.
I am only afraid 'twill not be believed. You told 'em it
was by an English-French disaster, and an English-French
chirurgeon, who has given me at once not only a cure,
but an antidote for the future against that damned
malady, and that worse distemper, love, and all other
women's evils?</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Your late journey into France has made it the
more credible, and your being here a fortnight before you
appeared in public, looks as if you apprehended the
shame, which I wonder you do not. Well, I have been
hired by young gallants to belie 'em t'other way; but you
