are the first would be thought a man unfit for women.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Dear Mr. Doctor, let vain rogues be contented
only to be thought abler men than they are, generally 'tis
all the pleasure they have; but mine lies another way.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> You take, methinks, a very preposterous way
to it, and as ridiculous as if we operators in physic
should put forth bills to disparage our medicaments, with
hopes to gain customers.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Doctor, there are quacks in love as well as
physic, who get but the fewer and worse patients for
their boasting; a good name is seldom got by giving it
one's self; and women, no more than honour, are compassed
by bragging. Come, come, Doctor, the wisest
lawyer never discovers the merits of his cause till the
trial; the wealthiest man conceals his riches, and the
cunning gamester his play. Shy husbands and keepers,
like old rooks, are not to be cheated but by a new unpractised
trick: false friendship will pass now no more than
false dice upon 'em; no, not in the city.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_251" id="Page_251">[Pg 251]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> There are two ladies and a gentleman coming up.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> A pox! some unbelieving sisters of my former
acquaintance, who, I am afraid, expect their sense should
be satisfied of the falsity of the report. No&mdash;this formal
fool and women!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>, Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, <i>and</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> His wife and sister.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> My coach breaking just now before your
door, sir, I look upon as an occasional reprimand to
me, sir, for not kissing your hands, sir, since your coming
out of France, sir; and so my disaster, sir, has been my
good fortune, sir; and this is my wife and sister, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What then, sir?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> My lady, and sister, sir.&mdash;Wife, this is Master
Horner.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Master Horner, husband!</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> My lady, my Lady Fidget, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Won't you be acquainted with her, sir?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
So, the report is true, I find, by his coldness or
aversion to the sex; but I'll play the wag with him.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Pray salute my wife, my lady, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I will kiss no man's wife, sir, for him, sir; I
have taken my eternal leave, sir, of the sex already, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Ha! ha! ha! I'll plague him yet.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Not know my wife, sir?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I do know your wife, sir; she's a woman, sir,
and consequently a monster, sir, a greater monster than
a husband, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> A husband! how, sir?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, sir; but I make no more cuckolds, sir.
[<i>Makes horns.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_252" id="Page_252">[Pg 252]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ha! ha! ha! Mercury! Mercury!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Pray, Sir Jasper, let us be gone from this
rude fellow.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Who, by his breeding, would think he had
ever been in France?</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Foh! he's but too much a French fellow,
such as hate women of quality and virtue for their love to
their husbands. Sir Jasper, a woman is hated by 'em as
much for loving her husband as for loving their money.
But pray let's be gone.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> You do well, madam; for I have nothing that
you came for. I have brought over not so much as a
bawdy picture, no new postures, nor the second part of
the <i>Ecole des Filles</i>; nor&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Hold, for shame, sir! what d'ye mean? you'll
ruin yourself for ever with the sex&mdash;[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ha! ha! ha! he hates women perfectly, I
find.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> What pity 'tis he should!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Ay, he's a base fellow for't. But affectation
makes not a woman more odious to them than virtue.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Because your virtue is your greatest affectation,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> How, you saucy fellow! would you wrong
my honour?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> If I could.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> How d'ye mean, sir?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ha! ha! ha! no, he can't wrong your ladyship's
honour, upon my honour. He, poor man&mdash;hark
you in your ear&mdash;a mere eunuch. [<i>Whispers.</i></p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> O filthy French beast! foh! foh! why do
we stay? let's be gone: I can't endure the sight of him.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Stay but till the chairs come; they'll be here
presently.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> No, no.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nor can I stay longer. 'Tis, let me see, a
quarter and half quarter of a minute past eleven. The<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_253" id="Page_253">[Pg 253]</a></span>
council will be sat; I must away. Business must be
preferred always before love and ceremony with the wise,
Mr. Horner.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And the impotent, Sir Jasper.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, ay, the impotent, Master Horner; hah!
hah! hah!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> What, leave us with a filthy man alone in his
lodgings?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He's an innocent man now, you know. Pray
stay, I'll hasten the chairs to you.&mdash;Mr. Horner, your
servant; I should be glad to see you at my house. Pray
come and dine with me, and play at cards with my wife
after dinner; you are fit for women at that game yet, ha!
ha!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] 'Tis as much a husband's prudence to
provide innocent diversion for a wife as to hinder her
unlawful pleasures; and he had better employ her than
let her employ herself.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Farewell.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Your servant, Sir Jasper. [<i>Exit</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> I will not stay with him, foh!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, madam, I beseech you stay, if it be but to
see I can be as civil to ladies yet as they would desire.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> No, no, foh! you cannot be civil to ladies.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> You as civil as ladies would desire?</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> No, no, no, foh! foh! foh!
[<i>Exeunt</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Now, I think, I, or you yourself, rather, have
done your business with the women.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Thou art an ass. Don't you see already, upon
the report, and my carriage, this grave man of business
leaves his wife in my lodgings, invites me to his house
and wife, who before would not be acquainted with me
out of jealousy?</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Nay, by this means you may be the more
acquainted with the husbands, but the less with the
wives.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Let me alone; if I can but abuse the husbands,
I'll soon disabuse the wives. Stay&mdash;I'll reckon you up<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_254" id="Page_254">[Pg 254]</a></span>
the advantages I am like to have by my stratagem.
First, I shall be rid of all my old acquaintances, the most
insatiable sort of duns, that invade our lodgings in a
morning; and next to the pleasure of making a new
mistress is that of being rid of an old one, and of all old
debts. Love, when it comes to be so, is paid the most
unwillingly.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Well, you may be so rid of your old acquaintances;
but how will you get any new ones?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Doctor, thou wilt never make a good chemist,
thou art so incredulous and impatient. Ask but all the
young fellows of the town if they do not lose more time,
like huntsmen, in starting the game, than in running it
down. One knows not where to find 'em; who will or
will not. Women of quality are so civil, you can hardly
distinguish love from good breeding, and a man is often
mistaken: but now I can be sure she that shows an
aversion to me loves the sport, as those women that are
gone, whom I warrant to be right. And then the next
thing is, your women of honour, as you call 'em, are only
chary of their reputations, not their persons; and 'tis
scandal they would avoid, not men. Now may I have,
by the reputation of an eunuch, the privileges of one, and
be seen in a lady's chamber in a morning as early as her
husband; kiss virgins before their parents or lovers; and
may be, in short, the <i>passe-partout</i> of the town. Now,
doctor.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Nay, now you shall be the doctor; and your
process is so new that we do not know but it may
succeed.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Not so new neither; <i>probatum est</i>, doctor.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Well, I wish you luck, and many patients,
whilst I go to mine. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Come, your appearance at the play yesterday, has,
I hope, hardened you for the future against the women's<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_255" id="Page_255">[Pg 255]</a></span>
contempt, and the men's raillery; and now you'll abroad
as you were wont.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Did I not bear it bravely?</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> With a most theatrical impudence, nay, more
than the orange-wenches show there, or a drunken vizard-mask,
or a great-bellied actress; nay, or the most impudent
of creatures, an ill poet; or what is yet more
impudent, a second-hand critic.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But what say the ladies? have they no pity?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> What ladies? The vizard-masks, you know,
never pity a man when all's gone, though in their service.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> And for the women in the boxes, you'd never pity
them when 'twas in your power.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> They say 'tis pity but all that deal with common
women should be served so.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Nay, I dare swear they won't admit you to play
at cards with them, go to plays with 'em, or do the little
duties which other shadows of men are wont to do for 'em.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What do you call shadows of men?</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Half-men.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What, boys?</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Ay, your old boys, old <i>beaux garçons</i>, who, like
superannuated stallions, are suffered to run, feed, and
whinny with the mares as long as they live, though they
can do nothing else.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, a pox on love and wenching! Women
serve but to keep a man from better company. Though
I can't enjoy them, I shall you the more. Good fellowship
and friendship are lasting, rational, and manly
pleasures.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> For all that, give me some of those pleasures you
call effeminate too; they help to relish one another.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> They disturb one another.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, mistresses are like books. If you pore upon
them too much, they doze you, and make you unfit for
company; but if used discreetly, you are the fitter for conversation
by 'em.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_256" id="Page_256">[Pg 256]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> A mistress should be like a little country retreat
near the town; not to dwell in constantly, but only for a
night and away, to taste the town the better when a man
returns.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I tell you, 'tis as hard to be a good fellow, a
good friend, and a lover of women, as 'tis to be a good
fellow, a good friend, and a lover of money. You cannot
follow both, then choose your side. Wine gives you
liberty, love takes it away.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Gad, he's in the right on't.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Wine gives you joy; love, grief and tortures,
besides surgeons. Wine makes us witty; love, only sots.
Wine makes us sleep; love breaks it.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> By the world he has reason, Harcourt.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Wine makes&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Ay, wine makes us&mdash;makes us princes; love
makes us beggars, poor rogues, egad&mdash;and wine&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, there's one converted.&mdash;No, no, love and
wine, oil and vinegar.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I grant it; love will still be uppermost.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Come, for my part, I will have only those
glorious manly pleasures of being very drunk and very
slovenly.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Mr. Sparkish is below, sir. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> What, my dear friend! a rogue that is fond of me
only, I think, for abusing him.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> No, he can no more think the men laugh at him
than that women jilt him; his opinion of himself is so
good.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, there's another pleasure by drinking I
thought not of,&mdash;I shall lose his acquaintance, because
he cannot drink: and you know 'tis a very hard thing to
be rid of him; for he's one of those nauseous offerers at
wit, who, like the worst fiddlers, run themselves into all
companies.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_257" id="Page_257">[Pg 257]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> One that, by being in the company of men of
sense, would pass for one.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And may so to the short-sighted world; as a
false jewel amongst true ones is not discerned at a distance.
His company is as troublesome to us as a cuckold's when
you have a mind to his wife's.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, the rogue will not let us enjoy one another,
but ravishes our conversation; though he signifies no
more to't than Sir Martin Mar-all's<a name="FNanchor_72_72" id="FNanchor_72_72"></a><a href="#Footnote_72_72" class="fnanchor">[72]</a> gaping, and awkward
thrumming upon the lute, does to his man's voice and
music.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> And to pass for a wit in town shows himself a
fool every night to us, that are guilty of the plot.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Such wits as he are, to a company of reasonable
men, like rooks to the gamesters; who only fill a room
at the table, but are so far from contributing to the play,
that they only serve to spoil the fancy of those that do.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Nay, they are used like rooks too, snubbed,
checked, and abused; yet the rogues will hang on.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> A pox on 'em, and all that force nature, and
would be still what she forbids 'em! Affectation is her
greatest monster.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Most men are the contraries to that they would
seem. Your bully, you see, is a coward with a long
sword; the little humbly-fawning physician, with his
ebony cane, is he that destroys men.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> The usurer, a poor rogue, possessed of mouldy
bonds and mortgages; and we they call spendthrifts,
are only wealthy, who lay out his money upon daily new
purchases of pleasure.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, your arrantest cheat is your trustee or
executor; your jealous man, the greatest cuckold; your<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_258" id="Page_258">[Pg 258]</a></span>
churchman the greatest atheist; and your noisy pert
rogue of a wit, the greatest fop, dullest ass, and worst
company, as you shall see; for here he comes.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How is't, sparks? how is't? Well, faith,
Harry, I must rally thee a little, ha! ha! ha! upon the
report in town of thee, ha! ha! ha! I can't hold i'faith;
shall I speak?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes; but you'll be so bitter then.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Honest Dick and Frank here shall answer for
me; I will not be extreme bitter, by the universe.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> We will be bound in a ten thousand pound bond,
he shall not be bitter at all.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Nor sharp, nor sweet.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What, not downright insipid?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay then, since you are so brisk, and provoke
me, take what follows. You must know, I was discoursing
and rallying with some ladies yesterday, and they happened
to talk of the fine new signs in town&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Very fine ladies, I believe.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Said I, I know where the best new sign is.&mdash;Where?
says one of the ladies.&mdash;In Covent-Garden, I
replied.&mdash;Said another, In what street?&mdash;In Russel-street,
answered I.&mdash;Lord, says another, I'm sure there
was never a fine new sign there yesterday.&mdash;Yes, but
there was, said I again; and it came out of France, and
has been there a fortnight.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> A pox! I can hear no more, prithee.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, hear him out; let him tune his crowd
a while.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> The worst music, the greatest preparation.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, faith, I'll make you laugh.&mdash;It cannot be,
says a third lady.&mdash;Yes, yes, quoth I again.&mdash;Says a
fourth lady&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Look to't, we'll have no more ladies.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No&mdash;then mark, mark, now. Said I to the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_259" id="Page_259">[Pg 259]</a></span>
fourth, Did you never see Mr. Horner? he lodges in
Russel-street, and he's a sign of a man, you know,
since he came out of France; ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But the devil take me if thine be the sign of a
jest.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> With that they all fell a-laughing, till they bepissed
themselves. What, but it does not move you, methinks?
Well, I see one had as good go to law without
a witness, as break a jest without a laugher on one's side.&mdash;Come,
come, sparks, but where do we dine? I have
left at Whitehall an earl, to dine with you.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Why, I thought thou hadst loved a man with a
title, better than a suit with a French trimming to't.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Go to him again.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, sir, a wit to me is the greatest title in the
world.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But go dine with your earl, sir; he may be exception.
We are your friends, and will not take it ill to
be left, I do assure you.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Nay, faith, he shall go to him.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, pray, gentlemen.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> We'll thrust you out, if you won't; what, disappoint
anybody for us?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, dear gentlemen, hear me.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, no, sir, by no means; pray go, sir.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Why, dear rogues&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> No, no. [<i>They all thrust him out of the room.</i></p>

<p><i>All.</i> Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> But, sparks, pray hear me. What, d'ye think
I'll eat then with gay shallow fops and silent coxcombs? I
think wit as necessary at dinner, as a glass of good wine;
and that's the reason I never have any stomach when I
eat alone.&mdash;Come, but where do we dine?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Even where you will.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> At Chateline's?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_260" id="Page_260">[Pg 260]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Yes, if you will.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Or at the Cock?<a name="FNanchor_73_73" id="FNanchor_73_73"></a><a href="#Footnote_73_73" class="fnanchor">[73]</a></p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Yes, if you please.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Or at the Dog and Partridge?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, if you have a mind to't; for we shall dine
at neither.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! with your fooling we shall lose the new
play; and I would no more miss seeing a new play the
first day, than I would miss sitting in the wit's row.
Therefore I'll go fetch my mistress, and away. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Who have we here? Pinchwife?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Gentlemen, your humble servant.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, Jack, by thy long absence from the town,
the grumness of thy countenance, and the slovenliness
of thy habit, I should give thee joy, should I not, of
marriage?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Death! does he know I'm married
too? I thought to have concealed it from him at least.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
My long stay in the country will excuse my
dress; and I have a suit of law that brings me up to
town, that puts me out of humour. Besides, I must give
Sparkish to-morrow five thousand pounds to lie with my
sister.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, you country gentlemen, rather than not
purchase, will buy anything; and he is a cracked title,
if we may quibble. Well, but am I to give thee joy? I
heard thou wert married.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What then?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, the next thing that is to be heard, is,
thou'rt a cuckold.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_261" id="Page_261">[Pg 261]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Insupportable name! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But I did not expect marriage from such a
whoremaster as you; one that knew the town so much,
and women so well.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Why, I have married no London wife.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Pshaw! that's all one. That grave circumspection
in marrying a country wife, is like refusing a
deceitful pampered Smithfield jade, to go and be cheated
by a friend in the country.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] A pox on him and his simile!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
At least we are a little surer of the breed there, know
what her keeping has been, whether foiled or unsound.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Come, come, I have known a clap gotten in
Wales; and there are cousins, justices' clerks, and chaplains
in the country, I won't say coachmen. But she's
handsome and young?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I'll answer as I should do.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
No, no; she has no beauty but her youth, no attraction
but her modesty: wholesome, homely, and huswifely;
that's all.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> He talks as like a grazier as he looks.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> She's too awkward, ill-favoured, and silly to bring
to town.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Then methinks you should bring her to be
taught breeding.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> To be taught! no, sir, I thank you. Good
wives and private soldiers should be ignorant&mdash;I'll keep
her from your instructions, I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> The rogue is as jealous as if his wife were not
ignorant. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, if she be ill-favoured, there will be less
danger here for you than by leaving her in the country.
We have such variety of dainties that we are seldom
hungry.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> But they have always coarse, constant, swingeing
stomachs in the country.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Foul feeders indeed!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_262" id="Page_262">[Pg 262]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> And your hospitality is great there.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Open house; every man's welcome.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So, so, gentlemen.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But prithee, why shouldst thou marry her? If
she be ugly, ill-bred, and silly, she must be rich then.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> As rich as if she brought me twenty thousand
pound out of this town; for she'll be as sure not to spend
her moderate portion, as a London baggage would be to
spend hers, let it be what it would: so 'tis all one. Then,
because she's ugly, she's the likelier to be my own; and
being ill-bred, she'll hate conversation; and since silly
and innocent, will not know the difference betwixt a man
of one-and-twenty and one of forty.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nine&mdash;to my knowledge. But if she be silly,
she'll expect as much from a man of forty-nine, as from
him of one-and-twenty. But methinks wit is more necessary
than beauty; and I think no young woman ugly that
has it, and no handsome woman agreeable without it.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Tis my maxim, he's a fool that marries; but
he's a greater that does not marry a fool. What is wit in
a wife good for, but to make a man a cuckold?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes, to keep it from his knowledge.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> A fool cannot contrive to make her husband a
cuckold.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No; but she'll club with a man that can: and
what is worse, if she cannot make her husband a cuckold,
she'll make him jealous, and pass for one: and then 'tis
all one.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, well, I'll take care for one. My wife
shall make me no cuckold, though she had your help,
Mr. Horner. I understand the town, sir.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> His help! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> He's come newly to town, it seems, and has not
heard how things are with him. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But tell me, has marriage cured thee of whoring,
which it seldom does?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> 'Tis more than age can do.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_263" id="Page_263">[Pg 263]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, the word is, I'll marry and live honest: but
a marriage vow is like a penitent gamester's oath, and
entering into bonds and penalties to stint himself to such
a particular small sum at play for the future, which makes
him but the more eager; and not being able to hold out,
loses his money again, and his forfeit to boot.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Ay, ay, a gamester will be a gamester whilst his
money lasts, and a whoremaster whilst his vigour.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Nay, I have known 'em, when they are broke,
and can lose no more, keep a fumbling with the box in
their hands to fool with only, and hinder other gamesters.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> That had wherewithal to make lusty stakes.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, gentlemen, you may laugh at me; but
you shall never lie with my wife: I know the town.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But prithee, was not the way you were in
better? is not keeping better than marriage?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> A pox on't! the jades would jilt me, I could
never keep a whore to myself.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, then you only married to keep a whore to
yourself. Well, but let me tell you, women, as you say,
are like soldiers, made constant and loyal by good pay,
rather than by oaths and covenants. Therefore I'd
advise my friends to keep rather than marry, since too
I find, by your example, it does not serve one's turn; for
I saw you yesterday in the eighteenpenny place with a
pretty country-wench.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How the devil! did he see my wife then? I
sat there that she might not be seen. But she shall
never go to a play again. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What! dost thou blush, at nine-and-forty, for
having been seen with a wench?</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> No, faith, I warrant 'twas his wife, which he
seated there out of sight; for he's a cunning rogue, and
understands the town.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> He blushes. Then 'twas his wife; for men are
now more ashamed to be seen with them in public than
with a wench.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_264" id="Page_264">[Pg 264]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Hell and damnation! I'm undone, since
Horner has seen her, and they know 'twas she.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But prithee, was it thy wife? She was exceeding
pretty: I was in love with her at that distance.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> You are like never to be nearer to her. Your
servant, gentlemen. [<i>Offers to go.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, prithee stay.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I cannot; I will not.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Come, you shall dine with us.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I have dined already.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Come, I know thou hast not: I'll treat thee,
dear rogue; thou sha't spend none of thy Hampshire
money to-day.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Treat me! So, he uses me already like his
cuckold. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, you shall not go.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I must; I have business at home. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> To beat his wife. He's as jealous of her, as a
Cheapside husband of a Covent-garden wife.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, 'tis as hard to find an old whoremaster
without jealousy and the gout, as a young one without
fear, or the pox:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">As gout in age from pox in youth proceeds,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">So wenching past, then jealousy succeeds;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The worst disease that love and wenching breeds.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_265" id="Page_265">[Pg 265]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE SECOND.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I <i>.&mdash;A Room in</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center">Mrs. <span class="smcap">Margery Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea. Pinchwife</span>
<i>peeping behind at the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray, sister, where are the
best fields and woods to walk in, in
London?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] A pretty question!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Why, sister, Mulberry-garden
and St. James's park; and, for
close walks, the New Exchange.<a name="FNanchor_74_74" id="FNanchor_74_74"></a><a href="#Footnote_74_74" class="fnanchor">[74]</a></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray, sister, tell me why my husband
looks so grum here in town, and keeps me up so close,
and will not let me go a-walking, nor let me wear my best
gown yesterday.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> O, he's jealous, sister.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Jealous! what's that?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> He's afraid you should love another man.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> How should he be afraid of my loving
another man, when he will not let me see any but
himself?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Did he not carry you yesterday to a play?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Ay; but we sat amongst ugly people.
He would not let me come near the gentry, who sat under
us, so that I could not see 'em. He told me, none but
naughty women sat there, whom they toused and moused.
But I would have ventured, for all that.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_266" id="Page_266">[Pg 266]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> But how did you like the play?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Indeed I was weary of the play; but I
liked hugeously the actors. They are the goodliest,
properest men, sister!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> O, but you must not like the actors, sister.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Ay, how should I help it, sister? Pray,
sister, when my husband comes in, will you ask leave for
me to go a-walking?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> A-walking! ha! ha! Lord, a country-gentlewoman's
pleasure is the drudgery of a footpost; and she
requires as much airing as her husband's horses.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
But here comes your husband: I'll ask, though I'm sure
he'll not grant it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> He says he won't let me go abroad for
fear of catching the pox.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Fy! the small-pox you should say.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O my dear, dear bud, welcome home!
Why dost thou look so fropish? who has nangered thee?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> You're a fool.
[Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>goes aside, and cries.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Faith, so she is, for crying for no fault, poor
tender creature!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, you would have her as impudent as
yourself, as arrant a jilflirt, a gadder, a magpie; and to
say all, a mere notorious town-woman?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Brother, you are my only censurer; and the
honour of your family will sooner suffer in your wife there
than in me, though I take the innocent liberty of the
town.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Hark you, mistress, do not talk so before my
wife.&mdash;The innocent liberty of the town!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Why, pray, who boasts of any intrigue with me?
what lampoon has made my name notorious? what ill
women frequent my lodgings? I keep no company with
any women of scandalous reputations.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_267" id="Page_267">[Pg 267]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, you keep the men of scandalous reputations
company.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Where? would you not have me civil? answer
'em in a box at the plays, in the drawing-room at
Whitehall, in St James'-park, Mulberry-garden, or&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Hold, hold! Do not teach my wife where the
men are to be found: I believe she's the worse for your
town-documents already. I bid you keep her in ignorance,
as I do.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Indeed, be not angry with her, bud, she
will tell me nothing of the town, though I ask her a
thousand times a day.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Then you are very inquisitive to know, I
find?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Not I indeed, dear; I hate London.
Our place-house in the country is worth a thousand of't:
would I were there again!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So you shall, I warrant. But were you not
talking of plays and players when I came in?&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.] You are her encourager in such discourses.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> No, indeed, dear; she chid me just now
for liking the playermen.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Nay, if she be so innocent as to own to
me her liking them, there is no hurt in't.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Come, my poor rogue, but thou likest none better than
me?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, indeed, but I do. The playermen
are finer folks.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But you love none better than me?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> You are my own dear bud, and I know
you. I hate a stranger.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Ay, my dear, you must love me only; and not
be like the naughty town-women, who only hate their
husbands, and love every man else; love plays, visits,
fine coaches, fine clothes, fiddles, balls, treats, and so
lead a wicked town-life.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_268" id="Page_268">[Pg 268]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, if to enjoy all these things be a
town-life, London is not so bad a place, dear.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How! if you love me, you must hate London.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> The fool has forbid me discovering to her the
pleasures of the town, and he is now setting her agog
upon them himself. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> But, husband, do the town-women love
the playermen too?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Yes, I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Ay, I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Why, you do not, I hope?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> No, no, bud. But why have we no playermen
in the country?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Ha!&mdash;Mrs. Minx, ask me no more to go to a
play.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, why, love? I did not care for going:
but when you forbid me, you make me, as 'twere, desire
it.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> So 'twill be in other things, I warrant. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray let me go to a play, dear.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Hold your peace, I wo' not.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Why, love?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Why, I'll tell you.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Nay, if he tell her, she'll give him more cause
to forbid her that place. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray why, dear?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> First, you like the actors; and the gallants may
like you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What, a homely country girl! No, bud,
nobody will like me.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I tell you yes, they may.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> No, no, you jest&mdash;I won't believe you:
I will go.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I tell you then, that one of the lewdest fellows
in town, who saw you there, told me he was in love with
you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Indeed! who, who, pray who was't?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_269" id="Page_269">[Pg 269]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I've gone too far, and slipped before I was
aware; how overjoyed she is! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Was it any Hampshire gallant, any of our
neighbours? I promise you, I am beholden to him.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I promise you, you lie; for he would but ruin
you, as he has done hundreds. He has no other love
for women but that; such as he look upon women, like
basilisks, but to destroy 'em.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch</i> Ay, but if he loves me, why should he
ruin me? answer me to that. Methinks he should not,
I would do him no harm.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Tis very well; but I'll keep him from doing
you any harm, or me either. But here comes company;
get you in, get you in.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> But, pray, husband, is he a pretty gentleman
that loves me?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> In, baggage, in.
[<i>Thrusts her in, and shuts the door.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>.</p>

<p>What, all the lewd libertines of the town brought to my
lodging by this easy coxcomb! 'sdeath, I'll not suffer it.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Here, Harcourt, do you approve my choice?&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.] Dear little rogue, I told you I'd bring
you acquainted with all my friends, the wits and&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>
<i>salutes her.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Ay, they shall know her, as well as you yourself
will, I warrant you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> This is one of those, my pretty rogue, that are
to dance at your wedding to-morrow; and him you must
bid welcome ever, to what you and I have.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Monstrous! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Harcourt, how dost thou like her, faith? Nay,
dear, do not look down; I should hate to have a wife of
mine out of countenance at anything.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Wonderful! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_270" id="Page_270">[Pg 270]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Tell me, I say, Harcourt, how dost thou like
her? Thou hast stared upon her enough, to resolve
me.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> So infinitely well, that I could wish I had a
mistress too, that might differ from her in nothing but
her love and engagement to you.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Sir, Master Sparkish has often told me that
his acquaintance were all wits and raillieurs, and now I
find it.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, by the universe, madam, he does not rally
now; you may believe him. I do assure you, he is the
honestest, worthiest, true-hearted gentlemen&mdash;a man of
such perfect honour, he would say nothing to a lady he
does not mean.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Praising another man to his mistress! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Sir, you are so beyond expectation obliging,
that&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, egad, I am sure you do admire her extremely;
I see't in your eyes.&mdash;He does admire you,
madam.&mdash;By the world, don't you?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Yes, above the world, or the most glorious part
of it, her whole sex: and till now I never thought I
should have envied you, or any man about to marry,
but you have the best excuse for marriage I ever knew.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Nay, now, sir, I'm satisfied you are of the society
of the wits and raillieurs, since you cannot spare your
friend, even when he is but too civil to you; but the
surest sign is, since you are an enemy to marriage,&mdash;for
that I hear you hate as much as business or bad
wine.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Truly, madam, I was never an enemy to marriage
till now, because marriage was never an enemy to me
before.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> But why, sir, is marriage an enemy to you now?
because it robs you of your friend here? for you look
upon a friend married, as one gone into a monastery,
that is, dead to the world.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_271" id="Page_271">[Pg 271]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> 'Tis indeed, because you marry him; I see,
madam, you can guess my meaning. I do confess
heartily and openly, I wish it were in my power to break
the match; by Heavens I would.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Poor Frank!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Would you be so unkind to me?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, no, 'tis not because I would be unkind to
you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Poor Frank! no gad, 'tis only his kindness to
me.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Great kindness to you indeed! Insensible fop,
let a man make love to his wife to his face! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, dear Frank, for all my wife there, that
shall be, thou shalt enjoy me sometimes, dear rogue.
By my honour, we men of wit condole for our deceased
brother in marriage, as much as for one dead in earnest:
I think that was prettily said of me, ha, Harcourt?&mdash;But
come, Frank, be not melancholy for me.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, I assure you, I am not melancholy for you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Prithee, Frank, dost think my wife that shall
be there, a fine person?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I could gaze upon her till I became as blind as
you are.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How as I am? how?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Because you are a lover, and true lovers are
blind, stock blind.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> True, true; but by the world she has wit too,
as well as beauty: go, go with her into a corner, and
try if she has wit; talk to her anything, she's bashful
before me.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Indeed if a woman wants wit in a corner, she
has it nowhere.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Sir, you dispose of me a little before your
time&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, nay, madam, let me have an earnest of
your obedience, or&mdash;go, go, madam&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>
<i>courts</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_272" id="Page_272">[Pg 272]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How, sir! if you are not concerned for the
honour of a wife, I am for that of a sister; he shall not
debauch her. Be a pander to your own wife! bring men
to her! let 'em make love before your face! thrust 'em
into a corner together, then leave 'em in private! is this
your town wit and conduct?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ha! ha! ha! a silly wise rogue would make
one laugh more than a stark fool, ha! ha! I shall burst.
Nay, you shall not disturb 'em; I'll vex thee, by the world.
[<i>Struggles with</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>to keep him from</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> The writings are drawn, sir, settlements made;
'tis too late, sir, and past all revocation.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Then so is my death.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I would not be unjust to him.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Then why to me so?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I have no obligation to you.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> My love.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I had his before.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> You never had it; he wants, you see, jealousy,
the only infallible sign of it.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Love proceeds from esteem; he cannot distrust
my virtue: besides, he loves me, or he would not marry
me.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Marrying you is no more sign of his love than
bribing your woman, that he may marry you, is a sign of
his generosity. Marriage is rather a sign of interest than
love; and he that marries a fortune covets a mistress, not
loves her. But if you take marriage for a sign of love,
take it from me immediately.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> No, now you have put a scruple in my head;
but in short, sir, to end our dispute, I must marry him,
my reputation would suffer in the world else.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No; if you do marry him, with your pardon,
madam, your reputation suffers in the world, and you
would be thought in necessity for a cloak.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Nay, now you are rude, sir.&mdash;Mr. Sparkish,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_273" id="Page_273">[Pg 273]</a></span>
pray come hither, your friend here is very troublesome,
and very loving.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Hold! hold!&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> D'ye hear that?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Why, d'ye think I'll seem to be jealous, like a
country bumpkin?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, rather be a cuckold, like a credulous cit.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Madam, you would not have been so little
generous as to have told him.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Yes, since you could be so little generous as to
wrong him.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Wrong him! no man can do't, he's beneath an
injury: a bubble, a coward, a senseless idiot, a wretch so
contemptible to all the world but you, that&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Hold, do not rail at him, for since he is like to
be my husband, I am resolved to like him: nay, I think
I am obliged to tell him you are not his friend.&mdash;Master
Sparkish, Master Sparkish!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> What, what?&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>.] Now, dear
rogue, has not she wit?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Not so much as I thought, and hoped she had.
[<i>Speaks surlily.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Mr. Sparkish, do you bring people to rail at you?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How! no; but if he does rail at me, 'tis but in
jest, I warrant: what we wits do for one another, and
never take any notice of it.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> He spoke so scurrilously of you, I had no
patience to hear him; besides, he has been making love
to me.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> True, damned tell-tale woman! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! to show his parts&mdash;we wits rail and
make love often, but to show our parts: as we have no
affections, so we have no malice, we&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> He said you were a wretch below an injury&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw!</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Damned, senseless, impudent, virtuous jade!<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_274" id="Page_274">[Pg 274]</a></span>
Well, since she won't let me have her, she'll do as good,
she'll make me hate her. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> A common bubble&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> A coward&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw, pshaw!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> A senseless, drivelling idiot&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How! did he disparage my parts? Nay, then,
my honour's concerned, I can't put up that, sir, by the
world&mdash;brother, help me to kill him&mdash;[<i>Aside</i>] I may draw
now, since we have the odds of him:&mdash;'tis a good
occasion, too, before my mistress&mdash;[<i>Offers to draw.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Hold, hold!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> What, what?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I must not let 'em kill the gentleman
neither, for his kindness to me: I am so far from hating
him, that I wish my gallant had his person and understanding.
Nay, if my honour&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> I'll be thy death.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Hold, hold! Indeed, to tell the truth, the
gentleman said after all, that what he spoke was but out
of friendship to you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How! say, I am, I am a fool, that is, no wit,
out of friendship to me?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Yes, to try whether I was concerned enough
for you; and made love to me only to be satisfied of my
virtue, for your sake.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Kind, however. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, if it were so, my dear rogue, I ask thee
pardon; but why would not you tell me so, faith?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Because I did not think on't, faith.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, Horner does not come; Harcourt, let's
be gone to the new play.&mdash;Come, madam.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I will not go, if you intend to leave me alone in
the box, and run into the pit, as you use to do.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! I'll leave Harcourt with you in the
box to entertain you, and that's as good; if I sat in the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_275" id="Page_275">[Pg 275]</a></span>
box, I should be thought no judge but of trimmings.&mdash;Come
away, Harcourt, lead her down.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish, Harcourt</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, go thy ways, for the flower of the true
town fops, such as spend their estates before they come
to 'em, and are cuckolds before they're married. But
let me go look to my own freehold.&mdash;How!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>, <i>and</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Your servant, sir: where is your lady? We
are come to wait upon her to the new play.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> New play!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> And my husband will wait upon you
presently.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Damn your civility.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Madam,
by no means; I will not see Sir Jasper here, till I have
waited upon him at home; nor shall my wife see you till
she has waited upon your ladyship at your lodgings.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Now we are here, sir?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, Madam.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Pray, let us see her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> We will not stir till we see her.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] A pox on you all!&mdash;[<i>Goes to the door,
and returns.</i>] She has locked the door, and is gone
abroad.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> No, you have locked the door, and she's
within.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> They told us below she was here.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Will nothing do?&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Well, it
must out then. To tell you the truth, ladies, which I was
afraid to let you know before, lest it might endanger your
lives, my wife has just now the small-pox come out upon
her; do not be frightened; but pray be gone, ladies;
you shall not stay here in danger of your lives; pray get
you gone, ladies.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> No, no, we have all had 'em.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_276" id="Page_276">[Pg 276]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Alack, alack!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Come, come, we must see how it goes with
her; I understand the disease.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Come!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, there is no being too hard for
women at their own weapon, lying, therefore I'll quit the
field. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Here's an example of jealousy!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Indeed, as the world goes, I wonder there
are no more jealous, since wives are so neglected.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Pshaw! as the world goes, to what end
should they be jealous?</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Foh! 'tis a nasty world.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> That men of parts, great acquaintance,
and quality, should take up with and spend themselves
and fortunes in keeping little playhouse creatures, foh!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Nay, that women of understanding, great
acquaintance, and good quality, should fall a-keeping too
of little creatures, foh!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Why, 'tis the men of quality's fault; they
never visit women of honour and reputation as they used
to do; and have not so much as common civility for
ladies of our rank, but use us with the same indifferency
and ill-breeding as if we were all married to 'em.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> She says true; 'tis an arrant shame women
of quality should be so slighted; methinks birth&mdash;birth
should go for something; I have known men admired,
courted, and followed for their titles only.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Ay, one would think men of honour
should not love, no more than marry, out of their own
rank.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Fy, fy, upon 'em! they are come to think
cross breeding for themselves best, as well as for their dogs
and horses.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> They are dogs and horses for't.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> One would think, if not for love, for
vanity a little.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_277" id="Page_277">[Pg 277]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Nay, they do satisfy their vanity upon us
sometimes; and are kind to us in their report, tell all the
world they lie with us.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Damned rascals, that we should be only
wronged by 'em! To report a man has had a person,
when he has not had a person, is the greatest wrong in
the whole world that can be done to a person.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Well, 'tis an arrant shame noble persons
should be so wronged and neglected.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But still 'tis an arranter shame for a noble
person to neglect her own honour, and defame her own
noble person with little inconsiderable fellows, foh!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> I suppose the crime against our honour is
the same with a man of quality as with another.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> How! no sure, the man of quality is likest
one's husband, and therefore the fault should be the less.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> But then the pleasure should be the less.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Fy, fy, fy, for shame, sister! whither shall
we ramble? Be continent in your discourse, or I shall
hate you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Besides, an intrigue is so much the more
notorious for the man's quality.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> 'Tis true that nobody takes notice of a
private man, and therefore with him 'tis more secret; and
the crime's the less when 'tis not known.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> You say true; i'faith, I think you are in the
right on't: 'tis not an injury to a husband, till it be an
injury to our honours; so that a woman of honour loses
no honour with a private person; and to say truth&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> So, the little fellow is grown a private person&mdash;with
her&mdash;[<i>Apart to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But still my dear, dear honour&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget, Horner</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, my dear, dear of honour, thou hast still
so much honour in thy mouth&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> That she has none elsewhere. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_278" id="Page_278">[Pg 278]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Oh, what d'ye mean to bring in these upon
us?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Foh! these are as bad as wits.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Foh!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Let us leave the room.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Stay, stay; faith, to tell you the naked
truth&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Fy, Sir Jasper! do not use that word
naked.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Well, well, in short I have business at Whitehall,
and cannot go to the play with you, therefore would
have you go&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> With those two to a play?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> No, not with t'other, but with Mr. Horner;
there can be no more scandal to go with him than with
Mr. Tattle, or Master Limberham.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> With that nasty fellow! no&mdash;no.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nay, prithee, dear, hear me.
[<i>Whispers to</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ladies&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Horner</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span> <i>draw near</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Squeamish</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Stand off.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Do not approach us.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> You herd with the wits, you are obscenity all
over.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And I would as soon look upon a
picture of Adam and Eve, without fig-leaves, as any of
you, if I could help it; therefore keep off, and do not
make us sick.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> What a devil are these?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, these are pretenders to honour, as critics
to wit, only by censuring others; and as every raw,
peevish, out-of-humoured, affected, dull, tea-drinking,
arithmetical fop, sets up for a wit by railing at men of
sense, so these for honour, by railing at the court, and
ladies of as great honour as quality.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_279" id="Page_279">[Pg 279]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Come, Mr. Horner, I must desire you to go
with these ladies to the play, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I, sir?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, ay, come, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I must beg your pardon, sir, and theirs; I will
not be seen in women's company in public again for the
world.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ha, ha, strange aversion!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> No, he's for women's company in
private.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He&mdash;poor man&mdash;he&mdash;ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> 'Tis a greater shame amongst lewd fellows
to be seen in virtuous women's company, than for the
women to be seen with them.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Indeed, madam, the time was I only hated
virtuous women, but now I hate the other too; I beg
your pardon, ladies.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> You are very obliging, sir, because we would
not be troubled with you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> In sober sadness, he shall go.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Nay, if he wo' not, I am ready to wait upon the
ladies, and I think I am the fitter man.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> You sir! no, I thank you for that. Master
Horner is a privileged man amongst the virtuous ladies,
'twill be a great while before you are so; he! he! he! he's
my wife's gallant; he! he! he! No, pray withdraw, sir, for
as I take it, the virtuous ladies have no business with
you.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> And I am sure he can have none with them.
'Tis strange a man can't come amongst virtuous women
now, but upon the same terms as men are admitted into
the Great Turk's seraglio. But heavens keep me from
being an ombre player with 'em!&mdash;But where is Pinchwife?
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Come, come, man; what, avoid the sweet
society of womankind? that sweet, soft, gentle, tame,
noble creature, woman, made for man's companion&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_280" id="Page_280">[Pg 280]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So is that soft, gentle, tame, and more noble
creature a spaniel, and has all their tricks; can fawn, lie
down, suffer beating, and fawn the more; barks at your
friends when they come to see you, makes your bed hard,
gives you fleas, and the mange sometimes. And all the
difference is, the spaniel's the more faithful animal, and
fawns but upon one master.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He! he! he!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> O the rude beast!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Insolent brute!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Brute! stinking, mortified, rotten French
wether, to dare&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Hold, an't please your ladyship.&mdash;For shame,
Master Horner! your mother was a woman&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
Now shall I never reconcile 'em.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> Lady
<span class="smcap">Fidget</span>.] Hark you, madam, take my advice in your anger.
You know you often want one to make up your drolling
pack of ombre players, and you may cheat him easily;
for he's an ill gamester, and consequently loves play.
Besides, you know you have but two old civil gentlemen
(with stinking breaths too) to wait upon you abroad;
take in the third into your service. The other are but
crazy; and a lady should have a supernumerary gentleman-usher
as a supernumerary coach-horse, lest sometimes
you should be forced to stay at home.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But are you sure he loves play, and has
money?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He loves play as much as you, and has
money as much as I.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Then I am contented to make him pay for
his scurrility. Money makes up in a measure all other
wants in men.&mdash;Those whom we cannot make hold for
gallants, we make fine. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, so; now to mollify, wheedle
him.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.] Master Horner, will you
never keep civil company? methinks 'tis time now, since
you are only fit for them. Come, come, man, you must<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_281" id="Page_281">[Pg 281]</a></span>
e'en fall to visiting our wives, eating at our tables, drinking
tea with our virtuous relations after dinner, dealing
cards to 'em, reading plays and gazettes to 'em, picking
fleas out of their smocks for 'em, collecting receipts, new
songs, women, pages, and footmen for 'em.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I hope they'll afford me better employment, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He! he! he! 'tis fit you know your work
before you come into your place. And since you are
unprovided of a lady to flatter, and a good house to eat
at, pray frequent mine, and call my wife mistress, and
she shall call you gallant, according to the custom.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Who, I?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Faith, thou sha't for my sake; come, for my
sake only.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> For your sake&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Come, come, here's a gamester for you; let
him be a little familiar sometimes; nay, what if a little
rude? Gamesters may be rude with ladies, you know.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Yes; losing gamesters have a privilege with
women.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I always thought the contrary, that the winning
gamester had most privilege with women; for when you
have lost your money to a man, you'll lose anything you
have, all you have, they say, and he may use you as he
pleases.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He! he! he! well, win or lose, you shall
have your liberty with her.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> As he behaves himself; and for your sake
I'll give him admittance and freedom.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> All sorts of freedom, madam?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, ay, ay, all sorts of freedom thou canst
take. And so go to her, begin thy new employment;
wheedle her, jest with her, and be better acquainted one
with another.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I think I know her already; therefore
may venture with her my secret for hers.
[<span class="smcap">Horner</span> <i>and</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span> <i>whisper.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_282" id="Page_282">[Pg 282]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Sister cuz, I have provided an innocent playfellow
for you there.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Who, he?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> There's a playfellow, indeed!</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Yes sure.&mdash;What, he is good enough to play
at cards, blindman's-buff, or the fool with, sometimes!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Foh! we'll have no such playfellows.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> No, sir; you shan't choose playfellows for
us, we thank you.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nay, pray hear me. [<i>Whispering to them.</i></p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But, poor gentleman, could you be so
generous, so truly a man of honour, as for the sakes of us
women of honour, to cause yourself to be reported no
man? No man! and to suffer yourself the greatest
shame that could fall upon a man, that none might fall
upon us women by your conversation? but, indeed, sir,
as perfectly, perfectly the same man as before your going
into France, sir? as perfectly, perfectly, sir?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> As perfectly, perfectly, madam. Nay, I scorn
you should take my word; I desire to be tried only,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Well, that's spoken again like a man of
honour: all men of honour desire to come to the test.
But, indeed, generally you men report such things of
yourselves, one does not know how or whom to believe;
and it is come to that pass, we dare not take your words
no more than your tailor's, without some staid servant of
yours be bound with you. But I have so strong a faith
in your honour, dear, dear, noble sir, that I'd forfeit mine
for yours, at any time, dear sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, madam, you should not need to forfeit it for
me; I have given you security already to save you harmless,
my late reputation being so well known in the world,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But if upon any future falling-out, or upon
a suspicion of my taking the trust out of your hands, to
employ some other, you yourself should betray your trust,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_283" id="Page_283">[Pg 283]</a></span>
dear sir? I mean, if you'll give me leave to speak
obscenely, you might tell, dear sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> If I did, nobody would believe me. The
reputation of impotency is as hardly recovered again in
the world as that of cowardice, dear madam.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Nay, then, as one may say, you may do
your worst, dear, dear sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Come, is your ladyship reconciled to him
yet? have you agreed on matters? for I must be gone to
Whitehall.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Why, indeed, Sir Jasper, Master Horner is
a thousand, thousand times a better man than I thought
him. Cousin Squeamish, sister Dainty, I can name him
now. Truly, not long ago, you know, I thought his very
name obscenity; and I would as soon have lain with him
as have named him.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Very likely, poor madam.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> I believe it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> No doubt on't.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Well, well&mdash;that your ladyship is as virtuous
as any she, I know, and him all the town knows&mdash;he! he!
he! therefore now you like him, get you gone to your
business together, go, go to your business, I say, pleasure,
whilst I go to my pleasure, business.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Come, then, dear gallant.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Come away, my dearest mistress.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> So, so; why, 'tis as I'd have it. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And as I'd have it.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who for his business from his wife will run,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Takes the best care to have her business done.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_284" id="Page_284">[Pg 284]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE THIRD.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Sister, what ails you? you are
grown melancholy.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Would it not make any
one melancholy to see you go every
day fluttering about abroad, whilst I
must stay at home like a poor lonely
sullen bird in a cage?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Ay, sister; but you came young, and just from
the nest to your cage: so that I thought you liked it, and
could be as cheerful in't as others that took their flight
themselves early, and are hopping abroad in the open
air.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, I confess I was quiet enough till my
husband told me what pure lives the London ladies live
abroad, with their dancing, meetings, and junketings, and
dressed every day in their best gowns; and I warrant
you, play at nine-pins every day of the week, so they do.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, what's here to do? you are putting the
town-pleasures in her head, and setting her a-longing.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Yes, after nine-pins. You suffer none to give
her those longings you mean but yourself.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I tell her of the vanities of the town like a
confessor.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_285" id="Page_285">[Pg 285]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> A confessor! just such a confessor as he that,
by forbidding a silly ostler to grease the horse's teeth,
taught him to do't.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, Mrs. Flippant, good precepts are lost
when bad examples are still before us: the liberty you
take abroad makes her hanker after it, and out of humour
at home. Poor wretch! she desired not to come to
London; I would bring her.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Very well.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> She has been this week in town, and never desired
till this afternoon to go abroad.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Was she not at a play yesterday?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Yes; but she ne'er asked me; I was myself the
cause of her going.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Then if she ask you again, you are the cause of
her asking, and not my example.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, to-morrow night I shall be rid of you;
and the next day, before 'tis light, she and I'll be rid of
the town, and my dreadful apprehensions.&mdash;Come, be not
melancholy; for thou sha't go into the country after
to-morrow, dearest.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Great comfort!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pish! what d'ye tell me of the country for?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How's this! what, pish at the country?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Let me alone; I am not well.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> O, if that be all&mdash;what ails my dearest?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Truly, I don't know: but I have not been
well since you told me there was a gallant at the play in
love with me.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Ha!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> That's by my example too!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Nay, if you are not well, but are so concerned,
because a lewd fellow chanced to lie, and say he liked
you, you'll make me sick too.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Of what sickness?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> O, of that which is worse than the plague,
jealousy.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_286" id="Page_286">[Pg 286]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pish, you jeer! I'm sure there's no such
disease in our receipt-book at home.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, thou never met'st with it, poor innocent.&mdash;Well,
if thou cuckold me, 'twill be my own fault&mdash;for
cuckolds and bastards are generally makers of their own
fortune. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Well, but pray, bud, let's go to a play to-night.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Tis just done, she comes from it. But why are
you so eager to see a play?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Faith, dear, not that I care one pin for
their talk there; but I like to look upon the player-men,
and would see, if I could, the gallant you say loves me:
that's all, dear bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Is that all, dear bud?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> This proceeds from my example!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> But if the play be done, let's go abroad,
however, dear bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come have a little patience and thou shalt go
into the country on Friday.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Therefore I would see first some sights to
tell my neighbours of. Nay, I will go abroad, that's once.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I'm the cause of this desire too!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But now I think on't, who, who was the cause
of Horner's coming to my lodgings to-day? That was
you.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> No, you, because you would not let him see
your handsome wife out of your lodging.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Why, O Lord! did the gentleman come
hither to see me indeed?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, no.&mdash;You are not the cause of that damned
question too, Mistress Alithea?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Well, she's in
the right of it. He is in love with my wife&mdash;and comes
after her&mdash;'tis so&mdash;but I'll nip his love in the bud; lest
he should follow us into the country, and break his
chariot-wheel near our house, on purpose for an excuse
to come to't. But I think I know the town.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_287" id="Page_287">[Pg 287]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Come, pray, bud, let's go abroad before
'tis late; for I will go, that's flat and plain.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So! the obstinacy already of the town-wife;
and I must, whilst she's here, humour her like one.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Sister, how shall we do, that she may not be
seen, or known?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Let her put on her mask.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Pshaw! a mask makes people but the more
inquisitive, and is as ridiculous a disguise as a stage-beard:
her shape, stature, habit will be known. And if
we should meet with Horner, he would be sure to take
acquaintance with us, must wish her joy, kiss her, talk to
her, leer upon her, and the devil and all. No, I'll not
use her to a mask, 'tis dangerous; for masks have made
more cuckolds than the best faces that ever were known.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> How will you do then?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, shall we go? The Exchange will
be shut, and I have a mind to see that.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So&mdash;I have it&mdash;I'll dress her up in the suit we
are to carry down to her brother, little Sir James; nay, I
understand the town-tricks. Come, let's go dress her.
A mask! no&mdash;a woman masked, like a covered dish,
gives a man curiosity and appetite; when, it may be,
uncovered, 'twould turn his stomach: no, no.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Indeed your comparison is something a greasy
one: but I had a gentle gallant used to say, A beauty
masked, like the sun in eclipse, gathers together more
gazers than if it shined out. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>The New Exchange.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Horner, Harcourt</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Engaged to women, and not sup with us!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, a pox on 'em all!</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> You were much a more reasonable man in the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_288" id="Page_288">[Pg 288]</a></span>
morning, and had as noble resolutions against 'em, as a
widower of a week's liberty.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Did I ever think to see you keep company with
women in vain?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> In vain: no&mdash;'tis since I can't love 'em, to be
revenged on 'em.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Now your sting is gone, you looked in the box
amongst all those women like a drone in the hive; all
upon you, shoved and ill-used by 'em all, and thrust from
one side to t'other.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Yet he must be buzzing amongst 'em still, like
other beetle-headed liquorish drones. Avoid 'em, and
hate 'em, as they hate you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Because I do hate 'em, and would hate 'em yet
more, I'll frequent 'em. You may see by marriage,
nothing makes a man hate a woman more than her
constant conversation. In short, I converse with 'em,
as you do with rich fools, to laugh at 'em and use 'em
ill.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> But I would no more sup with women, unless I
could lie with 'em, than sup with a rich coxcomb, unless
I could cheat him.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes, I have known thee sup with a fool for his
drinking; if he could set out your hand that way only,
you were satisfied, and if he were a wine-swallowing
mouth, 'twas enough.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Yes, a man drinks often with a fool, as he tosses
with a marker, only to keep his hand in use. But do the
ladies drink?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes, sir; and I shall have the pleasure at least
of laying 'em flat with a bottle, and bring as much scandal
that way upon 'em as formerly t'other.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Perhaps you may prove as weak a brother among
'em that way as t'other.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Foh! drinking with women is as unnatural as
scolding with 'em. But 'tis a pleasure of decayed fornicators,
and the basest way of quenching love.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_289" id="Page_289">[Pg 289]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Nay, 'tis drowning love, instead of quenching it.
But leave us for civil women too!</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Ay, when he can't be the better for 'em. We
hardly pardon a man that leaves his friend for a wench,
and that's a pretty lawful call.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Faith, I would not leave you for 'em, if they
would not drink.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Who would disappoint his company at Lewis's
for a gossiping?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Foh! Wine and women, good apart, together are
as nauseous as sack and sugar. But hark you, sir, before
you go, a little of your advice; an old maimed general,
when unfit for action, is fittest for counsel. I have other
designs upon women than eating and drinking with them;
I am in love with Sparkish's mistress, whom he is to marry
to-morrow: now how shall I get her?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>, <i>looking about.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, here comes one will help you to her.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> He! he, I tell you, is my rival, and will hinder
my love.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No; a foolish rival and a jealous husband
assist their rival's designs; for they are sure to make
their women hate them, which is the first step to their
love for another man.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> But I cannot come near his mistress but in his
company.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Still the better for you; for fools are most easily
cheated when they themselves are accessories: and he is
to be bubbled of his mistress as of his money, the
common mistress, by keeping him company.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Who is that that is to be bubbled? Faith, let
me snack; I han't met with a bubble since Christmas.
'Gad, I think bubbles are like their brother woodcocks,
go out with the cold weather.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> A pox! he did not hear all, I hope.
[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_290" id="Page_290">[Pg 290]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, you bubbling rogues you, where do we
sup?&mdash;Oh, Harcourt, my mistress tells me you have
been making fierce love to her all the play long: ha!
ha!&mdash;But I&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I make love to her!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, I forgive thee, for I think I know thee,
and I know her; but I am sure I know myself.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Did she tell you so? I see all women are like
these of the Exchange; who, to enhance the prize of
their commodities, report to their fond customers offers
which were never made 'em.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, women are apt to tell before the intrigue,
as men after it, and so show themselves the vainer sex.
But hast thou a mistress, Sparkish? 'Tis as hard for me
to believe it, as that thou ever hadst a bubble, as you
bragged just now.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> O, your servant, sir: are you at your raillery,
sir? But we are some of us beforehand with you to-day
at the play. The wits were something bold with you,
sir; did you not hear us laugh?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes; but I thought you had gone to plays, to
laugh at the poet's wit, not at your own.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Your servant, sir: no, I thank you. 'Gad I go
to a play as to a country treat; I carry my own wine to
one, and my own wit to t'other, or else I'm sure I should
not be merry at either. And the reason why we are so
often louder than the players, is, because we think we
speak more wit, and so become the poet's rivals in his
audience: for to tell you the truth, we hate the silly
rogues; nay, so much, that we find fault even with their
bawdy upon the stage, whilst we talk nothing else in the
pit as loud.</p>
