<p><i>Horn.</i> But why shouldst thou hate the silly poets?
Thou hast too much wit to be one; and they, like
whores, are only hated by each other: and thou dost
scorn writing, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Yes; I'd have you to know I scorn writing:<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_291" id="Page_291">[Pg 291]</a></span>
but women, women, that make men do all foolish things,
make 'em write songs too. Everybody does it. 'Tis
even as common with lovers, as playing with fans; and
you can no more help rhyming to your Phillis, than
drinking to your Phillis.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Nay, poetry in love is no more to be avoided
than jealousy.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> But the poets damned your songs, did they?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Damn the poets! they have turned 'em into
burlesque, as they call it. That burlesque is a hocus-pocus
trick they have got, which, by the virtue of <i>Hictius
doctius topsy turvy</i>, they make a wise and witty man in
the world, a fool upon the stage you know not how: and
'tis therefore I hate 'em too, for I know not but it may
be my own case; for they'll put a man into a play for
looking asquint. Their predecessors were contented to
make serving-men only their stage-fools: but these rogues
must have gentlemen, with a pox to 'em, nay, knights;
and, indeed, you shall hardly see a fool upon the stage
but he's a knight. And to tell you the truth, they have
kept me these six years from being a knight in earnest,
for fear of being knighted in a play, and dubbed a fool.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Blame 'em not, they must follow their copy, the
age.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> But why shouldst thou be afraid of being in a
play, who expose yourself every day in the play-houses,
and at public places?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> 'Tis but being on the stage, instead of standing
on a bench in the pit.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Don't you give money to painters to draw you
like? and are you afraid of your pictures at length in a
playhouse, where all your mistresses may see you?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> A pox! painters don't draw the small-pox or
pimples in one's face. Come, damn all your silly authors
whatever, all books and booksellers, by the world; and
all readers, courteous or uncourteous!</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> But who comes here, Sparkish?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_292" id="Page_292">[Pg 292]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>in man's clothes</i>,
<span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Oh, hide me! There's my mistress too.
[<span class="smcap">Sparkish</span> <i>hides himself behind</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> She sees you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> But I will not see her. 'Tis time to go to
Whitehall, and I must not fail the drawing-room.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Pray, first carry me, and reconcile me to her.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Another time. Faith, the king will have
supped.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Not with the worse stomach for thy absence.
Thou art one of those fools that think their attendance
at the king's meals as necessary as his physicians, when
you are more troublesome to him than his doctors or his
dogs.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! I know my interest, sir. Prithee hide
me.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Your servant, Pinchwife.&mdash;What, he knows us
not!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come along. [<i>To his</i> Wife <i>aside</i>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray, have you any ballads? give me sixpenny
worth.</p>

<p><i>Bookseller.</i> We have no ballads.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Then give me "Covent Garden Drollery,"
and a play or two&mdash;Oh, here's "Tarugo's Wiles," and
"The Slighted Maiden";<a name="FNanchor_75_75" id="FNanchor_75_75"></a><a href="#Footnote_75_75" class="fnanchor">[75]</a> I'll have them.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No; plays are not for your reading. Come
along; will you discover yourself? [<i>Apart to her.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Who is that pretty youth with him, Sparkish?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_293" id="Page_293">[Pg 293]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> I believe his wife's brother, because he's something
like her: but I never saw her but once.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Extremely handsome; I have seen a face like
it too. Let us follow 'em.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife, Alithea</span>,
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy; Horner</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span> <i>following
them.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Come, Sparkish, your mistress saw you, and will
be angry you go not to her. Besides, I would fain be
reconciled to her, which none but you can do, dear
friend.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Well, that's a better reason, dear friend. I
would not go near her now for her's or my own sake;
but I can deny you nothing: for though I have known
thee a great while, never go, if I do not love thee as well
as a new acquaintance.</p>

<p><i>Mar.</i> I am obliged to you indeed, dear friend. I
would be well with her, only to be well with thee still;
for these ties to wives usually dissolve all ties to friends.
I would be contented she should enjoy you a-nights, but
I would have you to myself a-days as I have had, dear
friend.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> And thou shalt enjoy me a-days, dear, dear
friend, never stir: and I'll be divorced from her, sooner
than from thee. Come along.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, we are hard put to't, when we make
our rival our procurer; but neither she nor her brother
would let me come near her now. When all's done, a
rival is the best cloak to steal to a mistress under, without
suspicion; and when we have once got to her as we
desire, we throw him off like other cloaks.
[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish, Harcourt</span> <i>following him.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.] Sister, if you will not go, we
must leave you.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] The fool her gallant and she
will muster up all the young saunterers of this place, and<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_294" id="Page_294">[Pg 294]</a></span>
they will leave their dear sempstresses to follow us. What
a swarm of cuckolds and cuckold-makers are here!&mdash;Come,
let's be gone, Mistress Margery.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Don't you believe that; I han't half my
bellyfull of sights yet.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Then walk this way.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Lord, what a power of brave signs are
here! stay&mdash;the Bull's-Head, the Ram's-Head, and the
Stag's-Head, dear&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Nay, if every husband's proper sign here were
visible, they would be all alike.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What d'ye mean by that, bud?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Tis no matter&mdash;no matter, bud.</p>

<p><i>Mrs Pinch.</i> Pray tell me: nay, I will know.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> They would be all Bulls, Stags, and Rams-heads.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish, Harcourt, Alithea</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>,
<i>at the other side.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, dear madam, for my sake you shall be
reconciled to him.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> For your sake I hate him.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> That's something too cruel, madam, to hate me
for his sake.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay indeed, madam, too, too cruel to me, to
hate my friend for my sake.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I hate him because he is your enemy; and you
ought to hate him too, for making love to me, if you love
me.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> That's a good one! I hate a man for loving
you! If he did love you, 'tis but what he can't help;
and 'tis your fault, not his, if he admires you. I hate a
man for being of my opinion! I'll n'er do't, by the world.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Is it for your honour, or mine, to suffer a man
to make love to me, who am to marry you to-morrow?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Is it for your honour, or mine, to have me
jealous? That he makes love to you, is a sign you are<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_295" id="Page_295">[Pg 295]</a></span>
handsome; and that I am not jealous, is a sign you are
virtuous. That I think is for your honour.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> But 'tis your honour too I am concerned for.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> But why, dearest madam, will you be more
concerned for his honour than he is himself? Let his
honour alone, for my sake and his. He! he has no
honour&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How's that?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> But what my dear friend can guard himself.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> O ho&mdash;that's right again.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Your care of his honour argues his neglect of it,
which is no honour to my dear friend here. Therefore
once more, let his honour go which way it will, dear
madam.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay, ay; were it for my honour to marry a
woman whose virtue I suspected, and could not trust her
in a friend's hands?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Are you not afraid to lose me?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> He afraid to lose you, madam! No, no&mdash;you may
see how the most estimable and most glorious creature
in the world is valued by him. Will you not see it?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Right, honest Frank, I have that noble value
for her that I cannot be jealous of her.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> You mistake him. He means, you care not for
me, nor who has me.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Lord, madam, I see you are jealous! Will you
wrest a poor man's meaning from his words?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> You astonish me, sir, with your want of jealousy.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> And you make me giddy, madam, with your
jealousy and fears, and virtue and honour. 'Gad, I see
virtue makes a woman as troublesome as a little reading
or learning.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Monstrous!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Well, to see what easy husbands these women of
quality can meet with! a poor chambermaid can never
have such ladylike luck. Besides, he's thrown away upon
her. She'll make no use of her fortune, her blessing,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_296" id="Page_296">[Pg 296]</a></span>
none to a gentleman, for a pure cuckold; for it requires
good breeding to be a cuckold. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I tell you then plainly, he pursues me to marry
me.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw!</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Come, madam, you see you strive in vain to make
him jealous of me. My dear friend is the kindest creature
in the world to me.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Poor fellow!</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> But his kindness only is not enough for me,
without your favour, your good opinion, dear madam:
'tis that must perfect my happiness. Good gentleman,
he believes all I say: would you would do so! Jealous
of me! I would not wrong him nor you for the world.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Look you there. Hear him, hear him, and do
not walk away so. [<span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>walks carelessly to and fro.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I love you, madam, so&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How's that? Nay, now you begin to go too far
indeed.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> So much, I confess, I say, I love you, that I would
not have you miserable, and cast yourself away upon so
unworthy and inconsiderable a thing as what you see here.
[<i>Clapping his hand on his breast, points at</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, faith, I believe thou wouldst not: now his
meaning is plain; but I knew before thou wouldst not
wrong me, nor her.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, no, Heavens forbid the glory of her sex
should fall so low, as into the embraces of such a contemptible
wretch, the least of mankind&mdash;my friend here&mdash;I
injure him! [<i>Embracing</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Very well.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, no, dear friend, I knew it.&mdash;Madam, you
see he will rather wrong himself than me, in giving himself
such names.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Do not you understand him yet?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Yes: how modestly he speaks of himself, poor
fellow!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_297" id="Page_297">[Pg 297]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Methinks he speaks impudently of yourself,
since&mdash;before yourself too; insomuch that I can no longer
suffer his scurrilous abusiveness to you, no more than his
love to me. [<i>Offers to go.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, nay, madam, pray stay&mdash;his love to you!
Lord, madam, has he not spoke yet plain enough?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Yes, indeed, I should think so.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Well then, by the world, a man can't speak
civilly to a woman now, but presently she says, he makes
love to her. Nay, madam, you shall stay, with your
pardon, since you have not yet understood him, till he
has made an eclaircissement of his love to you, that is,
what kind of love it is. Answer to thy catechism, friend;
do you love my mistress here?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Yes, I wish she would not doubt it.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> But how do you love her?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> With all my soul.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I thank him, methinks he speaks plain enough
now.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.] You are out still.&mdash;But with what
kind of love, Harcourt?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> With the best and the truest love in the world.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Look you there then, that is with no matrimonial
love, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> How's that? do you say matrimonial love is not
best?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> 'Gad, I went too far ere I was aware. But speak
for thyself, Harcourt, you said you would not wrong me
nor her.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, so, madam, e'en take him for Heaven's sake.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Look you there, madam.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Who should in all justice be yours, he that loves
you most. [<i>Claps his hand on his breast.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Look you there, Mr. Sparkish, who's that?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Who should it be?&mdash;Go on, Harcourt.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Who loves you more than women titles, or
fortune fools. [<i>Points at</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_298" id="Page_298">[Pg 298]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Look you there, he means me still, for he
points at me.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Ridiculous!</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Who can only match your faith and constancy in
love.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Who knows, if it be possible, how to value so
much beauty and virtue.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Whose love can no more be equalled in the world,
than that heavenly form of yours.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Who could no more suffer a rival, than your
absence, and yet could no more suspect your virtue, than
his own constancy in his love to you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Who, in fine, loves you better than his eyes, that
first made him love you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay&mdash;Nay, madam, faith, you shan't go till&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Have a care, lest you make me stay too long.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> But till he has saluted you; that I may be
assured you are friends, after his honest advice and
declaration. Come, pray, madam, be friends with him.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> You must pardon me, sir, that I am not yet so
obedient to you.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, invite your wife to kiss men? Monstrous!
are you not ashamed? I will never forgive you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Are you not ashamed, that I should have more
confidence in the chastity of your family than you have?
You must not teach me, I am a man of honour, sir, though
I am frank and free; I am frank, sir&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Very frank, sir, to share your wife with your
friends.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> He is an humble, menial friend, such as reconciles
the differences of the marriage bed; you know man<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_299" id="Page_299">[Pg 299]</a></span>
and wife do not always agree; I design him for that use,
therefore would have him well with my wife.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> A menial friend!&mdash;you will get a great many
menial friends, by showing your wife as you do.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> What then? It may be I have a pleasure in't,
as I have to show fine clothes at a play-house, the first day,
and count money before poor rogues.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> He that shows his wife or money, will be in
danger of having them borrowed sometimes.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> I love to be envied, and would not marry a wife
that I alone could love; loving alone is as dull as eating
alone. Is it not a frank age? and I am a frank person;
and to tell you the truth, it may be, I love to have rivals
in a wife, they make her seem to a man still but as a kept
mistress; and so good night, for I must to Whitehall.&mdash;Madam,
I hope you are now reconciled to my friend; and
so I wish you a good night, madam, and sleep if you
can: for to-morrow you know I must visit you early with
a canonical gentleman. Good night, dear Harcourt.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Madam, I hope you will not refuse my visit to-morrow,
if it should be earlier with a canonical gentleman
than Mr. Sparkish's.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> This gentlewoman is yet under my care, therefore
you must yet forbear your freedom with her, sir.
[<i>Coming between</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Must, sir?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Yes, sir, she is my sister.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> 'Tis well she is, sir&mdash;for I must be her servant,
sir.&mdash;Madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come away, sister, we had been gone, if it had
not been for you, and so avoided these lewd rake-hells,
who seem to haunt us.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> How now, Pinchwife!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Your servant.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_300" id="Page_300">[Pg 300]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What! I see a little time in the country makes
a man turn wild and unsociable, and only fit to converse
with his horses, dogs, and his herds.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I have business, sir, and must mind it; your
business is pleasure, therefore you and I must go different
ways.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, you may go on, but this pretty young
gentleman&mdash;[<i>Takes hold of Mrs.</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> The lady&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> And the maid&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Shall stay with us; for I suppose their business
is the same with ours, pleasure.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Sdeath, he knows her, she carries it so sillily!
yet if he does not, I should be more silly to discover it
first. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Pray, let us go, sir.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>To</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.] Had you not rather stay
with us?&mdash;Prithee, Pinchwife, who is this pretty young
gentleman?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> One to whom I'm a guardian.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I wish
I could keep her out of your hands.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Who is he? I never saw anything so pretty in
all my life.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Pshaw! do not look upon him so much, he's a
poor bashful youth, you'll put him out of countenance.&mdash;Come
away, brother. [<i>Offers to take her away.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> O, your brother!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Yes, my wife's brother.&mdash;Come, come, she'll
stay supper for us.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I thought so, for he is very like her I saw you
at the play with, whom I told you I was in love with.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O jeminy! is that he that was in
love with me? I am glad on't, I vow, for he's a curious
fine gentleman, and I love him already, too.&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.] Is this he, bud?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come away, come away. [<i>To his</i> Wife.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_301" id="Page_301">[Pg 301]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, what haste are you in? why won't you let
me talk with him?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Because you'll debauch him; he's yet young
and innocent, and I would not have him debauched for
anything in the world.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] How she gazes on him!
the devil!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Harcourt, Dorilant, look you here, this is the
likeness of that dowdy he told us of, his wife; did you
ever see a lovelier creature? The rogue has reason to be
jealous of his wife, since she is like him, for she would
make all that see her in love with her.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> And, as I remember now, she is as like him here
as can be.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> She is indeed very pretty, if she be like him.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Very pretty? a very pretty commendation!&mdash;she
is a glorious creature, beautiful beyond all things I
ever beheld.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So, so.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> More beautiful than a poet's first mistress of
imagination.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Or another man's last mistress of flesh and
blood.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, now you jeer, sir; pray don't jeer
me.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, come.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] By Heavens, she'll
discover herself!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I speak of your sister, sir.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Ay, but saying she was handsome, if like him,
made him blush.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I am upon a rack!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Methinks he is so handsome he should not be
a man.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O, there 'tis out! he has discovered
her! I am not able to suffer any longer.&mdash;[<i>To his</i> Wife.]
Come, come away, I say.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, by your leave, sir, he shall not go yet.&mdash;[<i>Aside
to them.</i>] Harcourt, Dorilant, let us torment this
jealous rogue a little.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_302" id="Page_302">[Pg 302]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Har. Dor.</i> How?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I'll show you.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, pray let him go, I cannot stay fooling
any longer; I tell you his sister stays supper for us.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Does she? Come then, we'll all go to sup with
he and thee.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, now I think on't, having stayed so long for
us, I warrant she's gone to bed.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I wish she and
I were well out of their hands.&mdash;[<i>To his</i> Wife.] Come,
I must rise early to-morrow, come.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well then, if she be gone to bed, I wish her and
you a good night. But pray, young gentleman, present
my humble service to her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Thank you heartily, sir.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] 'Sdeath, she will discover herself yet in
spite of me&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] He is something more civil to
you, for your kindness to his sister, than I am, it seems.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Tell her, dear sweet little gentleman, for all your
brother there, that you have revived the love I had for
her at first sight in the playhouse.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> But did you love her indeed, and indeed?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, so.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Away, I say.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, stay.&mdash;Yes, indeed, and indeed, pray
do you tell her so, and give her this kiss from me.
[<i>Kisses her.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O Heavens! what do I suffer? Now
'tis too plain he knows her, and yet&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And this, and this&mdash;[<i>Kisses her again.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What do you kiss me for? I am no
woman.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, there, 'tis out.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come, I
cannot, nor will stay any longer.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, they shall send your lady a kiss too. Here,
Harcourt, Dorilant, will you not? [<i>They kiss her.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] How! do I suffer this? Was I not
accusing another just now for this rascally patience, in
permitting his wife to be kissed before his face? Ten<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_303" id="Page_303">[Pg 303]</a></span>
thousand ulcers gnaw away their lips.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come,
come.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Good night, dear little gentleman; madam,
good night: farewell, Pinchwife.&mdash;[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.] Did not I tell you I would raise his
jealous gall?
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Horner, Harcourt</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So, they are gone at last; stay, let me see first
if the coach be at this door. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Horner, Harcourt</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What, not gone yet? Will you be sure to do as
I desired you, sweet sir?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Sweet sir, but what will you give me then?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Anything. Come away into the next walk.
[<i>Exit, haling away</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Hold! hold! what d'ye do?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Stay, stay, hold&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Hold, madam, hold, let him present him&mdash;he'll
come presently; nay, I will never let you go till you
answer my question.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> For God's sake, sir, I must follow 'em.
[<span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>, <i>struggling with</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>
<i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> No, I have something to present you with too,
you shan't follow them.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Where?&mdash;how&mdash;what's become of?&mdash;gone!&mdash;whither?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> He's only gone with the gentleman, who will
give him something, an't please your worship.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Something!&mdash;give him something, with a pox!&mdash;where
are they?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> In the next walk only, brother.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Only, only! where, where?
[<i>Exit and returns presently, then goes out again.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_304" id="Page_304">[Pg 304]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> What's the matter with him? why so much concerned?
But, dearest madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Pray let me go, sir; I have said and suffered
enough already.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Then you will not look upon, nor pity, my
sufferings?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> To look upon 'em, when I cannot help 'em,
were cruelty, not pity; therefore, I will never see you
more.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Let me then, madam, have my privilege of a
banished lover, complaining or railing, and giving you
but a farewell reason why, if you cannot condescend to
marry me, you should not take that wretch, my rival.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> He only, not you, since my honour is engaged
so far to him, can give me a reason why I should not
marry him; but if he be true, and what I think him to
me, I must be so to him. Your servant, sir.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Have women only constancy when 'tis a vice,
and are, like Fortune, only true to fools?</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Thou sha't not stir, thou robust creature; you
see I can deal with you, therefore you should stay the
rather, and be kind.
[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>, <i>who struggles to get from him.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Gone, gone, not to be found! quite gone! ten
thousand plagues go with 'em! Which way went they?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> But into t'other walk, brother.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Their business will be done presently sure, an't
please your worship; it can't be long in doing, I'm sure
on't.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Are they not there?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, you know where they are, you infamous
wretch, eternal shame of your family, which you do not
dishonour enough yourself you think, but you must help
her to do it too, thou legion of bawds!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Good brother&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_305" id="Page_305">[Pg 305]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Damned, damned sister!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Look you here, she's coming.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>running, with her hat full of
oranges and dried fruit under her arm,</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>
<i>following.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O dear bud, look you here what I have
got, see!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> And what I have got here too, which you can't
see! [<i>Aside, rubbing his forehead.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> The fine gentleman has given me better
things yet.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Has he so?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Out of breath and
coloured!&mdash;I must hold yet.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I have only given your little brother an orange,
sir.</p>

<p><i>Pinch. [To</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.] Thank you, sir.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] You
have only squeezed my orange, I suppose, and given it
me again; yet I must have a city patience.&mdash;[<i>To his</i>
Wife.] Come, come away.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Stay, till I have put up my fine things, bud.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> O, Master Horner, come, come, the ladies
stay for you; your mistress, my wife, wonders you make
not more haste to her.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I have stayed this half hour for you here, and
'tis your fault I am not now with your wife.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> But, pray, don't let her know so much; the
truth on't is, I was advancing a certain project to his
majesty about&mdash;I'll tell you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, let's go, and hear it at your house. Good
night, sweet little gentleman; one kiss more, you'll remember
me now, I hope. [<i>Kisses her.</i></p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> What, Sir Jasper, will you separate friends? He
promised to sup with us, and if you take him to your
house, you'll be in danger of our company too.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_306" id="Page_306">[Pg 306]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Alas! gentlemen, my house is not fit for
you; there are none but civil women there, which are not
for your turn. He, you know, can bear with the society
of civil women now, ha! ha! ha! besides, he's one of my
family&mdash;he's&mdash;he! he! he!</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> What is he?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Faith, my eunuch, since you'll have it; he!
he! he! [<i>Exeunt</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> I rather wish thou wert his or my cuckold.
Harcourt, what a good cuckold is lost there for want of a
man to make him one? Thee and I cannot have Horner's
privilege, who can make use of it.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Ay, to poor Horner 'tis like coming to an estate
at threescore, when a man can't be the better for't.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Presently, bud.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Come, let us go too.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.] Madam,
your servant.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.] Good night, strapper.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Madam, though you will not let me have a good
day or night, I wish you one; but dare not name the
other half of my wish.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Good night, sir, for ever.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> I don't know where to put this here, dear
bud, you shall eat it; nay, you shall have part of the fine
gentleman's good things, or treat, as you call it, when we
come home.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Indeed, I deserve it, since I furnished the best
part of it. [<i>Strikes away the orange.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The gallant treats presents, and gives the ball;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But 'tis the absent cuckold pays for all.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_307" id="Page_307">[Pg 307]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FOURTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Pinchwife's</span> <i>House in the morning.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>dressed in new clothes, and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Well&mdash;madam, now have I
dressed you, and set you out with so
many ornaments, and spent upon you
ounces of essence and pulvillio;<a name="FNanchor_76_76" id="FNanchor_76_76"></a><a href="#Footnote_76_76" class="fnanchor">[76]</a> and
all this for no other purpose but as
people adorn and perfume a corpse
for a stinking second-hand grave: such, or as bad, I
think Master Sparkish's bed.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Hold your peace.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Nay, madam, I will ask you the reason why you
would banish poor Master Harcourt for ever from your
sight; how could you be so hard-hearted?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> 'Twas because I was not hard-hearted.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> No, no; 'twas stark love and kindness, I
warrant.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> It was so; I would see him no more because I
love him.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Hey day, a very pretty reason!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> You do not understand me.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I wish you may yourself.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I was engaged to marry, you see, another man,
whom my justice will not suffer me to deceive or injure.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_308" id="Page_308">[Pg 308]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Can there be a greater cheat or wrong done to
a man than to give him your person without your heart?
I should make a conscience of it.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I'll retrieve it for him after I am married a
while.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> The woman that marries to love better, will be
as much mistaken as the wencher that marries to live
better. No, madam, marrying to increase love is like
gaming to become rich; alas! you only lose what little
stock you had before.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I find by your rhetoric you have been bribed to
betray me.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Only by his merit, that has bribed your heart,
you see, against your word and rigid honour. But what
a devil is this honour! 'tis sure a disease in the head,
like the megrim or falling-sickness, that always hurries
people away to do themselves mischief. Men lose their
lives by it; women, what's dearer to 'em, their love, the
life of life.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Come, pray talk you no more of honour, nor
Master Harcourt; I wish the other would come to secure
my fidelity to him and his right in me.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> You will marry him then?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Certainly, I have given him already my word,
and will my hand too, to make it good, when he comes.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Well, I wish I may never stick pin more, if he
be not an arrant natural, to t'other fine gentleman.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I own he wants the wit of Harcourt, which I
will dispense withal for another want he has, which is
want of jealousy, which men of wit seldom want.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Lord, madam, what should you do with a fool
to your husband? You intend to be honest, don't you?
then that husbandly virtue, credulity, is thrown away
upon you.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> He only that could suspect my virtue should
have cause to do it; 'tis Sparkish's confidence in my truth
that obliges me to be so faithful to him.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_309" id="Page_309">[Pg 309]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> You are not sure his opinion may last.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I am satisfied, 'tis impossible for him to be
jealous after the proofs I have had of him. Jealousy in
a husband&mdash;Heaven defend me from it! it begets a
thousand plagues to a poor woman, the loss of her
honour, her quiet, and her&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> And her pleasure.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> What d'ye mean, impertinent?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Liberty is a great pleasure, madam.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I say, loss of her honour, her quiet, nay, her
life sometimes; and what's as bad almost, the loss of this
town; that is, she is sent into the country, which is the
last ill-usage of a husband to a wife, I think.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O, does the wind lie there?&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Then of necessity, madam, you think a man must carry
his wife into the country, if he be wise. The country is
as terrible, I find, to our young English ladies, as a
monastery to those abroad; and on my virginity, I think
they would rather marry a London jailer, than a high
sheriff of a county, since neither can stir from his employment.
Formerly women of wit married fools for a great
estate, a fine seat, or the like; but now 'tis for a pretty
seat only in Lincoln's-Inn-Fields, St. James's-Fields, or
the Pall-Mall.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>, <i>dressed like a</i> Parson.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Madam, your humble servant, a happy day to
you, and to us all.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Amen.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Who have we here?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> My chaplain, faith&mdash;O madam, poor Harcourt
remembers his humble service to you; and, in obedience
to your last commands, refrains coming into your sight.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Is not that he?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, fy, no; but to show that he ne'er intended
to hinder our match, has sent his brother here to join our
hands. When I get me a wife, I must get her a chaplain,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_310" id="Page_310">[Pg 310]</a></span>
according to the custom; that is his brother, and my
chaplain.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> His brother!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> And your chaplain, to preach in your pulpit
then&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> His brother!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, I knew you would not believe it.&mdash;I told
you, sir, she would take you for your brother Frank.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Believe it!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> His brother! ha! ha! he! he has a trick left
still, it seems. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, my dearest, pray let us go to church
before the canonical hour is past.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> For shame, you are abused still.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> By the world, 'tis strange now you are so incredulous.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> 'Tis strange you are so credulous.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Dearest of my life, hear me. I tell you this is
Ned Harcourt of Cambridge, by the world; you see he
has a sneaking college look. 'Tis true he's something
like his brother Frank; and they differ from each other
no more than in their age, for they were twins.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Ha! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Your servant, sir; I cannot be so deceived,
though you are. But come, let's hear, how do you know
what you affirm so confidently?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Why, I'll tell you all. Frank Harcourt coming
to me this morning to wish me joy, and present his service
to you, I asked him if he could help me to a parson.
Whereupon he told me, he had a brother in town who was
in orders; and he went straight away, and sent him, you
see there, to me.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Yes, Frank goes and puts on a black coat, then
tells you he is Ned; that's all you have for't.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! pshaw! I tell you, by the same token,
the midwife put her garter about Frank's neck, to know
'em asunder, they were so like.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_311" id="Page_311">[Pg 311]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Frank tells you this too?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay, and Ned there too: nay, they are both in
a story.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> So, so; very foolish.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Lord, if you won't believe one, you had best
try him by your chambermaid there; for chambermaids
must needs know chaplains from other men, they are so
used to 'em.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Let's see: nay, I'll be sworn he has the canonical
smirk, and the filthy clammy palm of a chaplain.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Well, most reverend doctor, pray let us make an
end of this fooling.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> With all my soul, divine heavenly creature, when
you please.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> He speaks like a chaplain indeed.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Why, was there not soul, divine, heavenly, in
what he said?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Once more, most impertinent black coat, cease
your persecution, and let us have a conclusion of this
ridiculous love.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I had forgot, I must suit my style to my coat, or
I wear it in vain. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I have no more patience left; let us make once
an end of this troublesome love, I say.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> So be it, seraphic lady, when your honour shall
think it meet and convenient so to do.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> 'Gad I'm sure none but a chaplain could speak
so, I think.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Let me tell you, sir, this dull trick will not serve
your turn; though you delay our marriage, you shall not
hinder it.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Far be it from me, munificent patroness, to delay
your marriage; I desire nothing more than to marry you
presently, which I might do, if you yourself would; for
my noble, good-natured, and thrice generous patron here
would not hinder it.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, poor man, not I, faith.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_312" id="Page_312">[Pg 312]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Har.</i> And now, madam, let me tell you plainly nobody
else shall marry you; by Heavens! I'll die first, for I'm
sure I should die after it.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> How his love has made him forget his function,
as I have seen it in real parsons!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> That was spoken like a chaplain too? now you
understand him, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Poor man, he takes it heinously to be refused;
I can't blame him, 'tis putting an indignity upon him, not
to be suffered; but you'll pardon me, madam, it shan't
be; he shall marry us; come away, pray madam.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Ha! ha! he! more ado! 'tis late.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Invincible stupidity! I tell you, he would marry
me as your rival, not as your chaplain.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, come, madam. [<i>Pulling her away.</i></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I pray, madam, do not refuse this reverend divine
the honour and satisfaction of marrying you; for I dare
say, he has set his heart upon't, good doctor.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> What can you hope or design by this?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I could answer her, a reprieve for a day only,
often revokes a hasty doom. At worst, if she will not
take mercy on me, and let me marry her, I have at least
the lover's second pleasure, hindering my rival's enjoyment,
though but for a time. [<i>Aside</i>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, madam, 'tis e'en twelve o'clock, and my
mother charged me never to be married out of the canonical
hours. Come, come; Lord, here's such a deal of
modesty, I warrant, the first day.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Yes, an't please your worship, married women
show all their modesty the first day, because married men
show all their love the first day. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_313" id="Page_313">[Pg 313]</a></span></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>A Bedchamber in</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>discovered.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, tell me, I say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Lord! han't I told it a hundred times
over?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I would try, if in the repetition of the
ungrateful tale, I could find her altering it in the least
circumstance; for if her story be false, she is so too.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Come, how was't, baggage?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Lord, what pleasure you take to hear it
sure!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, you take more in telling it I find; but
speak, how was't?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> He carried me up into the house next to
the Exchange.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So, and you two were only in the room!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, for he sent away a youth that was
there, for some dried fruit, and China oranges.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Did he so? Damn him for it&mdash;and for&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> But presently came up the gentlewoman
of the house.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> O, 'twas well she did; but what did he do
whilst the fruit came?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> He kissed me a hundred times, and told
me he fancied he kissed my fine sister, meaning me, you
know, whom he said he loved with all his soul, and bid me
be sure to tell her so, and to desire her to be at her window,
by eleven of the clock this morning, and he would walk
under it at that time.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> And he was as good as his word, very punctual;
a pox reward him for't. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Well, and he said if you were not within,
he would come up to her, meaning me, you know, bud,
still.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So&mdash;he knew her certainly; but for<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_314" id="Page_314">[Pg 314]</a></span>
this confession, I am obliged to her simplicity.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
But what, you stood very still when he kissed you?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, I warrant you; would you have had
me discovered myself?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But you told me he did some beastliness to you,
as you call it; what was't?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Why, he put&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Why, he put the tip of his tongue
between my lips, and so mousled me&mdash;and I said, I'd
bite it.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> An eternal canker seize it, for a dog!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, you need not be so angry with him
neither, for to say truth, he has the sweetest breath I
ever knew.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> The devil! you were satisfied with it then, and
would do it again?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Not unless he should force me.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Force you, changeling! I tell you, no woman
can be forced.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, but she may sure, by such a one as
he, for he's a proper, goodly, strong man; 'tis hard, let
me tell you, to resist him.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, 'tis plain she loves him, yet she has
not love enough to make her conceal it from me; but the
sight of him will increase her aversion for me and love for
him; and that love instruct her how to deceive me and
satisfy him, all idiot as she is. Love! 'twas he gave
women first their craft, their art of deluding. Out of
Nature's hands they came plain, open, silly, and fit for
slaves, as she and Heaven intended 'em; but damned
Love&mdash;well&mdash;I must strangle that little monster whilst I
can deal with him.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Go fetch pen, ink, and
paper out of the next room.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, bud. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Why should women have more invention in love
than men? It can only be, because they have more<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_315" id="Page_315">[Pg 315]</a></span>
desires, more soliciting passions, more lust, and more of
the devil.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p>Come, minx, sit down and write.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Ay, dear bud, but I can't do't very
well.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I wish you could not at all.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> But what should I write for?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I'll have you write a letter to your lover.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O Lord, to the fine gentleman a letter!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Yes, to the fine gentleman.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Lord, you do but jeer: sure you jest.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I am not so merry: come, write as I bid
you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What, do you think I am a fool?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] She's afraid I would not dictate any love
to him, therefore she's unwilling.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] But you had
best begin.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Indeed, and indeed, but I won't, so I
won't.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Why?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Because he's in town; you may send for
him if you will.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Very well, you would have him brought to you;
is it come to this? I say, take the pen and write, or you'll
provoke me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Lord, what d'ye make a fool of me for?
Don't I know that letters are never writ but from the
country to London, and from London into the country?
Now he's in town, and I am in town too; therefore I can't
write to him, you know.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, I am glad it is no worse; she is
innocent enough yet.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Yes, you may, when
your husband bids you, write letters to people that are
in town.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O, may I so? then I'm satisfied.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, begin:&mdash;"Sir"&mdash;[<i>Dictates.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_316" id="Page_316">[Pg 316]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Shan't I say, "Dear Sir?"&mdash;You know one
says always something more than bare "sir."</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Write as I bid you, or I will write whore with
this penknife in your face.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, good bud&mdash;"Sir"&mdash;[<i>Writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> "Though I suffered last night your nauseous,
loathed kisses and embraces"&mdash;Write!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch</i> Nay, why should I say so? You know I
told you he had a sweet breath.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Write!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Let me but put out "loathed."</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Write, I say!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Well then. [<i>Writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Let's see, what have you writ?&mdash;[<i>Takes the
paper and reads.</i>] "Though I suffered last night your
kisses and embraces"&mdash;Thou impudent creature! where
is "nauseous" and "loathed?"</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> I can't abide to write such filthy words.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Once more write as I'd have you, and question
it not, or I will spoil thy writing with this. I will stab
out those eyes that cause my mischief.
[<i>Holds up the penknife.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O Lord! I will.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> So&mdash;so&mdash;let's see now.&mdash;[<i>Reads.</i>] "Though I
suffered last night your nauseous, loathed kisses and
embraces"&mdash;go on&mdash;"yet I would not have you presume
that you shall ever repeat them"&mdash;so&mdash;[<i>She writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> I have writ it.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> On, then&mdash;"I then concealed myself from your
knowledge, to avoid your insolencies."&mdash;[<i>She writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> So&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> "The same reason, now I am out of your
hands&mdash;" [<i>She writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> So&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> "Makes me own to you my unfortunate, though
innocent frolic, of being in man's clothes"&mdash;[<i>She writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> So&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_317" id="Page_317">[Pg 317]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> "That you may for evermore cease to pursue
her, who hates and detests you"&mdash;[<i>She writes on.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> So&mdash;heigh! [<i>Sighs.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, do you sigh?&mdash;"detests you&mdash;as much
as she loves her husband and her honour&mdash;"</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> I vow, husband, he'll ne'er believe I
should write such a letter.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, he'd expect a kinder from you? Come,
now your name only.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What, shan't I say "Your most faithful
humble servant till death?"</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, tormenting fiend!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Her style, I
find, would be very soft.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come, wrap it up
now whilst I go fetch wax and a candle; and write on
the backside, "For Mr. Horner." [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> "For Mr. Horner."&mdash;So, I am glad he
has told me his name. Dear Mr. Horner! but why
should I send thee such a letter that will vex thee, and
make thee angry with me?&mdash;Well, I will not send it.&mdash;Ay,
but then my husband will kill me&mdash;for I see plainly
he won't let me love Mr. Horner&mdash;but what care I for
my husband?&mdash;I won't, so I won't, send poor Mr.
Horner such a letter&mdash;But then my husband&mdash;but oh,
what if I writ at bottom my husband made me write it?&mdash;Ay,
but then my husband would see't&mdash;Can one have no
shift? ah, a London woman would have had a hundred
presently. Stay&mdash;what if I should write a letter, and
wrap it up like this, and write upon't too? Ay, but then
my husband would see't&mdash;I don't know what to do.&mdash;But
yet evads I'll try, so I will&mdash;for I will not send this
letter to poor Mr. Horner, come what will on't.</p>

<p>"Dear, sweet Mr. Horner"&mdash;[<i>Writes and repeats what
she writes.</i>]&mdash;so&mdash;"my husband would have me send you
a base, rude, unmannerly letter; but I won't"&mdash;so&mdash;"and
would have me forbid you loving me; but I won't"&mdash;so&mdash;"and
would have me say to you, I hate you, poor
Mr. Horner; but I won't tell a lie for him"&mdash;there&mdash;"for<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_318" id="Page_318">[Pg 318]</a></span>
I'm sure if you and I were in the country at cards
together"&mdash;so&mdash;"I could not help treading on your toe
under the table"&mdash;so&mdash;"or rubbing knees with you, and
staring in your face, till you saw me"&mdash;very well&mdash;"and
then looking down, and blushing for an hour together"&mdash;so&mdash;"but
I must make haste before my husband
comes: and now he has taught me to write letters,
you shall have longer ones from me, who am, dear,
dear, poor, dear Mr. Horner, your most humble friend,
and servant to command till death,&mdash;Margery Pinchwife."</p>

<p>Stay, I must give him a hint at bottom&mdash;so&mdash;now wrap
it up just like t'other&mdash;so&mdash;now write "For Mr. Horner"&mdash;But
oh now, what shall I do with it? for here comes
my husband.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I have been detained by a sparkish
coxcomb, who pretended a visit to me; but I fear 'twas
to my wife&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] What, have you done?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Ay, ay, bud, just now.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Let's see't: what d'ye tremble for? what, you
would not have it go?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Here&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] No, I must not give him
that: so I had been served if I had given him this.
[<i>He opens and reads the first letter.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, where's the wax and seal?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Lord, what shall I do now? Nay,
then I have it&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Pray let me see't. Lord, you
think me so arrant a fool, I cannot seal a letter; I will
do't, so I will.
[<i>Snatches the letter from him, changes it for the other,
seals it, and delivers it to him.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Nay, I believe you will learn that, and other
things too, which I would not have you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> So, han't I done it curiously<a name="FNanchor_77_77" id="FNanchor_77_77"></a><a href="#Footnote_77_77" class="fnanchor">[77]</a>?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_319" id="Page_319">[Pg 319]</a></span>
I think I have; there's my letter going to Mr. Horner,
since he'll needs have me send letters to folks.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Tis very well; but I warrant, you would not
have it go now?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, indeed, but I would, bud, now.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, you are a good girl then. Come, let me
lock you up in your chamber, till I come back; and be
sure you come not within three strides of the window
when I am gone, for I have a spy in the street.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i>
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife, Pinchwife</span> <i>locks the door.</i>] At least, 'tis
fit she think so. If we do not cheat women, they'll
cheat us, and fraud may be justly used with secret
enemies, of which a wife is the most dangerous; and he
that has a handsome one to keep, and a frontier town,
must provide against treachery, rather than open force.
Now I have secured all within, I'll deal with the foe
without, with false intelligence.
[<i>Holds up the letter. Exit.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Horner's</span> <i>Lodging</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span> <i>and</i> Quack.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Well, sir, how fadges<a name="FNanchor_78_78" id="FNanchor_78_78"></a><a href="#Footnote_78_78" class="fnanchor">[78]</a> the new design? have
you not the luck of all your brother projectors, to deceive
only yourself at last?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, good domine doctor, I deceive you, it
seems, and others too; for the grave matrons, and old,
rigid husbands think me as unfit for love, as they are;
but their wives, sisters, and daughters know, some of
'em, better things already.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Already!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Already, I say. Last night I was drunk with
half-a-dozen of your civil persons, as you call 'em, and<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_320" id="Page_320">[Pg 320]</a></span>
people of honour, and so was made free of their society
and dressing-rooms for ever hereafter; and am already
come to the privileges of sleeping upon their pallets,
warming smocks, tying shoes and garters, and the like,
doctor, already, already, doctor.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> You have made good use of your time, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I tell thee, I am now no more interruption to
'em, when they sing, or talk bawdy, than a little squab
French page who speaks no English.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> But do civil persons and women of honour
drink, and sing bawdy songs?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> O, amongst friends, amongst friends. For your
bigots in honour are just like those in religion; they fear
the eye of the world more than the eye of Heaven; and
think there is no virtue, but railing at vice, and no sin,
but giving scandal. They rail at a poor, little, kept
player, and keep themselves some young, modest pulpit
comedian to be privy to their sins in their closets, not
to tell 'em of them in their chapels.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Nay, the truth on't is, priests, amongst the
women now, have quite got the better of us lay-confessors,
physicians.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And they are rather their patients; but&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, <i>looking about her.</i></p>

<p>Now we talk of women of honour, here comes one. Step
behind the screen there, and but observe, if I have not
particular privileges with the women of reputation already,
doctor, already. [Quack <i>retires.</i></p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Well, Horner, am not I a woman of honour?
you see, I'm as good as my word.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And you shall see, madam, I'll not be behindhand
with you in honour; and I'll be as good as my
word too, if you please but to withdraw into the next
room.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But first, my dear sir, you must promise to
have a care of my dear honour.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_321" id="Page_321">[Pg 321]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> If you talk a word more of your honour,
you'll make me incapable to wrong it. To talk of
honour in the mysteries of love, is like talking of Heaven
or the Deity, in an operation of witchcraft, just when
you are employing the devil: it makes the charm
impotent.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Nay, fy! let us not be smutty. But you
talk of mysteries and bewitching to me; I don't understand
you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I tell you, madam, the word money in a
mistress's mouth, at such a nick of time, is not a more
disheartening sound to a younger brother, than that of
honour to an eager lover like myself.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> But you can't blame a lady of my reputation
to be chary.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Chary! I have been chary of it already, by the
report I have caused of myself.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Ay, but if you should ever let other women
know that dear secret, it would come out. Nay, you
must have a great care of your conduct; for my acquaintance
are so censorious, (oh, 'tis a wicked, censorious
world, Mr. Horner!) I say, are so censorious, and detracting,
that perhaps they'll talk to the prejudice of my
honour, though you should not let them know the dear
secret.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, madam, rather than they shall prejudice
your honour, I'll prejudice theirs; and, to serve
you, I'll lie with 'em all, make the secret their own,
and then they'll keep it. I am a Machiavel in love,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> O, no sir, not that way.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, the devil take me, if censorious women
are to be silenced any other way.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> A secret is better kept, I hope, by a single
person than a multitude; therefore pray do not trust any
body else with it, dear, dear Mr. Horner.
[<i>Embracing him.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_322" id="Page_322">[Pg 322]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> How now!</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O my husband!&mdash;prevented&mdash;and
what's almost as bad, found with my arms about another
man&mdash;that will appear too much&mdash;what shall I say?&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Sir Jasper, come hither: I am trying if Mr.
Horner were ticklish, and he's as ticklish as can be. I
love to torment the confounded toad; let you and I
tickle him.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> No, your ladyship will tickle him better
without me, I suppose. But is this your buying china?
I thought you had been at the china-house.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] China-house! that's my cue, I must
take it.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] A pox! can't you keep your impertinent
wives at home? Some men are troubled with the
husbands, but I with the wives; but I'd have you to
know, since I cannot be your journeyman by night, I
will not be your drudge by day, to squire your wife about,
and be your man of straw, or scarecrow only to pies and
jays, that would be nibbling at your forbidden fruit; I
shall be shortly the hackney gentleman-usher of the town.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] He! he! he! poor fellow, he's in
the right on't, faith. To squire women about for other
folks is as ungrateful an employment, as to tell money
for other folks.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] He! he! he! be'n't angry,
Horner.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> No, 'tis I have more reason to be angry,
who am left by you, to go abroad indecently alone; or,
what is more indecent, to pin myself upon such ill-bred
people of your acquaintance as this is.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nay, prithee, what has he done?</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Nay, he has done nothing.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> But what d'ye take ill, if he has done
nothing?</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Ha! ha! ha! faith, I can't but laugh however;
why, d'ye think the unmannerly toad would come<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_323" id="Page_323">[Pg 323]</a></span>
down to me to the coach? I was fain to come up to
fetch him, or go without him, which I was resolved not
to do; for he knows china very well, and has himself
very good, but will not let me see it, lest I should beg
some; but I will find it out, and have what I came for
yet.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Apart to</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, <i>as he follows her to the
door.</i>] Lock the door, madam.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, <i>and
locks the door.</i>]&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] So, she has got into my
chamber and locked me out. Oh the impertinency of
woman-kind! Well, Sir Jasper, plain-dealing is a jewel;
if ever you suffer your wife to trouble me again here, she
shall carry you home a pair of horns; by my lord mayor
she shall; though I cannot furnish you myself, you are
sure, yet I'll find a way.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ha! ha! he!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] At my first coming
in, and finding her arms about him, tickling him it seems,
I was half jealous, but now I see my folly.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
He! he! he! poor Horner.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, though you laugh now, 'twill be my turn
ere long. Oh women, more impertinent, more cunning,
and more mischievous than their monkeys, and to me
almost as ugly!&mdash;Now is she throwing my things about
and rifling all I have; but I'll get into her the back way,
and so rifle her for it.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ha! ha! ha! poor angry Horner.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Stay here a little, I'll ferret her out to you
presently, I warrant. <i>Exit at the other door.</i>
[Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper</span> <i>talks through the door to his</i> Wife,
<i>she answers from within.</i></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Wife! my Lady Fidget! wife! he is coming
in to you the back way.</p>

<p><i>Lady Fid.</i> Let him come, and welcome, which way he
will.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He'll catch you, and use you roughly, and
be too strong for you.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Don't you trouble yourself, let him if he can.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_324" id="Page_324">[Pg 324]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] This indeed I could not have believed
from him, nor any but my own eyes.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Where's this woman-hater, this toad,
this ugly, greasy, dirty sloven?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, the women all will have him
ugly; methinks he is a comely person, but his wants
make his form contemptible to 'em; and 'tis e'en as my
wife said yesterday, talking of him, that a proper handsome
eunuch was as ridiculous a thing as a gigantic
coward.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Sir Jasper, your servant: where is the
odious beast?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He's within in his chamber, with my wife;
she's playing the wag with him.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Is she so? and he's a clownish beast,
he'll give her no quarter, he'll play the wag with her
again, let me tell you: come, let's go help her&mdash;What,
the door's locked?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, my wife locked it.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Did she so? let's break it open then.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> No, no, he'll do her no hurt.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] But is there no other way to get
in to 'em? whither goes this? I will disturb 'em.
[<i>Exit at another door.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Old Lady <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Where is this harlotry, this impudent
baggage, this rambling tomrigg?<a name="FNanchor_79_79" id="FNanchor_79_79"></a><a href="#Footnote_79_79" class="fnanchor">[79]</a> O Sir Jasper, I'm glad
to see you here; did you not see my vile grandchild
come in hither just now?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Ay, but where is she then? where is she?
Lord, Sir Jasper, I have e'en rattled myself to pieces in
pursuit of her: but can you tell what she makes here?
they say below, no woman lodges here.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_325" id="Page_325">[Pg 325]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> No.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> No! what does she here then? say, if it
be not a woman's lodging, what makes she here? But
are you sure no woman lodges here?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> No, nor no man neither, this is Mr. Horner's
lodging.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Is it so, are you sure?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Yes, yes.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> So; then there's no hurt in't, I hope. But
where is he?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He's in the next room with my wife.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Nay, if you trust him with your wife, I
may with my Biddy. They say, he's a merry harmless
man now, e'en as harmless a man as ever came out of
Italy with a good voice, and as pretty, harmless company
for a lady, as a snake without his teeth.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, ay, poor man.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> I can't find 'em.&mdash;Oh, are you here,
grandmother? I followed, you must know, my Lady
Fidget hither; 'tis the prettiest lodging, and I have been
staring on the prettiest pictures&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span> <i>with a piece of china in her hand,
and</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span> <i>following.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> And I have been toiling and moiling for the
prettiest piece of china, my dear.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, she has been too hard for me, do what I
could.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Oh, lord, I'll have some china too.
Good Mr. Horner, don't think to give other people china,
and me none; come in with me too.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Upon my honour, I have none left now.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Nay, nay, I have known you deny your
china before now, but you shan't put me off so. Come.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> This lady had the last there.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_326" id="Page_326">[Pg 326]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Yes indeed, madam, to my certain knowledge,
he has no more left.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> O, but it may be he may have some you
could not find.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> What, d'ye think if he had had any left, I
would not have had it too? for we women of quality
never think we have china enough.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Do not take it ill, I cannot make china for
you all, but I will have a roll-waggon for you too, another
time.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Thank you, dear toad.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> What do you mean by that promise?
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Alas, she has an innocent, literal understanding.
[<i>Aside to</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Poor Mr. Horner! he has enough to do
to please you all, I see.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, madam, you see how they use me.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Poor gentleman, I pity you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I thank you, madam: I could never find pity,
but from such reverend ladies as you are; the young ones
will never spare a man.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Come, come, beast, and go dine with
us; for we shall want a man at ombre after dinner.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> That's all their use of me, madam, you see.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Come, sloven, I'll lead you, to be sure
of you. [<i>Pulls him by the cravat.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Alas, poor man, how she tugs him! Kiss,
kiss her; that's the way to make such nice women quiet.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, madam, that remedy is worse than the torment;
they know I dare suffer anything rather than do it.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Prithee kiss her, and I'll give you her picture
in little, that you admired so last night; prithee do.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, nothing but that could bribe me: I love
a woman only in effigy, and good painting as much as I
hate them.&mdash;I'll do't, for I could adore the devil well
painted. [<i>Kisses</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_327" id="Page_327">[Pg 327]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Foh, you filthy toad! nay, now I've
done jesting.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> Ha! ha I ha! I told you so.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Foh! a kiss of his&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Has no more hurt in't than one of my
spaniel's.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Nor no more good neither.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> I will now believe anything he tells me. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> O lord, here's a man! Sir Jasper, my mask,
my mask! I would not be seen here for the world.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> What, not when I am with you?</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> No, no, my honour&mdash;let's be gone.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Oh grandmother, let's be gone; make
haste, make haste, I know not how he may censure us.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Be found in the lodging of anything like a
man!&mdash;Away.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>, Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, Old
Lady <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>, <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> What's here? another cuckold? he looks like one,
and none else sure have any business with him. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, what brings my dear friend hither?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Your impertinency.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> My impertinency!&mdash;why, you gentlemen that
have got handsome wives, think you have a privilege of
saying anything to your friends, and are as brutish as if
you were our creditors.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No, sir, I'll ne'er trust you any way.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But why not, dear Jack? why diffide in me thou
know'st so well?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Because I do know you so well.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Han't I been always thy friend, honest Jack,
always ready to serve thee, in love or battle, before thou
wert married, and am so still?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I believe so, you would be my second now,
indeed.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_328" id="Page_328">[Pg 328]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well then, dear Jack, why so unkind, so grum,
so strange to me? Come, prithee kiss me, dear rogue:
gad I was always, I say, and am still as much thy servant
as&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> As I am yours, sir. What, you would send a
kiss to my wife, is that it?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, there 'tis&mdash;a man can't show his friendship
to a married man, but presently he talks of his wife to
you. Prithee, let thy wife alone, and let thee and I be
all one, as we were wont. What, thou art as shy of my
kindness, as a Lombard-street alderman of a courtier's
civility at Locket's!<a name="FNanchor_80_80" id="FNanchor_80_80"></a><a href="#Footnote_80_80" class="fnanchor">[80]</a></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But you are over-kind to me, as kind as if I
were your cuckold already; yet I must confess you ought
to be kind and civil to me, since I am so kind, so civil
to you, as to bring you this: look you there, sir.
[<i>Delivers him a letter.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What is't?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Only a love-letter, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> From whom?&mdash;how! this is from your wife&mdash;hum&mdash;and
hum&mdash;[<i>Reads.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Even from my wife, sir: am I not wondrous
kind and civil to you now too?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] But you'll not
think her so.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ha! is this a trick of his or hers? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> The gentleman's surprised I find.&mdash;What, you
expected a kinder letter?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No faith, not I, how could I?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Yes, yes, I'm sure you did. A man so well
made as you are, must needs be disappointed, if the
women declare not their passion at first sight or opportunity.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] But what should this mean? Stay, the
postscript.&mdash;[<i>Reads aside.</i>] "Be sure you love me, whatsoever
my husband says to the contrary, and let him not<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_329" id="Page_329">[Pg 329]</a></span>
see this, lest he should come home and pinch me, or kill
my squirrel."&mdash;It seems he knows not what the letter
contains.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, ne'er wonder at it so much.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Faith, I can't help it.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Now, I think I have deserved your infinite
friendship and kindness, and have showed myself
sufficiently an obliging kind friend and husband; am I
not so, to bring a letter from my wife to her gallant?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, the devil take me, art thou, the most
obliging, kind friend and husband in the world, ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, you may be merry, sir; but in short I
must tell you, sir, my honour will suffer no jesting.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What dost thou mean?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Does the letter want a comment? Then, know,
sir, though I have been so civil a husband, as to bring
you a letter from my wife, to let you kiss and court her
to my face, I will not be a cuckold, sir, I will not.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Thou art mad with jealousy. I never saw thy
wife in my life but at the play yesterday, and I know not
if it were she or no. I court her, kiss her!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I will not be a cuckold, I say; there will be
danger in making me a cuckold.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, wert thou not well cured of thy last clap?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I wear a sword.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> It should be taken from thee, lest thou shouldst
do thyself a mischief with it; thou art mad, man.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> As mad as I am, and as merry as you are,
I must have more reason from you ere we part. I
say again, though you kissed and courted last night my
wife in man's clothes, as she confesses in her letter&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ha! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Both she and I say, you must not design it
again, for you have mistaken your woman, as you have
done your man.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O&mdash;I understand something now&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Was that thy wife! Why wouldst thou not tell<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_330" id="Page_330">[Pg 330]</a></span>
me 'twas she? Faith, my freedom with her was your
fault, not mine.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Faith, so 'twas. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Fy! I'd never do't to a woman before her
husband's face, sure.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But I had rather you should do't to my wife
before my face, than behind my back; and that you shall
never do.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No&mdash;you will hinder me.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> If I would not hinder you, you see by her letter
she would.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, I must e'en acquiesce then, and be contented
with what she writes.</p>
