<p><i>Pinch.</i> I'll assure you 'twas voluntarily writ; I had no
hand in't you may believe me.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I do believe thee, faith.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> And believe her too, for she's an innocent
creature, has no dissembling in her: and so fare you
well, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Pray, however, present my humble service to
her, and tell her, I will obey her letter to a tittle, and
fulfil her desires, be what they will, or with what difficulty
soever I do't; and you shall be no more jealous of me, I
warrant her, and you.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well then, fare you well; and play with any
man's honour but mine, kiss any man's wife but mine, and
welcome. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ha! ha! ha! doctor.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> It seems, he has not heard the report of you,
or does not believe it.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ha! ha!&mdash;now, doctor, what think you?</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Pray let's see the letter&mdash;hum&mdash;"for&mdash;dear&mdash;love
you&mdash;" [<i>Reads the letter.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I wonder how she could contrive it! What
say'st thou to't? 'tis an original.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> So are your cuckolds too originals: for they
are like no other common cuckolds, and I will henceforth<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_331" id="Page_331">[Pg 331]</a></span>
believe it not impossible for you to cuckold the Grand
Signior amidst his guards of eunuchs, that I say.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And I say for the letter, 'tis the first love-letter
that ever was without flames, darts, fates, destinies, lying
and dissembling in't.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span> <i>pulling in</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come back, you are a pretty brother-in-law,
neither go to church nor to dinner with your sister bride!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> My sister denies her marriage, and you see is
gone away from you dissatisfied.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! upon a foolish scruple, that our parson
was not in lawful orders, and did not say all the common-prayer;
but 'tis her modesty only I believe. But let all
women be never so modest the first day, they'll be sure to
come to themselves by night, and I shall have enough of
her then. In the mean time, Harry Horner, you must
dine with me: I keep my wedding at my aunt's in the
Piazza.<a name="FNanchor_81_81" id="FNanchor_81_81"></a><a href="#Footnote_81_81" class="fnanchor">[81]</a></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Thy wedding! what stale maid has lived to
despair of a husband, or what young one of a gallant?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> O, your servant, sir&mdash;this gentleman's sister
then,&mdash;no stale maid.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I'm sorry for't.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How comes he so concerned for her? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> You sorry for't? why, do you know any ill by
her?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, I know none but by thee; 'tis for her sake,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_332" id="Page_332">[Pg 332]</a></span>
not yours, and another man's sake that might have hoped,
I thought.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Another man! another man! what is his
name?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, since 'tis past, he shall be nameless.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
Poor Harcourt! I am sorry thou hast missed her.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> He seems to be much troubled at the match.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Prithee, tell me&mdash;Nay, you shan't go, brother.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I must of necessity, but I'll come to you to
dinner. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> But, Harry, what, have I a rival in my wife
already? But with all my heart, for he may be of use to
me hereafter; for though my hunger is now my sauce,
and I can fall on heartily without, the time will come,
when a rival will be as good sauce for a married man to a
wife, as an orange to veal.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> O thou damned rogue! thou hast set my teeth
on edge with thy orange.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Then let's to dinner&mdash;there I was with you
again. Come.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But who dines with thee?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> My friends and relations, my brother Pinchwife,
you see, of your acquaintance.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And his wife?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, 'gad, he'll ne'er let her come amongst us
good fellows; your stingy country coxcomb keeps his
wife from his friends, as he does his little firkin of ale, for
his own drinking, and a gentleman can't get a smack
on't; but his servants, when his back is turned, broach it
at their pleasures, and dust it away, ha! ha! ha!&mdash;'Gad,
I am witty, I think, considering I was married to-day, by
the world; but come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, I will not dine with you, unless you can
fetch her too.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Pshaw! what pleasure canst thou have with
women now, Harry?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_333" id="Page_333">[Pg 333]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> My eyes are not gone; I love a good prospect
yet, and will not dine with you unless she does too; go
fetch her, therefore, but do not tell her husband 'tis for
my sake.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Well, I'll go try what I can do; in the meantime,
come away to my aunt's lodging, 'tis in the way to
Pinchwife's.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> The poor woman has called for aid, and
stretched forth her hand, doctor; I cannot but help her
over the pale out of the briars. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<i>A Room in</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center">Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>alone, leaning on her elbow.&mdash;A table,
pen, ink and paper.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Well, 'tis e'en so, I have got the London
disease they call love; I am sick of my husband, and for
my gallant. I have heard this distemper called a fever,
but methinks 'tis like an ague; for when I think of my
husband, I tremble, and am in a cold sweat, and have
inclinations to vomit; but when I think of my gallant,
dear Mr. Horner, my hot fit comes, and I am all in a
fever indeed; and, as in other fevers, my own chamber
is tedious to me, and I would fain be removed to his, and
then methinks I should be well. Ah, poor Mr. Horner!
Well, I cannot, will not stay here; therefore I'll make an
end of my letter to him, which shall be a finer letter than
my last, because I have studied it like anything. Oh
sick, sick! [<i>Takes the pen and writes.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>, <i>who seeing her writing, steals softly
behind her and looking over her shoulder, snatches the
paper from her.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, writing more letters?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_334" id="Page_334">[Pg 334]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O Lord, bud, why d'ye fright me so?
[<i>She offers to run out; he stops her, and reads.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How's this? nay, you shall not stir, madam:&mdash;"Dear,
dear, dear Mr. Horner"&mdash;very well&mdash;I have
taught you to write letters to good purpose&mdash;but let us
see't. "First, I am to beg your pardon for my boldness in
writing to you, which I'd have you to know I would not
have done, had not you said first you loved me so
extremely, which if you do, you will never suffer me to
lie in the arms of another man whom I loathe, nauseate,
and detest."&mdash;Now you can write these filthy words.
But what follows?&mdash;"Therefore, I hope you will speedily
find some way to free me from this unfortunate match,
which was never, I assure you, of my choice, but I'm
afraid 'tis already too far gone; however, if you love me,
as I do you, you will try what you can do; but you
must help me away before to-morrow, or else, alas! I
shall be for ever out of your reach, for I can defer no
longer our&mdash;our&mdash;" what is to follow "our"?&mdash;speak,
what&mdash;our journey into the country I suppose&mdash;Oh
woman, damned woman! and Love, damned Love, their
old tempter! for this is one of his miracles; in a moment
he can make those blind that could see, and those see
that were blind, those dumb that could speak, and those
prattle who were dumb before; nay, what is more than
all, make these dough-baked, senseless, indocile animals,
women, too hard for us their politic lords and rulers, in a
moment. But make an end of your letter, and then I'll
make an end of you thus, and all my plagues together.
[<i>Draws his sword.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O Lord, O Lord, you are such a passionate
man, bud!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> How now, what's here to do?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> This fool here now!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> What! drawn upon your wife? You should
never do that, but at night in the dark, when you can't<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_335" id="Page_335">[Pg 335]</a></span>
hurt her. This is my sister-in-law, is it not? ay, faith, e'en
our country Margery; [<i>Pulls aside her handkerchief</i>] one
may know her. Come, she and you must go dine with
me; dinner's ready, come. But where's my wife? is she
not come home yet? where is she?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Making you a cuckold; 'tis that they all do, as
soon as they can.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> What, the wedding-day? no, a wife that designs
to make a cully of her husband will be sure to let him
win the first stake of love, by the world. But come, they
stay dinner for us: come, I'll lead down our Margery.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No&mdash;sir, go, we'll follow you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> I will not wag without you.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> This coxcomb is a sensible torment to me
amidst the greatest in the world. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, come, Madam Margery.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No; I'll lead her my way: what, would you
treat your friends with mine, for want of your own wife?&mdash;[<i>Leads
her to the other door, and locks her in and returns.</i>]
I am contented my rage should take breath&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> I told Horner this.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come now.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Lord, how shy you are of your wife! but let
me tell you, brother, we men of wit have amongst us a
saying, that cuckolding, like the small-pox, comes with a
fear; and you may keep your wife as much as you will out
of danger of infection, but if her constitution incline her
to't, she'll have it sooner or later, by the world, say they.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] What a thing is a cuckold, that every
fool can make him ridiculous!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Well, sir&mdash;but
let me advise you, now you are come to be concerned,
because you suspect the danger, not to neglect the means
to prevent it, especially when the greatest share of the
malady will light upon your own head, for</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Hows'e'er the kind wife's belly comes to swell,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The husband breeds for her, and first is ill.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_336" id="Page_336">[Pg 336]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FIFTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Pinchwife's</span> <i>House.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>. <i>A table
and candle.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, take the pen and make
an end of the letter, just as you intended;
if you are false in a tittle, I
shall soon perceive it, and punish you
as you deserve.&mdash;[<i>Lays his hand on his
sword.</i>] Write what was to follow&mdash;let's
see&mdash;"You must make haste, and help me away before
to-morrow, or else I shall be for ever out of your reach,
for I can defer no longer our"&mdash;What follows "our"?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Must all out, then, bud?&mdash;Look you
there, then. [Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>takes the pen and writes.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Let's see&mdash;"For I can defer no longer
our&mdash;wedding&mdash;Your slighted Alithea."&mdash;What's the meaning
of this? my sister's name to't? speak, unriddle.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, indeed, bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But why her name to't? speak&mdash;speak, I say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Ay, but you'll tell her then again. If you
would not tell her again&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I will not:&mdash;I am stunned, my head turns
round.&mdash;Speak.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Won't you tell her, indeed, and indeed?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> No; speak, I say.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> She'll be angry with me; but I had
rather she should be angry with me than you, bud;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_337" id="Page_337">[Pg 337]</a></span>
and, to tell you the truth, 'twas she made me write the
letter, and taught me what I should write.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Ha!&mdash;I thought the style was somewhat
better than her own.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Could she come
to you to teach you, since I had locked you up alone?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O, through the key-hole, bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But why should she make you write a letter for
her to him, since she can write herself?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Why, she said because&mdash;for I was unwilling
to do it&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Because what&mdash;because?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Because, lest Mr. Horner should be
cruel, and refuse her; or be vain afterwards, and show
the letter, she might disown it, the hand not being
hers.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] How's this? Ha!&mdash;then I think I shall
come to myself again.&mdash;This changeling could not invent
this lie: but if she could, why should she? she might
think I should soon discover it.&mdash;Stay&mdash;now I think on't
too, Horner said he was sorry she had married Sparkish;
and her disowning her marriage to me makes me think
she has evaded it for Horner's sake: yet why should she
take this course? But men in love are fools; women
may well be so&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] But hark you, madam, your
sister went out in the morning, and I have not seen her
within since.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Alack-a-day, she has been crying all day
above, it seems, in a corner.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Where is she? let me speak with her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O Lord, then she'll discover
all!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Pray hold, bud; what, d'ye mean to discover
me? she'll know I have told you then. Pray, bud,
let me talk with her first.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I must speak with her, to know whether Horner
ever made her any promise, and whether she be married
to Sparkish or no.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray, dear bud, don't, till I have spoken<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_338" id="Page_338">[Pg 338]</a></span>
with her, and told her that I have told you all; for she'll
kill me else.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Go then, and bid her come out to me.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Yes, yes, bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Let me see&mdash;[<i>Pausing.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I'll go, but she is not within to
come to him: I have just got time to know of Lucy her
maid, who first set me on work, what lie I shall tell next;
for I am e'en at my wit's end. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, I resolve it, Horner shall have her: I'd
rather give him my sister than lend him my wife; and
such an alliance will prevent his pretensions to my wife,
sure. I'll make him of kin to her, and then he won't care
for her.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O Lord, bud! I told you what anger you
would make me with my sister.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Won't she come hither?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> No, no. Lack-a-day, she's ashamed to
look you in the face: and she says, if you go in to her,
she'll run away down stairs, and shamefully go herself to
Mr. Horner, who has promised her marriage, she says;
and she will have no other, so she won't.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Did he so?&mdash;promise her marriage!&mdash;then she
shall have no other. Go tell her so; and if she will come
and discourse with me a little concerning the means, I will
about it immediately. Go.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.] His
estate is equal to Sparkish's, and his extraction as much
better than his, as his parts are; but my chief reason is,
I'd rather be akin to him by the name of brother-in-law
than that of cuckold.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p>Well, what says she now?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Why, she says, she would only have you
lead her to Horner's lodging; with whom she first will
discourse the matter before she talks with you, which yet<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_339" id="Page_339">[Pg 339]</a></span>
she cannot do; for alack, poor creature, she says she
can't so much as look you in the face, therefore she'll
come to you in a mask. And you must excuse her, if
she make you no answer to any question of yours, till you
have brought her to Mr. Horner; and if you will not
chide her, nor question her, she'll come out to you
immediately.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Let her come: I will not speak a word to her,
nor require a word from her.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Oh, I forgot: besides she says, she cannot
look you in the face, though through a mask; therefore
would desire you to put out the candle.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I agree to all. Let her make haste.&mdash;There,
'tis out&mdash;[<i>Puts out the candle. Exit</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.] My
case is something better: I'd rather fight with Horner for
not lying with my sister, than for lying with my wife; and
of the two, I had rather find my sister too forward than
my wife. I expected no other from her free education, as
she calls it, and her passion for the town. Well, wife and
sister are names which make us expect love and duty,
pleasure and comfort; but we find 'em plagues and
torments, and are equally, though differently, troublesome
to their keeper; for we have as much ado to get people
to lie with our sisters as to keep 'em from lying with our
wives.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>masked, and in hoods and scarfs,
and a night-gown and petticoat of</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea's</span>.</p>

<p>What, are you come, sister? let us go then.&mdash;But first, let
me lock up my wife. Mrs. Margery, where are you?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Here, bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come hither, that I may lock you up: get you
in.&mdash;[<i>Locks the door.</i>] Come, sister, where are you now?
[Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>gives him her hand; but when
he lets her go, she steals softly on to the other
side of him, and is led away by him for his</i>
Sister, <span class="smcap">Alithea</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_340" id="Page_340">[Pg 340]</a></span></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Horner's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Horner</span> <i>and</i> Quack.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> What, all alone? not so much as one of your
cuckolds here, nor one of their wives! They use to take
their turns with you, as if they were to watch you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes, it often happens that a cuckold is but his
wife's spy, and is more upon family duty when he is with
her gallant abroad, hindering his pleasure, than when he
is at home with her playing the gallant. But the hardest
duty a married woman imposes upon a lover is keeping
her husband company always.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> And his fondness wearies you almost as soon as
hers.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> A pox! keeping a cuckold company, after you
have had his wife, is as tiresome as the company of a
country squire to a witty fellow of the town, when he has
got all his money.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> And as at first a man makes a friend of the
husband to get the wife, so at last you are fain to fall out
with the wife to be rid of the husband.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, most cuckold-makers are true courtiers;
when once a poor man has cracked his credit for 'em,
they can't abide to come near him.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> But at first, to draw him in, are so sweet, so
kind, so dear! just as you are to Pinchwife. But what
becomes of that intrigue with his wife?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> A pox! he's as surly as an alderman that has
been bit; and since he's so coy, his wife's kindness is in
vain, for she's a silly innocent.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Did she not send you a letter by him?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Yes; but that's a riddle I have not yet solved.
Allow the poor creature to be willing, she is silly too, and
he keeps her up so close&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Yes, so close, that he makes her but the more
willing, and adds but revenge to her love; which two,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_341" id="Page_341">[Pg 341]</a></span>
when met, seldom fail of satisfying each other one way or
other.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What! here's the man we are talking of, I think.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>, <i>leading in his</i> Wife <i>masked, muffled,
and in her</i> Sister's <i>gown.</i></p>

<p>Pshaw!</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Bringing his wife to you is the next thing to
bringing a love-letter from her.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What means this?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> The last time, you know, sir, I brought you a
love-letter; now, you see, a mistress; I think you'll say I
am a civil man to you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, the devil take me, will I say thou art the
civilest man I ever met with; and I have known some.
I fancy I understand thee now better than I did the letter.
But, hark thee, in thy ear&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nothing but the usual question, man: is she
sound, on thy word?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, you take her for a wench, and me for a
pimp?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Pshaw! wench and pimp, paw<a name="FNanchor_82_82" id="FNanchor_82_82"></a><a href="#Footnote_82_82" class="fnanchor">[82]</a> words; I know
thou art an honest fellow, and hast a great acquaintance
among the ladies, and perhaps hast made love for me,
rather than let me make love to thy wife.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, sir, in short, I am for no fooling.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nor I neither: therefore prithee, let's see her
face presently. Make her show, man: art thou sure I
don't know her?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I am sure you do know her.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> A pox! why dost thou bring her to me then?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Because she's a relation of mine&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Is she, faith, man? then thou art still more civil
and obliging, dear rogue.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_342" id="Page_342">[Pg 342]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Who desired me to bring her to you.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Then she is obliging, dear rogue.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> You'll make her welcome for my sake, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I hope she is handsome enough to make herself
welcome. Prithee let her unmask.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Do you speak to her; she would never be ruled
by me.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Madam&mdash;[Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span> <i>whispers to</i>
<span class="smcap">Horner</span>.] She says she must speak with me in private.
Withdraw, prithee.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] She's unwilling, it seems, I should
know all her indecent conduct in this business&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Well then, I'll leave you together, and hope when I am
gone, you'll agree; if not, you and I shan't agree, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> What means the fool? if she and I agree 'tis no
matter what you and I do.
[<i>Whispers to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>, <i>who makes signs
with her hand for him to be gone.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> In the mean time I'll fetch a parson, and find
out Sparkish, and disabuse him. You would have me
fetch a parson, would you not? Well then&mdash;now I think
I am rid of her, and shall have no more trouble with
her&mdash;our sisters and daughters, like usurers' money, are
safest when put out; but our wives, like their writings,
never safe, but in our closets under lock and key. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Sir Jasper Fidget, sir, is coming up. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Here's the trouble of a cuckold now we are
talking of. A pox on him! has he not enough to do to
hinder his wife's sport, but he must other women's too?&mdash;Step
in here, madam. [<i>Exit</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> My best and dearest friend.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> [<i>Aside to</i> Quack.] The old style, doctor.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_343" id="Page_343">[Pg 343]</a></span>
Well, be short, for I am busy. What would
your impertinent wife have now?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Well guessed, i'faith; for I do come from her.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> To invite me to supper! Tell her, I can't come;
go.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nay, now you are out, faith; for my lady,
and the whole knot of the virtuous gang, as they call
themselves, are resolved upon a frolic of coming to you
to-night in masquerade, and are all dressed already.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I shan't be at home.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Lord, how churlish he is to women!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Nay, prithee don't disappoint 'em; they'll
think 'tis my fault: prithee don't. I'll send in the
banquet and the fiddles. But make no noise on't; for
the poor virtuous rogues would not have it known, for the
world, that they go a-masquerading; and they would
come to no man's ball but yours.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well, well&mdash;get you gone; and tell 'em, if they
come, 'twill be at the peril of their honour and yours.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> He! he! he!&mdash;we'll trust you for that: farewell.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Doctor, anon you too shall be my guest,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But now I'm going to a private feast.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<i>The Piazza of Covent Garden.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Sparkish</span> <i>with a letter in his hand,</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>
<i>following.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> But who would have thought a woman could
have been false to me? By the world, I could not have
thought it.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> You were for giving and taking liberty: she has
taken it only, sir, now you find in that letter. You are a
frank person, and so is she, you see there.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, if this be her hand&mdash;for I never saw it.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_344" id="Page_344">[Pg 344]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> 'Tis no matter whether that be her hand or no;
I am sure this hand, at her desire, led her to Mr. Horner,
with whom I left her just now, to go fetch a parson to 'em
at their desire too, to deprive you of her for ever; for it
seems yours was but a mock marriage.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Indeed, she would needs have it that 'twas
Harcourt himself, in a parson's habit, that married us;
but I'm sure he told me 'twas his brother Ned.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> O, there 'tis out; and you were deceived, not
she: for you are such a frank person. But I must be
gone.&mdash;You'll find her at Mr. Horner's. Go, and believe
your eyes. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, I'll to her, and call her as many crocodiles,
sirens, harpies, and other heathenish names, as a poet
would do a mistress who had refused to hear his
suit, nay more, his verses on her.&mdash;But stay, is not
that she following a torch at t'other end of the Piazza?
and from Horner's certainly&mdash;'tis so.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Alithea</span> <i>following a torch, and</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span> <i>behind.</i></p>

<p>You are well met, madam, though you don't think
so. What, you have made a short visit to Mr. Horner?
but I suppose you'll return to him presently, by that time
the parson can be with him.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Mr. Horner and the parson, sir!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Come, madam, no more dissembling, no more
jilting; for I am no more a frank person.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> How's this?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> So, 'twill work, I see. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Could you find out no easy country fool to
abuse? none but me, a gentleman of wit and pleasure
about the town? But it was your pride to be too hard
for a man of parts, unworthy false woman! false as a
friend that lends a man money to lose; false as dice, who
undo those that trust all they have to 'em.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> He has been a great bubble, by his similes, as
they say. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_345" id="Page_345">[Pg 345]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> You have been too merry, sir, at your wedding-dinner,
sure.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> What, d'ye mock me too?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Or you have been deluded.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> By you.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Let me understand you.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Have you the confidence, (I should call it
something else, since you know your guilt,) to stand my
just reproaches? you did not write an impudent letter to
Mr. Horner? who I find now has clubbed with you in
deluding me with his aversion for women, that I might
not, forsooth, suspect him for my rival.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> D'ye think the gentleman can be jealous now,
madam? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> I write a letter to Mr. Horner!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Nay, madam, do not deny it. Your brother
showed it me just now; and told me likewise, he left
you at Horner's lodging to fetch a parson to marry you
to him; and I wish you joy, madam, joy, joy; and to him
too, much joy; and to myself more joy, for not marrying
you.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, I find my brother would break off
the match; and I can consent to't, since I see this gentleman
can be made jealous.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] O Lucy, by his
rude usage and jealousy, he makes me almost afraid I
am married to him. Art thou sure 'twas Harcourt himself,
and no parson, that married us?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> No, madam, I thank you. I suppose, that was
a contrivance too of Mr. Horner's and yours, to make
Harcourt play the parson; but I would as little as you
have him one now, no, not for the world. For, shall I
tell you another truth? I never had any passion for you
till now, for now I hate you. 'Tis true, I might have
married your portion, as other men of parts of the town
do sometimes; and so, your servant. And to show my
unconcernedness, I'll come to your wedding, and resign
you with as much joy, as I would a stale wench to a new<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_346" id="Page_346">[Pg 346]</a></span>
cully; nay, with as much joy as I would after the first
night, if I had been married to you. There's for you;
and so your servant, servant. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> How was I deceived in a man!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> You'll believe then a fool may be made jealous
now? for that easiness in him that suffers him to be led
by a wife, will likewise permit him to be persuaded
against her by others.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> But marry Mr. Horner! my brother does not
intend it, sure: if I thought he did, I would take thy
advice, and Mr. Harcourt for my husband. And now I
wish, that if there be any over-wise woman of the town,
who, like me, would marry a fool for fortune, liberty, or
title, first, that her husband may love play, and be a cully
to all the town but her, and suffer none but Fortune to
be mistress of his purse; then, if for liberty, that he may
send her into the country, under the conduct of some
huswifely mother-in-law; and if for title, may the world
give 'em none but that of cuckold.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> And for her greater curse, madam, may he not
deserve it.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Away, impertinent! Is not this my old Lady
Lanterlu's?<a name="FNanchor_83_83" id="FNanchor_83_83"></a><a href="#Footnote_83_83" class="fnanchor">[83]</a></p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Yes, madam.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] And here I hope we
shall find Mr. Harcourt. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Horner's</span> <i>Lodging. A table, banquet,
and bottles.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>, Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>,
<i>and</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> A pox! they are come too soon&mdash;before I have
sent back my new mistress. All that I have now to do
is to lock her in, that they may not see her. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_347" id="Page_347">[Pg 347]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> That we may be sure of our welcome, we have
brought our entertainment with us, and are resolved to
treat thee, dear toad.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> And that we may be merry to purpose, have
left Sir Jasper and my old Lady Squeamish, quarrelling
at home at backgammon.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Therefore let us make use of our time,
lest they should chance to interrupt us.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Let us sit then.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> First, that you may be private, let me lock this
door and that, and I'll wait upon you presently.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> No, sir, shut 'em only, and your lips for ever;
for we must trust you as much as our women.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> You know all vanity's killed in me; I have no
occasion for talking.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Now, ladies, supposing we had drank each of
us our two bottles, let us speak the truth of our hearts.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain. and Mrs. Squeam.</i> Agreed.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> By this brimmer, for truth is nowhere else to be
found&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.] not in thy heart, false man!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> You have found me a true man, I'm sure.
[<i>Aside to</i> Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.] Not every way.&mdash;But let
us sit and be merry. [<i>Sings.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Why should our damned tyrants oblige us to live</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">On the pittance of pleasure which they only give?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 5.5em;">We must not rejoice</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 5.5em;">With wine and with noise:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In vain we must wake in a dull bed alone,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Whilst to our warm rival the bottle they're gone.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 5.5em;">Then lay aside charms,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 5.5em;">And take up these arms.<a name="FNanchor_84_84" id="FNanchor_84_84"></a><a href="#Footnote_84_84" class="fnanchor">[84]</a></span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Tis wine only gives 'em their courage and wit;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Because we live sober, to men we submit.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 5.5em;">If for beauties you'd pass,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 5.5em;">Take a lick of the glass,</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_348" id="Page_348">[Pg 348]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Twill mend your complexions, and when they are gone,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 4em;">The best red we have is the red of the grape:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Then, sisters, lay't on,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 6em;">And damn a good shape.</span><br />
</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Fain.</i> Dear brimmer! Well, in token of our
openness and plain-dealing, let us throw our masks over
our heads.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, 'twill come to the glasses anon. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Lovely brimmer! let me enjoy him first.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> No, I never part with a gallant till I've tried
him. Dear brimmer! that makest our husbands short-sighted.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> And our bashful gallants bold.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And, for want of a gallant, the butler
lovely in our eyes.&mdash;Drink, eunuch.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Drink, thou representative of a husband.&mdash;Damn
a husband!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> And, as it were a husband, an old keeper.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And an old grandmother.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And an English bawd, and a French surgeon.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Ay, we have all reason to curse 'em.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> For my sake, ladies?</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> No, for our own; for the first spoils all young
gallants' industry.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> And the other's art makes 'em bold only
with common women.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And rather run the hazard of the vile
distemper amongst them, than of a denial amongst us.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> The filthy toads choose mistresses now as
they do stuffs, for having been fancied and worn by
others.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> For being common and cheap.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Whilst women of quality, like the richest
stuffs, lie untumbled, and unasked for.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, neat, and cheap, and new, often they think
best.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_349" id="Page_349">[Pg 349]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> No, sir, the beasts will be known by a
mistress longer than by a suit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And 'tis not for cheapness neither.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> No; for the vain fops will take up druggets,
and embroider 'em. But I wonder at the depraved
appetites of witty men; they use to be out of the common
road, and hate imitation. Pray tell me, beast, when you
were a man, why you rather chose to club with a multitude
in a common house for an entertainment, than to be
the only guest at a good table.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, faith, ceremony and expectation are unsufferable
to those that are sharp bent. People always eat
with the best stomach at an ordinary, where every man is
snatching for the best bit.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Though he get a cut over the fingers.&mdash;But I
have heard, that people eat most heartily of another man's
meat, that is, what they do not pay for.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> When they are sure of their welcome and freedom;
for ceremony in love and eating is as ridiculous as
in fighting: falling on briskly is all should be done on
those occasions.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Well then, let me tell you, sir, there is nowhere
more freedom than in our houses; and we take
freedom from a young person as a sign of good breeding;
and a person may be as free as he pleases with us,
as frolic, as gamesome, as wild as he will.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Han't I heard you all declaim against wild
men?</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Yes; but for all that, we think wildness in a
man as desirable a quality as in a duck or rabbit: a tame
man! foh!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I know not, but your reputations frightened me
as much as your faces invited me.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Our reputation! Lord, why should you not
think that we women make use of our reputation, as you
men of yours, only to deceive the world with less suspicion?
Our virtue is like the statesman's religion, the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_350" id="Page_350">[Pg 350]</a></span>
quaker's word, the gamester's oath, and the great man's
honour; but to cheat those that trust us.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And that demureness, coyness, and
modesty, that you see in our faces in the boxes at plays,
is as much a sign of a kind woman, as a vizard-mask in
the pit.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> For, I assure you, women are least masked
when they have the velvet vizard on.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> You would have found us modest women in
our denials only.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Our bashfulness is only the reflection of
the men's.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> We blush when they are shamefaced.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I beg your pardon, ladies, I was deceived in
you devilishly. But why that mighty pretence to
honour?</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> We have told you; but sometimes 'twas for
the same reason you men pretend business often, to avoid
ill company, to enjoy the better and more privately those
you love.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> But why would you ne'er give a friend a wink
then?</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Faith, your reputation frightened us, as much
as ours did you, you were so notoriously lewd.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And you so seemingly honest.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Was that all that deterred you?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And so expensive&mdash;you allow freedom, you say.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> That I was afraid of losing my little money, as
well as my little time, both which my other pleasures
required.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Money! foh! you talk like a little fellow
now: do such as we expect money?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I beg your pardon, madam, I must confess, I
have heard that great ladies, like great merchants, set but
the higher prices upon what they have, because they are
not in necessity of taking the first offer.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_351" id="Page_351">[Pg 351]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Such as we make sale of our hearts?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> We bribed for our love? foh!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> With your pardon ladies, I know, like great
men in offices, you seem to exact flattery and attendance
only from your followers; but you have receivers about
you, and such fees to pay, a man is afraid to pass your
grants. Besides, we must let you win at cards, or we
lose your hearts; and if you make an assignation, 'tis at
a goldsmith's, jeweller's, or china-house; where for your
honour you deposit to him, he must pawn his to the
punctual cit, and so paying for what you take up, pays
for what he takes up.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Would you not have us assured of our
gallants' love?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> For love is better known by liberality
than by jealousy.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> For one may be dissembled, the other not.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
But my jealousy can be no longer dissembled,
and they are telling ripe.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]&mdash;Come, here's to our
gallants in waiting, whom we must name, and I'll begin.
This is my false rogue. [<i>Claps him on the back.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> How!</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, all will out now. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Did you not tell me, 'twas for my sake
only you reported yourself no man? [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> Oh, wretch! did you not swear to me,
'twas for my love and honour you passed for that thing
you do? [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, so.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Come, speak, ladies: this is my false villain.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> And mine too.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> And mine.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Well then, you are all three my false rogues
too, and there's an end on't.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Well then, there's no remedy; sister sharers,
let us not fall out, but have a care of our honour.
Though we get no presents, no jewels of him, we are<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_352" id="Page_352">[Pg 352]</a></span>
savers of our honour, the jewel of most value and use,
which shines yet to the world unsuspected, though it be
counterfeit.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Nay, and is e'en as good as if it were true, provided
the world think so; for honour, like beauty now,
only depends on the opinion of others.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Well, Harry Common, I hope you can be true
to three. Swear; but 'tis to no purpose to require your
oath, for you are as often forsworn as you swear to new
women.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Come, faith, madam, let us e'en pardon one
another; for all the difference I find betwixt we men and
you women, we forswear ourselves at the beginning of an
amour, you as long as it lasts.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>, <i>and</i> Old Lady <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Oh, my Lady Fidget, was this your cunning,
to come to Mr. Horner without me? but you have been
nowhere else, I hope.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> No, Sir Jasper.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> And you came straight hither, Biddy?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Yes, indeed, lady grandmother.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> 'Tis well, 'tis well; I knew when once they
were thoroughly acquainted with poor Horner, they'd
ne'er be from him: you may let her masquerade it
with my wife and Horner, and I warrant her reputation
safe.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> O, sir, here's the gentleman come, whom you bid
me not suffer to come up, without giving you notice, with
a lady too, and other gentlemen.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Do you all go in there, whilst I send 'em away;
and, boy, do you desire 'em to stay below till I come,
which shall be immediately.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>, Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>,
Lady <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>, <i>and</i>
Mrs. <span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_353" id="Page_353">[Pg 353]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Yes, sir. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center">[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span> <i>at the other door, and returns
with</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> You would not take my advice, to be gone
home before your husband came back, he'll now discover
all; yet pray, my dearest, be persuaded to go home, and
leave the rest to my management; I'll let you down the
back way.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> I don't know the way home, so I don't.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> My man shall wait upon you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> No, don't you believe that I'll go at all;
what, are you weary of me already?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, my life, 'tis that I may love you long, 'tis
to secure my love, and your reputation with your husband;
he'll never receive you again else.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What care I? d'ye think to frighten me
with that? I don't intend to go to him again; you shall
be my husband now.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I cannot be your husband, dearest, since you
are married to him.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O, would you make me believe that?
Don't I see every day at London here, women leave
their first husbands, and go and live with other men as
their wives? pish, pshaw! you'd make me angry, but
that I love you so mainly.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So, they are coming up&mdash;In again, in, I hear
'em.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.] Well, a silly mistress is
like a weak place, soon got, soon lost, a man has scarce
time for plunder; she betrays her husband first to her
gallant, and then her gallant to her husband.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife, Alithea, Harcourt, Sparkish,
Lucy</span>, <i>and a</i> Parson.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, madam, 'tis not the sudden change of
your dress, the confidence of your asseverations, and
your false witness there, shall persuade me I did not
bring you hither just now; here's my witness, who cannot<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_354" id="Page_354">[Pg 354]</a></span>
deny it, since you must be confronted.&mdash;Mr. Horner,
did not I bring this lady to you just now?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Now must I wrong one woman for another's
sake,&mdash;but that's no new thing with me, for in these
cases I am still on the criminal's side against the
innocent. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Pray speak, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> It must be so. I must be impudent, and try
my luck; impudence uses to be too hard for truth. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What, you are studying an evasion or excuse
for her! Speak, sir.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, faith, I am something backward only to
speak in women's affairs or disputes.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> She bids you speak.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Ay, pray, sir, do, pray satisfy him.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Then truly, you did bring that lady to me just
now.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> O ho!</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> How, sir?</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> How, Horner?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> What mean you, sir? I always took you for a
man of honour.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Ay, so much a man of honour, that I must save
my mistress, I thank you, come what will on't. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> So, if I had had her, she'd have made me believe
the moon had been made of a Christmas pie.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Now could I speak, if I durst, and solve the
riddle, who am the author of it. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> O unfortunate woman! A combination
against my honour! which most concerns me now,
because you share in my disgrace, sir, and it is your
censure, which I must now suffer, that troubles me, not
theirs.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Madam, then have no trouble, you shall now
see 'tis possible for me to love too, without being
jealous; I will not only believe your innocence myself,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_355" id="Page_355">[Pg 355]</a></span>
but make all the world believe it.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.]
Horner, I must now be concerned for this lady's honour.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And I must be concerned for a lady's honour
too.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> This lady has her honour, and I will protect it.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> My lady has not her honour, but has given it
me to keep, and I will preserve it.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I understand you not.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I would not have you.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> What's the matter with 'em all?
[<i>Peeping in behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Come, come, Mr. Horner, no more disputing;
here's the parson, I brought him not in vain.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> No, sir, I'll employ him, if this lady please.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> How! what d'ye mean?</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ay, what does he mean?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Why, I have resigned your sister to him, he has
my consent.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But he has not mine, sir; a woman's injured
honour, no more than a man's, can be repaired or satisfied
by any but him that first wronged it; and you shall
marry her presently, or&mdash;[<i>Lays his hand on his sword.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> O Lord, they'll kill poor Mr. Horner!
besides, he shan't marry her whilst I stand by, and look
on; I'll not lose my second husband so.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> What do I see?</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> My sister in my clothes!</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Ha!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, pray now don't quarrel about finding
work for the parson, he shall marry me to Mr. Horner;
or now, I believe, you have enough of me.
[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Damned, damned loving changeling! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Pray, sister, pardon me for telling so
many lies of you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_356" id="Page_356">[Pg 356]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> I suppose the riddle is plain now.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> No, that must be my work.&mdash;Good sir, hear me.
[<i>Kneels to</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>, <i>who stands doggedly with
his hat over his eyes.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I will never hear woman again, but make 'em
all silent thus&mdash;[<i>Offers to draw upon his</i> Wife.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> No, that must not be.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> You then shall go first, 'tis all one to me.
[<i>Offers to draw on</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>, <i>but is stopped by</i>
<span class="smcap">Harcourt</span>.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> Hold!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper Fidget</span>, Lady <span class="smcap">Fidget</span>, Lady
<span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>, Mrs. <span class="smcap">Dainty Fidget</span>, <i>and</i> Mrs.
<span class="smcap">Squeamish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> What's the matter? what's the matter? pray,
what's the matter, sir? I beseech you communicate, sir.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Why, my wife has communicated, sir, as your
wife may have done too, sir, if she knows him, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Pshaw, with him! ha! ha! he!</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> D'ye mock me, sir? a cuckold is a kind of a
wild beast; have a care, sir.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> No, sure, you mock me, sir. He cuckold
you! it can't be, ha! ha! he! why, I'll tell you, sir&mdash;[<i>Offers
to whisper.</i></p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I tell you again, he has whored my wife, and
yours too, if he knows her, and all the women he comes
near; 'tis not his dissembling, his hypocrisy, can wheedle
me.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> How! does he dissemble? is he a hypocrite?
Nay, then&mdash;how&mdash;wife&mdash;sister, is he a hypocrite?</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> A hypocrite! a dissembler! Speak,
young harlotry, speak, how?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nay, then&mdash;O my head too!&mdash;O thou
libidinous lady!</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> O thou harloting harlotry! hast thou
done't then?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_357" id="Page_357">[Pg 357]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Speak, good Horner, art thou a dissembler,
a rogue? hast thou&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> So!</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I'll fetch you off, and her too, if she will but
hold her tongue. [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Canst thou? I'll give thee&mdash;[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.</p>

<p><i>Lucy. [To</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.] Pray have but patience to
hear me, sir, who am the unfortunate cause of all this
confusion. Your wife is innocent, I only culpable; for
I put her upon telling you all these lies concerning my
mistress, in order to the breaking off the match between
Mr. Sparkish and her, to make way for Mr. Harcourt.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> Did you so, eternal rotten tooth? Then, it
seems, my mistress was not false to me, I was only deceived
by you. Brother, that should have been, now
man of conduct, who is a frank person now, to bring
your wife to her lover, ha?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> I assure you, sir, she came not to Mr. Horner
out of love, for she loves him no more&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Hold, I told lies for you, but you shall
tell none for me, for I do love Mr. Horner with all my
soul, and nobody shall say me nay; pray, don't you go
to make poor Mr. Horner believe to the contrary; 'tis
spitefully done of you, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Peace, dear idiot. [<i>Aside to</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> Nay, I will not peace.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Not till I make you.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Dorilant</span> <i>and</i> Quack.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Horner, your servant; I am the doctor's guest,
he must excuse our intrusion.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> But what's the matter, gentlemen? for Heaven's
sake, what's the matter?</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Oh, 'tis well you are come. 'Tis a censorious
world we live in; you may have brought me a reprieve,
or else I had died for a crime I never committed, and
these innocent ladies had suffered with me; therefore,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_358" id="Page_358">[Pg 358]</a></span>
pray satisfy these worthy, honourable, jealous
gentlemen&mdash;that&mdash;[<i>Whispers.</i></p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> O, I understand you, is that all?&mdash;Sir Jasper,
by Heavens, and upon the word of a physician, sir&mdash;[<i>Whispers
to</i> Sir <span class="smcap">Jasper</span>.</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Nay, I do believe you truly.&mdash;Pardon me,
my virtuous lady, and dear of honour.</p>

<p><i>L. Squeam.</i> What, then all's right again?</p>

<p><i>Sir Jasp.</i> Ay, ay, and now let us satisfy him too.
[<i>They whisper with</i> <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> An eunuch! Pray, no fooling with me.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> I'll bring half the chirurgeons in town to
swear it.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> They!&mdash;they'll swear a man that bled to death
through his wounds, died of an apoplexy.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Pray, hear me, sir&mdash;why, all the town has
heard the report of him.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But does all the town believe it?</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> Pray, inquire a little, and first of all these.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> I'm sure when I left the town, he was the
lewdest fellow in't.</p>

<p><i>Quack.</i> I tell you, sir, he has been in France since;
pray, ask but these ladies and gentlemen, your friend Mr.
Dorilant. Gentlemen and ladies, han't you all heard the
late sad report of poor Mr. Horner?</p>

<p><i>All the Ladies.</i> Ay, ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> Why, thou jealous fool, dost thou doubt it? he's
an arrant French capon.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> 'Tis false, sir, you shall not disparage
poor Mr. Horner, for to my certain knowledge&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> O, hold!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Stop her mouth! [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> Upon my honour, sir, 'tis as true&mdash;[<i>To</i>
<span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Dain.</i> D'ye think we would have been seen in his
company?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Squeam.</i> Trust our unspotted reputations with him?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_359" id="Page_359">[Pg 359]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Fid.</i> This you get, and we too, by trusting your
secret to a fool. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Peace, madam.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> Quack.] Well,
doctor, is not this a good design, that carries a man on
unsuspected, and brings him off safe?</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> Well, if this were true&mdash;but my wife&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p class="center">[<span class="smcap">Dorilant</span> <i>whispers with</i> Mrs. <span class="smcap">Pinchwife</span>.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> Come, brother, your wife is yet innocent, you
see; but have a care of too strong an imagination, lest,
like an over-concerned timorous gamester, by fancying an
unlucky cast, it should come. Women and fortune are
truest still to those that trust 'em.</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> And any wild thing grows but the more fierce
and hungry for being kept up, and more dangerous to
the keeper.</p>

<p><i>Alith.</i> There's doctrine for all husbands, Mr. Harcourt.</p>

<p><i>Har.</i> I edify, madam, so much, that I am impatient
till I am one.</p>

<p><i>Dor.</i> And I edify so much by example, I will never be
one.</p>

<p><i>Spark.</i> And because I will not disparage my parts, I'll
ne'er be one.</p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> And I, alas! can't be one.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i> But I must be one&mdash;against my will to a
country wife, with a country murrain to me!</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> And I must be a country wife still too, I
find; for I can't, like a city one, be rid of my musty
husband, and do what I list. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i> Now, sir, I must pronounce your wife innocent,
though I blush whilst I do it; and I am the only man by
her now exposed to shame, which I will straight drown
in wine, as you shall your suspicion; and the ladies'
troubles we'll divert with a ballad.&mdash;Doctor, where are
your maskers?</p>

<p><i>Lucy.</i> Indeed, she's innocent, sir, I am her witness,
and her end of coming out was but to see her sister's
wedding; and what she has said to your face of her love to<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_360" id="Page_360">[Pg 360]</a></span>
Mr. Horner, was but the usual innocent revenge on a
husband's jealousy;&mdash;was it not, madam, speak?</p>

<p><i>Mrs. Pinch.</i> [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Lucy</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Horner</span>.] Since you'll
have me tell more lies&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Yes, indeed, bud.</p>

<p><i>Pinch.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For my own sake fain I would all believe;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Cuckolds, like lovers, should themselves deceive.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But&mdash;[<i>Sighs</i></span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">His honour is least safe (too late I find)</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who trusts it with a foolish wife or friend.</span><br />
</p>

<p class="center"><i>A Dance of Cuckolds.</i></p>

<p><i>Horn.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Vain fops but court and dress, and keep a pother,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To pass for women's men with one another;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But he who aims by women to be prized,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">First by the men, you see, must be despised.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>



<hr class="chap" />
<h3>EPILOGUE.</h3>

<h4>SPOKEN BY MRS. KNEP.<a name="FNanchor_85_85" id="FNanchor_85_85"></a><a href="#Footnote_85_85" class="fnanchor">[85]</a></h4>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Now you the vigorous, who daily here</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">O'er vizard-mask in public domineer,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And what you'd do to her, if in place where;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, have the confidence to cry, "Come out!"</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet when she says, "Lead on!" you are not stout;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But to your well-dressed brother straight turn round,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And cry "Pox on her, Ned, she can't be sound!"</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Then slink away, a fresh one to engage,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">With so much seeming heat and loving rage,</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_361" id="Page_361">[Pg 361]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">You'd frighten listening actress on the stage;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Till she at last has seen you huffing come,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And talk of keeping in the tiring-room,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet cannot be provoked to lead her home.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Next, you Falstaffs of fifty, who beset</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Your buckram maidenheads, which your friends get;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And whilst to them you of achievements boast,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">They share the booty, and laugh at your cost.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In fine, you essenced boys, both old and young,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who would be thought so eager, brisk, and strong,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet do the ladies, not their husbands wrong;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Whose purses for your manhood make excuse,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And keep your Flanders mares for show not use;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Encouraged by our woman's man to-day,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">A Horner's part may vainly think to play;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And may intrigues so bashfully disown,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">That they may doubted be by few or none;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">May kiss the cards at picquet, ombre, loo,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And so be taught to kiss the lady too;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But, gallants, have a care, faith, what you do.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The world, which to no man his due will give,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You by experience know you can deceive,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And men may still believe you vigorous,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But then we women&mdash;there's no cozening us.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="full" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_362" id="Page_362"></a></span></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_363" id="Page_363">[Pg 363]</a></span></p>




<h2><a name="THE_PLAIN_DEALER" id="THE_PLAIN_DEALER"><i>THE PLAIN DEALER.</i></a></h2>


<p>
<span style="margin-left: 13em;">Ridiculum acri</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Fortius et melius magnas plerumque secat res.<a name="FNanchor_86_86" id="FNanchor_86_86"></a><a href="#Footnote_86_86" class="fnanchor">[86]</a>&mdash;<span class="smcap">Horat</span>.</span><br />
<br /><br /></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_364" id="Page_364">[Pg 364]</a></span></p>




<p>According to Wycherley's own statement
<i>The Plain Dealer</i> was written when
the author was twenty-five years of age&mdash;<i>i.e.</i>,
in the year 1665-6.<a name="FNanchor_87_87" id="FNanchor_87_87"></a><a href="#Footnote_87_87" class="fnanchor">[87]</a> Its first performance
on the stage cannot have taken place
later than the spring of 1674, as there is an
interesting allusion to it in the preface to Dryden's <i>State of
Innocence</i>, which was registered at Stationers' Hall, April 17,
1674. Dryden writes in terms of noble eulogy: "The author
of <i>The Plain Dealer</i>, whom I am proud to call my friend,
has obliged all honest and virtuous men by one of the most
bold, most general, and most useful satires, which has ever
been presented on the English theatre." <i>The Plain Dealer</i>
was brought forward by the King's Company, probably, like
<i>The Country Wife</i>, at the house in Lincoln's Inn Fields, as
the new theatre, in Drury Lane, was not opened until
March 26 of that year. It was published three years later,
in 1677, the title-page bearing the <i>imprimatur</i>&mdash;"Licensed
Jan. 9, 1676, Roger L'Estrange." The license, of course,
was for printing, not for acting; the date, in new style,
would be 1677.</p>

<p>We shall have, I think, little difficulty in accepting
Wycherley's statement as to the year in which this play was
written, if we suppose, as would almost certainly be the case,
that it was revised and altered before its production on the
stage. The critique on <i>The Country Wife</i>, in particular,
cannot have been written earlier than 1672 or 1673, in one of
which years that comedy was first acted.</p>

<p>Of our author's four comedies <i>The Plain Dealer</i> is, questionless,
the most powerful. From the mock dedication to<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_365" id="Page_365">[Pg 365]</a></span>
the epilogue "the satire, wit, and strength, of manly
Wycherley"<a name="FNanchor_88_88" id="FNanchor_88_88"></a><a href="#Footnote_88_88" class="fnanchor">[88]</a> are everywhere conspicuous and triumphant.
The main purport of the plot, as well as the particular design
of certain scenes, is borrowed from <i>Le Misanthrope</i> of
Molière, but it is almost a truism that the most original
writers are frequently the most extensive plagiarists, and
Wycherley has so overlaid his appropriations with the
colouring of his own brilliant individuality, that his play
appears almost equally a masterpiece of originality as of
ingenuity. It is scarcely too much to say that in <i>The Plain
Dealer</i> we are conscious of a fertility of invention, a richness
of wit and satire, which make even <i>Le Misanthrope</i> seem
tame in comparison. Voltaire has justly contrasted the two
plays. "All Wycherley's strokes," he writes, "are stronger
and bolder than those of our <i>Misanthrope</i>, but then they are
less delicate, and the Rules of Decorum are not so well
observed in this Play."<a name="FNanchor_89_89" id="FNanchor_89_89"></a><a href="#Footnote_89_89" class="fnanchor">[89]</a></p>

<p>The scene in the second act, between Olivia, her cousin,
and the two "pretty fellows," Novel and Plausible, was
suggested by a dialogue between Célimène and her admirers,
in the second act of <i>Le Misanthrope</i>, but the detail is almost
entirely Wycherley's own, and is enlivened with such diverting
antitheses and such brilliant fancy that, perhaps, few
scenes more masterly are to be found in the entire range of
English comedy from the time of the Restoration downwards.
In this scene occurs the critique upon <i>The Country
Wife</i>, of which the hint was taken from Molière's <i>Critique de
l'Ecole des Femmes</i>. It is here introduced with great
felicity, and the contrast between the affected prudery of the
vicious Olivia and the simple candour of the truly modest
Eliza is both just and edifying. Again, the discovery by
Novel and Plausible of the duplicity of Olivia, by means of
an exchange of letters, is borrowed from the <i>dénouement</i> of
<i>Le Misanthrope</i>; but the scene in which it occurs owes little
to Molière beyond the incident; and the humorous device
of making each letter, <i>mutato nomine</i>, the exact counterpart
of the other, belongs to Wycherley alone. One or two more
particular coincidences between <i>The Plain Dealer</i> and <i>Le
Misanthrope</i> will be pointed out in the notes.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_366" id="Page_366">[Pg 366]</a></span></p>

<p>The admirably conceived character of the Widow Blackacre
has been described as a copy of that of the Countess in
Racine's comedy, <i>Les Plaideurs</i>, surely, in the first instance,
by one of those critics with whom "most authors steal their
works, or buy." There is a litigious old woman in <i>Les
Plaideurs</i>, there is a litigious old woman in <i>The Plain
Dealer</i>; and here the likeness begins and ends.<a name="FNanchor_90_90" id="FNanchor_90_90"></a><a href="#Footnote_90_90" class="fnanchor">[90]</a> Voltaire
calls the Widow Blackacre "the most comical character that
was ever brought upon the stage." Lastly, although Fidelia is
imitated from Shakespeare's Viola, and although the imitation
is immeasurably and at all points inferior to the original,
it must be admitted, nevertheless, that she fills her place in
the play with perfect propriety, and is even drawn with some
not inconsiderable degree of sweetness and pathos.</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_367" id="Page_367">[Pg 367]</a></span></p>




<h3>TO MY LADY B&mdash;&mdash;.<a name="FNanchor_91_91" id="FNanchor_91_91"></a><a href="#Footnote_91_91" class="fnanchor">[91]</a></h3>


<p>Madam,&mdash;</p>

<p>Though I never had the honour to receive
a favour from you, nay, or be known to
you, I take the confidence of an author to
write to you a <i>billet-doux</i> dedicatory;&mdash;which
is no new thing. For by most dedications
it appears that authors, though they
praise their patrons from top to toe, and seem to turn 'em
inside out, know 'em as little as sometimes their patrons their
books, though they read them out; and if the poetical
daubers did not write the name of the man or woman on top
of the picture, 'twere impossible to guess whose it were. But
you, madam, without the help of a poet, have made yourself
known and famous in the world; and because you do not
want it, are therefore most worthy of an epistle dedicatory.
And this play claims naturally your protection, since it has
lost its reputation with the ladies of stricter lives in the playhouse;
and, you know, when men's endeavours are discountenanced
and refused by the nice coy women of honour, they
come to you:&mdash;to you, the great and noble patroness of rejected
and bashful men (of which number I profess myself to
be one, though a poet, a dedicating poet), to you, I say,
madam, who have as discerning a judgment, in what's
obscene or not, as any quick-sighted civil person of 'em all,
and can make as much of a double-meaning saying as the
best of 'em; yet would not, as some do, make nonsense of a
poet's jest, rather than not make it bawdy; by which they
show, they as little value wit in a play as in a lover, provided
they can bring t'other thing about. Their sense, indeed, lies
all one way, and therefore are only for that in a poet, which
is moving, as they say. But what do they mean by that
word "moving?" Well, I must not put 'em to the blush,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_368" id="Page_368">[Pg 368]</a></span>
since I find I can do't. In short, madam, you would not be
one of those who ravish a poet's innocent words, and make
'em guilty of their own naughtiness (as 'tis termed) in spite of
his teeth. Nay, nothing is secure from the power of their
imaginations, no, not their husbands, whom they cuckold
with themselves, by thinking of other men; and so make the
lawful matrimonial embraces adultery, wrong husbands and
poets in thought and word, to keep their own reputations.
But your ladyship's justice, I know, would think a woman's
arraigning and damning a poet for her own obscenity like
her crying out a rape, and hanging a man for giving her
pleasure, only that she might be thought not to consent to't;
and so to vindicate her honour, forfeits her modesty. But
you, madam, have too much modesty to pretend to't, though
you have as much to say for your modesty as many a nicer
she: for you never were seen at this play, no, not the first
day; and 'tis no matter what people's lives have been, they
are unquestionably modest who frequent not this play. For,
as Mr. Bayes says of his, "That it is the only touchstone of
men's wit and understanding;" mine is, it seems, the only
touchstone of women's virtue and modesty. But hold, that
touchstone is equivocal, and, by the strength of a lady's
imagination, may become something that is not civil: but
your ladyship, I know, scorns to misapply a touchstone.</p>

<p>And, madam, though you have not seen this play, I hope
(like other nice ladies) you will the rather read it. Yet, lest
the chambermaid or page should not be trusted, and their
indulgence could gain no further admittance for it than to
their ladies' lobbies or outward rooms, take it into your care
and protection; for by your recommendation and procurement,
it may have the honour to get into their closets; for
what they renounce in public, often entertains 'em there, with
your help especially. In fine, madam, for these and many
other reasons, you are the fittest patroness or judge of this
play; for you show no partiality to this or that author. For
from some many ladies will take a broad jest as cheerfully as
from the watermen, and sit at some downright filthy plays (as
they call 'em) as well satisfied, and as still, as a poet could
wish 'em elsewhere. Therefore it must be the doubtful
obscenity of my play alone they take exceptions at, because
it is too bashful for 'em: and, indeed, most women hate men
for attempting by halves on their chastity; and bawdy, I<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_369" id="Page_369">[Pg 369]</a></span>
find, like satire, should be home, not to have it taken notice
of. But, now I mention satire, some there are who say, "'Tis
the plain-dealing of the play, not the obscenity; 'tis taking
off the ladies' masks, not offering at their petticoats, which
offends 'em:"&mdash;and generally they are not the handsomest,
or most innocent, who are the most angry at their being discovered:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 15em;">"Nihil est audacius illis</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Deprensis; iram atque animos a crimine sumunt."<a name="FNanchor_92_92" id="FNanchor_92_92"></a><a href="#Footnote_92_92" class="fnanchor">[92]</a></span><br />
</p>

<p>Pardon, madam, the quotation; for a dedication can no more
be without ends of Latin, than flattery: and 'tis no matter
whom it is writ to; for an author can as easily, I hope, suppose
people to have more understanding and languages than
they have, as well as more virtues. But why, the devil,
should any of the few modest and handsome be alarmed?&mdash;for
some there are, who, as well as any, deserve those attributes,
yet refrain not from seeing this play, nor think it any
addition to their virtue to set up for it in a playhouse, lest
there it should look too much like acting&mdash;but why, I say,
should any at all of the truly virtuous be concerned, if those
who are not so are distinguished from 'em? for by that mask
of modesty which women wear promiscuously in public, they
are all alike; and you can no more know a kept wench from
a woman of honour by her looks than by her dress. For
those who are of quality without honour (if any such there
are) they have their quality to set off their false modesty, as
well as their false jewels; and you must no more suspect
their countenances for counterfeit than their pendants, though
as the plain dealer Montaigne says, "<i>Els envoy leur conscience
au bordel, et tiennent leur continence en règle</i>." But
those who act as they look, ought not to be scandalised at
the reprehension of others' faults, lest they tax themselves
with 'em, and by too delicate and quick an apprehension not
only make that obscene which I meant innocent, but that
satire on all, which was intended only on those who deserved
it.</p>

<p>But, madam, I beg your pardon for this digression to civil
women and ladies of honour, since you and I shall never be
the better for 'em: for a comic poet and a lady of your profession<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_370" id="Page_370">[Pg 370]</a></span>
make most of the other sort; and the stage and your
houses, like our plantations, are propagated by the least nice
women; and, as with the ministers of justice, the vices of the
age are our best business. But now I mention public persons,
I can no longer defer doing you the justice of a dedication,
and telling you your own, who are, of all public-spirited
people, the most necessary, most communicative, most
generous and hospitable. Your house has been the house of
the people; your sleep still disturbed for the public; and
when you arose, 'twas that others might lie down; and you
waked that others might rest; the good you have done is unspeakable.
How many young inexperienced heirs have you
kept from rash foolish marriages, and from being jilted for
their lives by the worst sort of jilts, wives! How many unbewitched
widowers' children have you preserved from the
tyranny of stepmothers! How many old doters from cuckoldage,
