and keeping other men's wenches and children!
How many adulteries and unnatural sins have you prevented!
In fine, you have been a constant scourge to the old lecher,
and often a terror to the young: you have made concupiscence
its own punishment, and extinguished lust with lust,
like blowing up of houses to stop the fire.</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">"Nimirum propter continentiam, incontinentia</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Necessaria est, incendium ignibus exstinguitur."<a name="FNanchor_93_93" id="FNanchor_93_93"></a><a href="#Footnote_93_93" class="fnanchor">[93]</a></span><br />
</p>

<p>There's Latin for you again, madam: I protest to you, as
I am an author, I cannot help it: nay, I can hardly keep
myself from quoting Aristotle and Horace, and talking to
you of the rules of writing (like the French authors), to show
you and my reader I understand 'em, in my epistle, lest
neither of you should find it out by the play. And according
to the rules of dedications, 'tis no matter whether you understand
or no what I quote or say to you of writing; for an
author can as easily make any one a judge or critic in an
epistle, as a hero in his play. But, madam, that this may
prove to the end a true epistle dedicatory, I'd have you to
know 'tis not without a design upon you, which is in the
behalf of the fraternity of Parnassus; that songs and sonnets
may go at your houses, and in your liberties, for guineas and
half-guineas; and that wit, at least with you, as of old, may<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_371" id="Page_371">[Pg 371]</a></span>
be the price of beauty, and so you will prove a true encourager
of poetry; for love is a better help to it than wine;
and poets, like painters, draw better after the life than by
fancy. Nay, in justice, madam, I think a poet ought to be
as free of your houses, as of the play-houses; since he contributes
to the support of both, and is as necessary to such
as you, as a ballad-singer to a pick-purse, in convening the
cullies at the theatres, to be picked up and carried to supper
and bed at your houses. And, madam, the reason of this
motion of mine is, because poor poets can get no favour in
the tiring-rooms, for they are no keepers, you know; and
folly and money, the old enemies of wit, are even too hard
for it on its own dunghill: and for other ladies, a poet can
least go to the price of them. Besides, his wit, which ought
to recommend him to 'em, is as much an obstruction to his
love, as to his wealth or preferment; for most women now-a-days
apprehend wit in a lover, as much as in a husband;
they hate a man that knows 'em, they must have a blind easy
fool, whom they can lead by the nose; and, as the Scythian
women of old, must baffle a man, and put out his eyes, ere
they will lie with him; and then too like thieves, when they
have plundered and stripped a man, leave him. But if there
should be one of a hundred of those ladies generous enough
to give herself to a man that has more wit than money, (all
things considered,) he would think it cheaper coming to you
for a mistress, though you made him pay his guinea; as a
man in a journey (out of good husbandry), had better pay for
what he has at an inn, than lie on free-cost at a gentleman's
house.</p>

<p>In fine, madam, like a faithful dedicator, I hope I have
done myself right in the first place: then you, and your profession,
which in the wisest and most religious government
in the world is honoured with the public allowance; and in
those that are thought the most uncivilised and barbarous is
protected and supported by the ministers of justice. And
of you, madam, I ought to say no more here, for your virtues
deserve a poem rather than an epistle, or a volume entire to
give the world your memoirs, or life at large; and which
(upon the word of an author that has a mind to make an end
of his dedication) I promise to do, when I write the annals of
our British love, which shall be dedicated to the ladies concerned,
if they will not think them something too obscene<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_372" id="Page_372">[Pg 372]</a></span>
too; when your life, compared with many that are thought
innocent, I doubt not, may vindicate you, and me, to the
world, for the confidence I have taken in this address to you;
which then may be thought neither impertinent nor immodest;
and whatsoever your amorous misfortunes have been,
none can charge you with that heinous, and worst of women's
crimes, hypocrisy; nay, in spite of misfortunes or age, you
are the same woman still; though most of your sex grow
Magdalens at fifty, and as a solid French author has it&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">"Après le plaisir, vient la peine;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Après la peine, la vertu."</span><br />
</p>

<p>But sure an old sinner's continency is much like a gamester's
forswearing play, when he had lost all his money; and
modesty is a kind of a youthful dress, which, as it makes a
young woman more amiable, makes an old one more
nauseous: a bashful old woman is like a hopeful old man;
and the affected chastity of antiquated beauties is rather a
reproach than an honour to 'em; for it shows the men's
virtue only, not theirs. But you, in fine, madam, are no
more a hypocrite than I am when I praise you; therefore I
doubt not will be thought (even by yours and the play's
enemies, the nicest ladies) to be the fittest patroness for,</p>

<p>Madam,</p>

<p>Your ladyship's most obedient, faithful, humble servant, and</p>

<p>THE PLAIN DEALER.</p>



<hr class="chap" />
<h3>PROLOGUE.</h3>

<h4>SPOKEN BY THE PLAIN DEALER.</h4>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">I the Plain Dealer am to act to-day,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And my rough part begins before the play.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">First, you who scribble, yet hate all that write,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And keep each other company in spite,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">As rivals in your common mistress, fame,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And with faint praises one another damn;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Tis a good play, we know, you can't forgive,</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_373" id="Page_373">[Pg 373]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">But grudge yourselves the pleasure you receive:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our scribbler therefore bluntly bid me say,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He would not have the wits pleased here to-day</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Next, you, the fine, loud gentlemen o' th' pit,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who damn all plays, yet, if y'ave any wit,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Tis but what here you spunge and daily get;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Poets, like friends to whom you are in debt,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You hate; and so rooks laugh, to see undone</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Those pushing gamesters whom they live upon.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Well, you are sparks, and still will be i' th' fashion;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Rail then at plays, to hide your obligation.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Now, you shrewd judges, who the boxes sway,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Leading the ladies' hearts and sense astray,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And, for their sakes, see all, and hear no play;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Correct your cravats, foretops, lock behind:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The dress and breeding of the play ne'er mind;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Plain dealing is, you'll say, quite out of fashion;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You'll hate it here, as in a dedication:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And your fair neighbours, in a limning poet</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">No more than in a painter will allow it.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Pictures too like the ladies will not please;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">They must be drawn too here like goddesses.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">You, as at Lely's too, would truncheon wield,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And look like heroes in a painted field.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But the coarse dauber of the coming scenes</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To follow life and nature only means,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Displays you as you are, makes his fine woman</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">A mercenary jilt, and true to no man:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">His men of wit and pleasure of the age</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Are as dull rogues as ever cumber'd stage:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He draws a friend only to custom just,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And makes him naturally break his trust.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">I, only, act a part like none of you,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And yet you'll say, it is a fool's part too:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">An honest man who, like you, never winks</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At faults; but, unlike you, speaks what he thinks:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The only fool who ne'er found patron yet,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For truth is now a fault as well as wit.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And where else, but on stages, do we see</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Truth pleasing, or rewarded honesty?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Which our bold poet does this day in me.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">If not to th' honest, be to th' prosperous kind,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Some friends at court let the Plain Dealer find.</span><br />
</p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_374" id="Page_374">[Pg 374]</a></span></p>




<h3><i>DRAMATIS PERSONÆ.</i></h3>

<p>
<span class="smcap">Manly</span>, of an honest, surly, nice humour, supposed first, in
the time of the Dutch war, to have procured the command
of a ship, out of honour, not interest; and choosing
a sea-life only to avoid the world.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Freeman, Manly's</span> Lieutenant, a gentleman well educated,
but of a broken fortune, a complier with the age.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Vernish</span>, <span class="smcap">Manly's</span> bosom and only friend.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Novel</span>, a pert railing Coxcomb, and an admirer of novelties,
makes love to <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.<br />
<br />
Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>, an old impertinent Fop, given to scribbling,
makes love to the Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>.<br />
<br />
Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>, a ceremonious, supple, commending Coxcomb,
in love with <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Jerry Blackacre</span>, a true raw Squire, under age, and his
mother's government, bred to the law.<br />
<br />
Lawyers, Knights of the Post, Bailiffs and Aldermen, a Bookseller's
Apprentice, a Foot-boy, Sailors, Waiters, and
Attendants.<br />
<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Olivia, Manly's</span> Mistress.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>, in love with <span class="smcap">Manly</span>, and follows him to sea in
man's clothes.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Eliza</span>, Cousin of <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.<br />
<br />
<span class="smcap">Lettice, Olivia's</span> Woman.<br />
<br />
Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>, a petulant, litigious Widow, always in
law, and Mother of Squire <span class="smcap">Jerry</span>.<br />
<br />
<br />
SCENE&mdash;<span class="smcap">London.</span></p>


<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_375" id="Page_375">[Pg 375]</a></span></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<h2><i>THE PLAIN DEALER.</i></h2>

<h3>ACT THE FIRST.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Manly's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>, <i>surlily</i>, Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>, <i>following him;
and two</i> Sailors <i>behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Tell not me, my good Lord
Plausible, of your decorums, supercilious
forms, and slavish ceremonies!
your little tricks, which you,
the spaniels of the world, do daily
over and over, for and to one another;
not out of love or duty, but
your servile fear.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, i' faith, i' faith, you are too passionate;
and I must humbly beg your pardon and leave to tell
you, they are the arts and rules the prudent of the world
walk by.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Let 'em. But I'll have no leading-strings; I can
walk alone: I hate a harness, and will not tug on in a
faction, kissing my leader behind, that another slave may
do the like to me.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> What, will you be singular then, like nobody?
follow, love, and esteem nobody?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Rather than be general, like you, follow everybody;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_376" id="Page_376">[Pg 376]</a></span>
court and kiss everybody; though perhaps at the
same time you hate everybody.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Why, seriously, with your pardon, my dear
friend&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> With your pardon, my no friend, I will not, as
you do, whisper my hatred or my scorn; call a man fool
or knave by signs or mouths over his shoulder, whilst
you have him in your arms.&mdash;For such as you, like
common whores and pickpockets, are only dangerous to
those you embrace.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Such as I! Heavens defend me!&mdash;upon
my honour&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Upon your title, my lord, if you'd have me believe
you.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Well, then, as I am a person of honour, I
never attempted to abuse or lessen any person in my
life.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What, you were afraid?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> No; but seriously, I hate to do a rude
thing: no, faith, I speak well of all mankind.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I thought so: but know, that speaking well of
all mankind is the worst kind of detraction; for it takes
away the reputation of the few good men in the world, by
making all alike. Now, I speak ill of most men, because
they deserve it; I that can do a rude thing, rather than
an unjust thing.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Well, tell not me, my dear friend, what
people deserve; I ne'er mind that. I, like an author in
a dedication, never speak well of a man for his sake, but
my own; I will not disparage any man, to disparage myself:
for to speak ill of people behind their backs, is not
like a person of honour; and, truly, to speak ill of 'em
to their faces, is not like a complaisant person. But if I
did say or do an ill thing to anybody, it should be sure
to be behind their backs, out of pure good manners.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Very well; but I, that am an unmannerly sea-fellow,
if I ever speak well of people, (which is very<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_377" id="Page_377">[Pg 377]</a></span>
seldom indeed,) it should be sure to be behind their
backs; and if I would say or do ill to any, it should be
to their faces. I would jostle a proud, strutting, overlooking
coxcomb, at the head of his sycophants, rather
than put out my tongue at him when he were past me;
would frown in the arrogant, big, dull face of an overgrown
knave of business, rather than vent my spleen
against him when his back were turned; would give
fawning slaves the lie whilst they embrace or commend
me; cowards whilst they brag; call a rascal by no other
title, though his father had left him a duke's; laugh at
fools aloud before their mistresses; and must desire
people to leave me, when their visits grow at last as
troublesome as they were at first impertinent.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> I would not have my visits troublesome.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> The only way to be sure not to have 'em troublesome,
is to make 'em when people are not at home; for
your visits, like other good turns, are most obliging when
made or done to a man in his absence. A pox! why
should any one, because he has nothing to do, go and
disturb another man's business?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> I beg your pardon, my dear friend.&mdash;What,
you have business?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> If you have any, I would not detain your lordship.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Detain me, dear sir!&mdash;I can never have
enough of your company.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I'm afraid I should be tiresome: I know not
what you think.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Well, dear sir, I see you'd have me gone.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But I see you won't.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Your most faithful&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> God be w'ye, my lord.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Your most humble&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Farewell.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> And eternally&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_378" id="Page_378">[Pg 378]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And eternally ceremony&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Then the
devil take thee eternally.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> You shall use no ceremony, by my life.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I do not intend it.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Why do you stir then?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Only to see you out of doors, that I may shut
'em against more welcomes.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, faith, that shall not pass upon your most
faithful humble servant.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nor this any more upon me. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Well, you are too strong for me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I'd sooner be visited by the plague; for
that only would keep a man from visits, and his doors
shut. [<i>Exit thrusting out</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Here's a finical fellow, Jack! What a brave
fair-weather captain of a ship he would make!</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> He a captain of a ship! it must be when
she's in the dock then; for he looks like one of those
that get the king's commissions for hulls to sell a king's
ship, when a brave fellow has fought her almost to a longboat.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> On my conscience then, Jack, that's the
reason our bully tar sunk our ship; not only that the
Dutch might not have her; but that the courtiers, who
laugh at wooden legs, might not make her prize.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> A pox of his sinking, Tom! we have made
a base, broken, short voyage of it.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Ay, your brisk dealers in honour always
make quick returns with their ships to the dock, and their
men to the hospitals. 'Tis, let me see, just a month since
we set out of the river, and the wind was almost as cross
to us as the Dutch.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Well, I forgive him sinking my own poor
truck, if he would but have given me time and leave to
have saved black Kate of Wapping's small venture.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Faith, I forgive him, since, as the purser told
me, he sunk the value of five or six thousand pound of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_379" id="Page_379">[Pg 379]</a></span>
his own, with which he was to settle himself somewhere
in the Indies; for our merry lieutenant was to succeed
him in his commission for the ship back; for he was resolved
never to return again for England.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> So it seemed, by his fighting.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> No; but he was a-weary of this side of the
world here, they say.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Ay, or else he would not have bid so fair for
a passage into t'other.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Jack, thou thinkest thyself in the forecastle,
thou'rt so waggish. But I tell you, then, he had a mind to
go live and bask himself on the sunny side of the globe.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> What, out of any discontent? for he's always
as dogged as an old tarpaulin, when hindered of a voyage
by a young pantaloon captain.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> 'Tis true I never saw him pleased but in the
fight; and then he looked like one of us coming from the
pay-table, with a new lining to our hats under our arms.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> A pox! he's like the Bay of Biscay, rough
and angry, let the wind blow where 'twill.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Nay, there's no more dealing with him, than
with the land in a storm, no near&mdash;</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> 'Tis a hurry-durry blade. Dost thou remember
after we had tugged hard the old leaky longboat
to save his life, when I welcomed him ashore, he
gave me a box on the ear, and called me fawning water-dog?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>with</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Hold thy peace, Jack, and stand by; the
foul weather's coming.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You rascals! dogs! how could this tame thing
get through you?</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Faith, to tell your honour the truth, we were
at hob in the hall,<a name="FNanchor_94_94" id="FNanchor_94_94"></a><a href="#Footnote_94_94" class="fnanchor">[94]</a> and whilst my brother and I were
quarrelling about a cast, he slunk by us.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_380" id="Page_380">[Pg 380]</a></span></p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> He's a sneaking fellow I warrant for't.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Have more care for the future, you slaves. Go,
and with drawn cutlasses stand at the stair-foot, and keep
all that ask for me from coming up; suppose you were
guarding the scuttle to the powder-room. Let none enter
here, at your and their peril.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> No, for the danger would be the same: you
would blow them and us up, if we should.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Must no one come to you, sir?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No man, sir.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> No man, sir; but a woman then, an't like
your honour&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No woman neither, you impertinent dog!
Would you be pimping? sea-pimp is the strangest monster
she has.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Indeed, an't like your honour, 'twill be hard
for us to deny a woman anything, since we are so newly
come on shore.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> We'll let no old woman come up, though it
were our trusting landlady at Wapping.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Would you be witty, you brandy casks you?
you become a jest as ill as you do a horse. Begone, you
dogs! I hear a noise on the stairs. [<i>Exeunt</i> Sailors.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Faith, I am sorry you would let the fop go, I
intended to have had some sport with him.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Sport with him! A pox! then, why did you
not stay? You should have enjoyed your coxcomb, and
had him to yourself for me.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No, I should not have cared for him without you
neither; for the pleasure which fops afford is like that of
drinking, only good when 'tis shared; and a fool, like a
bottle, which would make you merry in company, will
make you dull alone. But how the devil could you turn
a man of his quality down stairs? You use a lord with
very little ceremony, it seems.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> A lord! What, thou art one of those who esteem
men only by the marks and value fortune has set upon<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_381" id="Page_381">[Pg 381]</a></span>
'em, and never consider intrinsic worth! but counterfeit
honour will not be current with me: I weigh the man,
not his title; 'tis not the king's stamp can make
the metal better or heavier. Your lord is a leaden
shilling, which you bend every way, and debases the
stamp he bears, instead of being raised by it.&mdash;Here
again, you slaves!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Sailors.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> Only to receive farther instructions, an't like
your honour.&mdash;What if a man should bring you money,
should we turn him back?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> All men, I say: must I be pestered with you
too?&mdash;You dogs, away!</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Nay, I know one man your honour would
not have us hinder coming to you, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Who's that? speak quickly, slaves.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Why, a man that should bring you a challenge.
For though you refuse money, I'm sure you love
fighting too well to refuse that.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Rogue! rascal! dog! [<i>Kicks the</i> Sailors <i>out.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, let the poor rogues have their forecastle
jests: they cannot help 'em in a fight, scarce when a
ship's sinking.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn their untimely jests! a servant's jest is
more sauciness than his counsel.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But what, will you see nobody? not your
friends?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Friends!&mdash;I have but one, and he, I hear, is
not in town; nay, can have but one friend, for a true
heart admits but of one friendship, as of one love. But
in having that friend, I have a thousand; for he has the
courage of men in despair, yet the diffidency and
caution of cowards; the secrecy of the revengeful, and
the constancy of martyrs; one fit to advise, to keep a
secret, to fight and die for his friend. Such I think
him; for I have trusted him with my mistress in my<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_382" id="Page_382">[Pg 382]</a></span>
absence: and the trust of beauty is sure the greatest we
can show.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, but all your good thoughts are not for him
alone, I hope? Pray, what d'ye think of me for a
friend?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Of thee! Why, thou art a latitudinarian in
friendship, that is, no friend; thou dost side with all
mankind, but wilt suffer for none. Thou art indeed like
your Lord Plausible, the pink of courtesy, therefore hast
no friendship: for ceremony and great professing renders
friendship as much suspected as it does religion.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And no professing, no ceremony at all in friendship,
were as unnatural and as undecent as in religion:
and there is hardly such a thing as an honest hypocrite,
who professes himself to be worse than he is, unless it
be yourself; for though I could never get you to say you
were my friend, I know you'll prove so.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I must confess, I am so much your friend, I
would not deceive you; therefore must tell you, not only
because my heart is taken up, but according to your rules
of friendship, I cannot be your friend.<a name="FNanchor_95_95" id="FNanchor_95_95"></a><a href="#Footnote_95_95" class="fnanchor">[95]</a></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Pray, why?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Because he that is, you'll say, a true friend to a
man, is a friend to all his friends. But you must pardon
me, I cannot wish well to pimps, flatterers, detractors,
and cowards, stiff nodding knaves, and supple, pliant,
kissing fools. Now, all these I have seen you use like
the dearest friends in the world.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ha! ha! ha!&mdash;What, you observed me, I warrant,
in the galleries at Whitehall, doing the business of the
place? Pshaw! Court-professions, like court promises,
go for nothing, man. But, faith, could you think I was
a friend to all those I hugged, kissed, flattered, bowed
to? Ha! ha!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You told 'em so, and swore it too; I heard you.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_383" id="Page_383">[Pg 383]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, but when their backs were turned, did not I
tell you they were rogues, villains, rascals, whom I
despised and hated?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Very fine! But what reason had I to believe
you spoke your heart to me, since you professed deceiving
so many?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, don't you know, good captain, that telling
truth is a quality as prejudicial to a man that would thrive
in the world, as square play to a cheat, or true love to a
whore? Would you have a man speak truth to his ruin?
You are severer than the law, which requires no man to
swear against himself. You would have me speak truth
against myself I warrant, and tell my promising friend
the courtier, he has a bad memory.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And so make him remember to forget my business?
And I should tell the great lawyer too, that he
takes oftener fees to hold his tongue, than to speak?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No doubt on't.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, and have him hang or ruin me, when he
should come to be a judge, and I before him? And you
would have me tell the new officer, who bought his
employment lately, that he is a coward?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And so get myself cashiered, not him, he having
the better friends, though I the better sword? And I
should tell the scribbler of honour, that heraldry were a
prettier and fitter study for so fine a gentleman than
poetry?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Certainly.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And so find myself mauled in his next hired
lampoon? And you would have me tell the holy lady,
too, she lies with her chaplain?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No doubt on't.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And so draw the clergy upon my back, and want
a good table to dine at sometimes? And by the same
reason too, I should tell you that the world thinks you a<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_384" id="Page_384">[Pg 384]</a></span>
mad man, a brutal, and have you cut my throat, or worse,
hate me. What other good success of all my plain-dealing
could I have, than what I've mentioned?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, first, your promising courtier would keep
his word out of fear of more reproaches, or at least would
give you no more vain hopes: your lawyer would serve
you more faithfully; for he, having no honour but his
interest, is truest still to him he knows suspects him: the
new officer would provoke thee to make him a coward,
and so be cashiered, that thou, or some other honest
fellow, who had more courage than money, might get his
place: the noble sonnetteer would trouble thee no more
with his madrigals: the praying lady would leave off railing
at wenching before thee, and not turn away her
chambermaid for her own known frailty with thee: and
I, instead of hating thee, should love thee for thy plain
dealing; and in lieu of being mortified, am proud that
the world and I think not well of one another.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, doctors differ. You are for plain dealing,
I find: but against your particular notions, I have the
practice of the whole world. Observe but any morning
what people do when they get together on the Exchange,
in Westminster-hall, or the galleries in Whitehall.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I must confess, there they seem to rehearse
Bayes's grand dance. Here you see a bishop bowing
low to a gaudy atheist; a judge to a door-keeper; a
great lord to a fishmonger, or scrivener with a jack-chain
about his neck; a lawyer to a sergeant-at-arms; a velvet
physician to a threadbare chemist; and a supple gentleman-usher
to a surly beefeater: and so tread round in a
preposterous huddle of ceremony to each other, whilst
they can hardly hold their solemn false countenances.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, they understand the world.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Which I do not, I confess.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But, sir, pray believe the friendship I promise
you real, whatsoever I have professed to others: try me,
at least.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_385" id="Page_385">[Pg 385]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, what would you do for me?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I would fight for you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> That you would do for your own honour. But
what else?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I would lend you money, if I had it.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> To borrow more of me another time. That
were putting your money to interest; a usurer would be
as good a friend.&mdash;But what other piece of friendship?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I would speak well of you to your enemies.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> To encourage others to be your friends, by a
show of gratitude.&mdash;But what else?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, I would not hear you ill spoken of behind
your back by my friend.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, then, thou'rt a friend, indeed.&mdash;But it were
unreasonable to expect it from thee, as the world goes
now, when new friends, like new mistresses, are got by
disparaging old ones.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p>But here comes another, will say as much at least.&mdash;Dost
thou not love me devilishly too, my little volunteer, as
well as he or any man can?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Better than any man can love you, my dear
captain.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Look you there, I told you so.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> As well as you do truth or honour, sir; as well.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, good young gentleman, enough, for shame!
Thou hast been a page, by thy flattering and lying, to
one of those praying ladies who love flattery so well they
are jealous of it; and wert turned away for saying the
same things to the old housekeeper for sweetmeats, as
you did to your lady; for thou flatterest everything and
everybody alike.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> You, dear sir, should not suspect the truth of
what I say of you, though to you. Fame, the old liar, is
believed when she speaks wonders of you: you cannot
be flattered, sir, your merit is unspeakable.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_386" id="Page_386">[Pg 386]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hold, hold, sir, or I shall suspect worse of you,
that you have been a cushion-bearer to some state-hypocrite,
and turned away by the chaplains, for out-flattering
their probation-sermons for a benefice.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Suspect me for anything, sir, but the want of love,
faith, and duty to you, the bravest, worthiest of mankind;
believe me, I could die for you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, there you lie, sir; did not I see thee more
afraid in the fight than the chaplain of the ship, or the
purser that bought his place?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Can he be said to be afraid, that ventures to sea
with you?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Fy! fy! no more; I shall hate thy flattery
worse than thy cowardice, nay, than thy bragging.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Well, I own then I was afraid, mightily afraid;
yet for you I would be afraid again, a hundred times
afraid. Dying is ceasing to be afraid, and that I could
do sure for you, and you'll believe me one day. [<i>Weeps.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Poor youth! believe his eyes, if not his tongue:
he seems to speak truth with them.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What, does he cry? A pox on't! a maudlin
flatterer is as nauseously troublesome as a maudlin
drunkard.&mdash;No more, you little milksop, do not cry, I'll
never make thee afraid again; for of all men, if I had
occasion, thou shouldst not be my second; and when I
go to sea again, thou shalt venture thy life no more with
me.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Why, will you leave me behind then?&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
If you would preserve my life, I'm sure you should not.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Leave thee behind! ay, ay, thou art a hopeful
youth for the shore only. Here thou wilt live to be
cherished by fortune and the great ones; for thou mayst
easily come to outflatter a dull poet, outlie a coffee-house
or gazette-writer, outswear a knight of the post,<a name="FNanchor_96_96" id="FNanchor_96_96"></a><a href="#Footnote_96_96" class="fnanchor">[96]</a> outwatch
a pimp, outfawn a rook, outpromise a lover, outrail
a wit, and outbrag a sea-captain:&mdash;all this thou canst do,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_387" id="Page_387">[Pg 387]</a></span>
because thou'rt a coward, a thing I hate; therefore thou'lt
do better with the world than with me, and these are the
good courses you must take in the world. There's good
advice, at least, at parting; go, and be happy with't.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Parting, sir! O let me not hear that dismal word.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> If my words frighten thee, begone the sooner;
for to be plain with thee, cowardice and I cannot dwell
together.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> And cruelty and courage never dwelt together
sure, sir. Do not turn me off to shame and misery, for I
am helpless and friendless.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Friendless! there are half a score friends for
thee then.&mdash;[<i>Offers her gold.</i>] I leave myself no more:
they'll help thee a little. Begone, go, I must be cruel to
thee (if thou callest it so) out of pity.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> If you would be cruelly pitiful, sir, let it be with
your sword, not gold. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> 1st Sailor.</p>

<p><i>1st Sail.</i> We have, with much ado, turned away two
gentlemen, who told us, forty times over, their names
were Mr. Novel and Major Oldfox.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, to your post again.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Sailor.] But
how come those puppies coupled always together?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> O, the coxcombs keep each other company, to
show each other, as Novel calls it; or, as Oldfox says,
like two knives, to whet one another.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And set other people's teeth on edge.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> 2nd Sailor.</p>

<p><i>2nd Sail.</i> Here is a woman, an't like your honour,
scolds and bustles with us, to come in, as much as a
seaman's widow at the Navy office: her name is Mrs.
Blackacre.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> That fiend too!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> The Widow Blackacre, is it not? that litigious
she petty-fogger, who is at law and difference with all the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_388" id="Page_388">[Pg 388]</a></span>
world; but I wish I could make her agree with me in
the church. They say she has fifteen hundred pounds a
year jointure, and the care of her son, that is, the
destruction of his estate.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Her lawyers, attorneys, and solicitors, have
fifteen hundred pounds a year, whilst she is contented to
be poor, to make other people so. For she is as
vexatious as her father was, the great attorney, nay, as a
dozen Norfolk attorneys, and as implacable an adversary
as a wife suing for alimony, or a parson for his tithes;
and she loves an Easter term, or any term, not as other
country ladies do, to come up to be fine, cuckold their
husbands, and take their pleasure; for she has no
pleasure but in vexing others, and is usually clothed and
daggled<a name="FNanchor_97_97" id="FNanchor_97_97"></a><a href="#Footnote_97_97" class="fnanchor">[97]</a> like a bawd in disguise, pursued through alleys
by sergeants. When she is in town, she lodges in one of
the inns of Chancery, where she breeds her son, and is
herself his tutoress in law-French; and for her country
abode, though she has no estate there, she chooses
Norfolk.&mdash;But, bid her come in, with a pox to her! she
is Olivia's kinswoman, and may make me amends for her
visit, by some discourse of that dear woman.
[<i>Exit</i> Sailor.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>, <i>with a mantle and a green
bag, and several papers in the other hand;</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry
Blackacre</span> <i>in a gown, laden with green bags,
following her.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I never had so much to do with a judge's door-keeper,
as with yours; but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But the incomparable Olivia, how does she
since I went?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Since you went, my suit&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Olivia, I say, is she well?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> My suit, if you had not returned&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn your suit! how does your cousin Olivia?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_389" id="Page_389">[Pg 389]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> My suit, I say, had been quite lost; but now&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But now, where is Olivia? in town? for&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> For to-morrow we are to have a hearing.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Would you would let me have a hearing to-day!</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> But why won't you hear me?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I am no judge, and you talk of nothing but
suits; but, pray tell me, when did you see Olivia?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I am no visitor, but a woman of business; or if
I ever visit, 'tis only the Chancery-lane ladies, ladies
towards the law; and not any of your lazy, good-for-nothing
flirts, who cannot read law-French, though a
gallant writ it. But as I was telling you, my suit&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn these impertinent vexatious people of
business, of all sexes! they are still troubling the world
with the tedious recitals of their lawsuits: and one can
no more stop their mouths than a wit's when he talks of
himself, or an intelligencer's when he talks of other
people.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> And a pox of all vexatious, impertinent lovers!
they are still perplexing the world with the tedious
narrations of their love-suits, and discourses of their
mistresses! You are as troublesome to a poor widow of
business, as a young coxcombly rhyming lover.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And thou art as troublesome to me, as a rook
to a losing gamester, or a young putter of cases to his
mistress or sempstress, who has love in her head for
another.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, since you talk of putting of cases, and will
not hear me speak, hear our Jerry a little; let him put
our case to you, for the trial's to-morrow: and since you
are my chief witness, I would have your memory refreshed
and your judgment informed, that you may not
give your evidence improperly.&mdash;Speak out, child.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Yes, forsooth. Hem! hem! John-a-Stiles&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You may talk, young lawyer, but I shall no
more mind you, than a hungry judge does a cause after
the clock has struck one.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_390" id="Page_390">[Pg 390]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, you'll find him as peevish too.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No matter. Jerry, go on.&mdash;Do you observe it
then, sir; for I think I have seen you in a gown once.
Lord, I could hear our Jerry put cases all day long.&mdash;Mark
him, sir.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> John-a-Stiles&mdash;no&mdash;there are first, Fitz, Pere, and
Ayle,&mdash;no, no, Ayle, Pere, and Fitz; Ayle is seised in
fee of Blackacre; John-a-Stiles disseises Ayle; Ayle
makes claim, and the disseisor dies; then the Ayle&mdash;no,
the Fitz&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, the Pere, sirrah.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Oh, the Pere! ay, the Pere, sir, and the Fitz&mdash;no,
the Ayle,&mdash;no, the Pere and the Fitz, sir, and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn Pere, Mere, and Fitz, sir!</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, you are out, child.&mdash;Hear me, captain, then.
There are Ayle, Pere, and Fitz; Ayle is seised in fee of
Blackacre; and, being so seised, John-a-Stiles disseises the
Ayle, Ayle makes claim, and the disseisor dies; and then
the Pere re-enters, the Pere, sirrah, the Pere&mdash;[<i>to</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span>.]
and the Fitz enters upon the Pere, and the Ayle brings
his writ of disseisin in the post; and the Pere brings his
writ of disseisin in the Pere, and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Canst thou hear this stuff, Freeman? I could as
soon suffer a whole noise of flatterers at a great man's
levee in a morning; but thou hast servile complacency
enough to listen to a quibbling statesman in disgrace,
nay, and be beforehand with him, in laughing at his dull
no-jest; but I&mdash;[<i>Offering to go out.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, sir, hold! Where's the subp&#339;na, Jerry?
I must serve you, sir. You are required by this, to give
your testimony&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I'll be forsworn to be revenged on thee.
[<i>Exit, throwing away the subp&#339;na.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Get you gone, for a lawless companion!&mdash;Come,
Jerry, I had almost forgot, we were to meet at the
master's at three: let us mind our business still, child.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, forsooth, e'en so let's.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_391" id="Page_391">[Pg 391]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, madam, now I would beg you to hear me a
little, a little of my business.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I have business of my own calls me away, sir.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> My business would prove yours too, dear
madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Yours would be some sweet business, I warrant.
What, 'tis no Westminster Hall business? would you
have my advice?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No, faith, 'tis a little Westminster Abbey business;
I would have your consent.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O fy, fy, sir! to me such discourse, before my
dear minor there!</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, ay, mother, he would be taking livery and
seisin of your jointure by digging the turf, but I'll watch
your waters,<a name="FNanchor_98_98" id="FNanchor_98_98"></a><a href="#Footnote_98_98" class="fnanchor">[98]</a> bully, i'fac.&mdash;Come away, mother.
[<i>Exit, haling away his</i> Mother.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Dear sir, you have pity; beget but some in our
captain for me.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Where is he?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Within; swearing as much as he did in the great
storm, and cursing you, and sometimes sinks into calms
and sighs, and talks of his Olivia.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> He would never trust me to see her.&mdash;Is she
handsome?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> No, if you'll take my word: but I am not a
proper judge.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> What is she?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> A gentlewoman, I suppose, but of as mean a
fortune as beauty; but her relations would not suffer her
to go with him to the Indies: and his aversion to this
side of the world, together with the late opportunity of
commanding the convoy, would not let him stay here
longer, though to enjoy her.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_392" id="Page_392">[Pg 392]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> He loves her mightily then?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Yes, so well, that the remainder of his fortune (I
hear about five or six thousand pounds) he has left her,
in case he had died by the way, or before she could prevail
with her friends to follow him; which he expected
she should do, and has left behind him his great bosom
friend to be her convoy to him.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> What charms has she for him, if she be not
handsome?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> He fancies her, I suppose, the only woman of
truth and sincerity in the world.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No common beauty, I confess.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Or else sure he would not have trusted her with
so great a share of his fortune, in his absence, I suppose
(since his late loss) all he has.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, has he left it in her own custody?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I am told so.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Then he has showed love to her indeed, in
leaving her, like an old husband that dies as soon as he
has made his wife a good jointure.&mdash;But I'll go in to
him, and speak for you, and know more from him of his
Olivia. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">His Olivia, indeed, his happy Olivia!</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet she was left behind, when I was with him:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But she was ne'er out of his mind or heart.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">She has told him she loved him; I have show'd it,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And durst not tell him so, till I had done,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Under this habit, such convincing acts</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Of loving friendship for him, that through it</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He first might find out both my sex and love;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And, when I'd had him from his fair Olivia,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And this bright world of artful beauties here,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Might then have hoped, he would have look'd on me,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Amongst the sooty Indians; and I could,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To choose, there live his wife, where wives are forced</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To live no longer, when their husbands die;</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_393" id="Page_393">[Pg 393]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, what's yet worse, to share 'em whilst they live</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">With many rival wives. But here he comes,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And I must yet keep out of his sight, not</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To lose it for ever. [<i>Exit.</i></span><br />
</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But pray what strange charms has she that could
make you love?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Strange charms indeed! she has beauty enough
to call in question her wit or virtue, and her form would
make a starved hermit a ravisher; yet her virtue and
conduct would preserve her from the subtle lust of a
pampered prelate. She is so perfect a beauty, that art
could not better it, nor affectation deform it. Yet all
this is nothing. Her tongue as well as face ne'er knew
artifice; nor ever did her words or looks contradict her
heart. She is all truth, and hates the lying, masking,
daubing world, as I do: for which I love her, and for
which I think she dislikes not me. For she has often
shut out of her conversation for mine, the gaudy fluttering
parrots of the town, apes and echoes of men only,
and refused their common-place pert chat, flattery and
submissions, to be entertained with my sullen bluntness,
and honest love: and, last of all, swore to me, since her
parents would not suffer her to go with me, she would
stay behind for no other man; but follow me without
their leave, if not to be obtained. Which oath&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Did you think she would keep?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes; for she is not (I tell you) like other
women, but can keep her promise, though she has sworn
to keep it. But, that she might the better keep it, I left
her the value of five or six thousand pounds: for women's
wants are generally the most importunate solicitors to
love or marriage.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And money summons lovers more than beauty,
and augments but their importunity, and their number;
so makes it the harder for a woman to deny 'em. For
my part, I am for the French maxim;&mdash;"If you would<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_394" id="Page_394">[Pg 394]</a></span>
have your female subjects loyal, keep 'em poor."&mdash;But
in short, that your mistress may not marry, you have
given her a portion.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> She had given me her heart first, and I am
satisfied with the security; I can never doubt her truth
and constancy.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> It seems you do, since you are fain to bribe it
with money. But how come you to be so diffident of
the man that says he loves you, and not doubt the woman
that says it?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I should, I confess, doubt the love of any other
woman but her, as I do the friendship of any other man
but him I have trusted; but I have such proofs of their
faith as cannot deceive me.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Cannot!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Not but I know that generally no man can be a
great enemy but under the name of friend; and if you
are a cuckold, it is your friend only that makes you so,
for your enemy is not admitted to your house: if you are
cheated in your fortune, 'tis your friend that does it, for
your enemy is not made your trustee: if your honour or
good name be injured, 'tis your friend that does it still,
because your enemy is not believed against you. Therefore,
I rather choose to go where honest, downright
barbarity is professed, where men devour one another
like generous hungry lions and tigers, not like crocodiles;
where they think the devil white, of our complexion;
and I am already so far an Indian. But if your weak
faith doubts this miracle of a woman, come along with
me, and believe; and thou wilt find her so handsome,
that thou, who art so much my friend, wilt have a mind
to lie with her, and so wilt not fail to discover what her
faith and thine is to me.</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">When we're in love, the great adversity,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our friends and mistresses at once we try.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_395" id="Page_395">[Pg 395]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE SECOND.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Olivia's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>, <span class="smcap">Eliza</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ah, cousin, what a world 'tis we
live in! I am so weary of it.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Truly, cousin, I can find no
fault with it, but that we cannot always
live in't, for I can never be
weary of it.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O hideous! you cannot be in
earnest sure, when you say you like the filthy world.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You cannot be in earnest sure, when you say
you dislike it.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> You are a very censorious creature, I find.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> I must confess, I think we women as often discover
where we love by railing, as men when they lie by
their swearing; and the world is but a constant keeping
gallant, whom we fail not to quarrel with when anything
crosses us, yet cannot part with't for our hearts.</p>

<p><i>Let.</i> A gallant indeed, madam, whom ladies first make
jealous, and then quarrel with it for being so; for if, by
her indiscretion, a lady be talked of for a man, she cries
presently, "'Tis a censorious world!" if by her vanity
the intrigue be found out, "'Tis a prying malicious
world!" if by her over-fondness the gallant proves unconstant,
"'Tis a false world!" and if by her niggardliness<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_396" id="Page_396">[Pg 396]</a></span>
the chambermaid tells, "'Tis a perfidious world!"
But that, I'm sure, your ladyship cannot say of the world
yet, as bad as 'tis.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But I may say, "'Tis a very impertinent world!"&mdash;Hold
your peace.&mdash;And, cousin, if the world be a
gallant, 'tis such a one as is my aversion. Pray name it
no more.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> But is it possible the world, which has such
variety of charms for other women, can have none for
you? Let's see&mdash;first, what d'ye think of dressing and
fine clothes?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Dressing! Fy, fy, 'tis my aversion.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>.]
But come hither, you dowdy; methinks you might
have opened this toure better; O hideous! I cannot
suffer it! D'ye see how't sits?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Well enough, cousin, if dressing be your aversion.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> 'Tis so: and for variety of rich clothes, they are
more my aversion.</p>

<p><i>Let.</i> Ay, 'tis because your ladyship wears 'em too long;
for indeed a gown, like a gallant, grows one's aversion by
having too much of it.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Insatiable creature! I'll be sworn I have had
this not above three days, cousin, and within this month
have made some six more.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Then your aversion to 'em is not altogether so
great.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Alas! 'tis for my woman only I wear 'em,
cousin.</p>

<p><i>Let.</i> If it be for me only, madam, pray do not wear
'em.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> But what d'ye think of visits&mdash;balls?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, I detest 'em!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Of plays?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I abominate 'em; filthy, obscene, hideous things.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> What say you to masquerading in the winter,
and Hyde Park in the summer?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_397" id="Page_397">[Pg 397]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Insipid pleasures I taste not.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Nay, if you are are for more solid pleasures, what
think you of a rich young husband?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O horrid! marriage! what a pleasure you have
found out! I nauseate it of all things.</p>

<p><i>Let.</i> But what does your ladyship think then of a
liberal handsome young lover?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> A handsome young fellow, you impudent!
begone out of my sight. Name a handsome young
fellow to me! foh, a hideous handsome young fellow I
abominate! [<i>Spits.</i></p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Indeed! But let's see&mdash;will nothing please
you? what d'ye think of the court?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> How, the court! the court, cousin! my aversion,
my aversion, my aversion of all aversions!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> How, the court! where&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Where sincerity is a quality as much out of
fashion and as unprosperous as bashfulness: I could not
laugh at a quibble, though it were a fat privy-counsellor's;
nor praise a lord's ill verses, though I were myself the
subject; nor an old lady's young looks, though I were
her woman; nor sit to a vain young smile-maker, though
he flattered me. In short, I could not glout<a name="FNanchor_99_99" id="FNanchor_99_99"></a><a href="#Footnote_99_99" class="fnanchor">[99]</a> upon a
man when he comes into a room, and laugh at him when
he goes out; I cannot rail at the absent to flatter the
standers-by; I&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Well, but railing now is so common, that 'tis
no more malice, but the fashion; and the absent think
they are no more the worse for being railed at, than the
present think they're the better for being flattered. And
for the court&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, do not defend the court; for you'll make
me rail at it like a trusting citizen's widow.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Or like a Holborn lady, who could not get in
to the last ball, or was out of countenance in the drawing-room
the last Sunday of her appearance there. For<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_398" id="Page_398">[Pg 398]</a></span>
none rail at the court but those who cannot get into it,
or else who are ridiculous when they are there; and I
shall suspect you were laughed at when you were last
there, or would be a maid of honour.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I a maid of honour! To be a maid of honour,
were yet of all things my aversion.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> In what sense am I to understand you? But
in fine, by the word aversion, I'm sure you dissemble;
for I never knew woman yet used it who did not.
Come, our tongues belie our hearts more than our
pocket-glasses do our faces. But methinks we ought to
leave off dissembling, since 'tis grown of no use to us;
for all wise observers understand us now-a-days, as they
do dreams, almanacs, and Dutch gazettes, by the contrary:
and a man no more believes a woman, when she
says she has an aversion for him, than when she says
she'll cry out.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O filthy! hideous! Peace, cousin, or your
discourse will be my aversion: and you may believe
me.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Yes; for if anything be a woman's aversion,
'tis plain dealing from another woman: and perhaps
that's your quarrel to the world; for that will talk, as
your woman says.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Talk? not of me sure; for what men do I
converse with? what visits do I admit?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Here's the gentleman to wait upon you, madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> On me! you little unthinking fop; d'ye know
what you say?</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Yes, madam, 'tis the gentleman that comes
every day to you, who&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Hold your peace, you heedless little animal, and
get you gone.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Boy.] This country boy, cousin,
takes my dancing-master, tailor, or the spruce milliner,
for visitors.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_399" id="Page_399">[Pg 399]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Let.</i> No, madam; 'tis Mr. Novel, I'm sure, by his
talking so loud: I know his voice too, madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> You know nothing, you buffle-headed stupid
creature you: you would make my cousin believe I
receive visits. But if it be Mr.&mdash;what did you call
him?</p>

<p><i>Let.</i> Mr. Novel, madam; he that&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Hold your peace; I'll hear no more of him.
But if it be your Mr.&mdash;(I cannot think of his name again)
I suppose he has followed my cousin hither.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> No, cousin, I will not rob you of the honour of
the visit: 'tis to you, cousin; for I know him not.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nor did I ever hear of him before, upon my
honour, cousin; besides, han't I told you, that visits, and
the business of visits, flattery and detraction, are my aversion?
D'ye think then I would admit such a coxcomb as
he is? who rather than not rail, will rail at the dead,
whom none speak ill of; rather than not flatter, will
flatter the poets of the age, whom none will flatter; who
affects novelty as much as the fashion, and is as fantastical
as changeable, and as well known as the fashion; who
likes nothing but what is new, nay, would choose to have
his friend or his title a new one. In fine, he is my
aversion.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> I find you do know him, cousin; at least, have
heard of him.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Yes, now I remember. I have heard of him.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Well; but since he is such a coxcomb, for
Heaven's sake, let him not come up. Tell him, Mrs.
Lettice, your lady is not within.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No, Lettice, tell him my cousin is here, and that
he may come up. For notwithstanding I detest the sight
of him, you may like his conversation; and though I
would use him scurvily, I will not be rude to you in my
own lodging: since he has followed you hither, let him
come up, I say.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Very fine! pray let him go to the devil, I say,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_400" id="Page_400">[Pg 400]</a></span>
for me: I know him not, nor desire it. Send him away,
Mrs. Lettice.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Upon my word, she shan't: I must disobey your
commands, to comply with your desires. Call him up,
Lettice.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Nay, I'll swear she shall not stir on that errand.
[<i>Holds</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Well then, I'll call him myself for you, since you
will have it so.&mdash;[<i>Calls out at the door.</i>] Mr. Novel,
sir, sir!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Madam, I beg your pardon; perhaps you were
busy: I did not think you had company with you.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Yet he comes to me, cousin!
[<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Chairs there. [<i>They sit.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well; but, madam, d'ye know whence I come
now?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> From some melancholy place, I warrant, sir,
since they have lost your good company.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> So!</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> From a place where they have treated me at
dinner with so much civility and kindness, a pox on
them! that I could hardly get away to you, dear
madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> You have a way with you so new and obliging,
sir!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You hate flattery, cousin! [<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nay, faith, madam, d'ye think my way new?
Then you are obliging, madam. I must confess, I hate
imitation, to do anything like other people. All that
know me do me the honour to say, I am an original,
faith. But, as I was saying, madam, I have been treated
to-day with all the ceremony and kindness imaginable at
my Lady Autumn's. But, the nauseous old woman at
the upper end of her table&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_401" id="Page_401">[Pg 401]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Revives the old Grecian custom, of serving in a
death's head with their banquets.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ha! ha! fine, just, i'faith, nay, and new. 'Tis
like eating with the ghost in "The Libertine:"<a name="FNanchor_100_100" id="FNanchor_100_100"></a><a href="#Footnote_100_100" class="fnanchor">[100]</a> she
would frighten a man from her dinner with her hollow
invitations, and spoil one's stomach&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> To meat or women. I detest her hollow cherry
cheeks: she looks like an old coach new painted;
affecting an unseemly smugness, whilst she is ready to
drop in pieces.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You hate detraction, I see, cousin.
[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> But the silly old fury, whilst she affects to look
like a woman of this age, talks&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Like one of the last; and as passionately as an
old courtier who has outlived his office.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Yes, madam; but pray let me give you her
character. Then she never counts her age by the years,
but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> By the masques she has lived to see.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nay then, madam, I see you think a little harmless
railing too great a pleasure for any but yourself; and
therefore I've done.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, faith, you shall tell me who you had there
at dinner.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> If you would hear me, madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Most patiently; speak, sir.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Then, we had her daughter&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay, her daughter; the very disgrace to good
clothes, which she always wears but to heighten her
deformity, not mend it: for she is still most splendidly,
gallantly ugly, and looks like an ill piece of daubing in a
rich frame.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> So! But have you done with her, madam? and
can you spare her to me a little now?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_402" id="Page_402">[Pg 402]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay, ay, sir.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Then, she is like&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> She is, you'd say, like a city bride; the greater
fortune, but not the greater beauty, for her dress.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well: yet have you done, madam? Then she&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Then she bestows as unfortunately on her face
all the graces in fashion, as the languishing eye, the
hanging or pouting lip. But as the fool is never more
provoking than when he aims at wit, the ill-favoured of
our sex are never more nauseous than when they would
be beauties, adding to their natural deformity the artificial
ugliness of affectation.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> So, cousin, I find one may have a collection of
all one's acquaintance's pictures as well at your house as
at Mr. Lely's.<a name="FNanchor_101_101" id="FNanchor_101_101"></a><a href="#Footnote_101_101" class="fnanchor">[101]</a> Only the difference is, there we find 'em
much handsomer than they are, and like; here much
uglier, and like: and you are the first of the profession
of picture-drawing I ever knew without flattery.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I draw after the life; do nobody wrong, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> No, you hate flattery and detraction.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But, Mr. Novel, who had you besides at dinner?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nay, the devil take me if I tell you, unless you
will allow me the privilege of railing in my turn.&mdash;But,
now I think on't, the women ought to be your province,
as the men are mine: and you must know we had him
whom&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Him, whom&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> What, invading me already? and giving the
character before you know the man?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> No, that is not fair, though it be usual.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I beg your pardon, Mr. Novel; pray go on.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Then, I say, we had that familiar coxcomb who
is at home wheresoe'er he comes.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay, that fool&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nay then, madam, your servant; I'm gone.<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_403" id="Page_403">[Pg 403]</a></span>
Taking the fool out of one's mouth is worse than taking
the bread out of one's mouth.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I've done; your pardon, Mr. Novel: pray proceed.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> I say, the rogue, that he may be the only wit in
company, will let nobody else talk, and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay, those fops who love to talk all themselves
are of all things my aversion.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Then you'll let me speak, madam, sure. The
rogue, I say, will force his jest upon you; and I hate a
jest that's forced upon a man, as much as a glass.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Why, I hope, sir, he does not expect a man of
your temperance in jesting should do him reason?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> What! interruption from this side too? I must
then&mdash;[<i>Offers to rise.</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>holds him.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No, sir.&mdash;You must know, cousin, that fop he
means, though he talks only to be commended, will not
give you leave to do't.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> But, madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> He a wit! Hang him; he's only an adopter of
straggling jests and fatherless lampoons; by the credit of
which he eats at good tables, and so, like the barren
beggar-woman, lives by borrowed children.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And never was author of anything but his news;
but that is still all his own.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Madam, pray&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> An eternal babbler; and makes no more use of
his ears, than a man that sits at a play by his mistress, or
in Fop-corner. He's, in fine, a base detracting fellow,
and is my aversion.&mdash;But who else, prithee Mr. Novel,
was there with you? Nay, you shan't stir.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> I beg your pardon, madam; I cannot stay in any
place where I'm not allowed a little Christian liberty of
railing.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, prithee Mr. Novel, stay: and though you
should rail at me, I would hear you with patience.
Prithee, who else was there with you?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_404" id="Page_404">[Pg 404]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Your servant, madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, prithee tell us, Mr. Novel, prithee do.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> We had nobody else.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, faith, I know you had. Come, my Lord
Plausible was there too; who is, cousin, a&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You need not tell me what he is, cousin; for
I know him to be a civil, good-natured, harmless gentleman,
that speaks well of all the world, and is always in
good-humour; and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Hold, cousin, hold; I hate detraction. But I
must tell you, cousin, his civility is cowardice, his good-nature
want of wit; and he has neither courage nor sense
to rail: and for his being always in humour, 'tis because
he is never dissatisfied with himself. In fine, he is my
aversion; and I never admit his visits beyond my
hall.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> No, he visit you! Damn him, cringing grinning
rogue! if I should see him coming up to you, I would
make bold to kick him down again.&mdash;Ha!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>.</p>

<p>My dear lord, your most humble servant.
[<i>Rises and salutes</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>, <i>and kisses him.</i></p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> So, I find kissing and railing succeed each other
with the angry men as well as with the angry women; and
their quarrels are like love-quarrels, since absence is the
only cause of them; for as soon as the man appears
again, they are over. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Your most faithful humble servant, generous
Mr. Novel. And, madam, I am your eternal slave, and
kiss your fair hands; which I had done sooner, according
to your commands, but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No excuses, my lord.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> What, you sent for him then, cousin?
[<i>Apart to</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ha! invited! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I know you must divide yourself; for your good<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_405" id="Page_405">[Pg 405]</a></span>
company is too general a good to be engrossed by any
particular friend.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> O Lord, madam, my company! your most
obliged, faithful, humble servant. But I could have
brought you good company indeed; for I parted at your
door with two of the worthiest, bravest men&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Who were they, my lord?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Who do you call the worthiest, bravest men, pray?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> O, the wisest, bravest gentlemen! men of
such honour and virtue! of such good qualities! ah&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> This is a coxcomb that speaks ill of all people
a different way, and libels everybody with dull praise, and
commonly in the wrong place; so makes his panegyrics
abusive lampoons. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But pray let me know who they were?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Ah! such patterns of heroic virtue! such&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well: but who the devil were they?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The honour of our nation! the glory of our
age! Ah, I could dwell a twelvemonth on their praise;
which indeed I might spare by telling their names; Sir
John Current and Sir Richard Court-Title.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Court-Title! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And Sir John Current! Why will you keep such
a wretch company, my lord?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> O madam, seriously you are a little too severe;
for he is a man of unquestioned reputation in everything.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Yes, because he endeavours only with the women
to pass for a man of courage, and with the bullies for a
wit; with the wits for a man of business, and with the
men of business for a favourite at court; and at court for
city security.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And for Sir Richard, he&mdash;</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> He loves your choice picked company, persons
that&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> He loves a lord indeed; but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Pray, dear madam, let me have but a bold stroke
or two at his picture. He loves a lord, as you say, though&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_406" id="Page_406">[Pg 406]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Though he borrowed his money, and ne'er paid
him again.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And would bespeak a place three days before at
the back-end of a lord's coach to Hyde Park.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, i'faith, i'faith, you are both too severe.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Then to show yet more his passion for quality,
he makes love to that fulsome coach-load of honour, my
Lady Goodly, for he's always at her lodging.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Because it is the conventicle-gallant, the
meeting-house of all the fair ladies, and glorious superfine
beauties of the town.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Very fine ladies! there's first&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Her honour, as fat as an hostess.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> She is something plump indeed, a goodly,
comely, graceful person.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Then there's my Lady Frances&mdash;what d'ye call
her? as ugly&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> As a citizen's lawfully begotten daughter.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> She has wit in abundance, and the handsomest
heel, elbow, and tip of an ear, you ever saw.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Heel and elbow! ha! ha! And there's my Lady
Betty, you know&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> As sluttish and slatternly as an Irish woman bred
in France.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Ah! all she has hangs with a loose air, indeed,
and becoming negligence.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You see all faults with lovers' eyes, I find, my
lord.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Ah, madam, your most obliged, faithful,
humble servant to command! But you can say nothing
sure against the superfine mistress&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I know who you mean. She is as censorious
and detracting a jade as a superannuated sinner.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> She has a smart way of raillery, 'tis confessed.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And then for Mrs. Grideline&mdash;</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> She, I'm sure is&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_407" id="Page_407">[Pg 407]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> One that never spoke ill of anybody, 'tis confessed.
For she is as silent in conversation as a country
lover, and no better company than a clock, or a weather-glass:
for if she sounds, 'tis but once an hour to put you
in mind of the time of day, or to tell you 'twill be cold or
hot, rain or snow.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Ah, poor creature! she's extremely good and
modest.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And for Mrs. Bridlechin, she's&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> As proud as a churchman's wife.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> She's a woman of great spirit and honour,
and will not make herself cheap, 'tis true.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Then Mrs. Hoyden, that calls all people by their
surnames, and is&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> As familiar a duck&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> As an actress in the tiring room. There I was
once beforehand with you, madam.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Mrs. Hoyden! a poor, affable, good-natured
soul. But the divine Mrs. Trifle comes thither too.
Sure her beauty, virtue, and conduct, you can say
nothing to.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No!</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> No!&mdash;Pray let me speak, madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> First, can any one be called beautiful that
squints?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Her eyes languish a little, I own.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Languish! ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Languish!&mdash;Then, for her conduct, she was
seen at the "Country Wife" after the first day. There's
for you, my lord.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> But, madam, she was not seen to use her
fan all the play long, turn aside her head, or by a
conscious blush discover more guilt than modesty.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Very fine! Then you think a woman modest
that sees the hideous "Country Wife" without blushing
or publishing her detestation of it? D'ye hear him,
cousin?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_408" id="Page_408">[Pg 408]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Yes, and am, I must confess, something of his
opinion; and think, that as an over-conscious fool at a
play, by endeavouring to show the author's want of wit,
exposes his own to more censure, so may a lady call her
own modesty in question, by publicly cavilling with the
poet's. For all those grimaces of honour and artificial
modesty disparage a woman's real virtue, as much as the
use of white and red does the natural complexion: and
you must use very, very little, if you would have it thought
your own.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Then you would have a woman of honour with
passive looks, ears, and tongue, undergo all the hideous
obscenity she hears at nasty plays.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Truly, I think a woman betrays her want of
modesty, by showing it publicly in a playhouse, as much
as a man does his want of courage by a quarrel there;
for the truly modest and stout say least, and are least
exceptious, especially in public.</p>
