<p><i>Oliv.</i> O hideous, cousin! this cannot be your opinion.
But you are one of those who have the confidence to
pardon the filthy play.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Why, what is there of ill in't, say you?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O fy! fy! fy! would you put me to the blush
anew? call all the blood into my face again? But to
satisfy you then; first, the clandestine obscenity in the
very name of Horner.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Truly, 'tis so hidden, I cannot find it out, I
confess.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O horrid! Does it not give you the rank conception
or image of a goat, or town-bull, or a satyr? nay,
what is yet a filthier image than all the rest, that of an
eunuch?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> What then? I can think of a goat, a bull, or a
satyr, without any hurt.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay: but cousin, one cannot stop there.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> I can, cousin.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O no; for when you have those filthy creatures<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_409" id="Page_409">[Pg 409]</a></span>
in your head once, the next thing you think, is what they
do; as their defiling of honest men's beds and couches,
rapes upon sleeping and waking country virgins under
hedges, and on haycocks. Nay, farther&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Nay, no farther, cousin. We have enough of
your comment on the play, which will make me more
ashamed than the play itself.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, believe me, 'tis a filthy play! and you may
take my word for a filthy play as soon as another's.
But the filthiest thing in that play, or any other play,
is&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Pray keep it to yourself, if it be so.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No, faith, you shall know it; I'm resolved to
make you out of love with the play. I say, the lewdest,
filthiest thing is his china; nay, I will never forgive the
beastly author his china. He has quite taken away the
reputation of poor china itself, and sullied the most
innocent and pretty furniture of a lady's chamber;
insomuch that I was fain to break all my defiled vessels.
You see I have none left; nor you, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You'll pardon me, I cannot think the worse of
my china for that of the playhouse.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Why, you will not keep any now, sure! 'Tis
now as unfit an ornament for a lady's chamber as the
pictures that come from Italy and other hot countries;
as appears by their nudities, which I always cover, or
scratch out, whereso'er I find 'em. But china! out
upon't, filthy china! nasty debauched china!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> All this will not put me out of conceit with
china, nor the play, which is acted to-day, or another of
the same beastly author's, as you call him, which I'll go
see.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> You will not, sure! nay, you sha' not venture
your reputation by going, and mine by leaving me alone
with two men here: nay, you'll disoblige me for ever, if&mdash;[<i>Pulls
her back.</i></p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> I stay!&mdash;your servant. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_410" id="Page_410">[Pg 410]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Well&mdash;but, my lord, though you justify everybody,
you cannot in earnest uphold so beastly a writer,
whose ink is so smutty as one may say.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Faith, I dare swear the poor man did not
think to disoblige the ladies, by any amorous, soft,
passionate, luscious saying in his play.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Fy, my lord! But what think you, Mr. Novel, of
the play? though I know you are a friend to all that are
new.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Faith, madam, I must confess, the new plays
would not be the worse for my advice, but I could never
get the silly rogues, the poets, to mind what I say; but
I'll tell you what counsel I gave the surly fool you
spake of.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What was't?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Faith, to put his play into rhyme; for rhyme,
you know, often makes mystical nonsense pass with the
critics for wit, and a double-meaning saying with the
ladies, for soft, tender, and moving passion. But now I
talk of passion, I saw your old lover this morning&mdash;Captain&mdash;[<i>Whispers.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly, Freeman</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span> <i>standing behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Whom?&mdash;nay, you need not whisper.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> We are luckily got hither unobserved!&mdash;How!
in a close conversation with these supple rascals, the outcasts
of sempstresses' shops!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Faith, pardon her, captain, that, since she could
no longer be entertained with your manly bluntness and
honest love, she takes up with the pert chat and commonplace
flattery of these fluttering parrots of the town, apes
and echoes of men only.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Do not you, sir, play the echo too, mock me,
dally with my own words, and show yourself as impertinent
as they are.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, captain&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, lieutenant, do not excuse her; methinks she<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_411" id="Page_411">[Pg 411]</a></span>
looks very kindly upon 'em both, and seems to be pleased
with what that fool there says to her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You lie, sir! and hold your peace, that I may
not be provoked to give you a worse reply.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Manly returned, d'ye say! and is he safe?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> My lord saw him too.&mdash;Hark you, my lord.
[<i>Whispers to</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> She yet seems concerned for my safety, and perhaps
they are admitted now here but for their news of
me: for intelligence indeed is the common passport of
nauseous fools, when they go their round of good tables
and houses. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I heard of his fighting only, without particulars,
and confess I always loved his brutal courage, because
it made me hope it might rid me of his more brutal
love.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What's that? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But is he at last returned, d'ye say, unhurt?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ay, faith, without doing his business; for the
rogue has been these two years pretending to a wooden
leg, which he would take from fortune as kindly as the
staff of a marshal of France, and rather read his name in
a gazette&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Than in the entail of a good estate.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> So! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> I have an ambition, I must confess, of losing my
heart before such a fair enemy us yourself, madam; but
that silly rogues should be ambitious of losing their arms,
and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Looking like a pair of compasses.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> But he has no use of his arms but to set 'em on
kimbow, for he never pulls off his hat, at least not to me,
I'm sure; for you must know, madam, he has a fanatical
hatred to good company: he can't abide me.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> O, be not so severe to him, as to say he hates
good company: for I assure you he has a great respect,
esteem and kindness for me.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_412" id="Page_412">[Pg 412]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> That kind, civil rogue has spoken yet ten thousand
times worse of me than t'other. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Well, if he be returned, Mr. Novel, then shall I
be pestered again with his boisterous sea-love; have my
alcove smell like a cabin, my chamber perfumed with his
tarpaulin Brandenburgh; and hear volleys of brandy-sighs,
enough to make a fog in one's room. Foh! I hate
a lover that smells like Thames Street!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I can bear no longer, and need hear no
more.&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.] But since you have these two
pulvillio<a name="FNanchor_102_102" id="FNanchor_102_102"></a><a href="#Footnote_102_102" class="fnanchor">[102]</a> boxes, these essence-bottles, this pair of
musk-cats here, I hope I may venture to come yet nearer
you.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Overheard us then!</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> I hope he heard me not. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Most noble and heroic captain, your most
obliged, faithful, humble servant.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Dear tar, thy humble servant.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Away!&mdash;[<i>Thrusts</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span> <i>and</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span>
<i>on each side.</i>] Madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, I think I have fitted<a name="FNanchor_103_103" id="FNanchor_103_103"></a><a href="#Footnote_103_103" class="fnanchor">[103]</a> you for listening.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You have fitted me for believing you could not
be fickle, though you were young; could not dissemble
love, though 'twas your interest; nor be vain, though you
were handsome; nor break your promise, though to a
parting lover; nor abuse your best friend, though you had
wit: but I take not your contempt of me worse than your
esteem, or civility for these things here, though you know
'em.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Things!</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Let the captain rally a little.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, things! Canst thou be angry, thou thing?
[<i>Coming up to</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> No, since my lord says you speak in raillery; for
though your sea-raillery be something rough, yet, I confess,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_413" id="Page_413">[Pg 413]</a></span>
we use one another too as bad every day at Locket's,<a name="FNanchor_104_104" id="FNanchor_104_104"></a><a href="#Footnote_104_104" class="fnanchor">[104]</a>
and never quarrel for the matter.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, noble captain, be not angry with him.&mdash;A
word with you, I beseech you&mdash;[<i>Whispers
to</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Well, we women, like the rest of the cheats of
the world, when our cullies or creditors have found us out,
and will or can trust no longer, pay debts and satisfy
obligations with a quarrel, the kindest present a man can
make to his mistress, when he can make no more
presents. For oftentimes in love, as at cards, we are
forced to play foul, only to give over the game; and
use our lovers like the cards, when we can get no more
by them, throw 'em up in a pet upon the first dispute.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> My lord, all that you have made me know by
your whispering, which I knew not before, is, that you
have a stinking breath; there's a secret for your secret.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Pshaw! pshaw!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But, madam, tell me, pray, what was't about this
spark could take you? Was it the merit of his fashionable
impudence; the briskness of his noise, the wit of his
laugh, his judgment, or fancy in his garniture? or was it
a well-trimmed glove, or the scent of it, that charmed
you?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Very well, sir: 'gad these sea captains make
nothing of dressing. But let me tell you, sir, a man by
his dress, as much as by anything, shows his wit and
judgment; nay, and his courage too.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> How, his courage, Mr. Novel?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Why, for example, by red breeches, tucked-up
hair or peruke, a greasy broad belt, and now-a-days a
short sword.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thy courage will appear more by thy belt than
thy sword, I dare swear.&mdash;Then, madam, for this gentle
piece of courtesy, this man of tame honour, what could<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_414" id="Page_414">[Pg 414]</a></span>
you find in him? Was it his languishing affected tone?
his mannerly look? his second-hand flattery? the refuse
of the playhouse tiring-rooms? or his slavish obsequiousness
in watching at the door of your box at the playhouse,
for your hand to your chair? or his jaunty way of playing
with your fan? or was it the gunpowder spot on his
hand, or the jewel in his ear, that purchased your heart?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Good jealous captain, no more of your&mdash;</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> No, let him go on, madam, for perhaps he
may make you laugh: and I would contribute to your
pleasure any way.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Gentle rogue!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No, noble captain, you cannot sure think anything
could take me more than that heroic title of yours,
captain; for you know we women love honour inordinately.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ha! ha! faith, she is with thee, bully, for thy
raillery.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Faith, so shall I be with you, no bully, for your
grinning. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Then that noble lion-like mien of yours, that
soldier-like, weather-beaten complexion, and that manly
roughness of your voice; how can they otherwise than
charm us women, who hate effeminacy!</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ha! ha! faith I can't hold from laughing.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nor shall I from kicking anon. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And then, that captain-like carelessness in your
dress, but especially your scarf; 'twas just such another,
only a little higher tied, made me in love with my tailor
as he passed by my window the last training-day; for we
women adore a martial man, and you have nothing wanting
to make you more one, or more agreeable, but a
wooden leg.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, i'faith, there your ladyship was a wag,
and it was fine, just, and well rallied.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ay, ay, madam, with you ladies too, martial men
must needs be very killing.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_415" id="Page_415">[Pg 415]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Peace, you Bartholomew-fair buffoons! And be
not you vain that these laugh on your side, for they will
laugh at their own dull jests; but no more of 'em, for I
will only suffer now this lady to be witty and merry.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> You would not have your panegyric interrupted.
I go on then to your humour. Is there anything more
agreeable than the pretty sullenness of that? than the
greatness of your courage, which most of all appears in
your spirit of contradiction? for you dare give all mankind
the lie; and your opinion is your only mistress,
for you renounce that too, when it becomes another
man's.<a name="FNanchor_105_105" id="FNanchor_105_105"></a><a href="#Footnote_105_105" class="fnanchor">[105]</a></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ha! ha! I cannot hold, I must laugh at thee,
tar, faith!</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> And i'faith, dear captain, I beg your pardon,
and leave to laugh at you too, though I protest I mean
you no hurt; but when a lady rallies, a stander-by must
be complaisant, and do her reason in laughing: ha! ha!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, you impudent, pitiful wretches, you presume
sure upon your effeminacy to urge me; for you are
in all things so like women, that you may think it in me
a kind of cowardice to beat you.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No hectoring, good captain.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Or, perhaps, you think this lady's presence
secures you; but have a care, she has talked herself out
of all the respect I had for her; and by using me ill
before you, has given me a privilege of using you so
before her; but if you would preserve your respect to
her, and not be beaten before her, go, begone
immediately.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Begone! what?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, worthy, noble, generous, captain&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Begone, I say!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_416" id="Page_416">[Pg 416]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Begone again! to us begone!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No chattering, baboons, instantly begone, or&mdash;[<i>Puts
them out of the room:</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span> <i>struts,</i>
Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span> <i>cringes.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well, madam, we'll go make the cards ready in
your bedchamber: sure you will not stay long with him.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Novel.</span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Turn hither your rage, good captain Swaggerhuff,
and be saucy with your mistress, like a true captain;
but be civil to your rivals and betters, and do not
threaten anything but me here; no, not so much as my
windows; nor do not think yourself in the lodgings of
one of your suburb mistresses beyond the Tower.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Do not give me cause to think so; for those less
infamous women part with their lovers, just as you did
from me, with unforced vows of constancy and floods of
willing tears; but the same winds bear away their lovers
and their vows: and for their grief, if the credulous
unexpected fools return, they find new comforters, fresh
cullies, such as I found here. The mercenary love of
those women too suffers shipwreck with their gallants'
fortunes; now you have heard chance has used me
scurvily, therefore you do too. Well, persevere in your
ingratitude, falsehood, and disdain; have constancy in
something, and I promise you to be as just to your real
scorn as I was to your feigned love; and henceforward
will despise, contemn, hate, loathe, and detest you most
faithfully.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Get the ombre-cards ready in the next room,
Lettice, and&mdash;[<i>Whispers to</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>, <i>who goes out.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Bravely resolved, captain!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> And you'll be sure to keep your word, I hope, sir?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I hope so too.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Do you but hope it, sir? If you are not as good
as your word, 'twill be the first time you ever bragged,
sure.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_417" id="Page_417">[Pg 417]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> She has restored my reason with my heart.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But now you talk of restoring, captain, there are
other things, which next to one's heart one would not
part with; I mean your jewels and money, which it
seems she has, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What's that to you, sir?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Pardon me, whatsoever is yours I have a share
in't I'm sure, which I will not lose for asking, though you
may be too generous or too angry now to do't yourself.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, then I'll make bold to make my claim too.
[<i>Both going towards</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hold, you impertinent, officious fops&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
How have I been deceived!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Madam, there are certain appurtenances to a
lover's heart, called jewels, which always go along
with it.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> And which, with lovers, have no value in themselves,
but from the heart they come with. Our captain's,
madam, it seems you scorn to keep, and much more will
those worthless things without it, I am confident.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> A gentleman so well made as you are, may be
confident&mdash;us easy women could not deny you anything
you ask, if 'twere for yourself, but, since 'tis for another,
I beg your leave to give him my answer.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] An
agreeable young fellow this&mdash;and would not be my aversion.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Captain, your young friend here has a
very persuading face, I confess; yet you might have
asked me yourself for those trifles you left with me, which
(hark you a little, for I dare trust you with the secret;
you are a man of so much honour, I'm sure) I say then,
not expecting your return, or hoping ever to see you
again, I have delivered your jewels to&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Whom?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> My husband.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Your husband!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay, my husband. For since you could leave me,
I am lately and privately married to one, who is a man of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_418" id="Page_418">[Pg 418]</a></span>
so much honour and experience in the world, that I dare
not ask him for your jewels again to restore 'em to you;
lest he should conclude you never would have parted
with 'em to me on any other score but the exchange of
my honour: which rather than you'd let me lose, you'd
lose I'm sure yourself, those trifles of yours.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Triumphant impudence! but married too!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, speak not so loud, my servants know it not:
I am married, there's no resisting one's destiny or love,
you know.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, did you love him too?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Most passionately; nay, love him now, though I
have married him, and he me: which mutual love I hope
you are too good, too generous a man to disturb, by any
future claim, or visits to me. 'Tis true, he is now absent
in the country, but returns shortly; therefore I beg of you,
for your own ease and quiet, and my honour, you will
never see me more.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I wish I never had seen you.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But if you should ever have anything to say to
me hereafter, let that young gentleman there be your
messenger.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You would be kinder to him; I find he should
be welcome.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Alas! his youth would keep my husband from
suspicions, and his visits from scandal; for we women
may have pity for such as he, but no love: and I already
think you do not well to spirit him away to sea; and the
sea is already but too rich with the spoils of the shore.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> True perfect woman! If I could say anything
more injurious to her now, I would; for I could
outrail a bilked whore, or a kicked coward; but now
I think on't, that were rather to discover my love than
hatred; and I must not talk, for something I must do.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I think I have given him enough of me now, never
to be troubled with him again. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_419" id="Page_419">[Pg 419]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>.</p>

<p>Well, Lettice, are the cards and all ready within? I come
then.&mdash;Captain, I beg your pardon: you will not make
one at ombre?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, madam, but I'll wish you a little good luck
before you go.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No, if you would have me thrive, curse me: for
that you'll do heartily, I suppose.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Then if you will have it so, may all the curses
light upon you, women ought to fear, and you deserve!&mdash;First,
may the curse of loving play attend your sordid
covetousness, and fortune cheat you, by trusting to her,
as you have cheated me; the curse of pride, or a good
reputation, fall on your lust; the curse of affectation on
your beauty; the curse of your husband's company on
your pleasures; and the curse of your gallant's disappointments
in his absence; and the curse of scorn,
jealousy, or despair on your love; and then the curse of
loving on!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And to requite all your curses, I will only return
you your last; may the curse of loving me still fall upon
your proud hard heart, that could be so cruel to me in
these horrid curses! but heaven forgive you! [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hell and the devil reward thee!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, you see now, mistresses, like friends, are
lost by letting 'em handle your money; and most
women are such kind of witches, who can have no
power over a man, unless you give 'em money: but
when once they have got any from you, they never leave
you till they have all. Therefore I never give a woman
a farthing.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, there is yet this comfort by losing one's
money with one's mistress, a man is out of danger of
getting another; of being made prize again by love, who,
like a pirate, takes you by spreading false colours: but
when once you have run your ship a-ground, the<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_420" id="Page_420">[Pg 420]</a></span>
treacherous picaroon<a name="FNanchor_106_106" id="FNanchor_106_106"></a><a href="#Footnote_106_106" class="fnanchor">[106]</a> loofs; so by your ruin you save
yourself from slavery at least.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Mrs. Lettice, here's Madam Blackacre come to
wait upon her honour. [<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span> <i>and</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> D'ye hear that? Let us be gone before she
comes: for henceforth I'll avoid the whole damned sex
for ever, and woman as a sinking ship.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And I'll stay, to revenge on her your quarrel to
the sex: for out of love to her jointure, and hatred to
business, I would marry her, to make an end of her
thousand suits, and my thousand engagements, to the
comfort of two unfortunate sort of people, my plaintiffs
and her defendants, my creditors and her adversaries.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>, <i>led in by</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>, <i>and</i>
<span class="smcap">Jerry Blackacre</span> <i>following, laden with green bags.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> 'Tis an arrant sea-ruffian; but I am glad I met
with him at last, to serve him again, major; for the
last service was not good in law. Boy, duck, Jerry,
where is my paper of memorandums? Give me, child:
so. Where is my cousin Olivia now, my kind relation?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Here is one that would be your kind relation,
madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> What mean you, sir?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, faith, (to be short) to marry you, widow.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Is not this the wild rude person we saw at
Captain Manly's?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, forsooth, an't please.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> What would you? what are you? Marry me!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, faith; for I am a younger brother, and you
are a widow.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> You are an impertinent person; and go about
your business.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_421" id="Page_421">[Pg 421]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I have none, but to marry thee, widow.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> But I have other business, I'd have you to know.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But you have no business a-nights, widow; and
I'll make you pleasanter business than any you have.
For a-nights, I assure you, I am a man of great business;
for the business&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Go, I'm sure you're an idle fellow.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Try me but, widow, and employ me as you find
my abilities and industry.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Pray be civil to the lady, Mr.&mdash;&mdash;she is a person
of quality, a person that is no person&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Yes, but she's a person that is a widow. Be you
mannerly to her, because you are to pretend only to be
her squire, to arm her to her lawyer's chambers; but I
will be impudent and bawdy; for she must love and
marry me.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Marry come up, you saucy familiar Jack! You
think, with us widows, 'tis no more than up, and ride.
Gad forgive me! now-a-days, every idle, young, hectoring,
roaring companion, with a pair of turned red breeches,
and a broad back, thinks to carry away any widow of the
best degree. But I'd have you to know, sir, all widows
are not got, like places at court, by impudence and importunity
only.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> No, no, soft, soft, you are a young man, and not
fit&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> For a widow? yes sure, old man, the fitter.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Go to, go to; if others had not laid in their
claims before you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Not you, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Why not I, sir? sure I am a much more proportionable
match for her than you, sir; I, who am an elder
brother, of a comfortable fortune, and of equal years with
her.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How's that, you unmannerly person? I'd have
you to know, I was born but in <i>Ann' undec' Caroli
prim'</i>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_422" id="Page_422">[Pg 422]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Your pardon, lady, your pardon: be not offended
with your very humble servant&mdash;But, I say, sir, you are
a beggarly younger brother, twenty years younger than
her, without any land or stock, but your great stock of
impudence: therefore what pretension can you have to
her?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> You have made it for me: first, because I am a
younger brother.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Why, is that a sufficient plea to a relict? how
appears it, sir? by what foolish custom?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> By custom time out of mind only. Then, sir,
because I have nothing to keep me after her death, I am
the likelier to take care of her life. And for my being
twenty years younger than her, and having a sufficient
stock of impudence, I leave it to her whether they will be
valid exceptions to me in her widow's law or equity.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Well, she has been so long in chancery, that I'll
stand to her equity and decree between us. Come, lady,
pray snap up this young snap<a name="FNanchor_107_107" id="FNanchor_107_107"></a><a href="#Footnote_107_107" class="fnanchor">[107]</a> at first, or we shall be
troubled with him. Give him a city-widow's answer, that
is, with all the ill-breeding imaginable.&mdash;[<i>Aside to</i> Widow
<span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>.] Come, madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Well then, to make an end of this foolish wooing,
for nothing interrupts business more: first for you,
major&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> You declare in my favour, then?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> What, direct the court! come, young lawyer,
thou shalt be a counsel for me. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span>.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Gad, I shall betray your cause then, as well as an
older lawyer; never stir.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> First, I say, for you, major, my walking hospital
of an ancient foundation; thou bag of mummy, that
wouldst fall asunder, if 'twere not for thy cerecloths&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> How, lady!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ha! ha!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Hey, brave mother! use all suitors thus, for my
sake.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_423" id="Page_423">[Pg 423]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Thou withered, hobbling, distorted cripple; nay,
thou art a cripple all over: wouldst thou make me the
staff of thy age, the crutch of thy decrepidness? me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well said, widow! Faith, thou wouldst make a
man love thee now, without dissembling.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Thou senseless, impertinent, quibbling, drivelling,
feeble, paralytic, impotent, fumbling, frigid nincompoop!</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Hey, brave mother, for calling of names, i'fac!</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Wouldst thou make a caudle-maker, a nurse of
me? can't you be bedrid without a bed-fellow? won't
your swan-skins, furs, flannels, and the scorched trencher,
keep you warm there? would you have me your Scotch
warming-pan,<a name="FNanchor_108_108" id="FNanchor_108_108"></a><a href="#Footnote_108_108" class="fnanchor">[108]</a> with a pox to you! me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> O Heavens!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I told you I should be thought the fitter man,
major.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, you old fobus, and you would have been my
guardian, would you, to have taken care of my estate,
that half of't should never come to me, by letting long
leases at pepper-corn rents?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> If I would have married an old man, 'tis well
known I might have married an earl, nay, what's more, a
judge, and been covered the winter nights with the lambskins,
which I prefer to the ermines of nobles. And
dost thou think I would wrong my poor minor there for
you?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Your minor is a chopping minor, God bless him!
[<i>Strokes</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span> <i>on the head.</i></p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Your minor may be a major of horse or foot, for
his bigness; and it seems you will have the cheating of
your minor to yourself.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Pray, sir, bear witness:&mdash;cheat my minor! I'll
bring my action of the case for the slander.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, I would bear false witness for thee now,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_424" id="Page_424">[Pg 424]</a></span>
widow, since you have done me justice, and have thought
me the fitter man for you.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Fair and softly, sir, 'tis my minor's case, more
than my own; and I must do him justice now on you.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> How!</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> So then.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> You are, first, (I warrant,) some renegado from
the inns of court and the law; and thou'lt come to suffer
for't by the law, that is, be hanged.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Not about your neck, forsooth, I hope.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But, madam&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Hear the court.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Thou art some debauched, drunken, lewd,
hectoring, gaming companion, and wantest some widow's
old gold to nick<a name="FNanchor_109_109" id="FNanchor_109_109"></a><a href="#Footnote_109_109" class="fnanchor">[109]</a> upon; but I thank you, sir, that's for
my lawyers.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Faith, we should ne'er quarrel about that; for
guineas would serve my turn.<a name="FNanchor_110_110" id="FNanchor_110_110"></a><a href="#Footnote_110_110" class="fnanchor">[110]</a> But, widow&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Thou art a foul-mouthed boaster of thy lust, a
mere bragadochio of thy strength for wine and women,
and wilt belie thyself more than thou dost women, and
art every way a base deceiver of women; and would
deceive me too, would you?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, faith, widow, this is judging without seeing
the evidence.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I say, you are a worn-out whoremaster at five-and-twenty,
both in body and fortune, and cannot be
trusted by the common wenches of the town, lest you
should not pay 'em; nor by the wives of the town lest
you should pay 'em: so you want women, and would
have me your bawd to procure 'em for you.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Faith, if you had any good acquaintance, widow,
'twould be civilly done of thee; for I am just come from
sea.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_425" id="Page_425">[Pg 425]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I mean, you would have me keep you, that you
might turn keeper; for poor widows are only used like
bawds by you; you go to church with us, but to get other
women to lie with. In fine, you are a cheating, cozening
spendthrift; and having sold your own annuity, would
waste my jointure.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> And make havoc of our estate personal, and all
our gilt plate; I should soon be piling up all our
mortgaged apostle-spoons, bowls, and beakers, out of
most of the ale-houses betwixt Hercules-pillars<a name="FNanchor_111_111" id="FNanchor_111_111"></a><a href="#Footnote_111_111" class="fnanchor">[111]</a> and the
Boatswain in Wapping; nay, and you'd be scouring
amongst my trees, and make 'em knock down one
another, like routed reeling watchmen at midnight;
would you so, bully?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, prithee, widow, hear me.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, sir; I'd have you to know, thou pitiful,
paltry, lath-backed fellow, if I would have married a
young man, 'tis well known I could have had any young
heir in Norfolk, nay, the hopefullest young man this day
at the King's-bench bar; I that am a relict and executrix
of known plentiful assets and parts, who understand
myself and the law. And would you have me under
covert-baron<a name="FNanchor_112_112" id="FNanchor_112_112"></a><a href="#Footnote_112_112" class="fnanchor">[112]</a> again? No, sir, no covert-baron for me.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But, dear widow, hear me. I value you only,
not your jointure.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, sir, hold there; I know your love to a
widow is covetousness of her jointure: and a widow, a
little stricken in years, with a good jointure, is like an old
mansion-house in a good purchase, never valued, but
take one, take t'other: and perhaps, when you are in
possession, you'd neglect it, let it drop to the ground, for
want of necessary repairs or expenses upon't.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No, widow, one would be sure to keep all tight,
when one is to forfeit one's lease by dilapidation.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_426" id="Page_426">[Pg 426]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Fy! fy! I neglect my business with this foolish
discourse of love. Jerry, child, let me see the list of the
jury: I'm sure my cousin Olivia has some relations
amongst them. But where is she?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, widow, but hear me one word only.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, sir, no more, pray. I will no more hearken
to your foolish love-motions, than to offers of arbitration.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, I'll follow thee yet; for he that has a
pretension at court, or to a widow, must never give over
for a little ill-usage.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Therefore, I'll get her by assiduity, patience, and
long sufferings, which you will not undergo; for you
idle young fellows leave off love when it comes to be
business; and industry gets more women than love.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, industry, the fool's and old man's merit.&mdash;But
I'll be industrious too, and make a business on't, and
get her by law, wrangling, and contests, and not by
sufferings: and, because you are no dangerous rival, I'll
give thee counsel, major:&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">If you litigious widow e'er would gain,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Sigh not to her, but by the law complain;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To her, as to a bawd, defendant sue</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">With statutes, and make justice pimp for you.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_427" id="Page_427">[Pg 427]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE THIRD.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<i>Westminster Hall.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>, <i>two</i> Sailors <i>behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I hate this place worse than a man
that has inherited a chancery suit: I
wish I were well out on't again.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, you need not be afraid
of this place: for a man without
money needs no more fear a crowd
of lawyers than a crowd of pickpockets.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> This, the reverend of the law would have
thought the palace or residence of Justice; but, if it be,
she lives here with the state of a Turkish emperor, rarely
seen; and besieged rather than defended by her numerous
black-guard here.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Methinks 'tis like one of their own halls in
Christmas time, whither from all parts fools bring their
money, to try by the dice (not the worst judges) whether
it shall be their own or no: but after a tedious fretting
and wrangling, they drop away all their money on both
sides; and, finding neither the better, at last go emptily
and lovingly away together to the tavern, joining their
curses against the young lawyer's box, that sweeps all,
like the old ones.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Spoken like a revelling Christmas lawyer.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Yes, I was one, I confess, but was fain to leave<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_428" id="Page_428">[Pg 428]</a></span>
the law, out of conscience, and fall to making false
musters: rather choose to cheat the king than his subjects;
plunder rather than take fees.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, a plague and a purse-famine light on the
law; and that female limb of it who dragged me hither
to-day! But prithee go see if, in that crowd of daggled
gowns there, [<i>Pointing to a crowd of</i> Lawyers <i>at the end of
the stage</i>,] thou canst find her. [<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">How hard it is to be a hypocrite!</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">At least to me, who am but newly so.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">I thought it once a kind of knavery,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, cowardice, to hide one's fault; but now</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The common frailty, love, becomes my shame.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He must not know I love the ungrateful still,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Lest he contemn me more than she; for I,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">It seems, can undergo a woman's scorn,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But not a man's&mdash;</span><br />
</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Sir, good sir, generous captain.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Prithee, kind impertinence, leave me. Why
should'st thou follow me, flatter my generosity now, since
thou knowest I have no money left? if I had it, I'd give
it thee, to buy my quiet.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I never followed yet, sir, reward or fame, but you
alone; nor do I now beg anything but leave to share
your miseries. You should not be a niggard of 'em,
since, methinks, you have enough to spare. Let me
follow you now, because you hate me, as you have often
said.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I ever hated a coward's company, I must
confess.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Let me follow you till I am none, then; for you,
I'm sure, will go through such worlds of dangers, that,
I shall be inured to 'em; nay, I shall be afraid of your
anger more than danger, and so turn valiant out of fear.
Dear captain, do not cast me off till you have tried<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_429" id="Page_429">[Pg 429]</a></span>
me once more: do not, do not go to sea again without
me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou to sea! to court, thou fool; remember
the advice I gave thee: thou art a handsome spaniel, and
canst fawn naturally: go, busk about and run thyself into
the next great man's lobby; first fawn upon the slaves
without, and then run into the lady's bedchamber; thou
mayst be admitted at last to tumble her bed. Go seek,
I say, and lose me; for I am not able to keep thee; I
have not bread for myself.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Therefore I will not go, because then I may help
and serve you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I warrant you, sir; for, at worst, I could beg or
steal for you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, more bragging! Dost thou not know
there's venturing your life in stealing? Go, prithee,
away: thou art as hard to shake off as that flattering,
effeminating mischief, love.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Love did you name? Why, you are not so
miserable as to be yet in love, sure?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, no, prithee away, begone, or&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I
had almost discovered my love and shame; well, if I
had, that thing could not think the worse of me&mdash;or if
he did&mdash;no&mdash;yes, he shall know it&mdash;he shall&mdash;but then I
must never leave him, for they are such secrets, that
make parasites and pimps lords of their masters: for any
slavery or tyranny is easier than love's.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come
hither, since thou art so forward to serve me: hast thou
but resolution enough to endure the torture of a secret?
for such to some is insupportable.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I would keep it as safe as if your dear, precious
life depended on't.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn your dearness! It concerns more than
my life,&mdash;my honour.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Doubt it not, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And do not discover it, by too much fear of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_430" id="Page_430">[Pg 430]</a></span>
discovering it; but have a great care you let not Freeman
find it out.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I warrant you, sir, I am already all joy with the
hopes of your commands; and shall be all wings in the
execution of 'em: speak quickly, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You said you'd beg for me.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I did, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Then you shall beg for me.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> With all my heart, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> That is, pimp for me.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> How, sir?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> D'ye start! Thinkest thou, thou couldst do me
any other service? Come, no dissembling honour: I
know you can do it handsomely, thou wert made for't.
You have lost your time with me at sea, you must recover
it.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Do not, sir, beget yourself more reasons for your
aversion to me, and make my obedience to you a fault;
I am the unfittest in the world to do you such a service.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Your cunning arguing against it shows but how
fit you are for it. No more dissembling; here, I say,
you must go use it for me to Olivia.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> To her, sir?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Go flatter, lie, kneel, promise, anything to get
her for me: I cannot live unless I have her. Didst thou
not say thou wouldst do anything to save my life? and
she said you had a persuading face.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But did you not say, sir, your honour was dearer
to you than your life? and would you have me contribute
to the loss of that, and carry love from you to the
most infamous, most false, and&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And most beautiful!&mdash;[<i>Sighs aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Most ungrateful woman that ever lived; for sure
she must be so, that could desert you so soon, use you
so basely, and so lately too: do not, do not forget it,
sir, and think&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, I will not forget it, but think of revenge;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_431" id="Page_431">[Pg 431]</a></span>
I will lie with her out of revenge. Go, begone, and prevail
for me, or never see me more.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> You scorned her last night.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I know not what I did last night; I dissembled
last night.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Heavens!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Begone, I say, and bring me love or compliance
back, or hopes at least, or I'll never see thy face again,
by&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> O, do not swear, sir! first hear me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I'm impatient, away! you'll find me here till
twelve. [<i>Turns away.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Sir&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Not one word; no insinuating argument more,
or soothing persuasion; you'll have need of all your
rhetoric with her; go strive to alter her, not me; begone.
[<i>Retires to the end of the stage, and exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Should I discover to him now my sex,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And lay before him his strange cruelty,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Twould but incense it more.&mdash;No, 'tis not time.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For his love must I then betray my own?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Were ever love or chance till now severe?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Or shifting woman posed with such a task?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Forced to beg that which kills her, if obtained,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And give away her lover not to lose him! [<i>Exit.</i></span><br />
</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>, <i>in the middle of half-a-dozen</i>
Lawyers, <i>whispered to by a fellow in black</i>, <span class="smcap">Jerry
Blackacre</span> <i>following the crowd.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Offer me a reference, you saucy companion you!
d'ye know who you speak to? Art thou a solicitor in
chancery, and offer a reference? A pretty fellow! Mr.
Serjeant Ploddon, here's a fellow has the impudence to
offer me a reference!</p>

<p><i>Serj. Plod.</i> Who's that has the impudence to offer a
reference within these walls?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, for a splitter of causes to do't!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_432" id="Page_432">[Pg 432]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Serj. Plod.</i> No, madam; to a lady learned in the law,
as you are, the offer of a reference were to impose upon
you.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, no, never fear me for a reference, Mr.
Serjeant. But come, have you not forgot your brief?
Are you sure you shan't make the mistake of&mdash;hark you&mdash;[<i>Whispers.</i>]
Go then, go to your court of Common-pleas,
and say one thing over and over again: you do it
so naturally, you'll never be suspected for protracting
time.</p>

<p><i>Serj. Plod.</i> Come, I know the course of the court, and
your business. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Let's see, Jerry, where are my minutes? Come,
Mr. Quaint, pray go talk a great deal for me in chancery,
let your words be easy, and your sense hard; my cause
requires it: branch it bravely, and deck my cause with
flowers, that the snake may lie hidden. Go, go, and be
sure you remember the decree of my Lord Chancellor,
<i>Tricesimo quart'</i> of the queen.</p>

<p><i>Quaint.</i> I will, as I see cause, extenuate or examplify
matter of fact; baffle truth with impudence; answer
exceptions with questions, though never so impertinent;
for reasons give 'em words; for law and equity, tropes
and figures; and so relax and enervate the sinews of
their argument with the oil of my eloquence. But when
my lungs can reason no longer, and not being able to
say anything more for our cause, say everything of our
adversary; whose reputation, though never so clear and
evident in the eye of the world, yet with sharp invectives&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Alias, Billingsgate.</p>

<p><i>Quaint.</i> With poignant and sour invectives, I say, I
will deface, wipe out, and obliterate his fair reputation,
even as a record with the juice of lemons; and tell such a
story, (for the truth on't is, all that we can do for our
client in chancery, is telling a story,) a fine story, a long
story, such a story&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_433" id="Page_433">[Pg 433]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Go, save thy breath for the cause; talk at the
bar, Mr. Quaint: you are so copiously fluent, you can
weary any one's ears sooner than your own tongue. Go,
weary our adversaries' counsel, and the court; go, thou
art a fine-spoken person: adad, I shall make thy wife
jealous of me, if you can but court the court into a
decree for us. Go, get you gone, and
remember&mdash;[Whispers.]&mdash;[Exit <span class="smcap">Quaint</span>.]&mdash;Come, Mr. Blunder, pray
bawl soundly for me, at the King's-bench, bluster, sputter,
question, cavil; but be sure your argument be intricate
enough to confound the court; and then you do my
business. Talk what you will, but be sure your tongue
never stand still; for your own noise will secure your
sense from censure: 'tis like coughing or hemming when
one has got the belly-ache, which stifles the unmannerly
noise. Go, dear rogue, and succeed; and I'll invite thee,
ere it be long, to more soused venison.</p>

<p><i>Blund.</i> I'll warrant you, after your verdict, your judgment
shall not be arrested upon if's and and's. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Come, Mr. Petulant, let me give you some new
instructions for our cause in the Exchequer. Are the
barons sat?</p>

<p><i>Pet.</i> Yes, no; may be they are, may be they are not:
what know I? what care I?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Heyday! I wish you would but snap up the
counsel on t'other side anon at the bar as much; and
have a little more patience with me, that I might instruct
you a little better.</p>

<p><i>Pet.</i> You instruct me! what is my brief for, mistress?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Ay, but you seldom read your brief but at the
bar, if you do it then.</p>

<p><i>Pet.</i> Perhaps I do, perhaps I don't, and perhaps 'tis
time enough: pray hold yourself contented, mistress.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, if you go there too, I will not be contented,
sir; though you, I see, will lose my cause for want of
speaking, I wo' not: you shall hear me, and shall be instructed.
Let's see your brief.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_434" id="Page_434">[Pg 434]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Pet.</i> Send your solicitor to me. Instructed by a woman!
I'd have you to know, I do not wear a bar-gown&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> By a woman! and I'd have you to know, I am no
common woman; but a woman conversant in the laws of
the land, as well as yourself, though I have no bar-gown.</p>

<p><i>Pet.</i> Go to, go to, mistress, you are impertinent, and
there's your brief for you: instruct me!
[<i>Flings her breviate at her.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Impertinent to me, you saucy Jack, you! you
return my breviate, but where's my fee? you'll be sure to
keep that, and scan that so well, that if there chance to be
but a brass half-crown in't, one's sure to hear on't again:
would you would but look on your breviate half so narrowly!
But pray give me my fee too, as well as my brief.</p>

<p><i>Pet.</i> Mistress, that's without precedent. When did a
counsel ever return his fee, pray? and you are impertinent
and ignorant to demand it.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Impertinent again, and ignorant, to me! Gads-bodikins,
you puny upstart in the law, to use me so! you
green-bag carrier, you murderer of unfortunate causes, the
clerk's ink is scarce off of your fingers,&mdash;you that newly
come from lamp-blacking the judges' shoes, and are not
fit to wipe mine; you call me impertinent and ignorant!
I would give thee a cuff on the ear, sitting the courts, if
I were ignorant. Marry-gep, if it had not been for me,
thou hadst been yet but a hearing counsel at the bar.
[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Petulant</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Mr. <span class="smcap">Buttongown</span>, <i>crossing the stage in haste.</i></p>

<p>Mr. Buttongown, Mr. Buttongown, whither so fast? what,
won't you stay till we are heard?</p>

<p><i>But.</i> I cannot, Mrs. Blackacre, I must be at the
council, my lord's cause stays there for me.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> And mine suffers here.</p>

<p><i>But.</i> I cannot help it.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I'm undone.</p>

<p><i>But.</i> What's that to me?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_435" id="Page_435">[Pg 435]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Consider the five-pound fee, if not my cause:
that was something to you.</p>

<p><i>But.</i> Away, away! pray be not so troublesome, mistress:
I must be gone.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, but consider a little: I am your old client,
my lord but a new one; or let him be what he will, he
will hardly be a better client to you than myself: I hope
you believe I shall be in law as long as I live; therefore
am no despicable client. Well, but go to your lord; I
know you expect he should make you a judge one day;
but I hope his promise to you will prove a true lord's
promise. But that he might be sure to fail you, I wish
you had his bond for't.</p>

<p><i>But.</i> But what, will you yet be thus impertinent,
mistress?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, I beseech you, sir, stay; if it be but to tell
me my lord's case; come, in short&mdash;</p>

<p><i>But.</i> Nay, then&mdash;[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Well, Jerry, observe child, and lay it up for
hereafter. These are those lawyers who, by being in all
causes, are in none: therefore if you would have 'em for
you, let your adversary fee 'em; for he may chance to
depend upon 'em; and so, in being against thee, they'll
be for thee.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, mother; they put me in mind of the unconscionable
wooers of widows, who undertake briskly their
matrimonial business for their money; but when they
have got it once, let who will drudge for them. Therefore
have a care of 'em, forsooth. There's advice for
your advice.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Well said, boy.&mdash;Come, Mr. Splitcause, pray go
see when my cause in Chancery comes on; and go speak
with Mr. Quillit in the King's-bench, and Mr. Quirk in
the Common-pleas, and see how matters go there.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Lady, a good and propitious morning to you;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_436" id="Page_436">[Pg 436]</a></span>
and may all your causes go as well as if I myself were
judge of 'em!</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Sir, excuse me; I am busy, and cannot answer
compliments in Westminster Hall.&mdash;Go, Mr. Splitcause,
and come to me again to that bookseller's; there I'll
stay for you, that you may be sure to find me.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> No, sir, come to the other bookseller's. I'll
attend your ladyship thither. [<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Splitcause</span>.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Why to the other?</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Because he is my bookseller, lady.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> What, to sell you lozenges for your catarrh? or
medicines for your corns? What else can a major deal
with a bookseller for?</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Lady, he prints for me.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Why, are you an author?</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Of some few essays; deign you, lady, to peruse
'em.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] She is a woman of parts; and I must win
her by showing mine.</p>

<p><i>Bookseller's Boy.</i> Will you see Culpepper, mistress?
"Aristotle's Problems?" "The Complete Midwife?"</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No; let's see Dalton, Hughs, Shepherd, Wingate.</p>

<p><i>B. Boy.</i> We have no law books.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No! you are a pretty bookseller then.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Come, have you e'er a one of my essays left?</p>

<p><i>B. Boy.</i> Yes, sir, we have enough, and shall always
have 'em.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> How so?</p>

<p><i>B. Boy.</i> Why, they are good, steady, lasting ware.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Nay, I hope they will live; let's see.&mdash;Be pleased,
madam, to peruse the poor endeavours of my pen: for I
have a pen, though I say it, that&mdash;[<i>Gives her a book.</i></p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Pray let me see "St. George for Christendom,"
or, "The Seven Champions of England."</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, no; give him "The Young Clerk's Guide."&mdash;What,
we shall have you read yourself into a humour
of rambling and fighting, and studying military discipline,
and wearing red breeches.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_437" id="Page_437">[Pg 437]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Nay, if you talk of military discipline, show him
my "Treatise of the Art Military."</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Hold; I would as willingly he should read a
play.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O, pray forsooth, mother, let me have a play.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, sirrah; there are young students of the law
enough spoiled already by plays. They would make you
in love with your laundress, or, what's worse, some queen
of the stage that was a laundress; and so turn keeper before
you are of age. [<i>Several cross the stage.</i>] But stay, Jerry,
is not that Mr. What d'ye-call-him, that goes there, he
that offered to sell me a suit in chancery for five hundred
pounds, for a hundred down, and only paying the clerk's
fees?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, forsooth, 'tis he.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Then stay here, and have a care of the bags,
whilst I follow him.&mdash;Have a care of the bags, I say.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> And do you have a care, forsooth, of the statute
against champarty,<a name="FNanchor_113_113" id="FNanchor_113_113"></a><a href="#Footnote_113_113" class="fnanchor">[113]</a> I say. [<i>Exit</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, there's a limb of my widow, which
was wont to be inseparable from her: she can't be far.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
How now, my pretty son-in-law that shall be,
where's my widow?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> My mother, but not your widow, will be forthcoming
presently.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Your servant, major. What, are you buying
furniture for a little sleeping closet, which you miscall a
study? For you do only by your books, as by your
wenches, bind 'em up neatly and make 'em fine, for other
people to use 'em. And your bookseller is properly your
upholsterer, for he furnishes your room, rather than your
head.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Well, well, good sea-lieutenant, study you your<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_438" id="Page_438">[Pg 438]</a></span>
compass; that's more than your head can deal with.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
I will go find out the widow, to keep her out of
his sight, or he'll board her, whilst I am treating a peace.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Nay, prithee, friend, now let me have but "The
Seven Champions." You shall trust me no longer than
till my mother's Mr. Splitcause comes; for I hope he'll
lend me wherewithal to pay for't.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Lend thee! here, I'll pay him. Do you want
money, squire? I'm sorry a man of your estate should
want money.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Nay, my mother will ne'er let me be at age: and
till then, she says&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> At age! why you are at age already to have
spent an estate, man. There are younger than you have
kept their women these three years, have had half a
dozen claps, and lost as many thousand pounds at play.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, they are happy sparks! Nay, I know some
of my schoolfellows, who, when we were at school, were
two years younger than me; but now, I know not how,
are grown men before me, and go where they will, and
look to themselves. But my curmudgeonly mother won't
allow me wherewithal to be a man of myself with.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, there 'tis; I knew your mother was in
fault. Ask but your schoolfellows what they did to be
men of themselves.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Why, I know they went to law with their mothers:
for they say, there's no good to be done upon a widow
mother, till one goes to law with her; but mine is as
plaguy a lawyer as any's of our inn. Then would she
marry too, and cut down my trees. Now, I should hate,
man, to have my father's wife kissed and slapped, and
t'other thing too, (you know what I mean,) by another
man: and our trees are the purest, tall, even, shady
twigs, by my fa&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Come, squire, let your mother and your trees
fall as she pleases, rather than wear this gown and carry<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_439" id="Page_439">[Pg 439]</a></span>
green bags all thy life, and be pointed at for a Tony.<a name="FNanchor_114_114" id="FNanchor_114_114"></a><a href="#Footnote_114_114" class="fnanchor">[114]</a>
But you shall be able to deal with her yet the common
way. Thou shalt make false love to some lawyer's
daughter, whose father, upon the hopes of thy marrying
her, shall lend thee money and law to preserve thy
estate and trees: and thy mother is so ugly nobody will
have her, if she cannot cut down thy trees.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Nay, if I had but anybody to stand by me, I am
as stomachful as another.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> That will I: I'll not see any hopeful young
gentleman abused.</p>

<p><i>B. Boy.</i> By any but yourself. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> The truth on't is, mine's as arrant a widow-mother
to her poor child as any's in England. She won't so
much as let one have sixpence in one's pocket to see a
motion,<a name="FNanchor_115_115" id="FNanchor_115_115"></a><a href="#Footnote_115_115" class="fnanchor">[115]</a> or the dancing of the ropes, or&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Come, you shan't want money; there's gold for
you.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O lord, sir, two guineas! D'ye lend me this? Is
there no trick in't? Well, sir, I'll give you my bond for
security.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No, no; thou hast given me thy face for
security: anybody would swear thou dost not look like a
cheat. You shall have what you will of me; and if your
mother will not be kinder to you, come to me, who will.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] By my fa&mdash;he's a curious fine
gentleman!&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] But will you stand by one?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> If you can be resolute.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Can be resolved! Gad, if she gives me but a
cross word, I'll leave her to-night, and come to you. But
now I have got money, I'll go to Jack-of-all-Trades, at
t'other end of the Hall, and buy the neatest purest
things&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] And I'll follow the great boy, and my
blow at his mother. Steal away the calf, and the cow
will follow you. [<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span>, <i>followed by</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_440" id="Page_440">[Pg 440]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter, on the other side</i>, <span class="smcap">Manly</span>, Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>,
<i>and</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn your cause, can't you lose it without me?
which you are like enough to do, if it be, as you say, an
honest one: I will suffer no longer for't.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, captain, I tell you, you are my prime witness;
and the cause is just now coming on, Mr. Splitcause
tells me. Lord, methinks you should take a pleasure in
walking here, as half you see now do; for they have no
business here, I assure you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes; but I'll assure you then, their business is
to persecute me. But d'ye think I'll stay any longer, to
have a rogue, because he knows my name, pluck me aside
and whisper a news-book secret to me with a stinking
breath? a second come piping angry from the court, and
sputter in my face his tedious complaints against it? a
third law-coxcomb, because he saw me once at a reader's
dinner, come and put me a long law case, to make a
discovery of his indefatigable dulness and my wearied
patience? a fourth, a most barbarous civil rogue, who
will keep a man half an hour in the crowd with a bowed
body, and a hat off, acting the reformed sign of the Salutation
tavern, to hear his bountiful professions of service and
friendship, whilst he cares not if I were damned, and I
am wishing him hanged out of my way?&mdash;I'd as soon run
the gauntlet, as walk t'other turn.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry Blackacre</span>, <i>without his bags, but laden
with trinkets, which he endeavours to hide from his</i>
Mother, <i>and followed at a distance by</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O, are you come, sir? but where have you been,
you ass? and how came you thus laden?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Look here, forsooth, mother; now here's a duck,
here's a boar-cat, and here's an owl.
[<i>Making a noise with catcalls and other such like
instruments.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_441" id="Page_441">[Pg 441]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Yes, there is an owl, sir.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> He's an ungracious bird indeed.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> But go, thou trangame,<a name="FNanchor_116_116" id="FNanchor_116_116"></a><a href="#Footnote_116_116" class="fnanchor">[116]</a> and carry back those
trangames, which thou hast stolen or purloined; for
nobody would trust a minor in Westminster Hall, sure.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Hold yourself contented, forsooth: I have these
commodities by a fair bargain and sale; and there stands
my witness and creditor.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How's that? What sir, d'ye think to get the
mother by giving the child a rattle?&mdash;But where are my
bags, my writings, you rascal?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O, la! where are they, indeed! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How, sirrah? speak, come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You can tell her, Freeman, I suppose.
[<i>Apart to him.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> 'Tis true, I made one of your salt-water sharks
steal 'em whilst he was eagerly choosing his commodities,
as he calls 'em, in order to my design upon his mother.
[<i>Apart to him.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Won't you speak? Where were you, I say, you
son of a&mdash;an unfortunate woman?&mdash;O, major, I'm undone!
They are all that concern my estate, my jointure,
my husband's deed of gift, my evidences for all my suits
now depending! What will become of them?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] I'm glad to hear this.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] They'll
be all safe, I warrant you, madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O where? where? Come, you villain, along
with me, and show me where.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre, Jerry</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou hast taken the right way to get a widow,
by making her great boy rebel; for when nothing will
make a widow marry, she'll do it to cross her children.
But canst thou in earnest marry this harpy, this volume
of shrivelled blurred parchments and law, this attorney's
desk?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, ay; I'll marry and live honestly, that is,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_442" id="Page_442">[Pg 442]</a></span>
give my creditors, not her, due benevolence,&mdash;pay my
debts.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thy creditors, you see, are not so barbarous as
to put thee in prison; and wilt thou commit thyself to a
noisome dungeon for thy life? which is the only satisfaction
thou canst give thy creditors by this match.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, is not she rich?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay; but he that marries a widow for her money,
will find himself as much mistaken as the widow that
marries a young fellow for due benevolence, as you call it.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, d'ye think I shan't deserve wages? I'll
drudge faithfully.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I tell thee again, he that is the slave in the mine
has the least propriety in the ore. You may dig, and dig;
but if thou wouldst have her money, rather get to be her
trustee than her husband; for a true widow will make
over her estate to anybody, and cheat herself rather than
be cheated by her children or a second husband.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span>, <i>running in a fright.</i></p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O la, I'm undone! I'm undone! my mother will
kill me:&mdash;you said you'd stand by one.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> So I will, my brave squire, I warrant thee.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, but I dare not stay till she comes; for she's
as furious, now she has lost her writings, as a bitch when
she has lost her puppies.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> The comparison's handsome!</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O, she's here!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> [<i>To the</i> Sailor.] Take him, Jack, and make haste
with him to your master's lodging; and be sure you keep
him up till I come. [<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry</span> <i>and</i> Sailor.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span> <i>and</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O my dear writings! Where's this heathen
rogue, my minor?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Gone to drown or hang himself.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, I know him too well; he'll ne'er be <i>felo de
se</i> that way: but he may go and choose a guardian of his<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_443" id="Page_443">[Pg 443]</a></span>
own head, and so be <i>felo de ses biens</i>; for he has not yet
chosen one.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Say you so? And he shan't want one. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> But, now I think on't, 'tis you, sir, have put this
cheat upon me; for there is a saying, "Take hold of a
maid by her smock, and a widow by her writings, and
they cannot get from you." But I'll play fast and loose
with you yet, if there be law, and my minor and writings
are not forthcoming; I'll bring my action of detinue or
trover. But first, I'll try to find out this guardianless,
graceless villain.&mdash;Will you jog, major?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> If you have lost your evidence, I hope your
causes cannot go on, and I may be gone?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O no; stay but a making-water while (as one
may say) and I'll be with you again.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span> <i>and</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well; sure I am the first man that ever began a
love-intrigue in Westminster Hall.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, sure; for the love to a widow generally
begins here: and as the widow's cause goes against the
heir or executors, the jointure-rivals commence their suit
to the widow.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well; but how, pray, have you passed your time
here, since I was forced to leave you alone? You have
had a great deal of patience.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Is this a place to be alone, or have patience in?
But I have had patience, indeed; for I have drawn upon
me, since I came, but three quarrels and two lawsuits.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, faith, you are too curst to be let loose in
the world: you should be tied up again in your sea-kennel,
called a ship. But how could you quarrel here?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How could I refrain? A lawyer talked peremptorily
and saucily to me, and as good as gave me the lie.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> They do it so often to one another at the bar,
that they make no bones on't elsewhere.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> However, I gave him a cuff on the ear; whereupon
he jogs two men, whose backs were turned to us,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_444" id="Page_444">[Pg 444]</a></span>
(for they were reading at a bookseller's,) to witness I
struck him, sitting the courts; which office they so readily
promised, that I called 'em rascals and knights of the
post.<a name="FNanchor_117_117" id="FNanchor_117_117"></a><a href="#Footnote_117_117" class="fnanchor">[117]</a> One of 'em presently calls two other absent witnesses,
who were coming towards us at a distance; whilst
the other, with a whisper, desires to know my name, that
he might have satisfaction by way of challenge, as t'other
by way of writ; but if it were not rather to direct his
brother's writ, than his own challenge.&mdash;There, you see,
is one of my quarrels, and two of my lawsuits.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> So!&mdash;and the other two?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> For advising a poet to leave off writing, and
turn lawyer, because he is dull and impudent, and says or
writes nothing now but by precedent.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And the third quarrel?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> For giving more sincere advice to a handsome,
well-dressed young fellow, (who asked it too,) not to
marry a wench that he loved, and I had lain with.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, if you will be giving your sincere advice to
lovers and poets, you will not fail of quarrels.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Or if I stay in this place; for I see more quarrels
crowding upon me. Let's be gone, and avoid 'em.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span> <i>at a distance, coming towards them.</i></p>

<p>A plague on him, that sneer is ominous to us; he is
coming upon us, and we shall not be rid of him.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Dear bully, don't look so grum upon me; you
told me just now, you had forgiven me a little harmless
raillery upon wooden legs last night.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, yes, pray begone, I am talking of business.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Can't I hear it? I love thee, and will be faithful,
and always&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Impertinent. 'Tis business that concerns Freeman
only.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well, I love Freeman too, and would not divulge
his secret.&mdash;Prithee speak, prithee, I must&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Prithee let me be rid of thee, I must be rid of thee.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_445" id="Page_445">[Pg 445]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Faith, thou canst hardly, I love thee so. Come,
I must know the business.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] So, I have it now.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Why, if
you needs will know it, he has a quarrel, and his adversary
bids him bring two friends with him: now, I am one,
and we are thinking who we shall have for a third.
[<i>Several cross the stage.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> A pox, there goes a fellow owes me a hundred
pounds, and goes out of town to-morrow: I'll speak with
him, and come to you presently. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, but you won't.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> You are dexterously rid of him.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> To what purpose, since here comes another as
impertinent? I know by his grin he is bound hither.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Your servant, worthy, noble captain. Well, I
have left the widow, because she carried me from your
company: for, faith, captain, I must needs tell thee thou
art the only officer in England, who was not an Edgehill
officer, that I care for.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I'm sorry for't.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Why, wouldst thou have me love them?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Anybody rather than me.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> What! you are modest, I see; therefore, too, I
love thee.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, I am not modest; but love to brag myself,
and can't patiently hear you fight over the last civil war.
Therefore, go look out the fellow I saw just now here,
that walks with his sword and stockings out at heels, and
let him tell you the history of that scar on his cheek, to
give you occasion to show yours got in the field at
Bloomsbury, not that of Edgehill. Go to him, poor
fellow; he is fasting, and has not yet the happiness this
morning to stink of brandy and tobacco: go, give him
some to hear you; I am busy.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Well, egad, I love thee now, boy, for thy surliness.
Thou art no tame captain, I see, that will suffer&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_446" id="Page_446">[Pg 446]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> An old fox.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> All that shan't make me angry: I consider that
thou art peevish, and fretting at some ill success at law.
Prithee, tell me what ill luck you have met with here.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Do I look like the picture of ill luck? gadsnouns,
I love thee more and more. And shall I tell thee what
made me love thee first?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Do; that I may be rid of that damned quality
and thee.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> 'Twas thy wearing that broad sword there.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Here, Freeman, let's change: I'll never wear it
more.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> How! you won't, sure. Prithee, don't look like
one of our holiday captains now-a-days, with a bodkin by
your side, your martinet rogues.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] O, then, there's hopes.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] What,
d'ye find fault with martinet? Let me tell you, sir, 'tis
the best exercise in the world; the most ready, most easy,
most graceful exercise that ever was used, and the most&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Nay, nay, sir, no more; sir, your servant: if you
praise martinet once, I have done with you, sir.&mdash;Martinet!
martinet!&mdash;[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, you have made him leave you as willingly
as ever he did an enemy; for he was truly for the king
and parliament: for the parliament in their list; and for
the king in cheating 'em of their pay, and never hurting
the king's party in the field.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter a</i> Lawyer <i>towards them.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> A pox! this way:&mdash;here's a lawyer I know
threatening us with another greeting.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> Sir, sir, your very servant; I was afraid you had
forgotten me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I was not afraid you had forgotten me.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> No, sir; we lawyers have pretty good memories.</p>
