<p><i>Man.</i> You ought to have by your wits.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_447" id="Page_447">[Pg 447]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Law.</i> O, you are a merry gentleman, sir: I remember
you were merry when I was last in your company.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I was never merry in thy company, Mr. Lawyer,
sure.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> Why, I'm sure you joked upon me, and shammed
me all night long.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Shammed! prithee what barbarous law-term is
that?</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> Shamming! why, don't you know that? 'tis all
our way of wit, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I am glad I do not know it then. Shamming!
what does he mean by't, Freeman!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Shamming is telling you an insipid dull lie with
a dull face, which the sly wag the author only laughs at
himself; and making himself believe 'tis a good jest, puts
the sham only upon himself.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> So, your lawyer's jest, I find, like his practice,
has more knavery than wit in't. I should make the worst
shammer in England: I must always deal ingenuously,
as I will with you, Mr. Lawyer, and advise you to be
seen rather with attorneys and solicitors, than such fellows
as I am: they will credit your practice more.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> No, sir, your company's an honour to me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, faith; go this way, there goes an attorney;
leave me for him; let it never be said a lawyer's civility
did him hurt.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> No, worthy, honoured sir; I'll not leave you for
any attorney, sure.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Unless he had a fee in his hand.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> Have you any business here, sir? Try me: I'd
serve you sooner than any attorney breathing.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Business&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] So, I have thought of a sure
way.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Yes, faith, I have a little business.</p>

<p><i>Law.</i> Have you so, sir? in what court, sir? what is't,
sir? Tell me but how I may serve you, and I'll do't, sir,
and take it for as great an honour&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Faith, 'tis for a poor orphan of a sea officer of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_448" id="Page_448">[Pg 448]</a></span>
mine, that has no money. But if it could be followed in
<i>forma pauperis</i>, and when the legacy's recovered&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Law. Forma pauperis</i>, sir!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay, sir. [<i>Several crossing the stage.</i></p>

<p><i>Law.</i> Mr. Bumblecase, Mr. Bumblecase! a word with
you.&mdash;Sir, I beg your pardon at present; I have a little
business&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Which is not in <i>forma pauperis</i>. [<i>Exit</i> Lawyer.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> So, you have now found a way to be rid of people
without quarrelling?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Alderman.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But here's a city-rogue will stick as hard upon
us, as if I owed him money.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Captain, noble sir, I am yours heartily, d'ye see;
why should you avoid your old friends?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And why should you follow me? I owe you
nothing.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Out of my hearty respects to you: for there is
not a man in England&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou wouldst save from hanging with the expense
of a shilling only.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Nay, nay, but, captain, you are like enough to
tell me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Truth, which you won't care to hear; therefore
you had better go talk with somebody else.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> No, I know nobody can inform me better of some
young wit, or spendthrift, that has a good dipped<a name="FNanchor_118_118" id="FNanchor_118_118"></a><a href="#Footnote_118_118" class="fnanchor">[118]</a> seat
and estate in Middlesex, Hertfordshire, Essex, or Kent;
any of these would serve my turn: now, if you knew of
such a one, and would but help&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You to finish his ruin.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> I'faith, you should have a snip&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Of your nose, you thirty-in-the-hundred rascal;
would you make me your squire setter, your bawd for
manors? [<i>Takes him by the nose.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_449" id="Page_449">[Pg 449]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Oh!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Hold, or here will be your third law-suit.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Gads-precious, you hectoring person you, are you
wild? I meant you no hurt, sir: I begin to think, as
things go, land-security best, and have for a convenient
mortgage, some ten, fifteen or twenty thousand pound by
me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Then go lay it out upon an hospital, and take a
mortgage of Heaven, according to your city custom; for
you think by laying out a little money to hook in that too
hereafter. Do, I say, and keep the poor you've made by
taking forfeitures, that Heaven may not take yours.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> No, to keep the cripples you make this war.
This war spoils our trade.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn your trade! 'tis the better for't.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> What, will you speak against our trade?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And dare you speak against the war, our trade?</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, he may be a convoy of ships I am
concerned in.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Come, captain, I will have a fair
correspondence with you, say what you will.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Then prithee be gone.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> No, faith; prithee, captain, let's go drink a dish
of laced coffee,<a name="FNanchor_119_119" id="FNanchor_119_119"></a><a href="#Footnote_119_119" class="fnanchor">[119]</a> and talk of the times. Come, I'll treat
you: nay, you shall go, for I have no business here.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But I have.</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> To pick up a man to give thee a dinner. Come,
I'll do thy business for thee.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Faith, now I think on't, so you may, as well as
any man: for 'tis to pick up a man to be bound with me,
to one who expects city security for&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Nay, then your servant, captain; business must
be done.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay, if it can. But hark you, alderman, without
you&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ald.</i> Business, sir, I say, must be done; and there's<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_450" id="Page_450">[Pg 450]</a></span>
an officer of the treasury [<i>Several cross the stage.</i>] I have
an affair with&mdash;[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> You see now what the mighty friendship of the
world is; what all ceremony, embraces, and plentiful
professions come to! You are no more to believe a professing
friend than a threatening enemy; and as no man
hurts you, that tells you he'll do you a mischief, no man,
you see, is your servant who says he is so. Why the
devil, then, should a man be troubled with the flattery of
knaves if he be not a fool or cully; or with the fondness
of fools, if he be not a knave or cheat?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Only for his pleasure: for there is some in laughing
at fools, and disappointing knaves.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> That's a pleasure, I think, would cost you too
dear, as well as marrying your widow to disappoint her.
But, for my part, I have no pleasure by 'em but in
despising 'em, wheresoe'er I meet 'em; and then the
pleasure of hoping so to be rid of 'em. But now my
comfort is, I am not worth a shilling in the world, which
all the world shall know; and then I'm sure I shall have
none of 'em come near me.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> A very pretty comfort, which I think you pay too
dear for.&mdash;But is the twenty pound gone since the morning?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> To my boat's crew.&mdash;Would you have the poor,
honest, brave fellows want?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Rather than you or I.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, art thou without money? thou who art a
friend to everybody?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I ventured my last stake upon the squire to nick
him of his mother; and cannot help you to a dinner,
unless you will go dine with my lord&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, no; the ordinary is too dear for me, where
flattery must pay for my dinner: I am no herald or poet.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> We'll go then to the bishop's&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> There you must flatter the old philosophy: I
cannot renounce my reason for a dinner.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Why, then let's go to your alderman's.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_451" id="Page_451">[Pg 451]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hang him, rogue! that were not to dine; for
he makes you drunk with lees of sack before dinner, to
take away your stomach: and there you must call usury
and extortion God's blessings, or the honest turning of
the penny; hear him brag of the leather breeches in
which he trotted first to town, and make a greater noise
with his money in his parlour, than his cashiers do
in his counting-house, without hopes of borrowing a
shilling.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, a pox on't! 'tis like dining with the great
gamesters; and when they fall to their common dessert,
to see the heaps of gold drawn on all hands, without
going to twelve. Let us go to my Lady Goodly's.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> There to flatter her looks. You must mistake
her grandchildren for her own; praise her cook, that she
may rail at him; and feed her dogs, not yourself.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> What d'ye think of eating with your lawyer,
then?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Eat with him! damn him! To hear him employ
his barbarous eloquence in a reading upon the two-and-thirty
good bits in a shoulder of veal, and be forced
yourself to praise the cold bribe-pie that stinks, and
drink law-French wine as rough and harsh as his law-French.
A pox on him! I'd rather dine in the Temple-rounds
or walks, with the knights without noses, or the
knights of the post, who are honester fellows and better
company. But let us home and try our fortune; for I'll
stay no longer here for your damned widow.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, let us go home then; for I must go for my
damned widow, and look after my new damned charge.
Three or four hundred years ago a man might have dined
in this Hall.<a name="FNanchor_120_120" id="FNanchor_120_120"></a><a href="#Footnote_120_120" class="fnanchor">[120]</a></p>

<p><i>Man.</i></p>

<p>
But now the lawyer only here is fed;<br />
And, bully-like, by quarrels gets his bread.<br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_452" id="Page_452">[Pg 452]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FOURTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Manly's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, there's success in thy face.
Hast thou prevailed? say.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> As I could wish, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> So; I told thee what thou
wert fit for, and thou wouldst not
believe me. Come, thank me for
bringing thee acquainted with thy
genius. Well, thou hast mollified her heart for me?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> No, sir, not so; but what's better.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How, what's better?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I shall harden your heart against her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Have a care, sir; my heart is too much in
earnest to be fooled with, and my desire at height, and
needs no delay to incite it. What, you are too good a
pimp already, and know how to endear pleasure by withholding
it? But leave off your page's bawdy-house
tricks, sir, and tell me, will she be kind?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Kinder than you could wish, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> So, then: well, prithee, what said she?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> She said&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What? thou'rt so tedious: speak comfort to
me; what?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> That of all things you are her aversion.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_453" id="Page_453">[Pg 453]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> That she would sooner take a bedfellow out of an
hospital, and diseases into her arms, than you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> That she would rather trust her honour with a
dissolute debauched hector, nay worse, with a finical
baffled coward, all over loathsome with affectation of the
fine gentleman.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What's all this you say?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, that my offers of your love to her were more
offensive, than when parents woo their virgin-daughters
to the enjoyment of riches only; and that you were in
all circumstances as nauseous to her as a husband on
compulsion.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hold! I understand you not.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> So, 'twill work, I see. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Did you not tell me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> She called you ten thousand ruffians.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hold, I say.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Brutes&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hold.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Sea-monsters&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn your intelligence! Hear me a little now.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, surly coward she called you too.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Won't you hold yet? Hold, or&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, sir, pardon me; I could not but tell you she
had the baseness, the injustice, to call you coward, sir;
coward, coward, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Not yet&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I've done:&mdash;coward, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Did not you say, she was kinder than I could
wish her?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Yes, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How then?&mdash;O&mdash;I understand you now. At
first she appeared in rage and disdain; the truest sign of
a coming woman: but at last you prevailed, it seems; did
you not?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Yes, sir.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_454" id="Page_454">[Pg 454]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> So then; let's know that only: come, prithee,
without delays. I'll kiss thee for that news beforehand.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> So; the kiss I'm sure is welcome to me, whatsoe'er
the news will be to you. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Come, speak, my dear volunteer.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> How welcome were that kind word too, if it were
not for another woman's sake! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What, won't you speak? You prevailed for me
at last, you say?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> No, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No more of your fooling, sir: it will not agree
with my impatience or temper.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Then not to fool you, sir, I spoke to her for you,
but prevailed for myself; she would not hear me when I
spoke in your behalf, but bid me say what I would in my
own, though she gave me no occasion, she was so coming,
and so was kinder, sir, than you could wish; which I was
only afraid to let you know, without some warning.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How's this? Young man, you are of a lying
age; but I must hear you out, and if&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I would not abuse you, and cannot wrong her by
any report of her, she is so wicked.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How, wicked! had she the impudence, at the
second sight of you only&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Impudence, sir! oh, she has impudence enough
to put a court out of countenance, and debauch a stews.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, what said she?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Her tongue, I confess, was silent; but her speaking
eyes gloated such things, more immodest and lascivious
than ravishers can act, or women under a confinement
think.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I know there are those whose eyes reflect more
obscenity than the glasses in alcoves; but there are others
too who use a little art with their looks, to make 'em seem
more beautiful, not more loving; which vain young
fellows like you are apt to interpret in their own favour,
and to the lady's wrong.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_455" id="Page_455">[Pg 455]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Seldom, sir. Pray, have you a care of gloating
eyes; for he that loves to gaze upon 'em, will find at last
a thousand fools and cuckolds in 'em instead of cupids.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Very well, sir.&mdash;But what, you had only eye-kindness
from Olivia?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I tell you again, sir, no woman sticks there; eye-promises
of love they only keep; nay, they are contracts
which make you sure of 'em. In short, sir, she seeing
me, with shame and amazement dumb, unactive, and
resistless, threw her twisting arms about my neck, and
smothered me with a thousand tasteless kisses. Believe
me, sir, they were so to me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why did you not avoid 'em then?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I fenced with her eager arms, as you did with the
grapples of the enemy's fireship; and nothing but cutting
'em off could have freed me.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damned, damned woman, that could be so
false and infamous! and damned, damned heart of mine,
that cannot yet be false, though so infamous! what easy,
tame suffering trampled things does that little god of
talking cowards make of us! but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> So; it works, I find, as I expected. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But she was false to me before, she told me so
herself, and yet I could not quite believe it; but she was,
so that her second falseness is a favour to me, not an
injury, in revenging me upon the man that wronged me
first of her love. Her love! a whore's, a witch's love!&mdash;But
what, did she not kiss well, sir?&mdash;I'm sure I
thought her lips&mdash;but I must not think of 'em more&mdash;but
yet they are such I could still kiss&mdash;grow to&mdash;and
then tear off with my teeth, grind 'em into mammocks,<a name="FNanchor_121_121" id="FNanchor_121_121"></a><a href="#Footnote_121_121" class="fnanchor">[121]</a>
and spit 'em into her cuckold's face.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Poor man, how uneasy he is! I have hardly the
heart to give so much pain, though withal I give him
cure, and to myself new life. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But what, her kisses sure could not but warm<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_456" id="Page_456">[Pg 456]</a></span>
you into desire at last, or a compliance with hers at
least?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, more, I confess&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What more? speak.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> All you could fear had passed between us, if I
could have been made to wrong you, sir, in that nature.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Could have been made! you lie, you did.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Indeed, sir, 'twas impossible for me; besides, we
were interrupted by a visit; but I confess, she would not
let me stir, till I promised to return to her again within
this hour, as soon as it should be dark; by which time
she would dispose of her visit, and her servants, and herself,
for my reception. Which I was fain to promise, to
get from her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ha!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But if ever I go near her again, may you, sir,
think me as false to you, as she is; hate and renounce me,
as you ought to do her, and, I hope, will do now.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, but now I think on't, you shall keep your
word with your lady. What, a young fellow, and fail the
first, nay, so tempting an assignation!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> How, sir?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I say, you shall go to her when 'tis dark, and
shall not disappoint her.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I, sir! I should disappoint her more by going.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How so?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Her impudence and injustice to you will make
me disappoint her love, loathe her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Come, you have my leave; and if you disgust<a name="FNanchor_122_122" id="FNanchor_122_122"></a><a href="#Footnote_122_122" class="fnanchor">[122]</a>
her, I'll go with you, and act love, whilst you shall talk it
only.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> You, sir! nay, then I'll never go near her. You
act love, sir! You must but act it indeed, after all I
have said to you. Think of your honour, sir: love!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, call it revenge, and that is honourable:
I'll be avenged on her; and thou shalt be my second.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_457" id="Page_457">[Pg 457]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Not in a base action, sir, when you are your own
enemy. O go not near her, sir; for Heaven's sake, for
your own, think not of it!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How concerned you are! I thought I should
catch you. What, you are my rival at last, and are in
love with her yourself; and have spoken ill of her out of
your love to her, not me: and therefore would not have
me go to her!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Heaven witness for me, 'tis because I love you
only, I would not have you go to her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Come, come, the more I think on't, the more
I'm satisfied you do love her. Those kisses, young man,
I knew were irresistible; 'tis certain.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> There is nothing certain in the world, sir, but my
truth and your courage.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Your servant, sir. Besides, false and ungrateful
as she has been to me, and though I may believe her
hatred to me great as you report it, yet I cannot think
you are so soon and at that rate beloved by her, though
you may endeavour it.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, if that be all, and you doubt it still, sir, I
will conduct you to her; and, unseen, your ears shall
judge of her falseness, and my truth to you, if that will
satisfy you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, there is some satisfaction in being quite
out of doubt; because 'tis that alone withholds us from
the pleasure of revenge.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Revenge! What revenge can you have, sir?
Disdain is best revenged by scorn; and faithless love, by
loving another, and making her happy with the other's
losings. Which, if I might advise&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Not a word more.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> What, are you talking of love yet, captain? I
thought you had done with't.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, what did you hear me say?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_458" id="Page_458">[Pg 458]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Something imperfectly of love, I think.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I was only wondering why fools, rascals, and
desertless wretches, should still have the better of men
of merit with all women, as much as with their own
common mistress, Fortune.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Because most women, like Fortune, are blind,
seem to do all things in jest, and take pleasure in
extravagant actions. Their love deserves neither thanks,
nor blame, for they cannot help it: 'tis all sympathy;
therefore, the noisy, the finical, the talkative, the
cowardly, and effeminate, have the better of the brave,
the reasonable, and man of honour; for they have no
more reason in their love, or kindness, than Fortune
herself.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, they have their reason. First, honour in a
man they fear too much to love; and sense in a lover
upbraids their want of it; and they hate anything that
disturbs their admiration of themselves; but they are of
that vain number, who had rather show their false
generosity, in giving away profusely to worthless flatterers,
than in paying just debts. And, in short, all women,
like fortune (as you say) and rewards, are lost by too
much meriting.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> All women, sir! sure there are some who have
no other quarrel to a lover's merit, but that it begets
their despair of him.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou art young enough to be credulous; but
we&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Sailor.</p>

<p><i>Sail.</i> Here are now below, the scolding daggled
gentlewoman, and that Major Old&mdash;Old&mdash;Fop, I think
you call him.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Oldfox:&mdash;prithee bid 'em come up, with your
leave, captain, for now I can talk with her upon the
square, if I shall not disturb you. [<i>Exit</i> Sailor.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No; for I'll begone. Come, volunteer.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_459" id="Page_459">[Pg 459]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, pray stay; the scene between us will not
be so tedious to you as you think. Besides, you shall
see how I rigged my 'squire out, with the remains
of my shipwrecked wardrobe; he is under your sea
valet-de-chambre's hands, and by this time dressed,
and will be worth your seeing. Stay, and I'll fetch my
fool.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No; you know I cannot easily laugh: besides,
my volunteer and I have business abroad.
[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span> <i>on one side</i>;
<span class="smcap">Freeman</span> <i>on the other.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span> <i>and</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> What, nobody here! did not the fellow say he
was within?</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Yes, lady; and he may be perhaps a little busy
at present; but if you think the time long till he comes,
[<i>Unfolding papers</i>] I'll read you here some of the fruits of
my leisure, the overflowings of my fancy and pen.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>]
To value me right, she must know my parts.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>]
Come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, no; I have reading work enough of my
own in my bag, I thank you.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Ay, law, madam; but here's a poem, in blank
verse, which I think a handsome declaration of one's
passion.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O, if you talk of declarations, I'll show you one
of the prettiest penned things, which I mended too myself,
you must know.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Nay, lady, if you have used yourself so much to
the reading harsh law, that you hate smooth poetry, here
is a character for you, of&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> A character! nay, then I'll show you my bill in
chancery here, that gives you such a character of my
adversary, makes him as black&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Pshaw! away, away, lady! But if you think the
character too long, here is an epigram, not above twenty<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_460" id="Page_460">[Pg 460]</a></span>
lines, upon a cruel lady, who decreed her servant should
hang himself, to demonstrate his passion.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Decreed! if you talk of decreeing, I have such a
decree here, drawn by the finest clerk&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> O lady, lady, all interruption, and no sense
between us, as if we were lawyers at the bar! but I had
forgot, Apollo and Littleton never lodge in a head
together. If you hate verses, I'll give you a cast of my
politics in prose. 'Tis "a Letter to a Friend in the
Country;" which is now the way of all such sober solid
persons as myself, when they have a mind to publish
their disgust to the times; though perhaps, between you
and I, they have no friend in the country. And sure a
politic, serious person may as well have a feigned friend
in the country to write to, as an idle poet a feigned
mistress to write to. And so here's my letter to a friend,
or no friend, in the country, concerning the late conjuncture
of affairs, in relation to coffee-houses; or,
"The Coffee-man's Case."</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, if your letter have a case in't, 'tis something;
but first I'll read you a letter of mine to a friend
in the country, called a letter of attorney.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>, <i>with</i> <span class="smcap">Jerry Blackacre</span> <i>in an old
gaudy suit and red breeches of</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman's</span>.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> What, interruption still! O the plague of interruption!
worse to an author than the plague of critics.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> What's this I see? Jerry Blackacre, my minor,
in red breeches! What, hast thou left the modest
seemly garb of gown and cap for this? and have I
lost all my good inns-of-chancery breeding upon thee
then? and thou wilt go a-breeding thyself from our inn
of chancery and Westminster Hall, at coffee-houses,
and ordinaries, play-houses, tennis-courts, and bawdy-houses?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, ay, what then? perhaps I will; but what's<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_461" id="Page_461">[Pg 461]</a></span>
that to you? Here's my guardian and tutor now,
forsooth, that I am out of your huckster's hands.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How! thou hast not chosen him for thy guardian
yet?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> No, but he has chosen me for his charge, and
that's all one; and I'll do anything he'll have me, and go
all the world over with him; to ordinaries, and bawdy-houses,
or anywhere else.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> To ordinaries and bawdy-houses! have a care,
minor, thou wilt enfeeble there thy estate and body: do
not go to ordinaries and bawdy-houses, good Jerry.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Why, how come you to know any ill by bawdy-houses?
you never had any hurt by 'em, had you,
forsooth? Pray hold yourself contented; if I do go
where money and wenches are to be had, you may thank
yourself; for you used me so unnaturally, you would
never let me have a penny to go abroad with; nor so
much as come near the garret where your maidens lay;
nay, you would not so much as let me play at hotcockles
with 'em, nor have any recreation with 'em though one
should have kissed you behind, you were so unnatural a
mother, so you were.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Ay, a very unnatural mother, faith, squire.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> But, Jerry, consider thou art yet but a minor;
however, if thou wilt go home with me again, and be a
good child, thou shalt see&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Madam, I must have a better care of my heir
under age, than so; I would sooner trust him alone with
a stale waiting-woman and a parson, than with his widow-mother
and her lover or lawyer.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Why, thou villain, part mother and minor! rob
me of my child and my writings! but thou shalt find
there's law; and as in the case of ravishment of guard&mdash;Westminster
the Second.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Young gentleman squire, pray be ruled by your
mother and your friends.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Yes, I'll be ruled by my friends, therefore not by<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_462" id="Page_462">[Pg 462]</a></span>
my mother, so I won't: I'll choose him for my guardian
till I am of age; nay, maybe, for as long as I live.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Wilt thou so, thou wretch? and when thou'rt of
age, thou wilt sign, seal and deliver too, wilt thou?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Yes, marry will I, if you go there too.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O do not squeeze wax, son; rather go to ordinaries
and bawdy-houses, than squeeze wax. If thou
dost that, farewell the goodly manor of Blackacre, with
all its woods, underwoods, and appurtenances whatever!
Oh, oh! [<i>Weeps.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Come, madam, in short, you see I am resolved
to have a share in the estate, yours or your son's; if I
cannot get you, I'll keep him, who is less coy, you find;
but if you would have your son again, you must take me
too. Peace or war? love or law? You see my hostage
is in my hand: I'm in possession.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Nay, if one of us must be ruined, e'en let it be
him. By my body, a good one! Did you ever know
yet a widow marry or not marry for the sake of her
child? I'd have you to know, sir, I shall be hard enough
for you both yet, without marrying you, if Jerry won't
be ruled by me. What say you, booby, will you be
ruled? speak.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Let one alone, can't you?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Wilt thou choose him for guardian, whom I
refuse for husband?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, to choose, I thank you.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> And are all my hopes frustrated? Shall I never
hear thee put cases again to John the butler, or our
vicar? never see thee amble the circuit with the judges;
and hear thee, in our town-hall, louder than the crier?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> No, for I have taken my leave of lawyering and
pettifogging.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Pettifogging! thou profane villain, hast thou so?
Pettifogging!&mdash;then you shall take your leave of me, and
your estate too; thou shalt be an alien to me and it
forever. Pettifogging!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_463" id="Page_463">[Pg 463]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O, but if you go there too, mother, we have the
deeds and settlements, I thank you. Would you cheat
me of my estate, i'fac?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, no, I will not cheat your little brother Bob;
for thou wert not born in wedlock.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> How's that?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> How? what quirk has she got in her head now?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> I say, thou canst not, shalt not inherit the
Blackacres' estate.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Why? why, forsooth? What d'ye mean, if you go
there too?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Thou art but my base child; and according to
the law, canst not inherit it. Nay, thou art not so much
as bastard eigne.<a name="FNanchor_123_123" id="FNanchor_123_123"></a><a href="#Footnote_123_123" class="fnanchor">[123]</a></p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> What, what, am I then the son of a whore, mother?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> The law says&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Madam, we know what the law says; but have a
care what you say. Do not let your passion, to ruin your
son, ruin your reputation.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Hang reputation, sir! am not I a widow? have
no husband, nor intend to have any? Nor would you,
I suppose, now have me for a wife. So I think now I'm
revenged on my son and you, without marrying, as I told
you.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But consider, madam.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> What, have you no shame left in you, mother?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Wonder not at it, major. 'Tis often the poor
pressed widow's case, to give up her honour to save her
jointure; and seem to be a light woman, rather than
marry: as some young men, they say, pretend to have
the filthy disease, and lose their credit with most women,
to avoid the importunities of some. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But one word with you, madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> No, no, sir. Come, major, let us make haste
now to the Prerogative-court.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> But, lady, if what you say be true, will you stigmatise<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_464" id="Page_464">[Pg 464]</a></span>
your reputation on record? and if it be not true,
how will you prove it?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Pshaw! I can prove anything: and for my reputation,
know, major, a wise woman will no more value
her reputation, in disinheriting a rebellious son of a good
estate, than she would in getting him, to inherit an estate.
[<i>Exeunt</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span> <i>and</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Madam.&mdash;We must not let her go so, squire.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Nay, the devil can't stop her though, if she has a
mind to't. But come, bully-guardian, we'll go and advise
with three attorneys, two proctors, two solicitors, and a
shrewd man of Whitefriars, neither attorney, proctor, nor
solicitor, but as pure a pimp to the law as any of 'em:
and sure all they will be hard enough for her, for I fear,
bully-guardian, you are too good a joker to have any law
in your head.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Thou'rt in the right on't, squire, I understand no
law; especially that against bastards, since I'm sure the
custom is against that law, and more people get estates
by being so, than lose 'em. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Olivia's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible</span> <i>and</i> Boy <i>with a candle.</i></p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Little gentleman, your most obedient, faithful,
humble servant. Where, I beseech you, is that divine
person, your noble lady?</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Gone out, my lord; but commanded me to give
you this letter. [<i>Gives him a letter.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span>.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Which he must not observe.
[<i>Aside. Puts letter up.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Hey, boy, where is thy lady?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_465" id="Page_465">[Pg 465]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Gone out, sir; but I must beg a word with you.
[<i>Gives him a letter, and exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> For me? So.&mdash;[<i>Puts up the letter.</i>] Servant,
servant, my lord; you see the lady knew of your coming,
for she is gone out.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Sir, I humbly beseech you not to censure
the lady's good breeding: she has reason to use more
liberty with me than with any other man.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> How, viscount, how?</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, I humbly beseech you, be not in
choler; where there is most love, there may be most
freedom.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nay, then 'tis time to come to an eclaircissement
with you, and to tell you, you must think no more of this
lady's love.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Why, under correction, dear sir?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> There are reasons, reasons, viscount.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> What, I beseech you, noble sir?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Prithee, prithee, be not impertinent, my lord;
some of you lords are such conceited, well-assured, impertinent
rogues.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> And you noble wits are so full of shamming
and drolling, one knows not where to have you
seriously.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well, you shall find me in bed with this lady one
of these days.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, I beseech you, spare the lady's honour;
for hers and mine will be all one shortly.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Prithee, my lord, be not an ass. Dost thou
think to get her from me? I have had such encouragements&mdash;</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> I have not been thought unworthy of
'em.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> What, not like mine! Come to an eclaircissement,
as I said.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Why, seriously then, she has told me
viscountess sounded prettily.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_466" id="Page_466">[Pg 466]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And me, that Novel was a name she would
sooner change hers for than for any title in England.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> She has commended the softness and respectfulness
of my behaviour.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> She has praised the briskness of my raillery, of
all things, man.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The sleepiness of my eyes she liked.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Sleepiness! dulness, dulness. But the fierceness
of mine she adored.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The brightness of my hair she liked.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> The brightness! no, the greasiness, I warrant.
But the blackness and lustre of mine she admires.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The gentleness of my smile.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> The subtilty of my leer.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The clearness of my complexion.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> The redness of my lips.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The whiteness of my teeth.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> My jaunty way of picking them.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> The sweetness of my breath.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ha! ha! nay, then she abused you, 'tis plain;
for you know what Manly said:&mdash;the sweetness of your
pulvillio she might mean; but for your breath! ha! ha!
ha! Your breath is such, man, that nothing but tobacco
can perfume; and your complexion nothing could mend
but the small-pox.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Well, sir, you may please to be merry; but,
to put you out of all doubt, sir, she has received some
jewels from me of value.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And presents from me; besides what I presented
her jauntily, by way of ombre, of three or four hundred
pounds value, which I'm sure are the earnest-pence for
our love-bargain.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Nay, then, sir, with your favour, and to make
an end of all your hopes, look you there, sir, she has
writ to me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> How! how! well, well, and so she has to me;
look you there&mdash;[<i>They deliver to each other their letters.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_467" id="Page_467">[Pg 467]</a></span></p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> What's here?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> How's this?
[<i>Reads out.</i>]&mdash;"My dear lord,&mdash;You'll excuse me for
breaking my word with you, since 'twas to oblige, not
offend you; for I am only gone abroad but to disappoint
Novel, and meet you in the drawing-room; where I
expect you with as much impatience as when I used to
suffer Novel's visits&mdash;the most impertinent fop that ever
affected the name of a wit, therefore not capable, I hope,
to give you jealousy; for, for your sake alone, you saw I
renounced an old lover, and will do all the world. Burn
the letter, but lay up the kindness of it in your heart,
with your&mdash;Olivia."
Very fine! but pray let's see mine.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> I understand it not; but sure she cannot
think so of me.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> [<i>Reads the other letter.</i>] Hum! ha!&mdash;"meet&mdash;for
your sake"&mdash;hum&mdash;"quitted an old lover&mdash;world&mdash;burn&mdash;in
your heart&mdash;with your&mdash;Olivia."
Just the same, the names only altered.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> Surely there must be some mistake, or somebody
has abused her and us.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Yes, you are abused, no doubt on't, my lord;
but I'll to Whitehall, and see.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> And I, where I shall find you are abused.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Where, if it be so, for our comfort, we cannot
fail of meeting with fellow-sufferers enough; for, as
Freeman said of another, she stands in the drawing room,
like the glass, ready for all comers, to set their gallantry
by her: and, like the glass too, lets no man go from her
unsatisfied with himself. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>and</i> Boy.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Both here, and just gone?</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Yes, madam.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But are you sure neither saw you deliver the
other a letter?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_468" id="Page_468">[Pg 468]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Yes, yes, madam, I am very sure.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Go then to the Old Exchange, to Westminster,
Holborn, and all the other places I told you of; I shall
not need you these two hours: begone, and take the
candle with you, and be sure you leave word again below,
I am gone out, to all that ask.</p>

<p><i>Boy.</i> Yes, madam. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And my new lover will not ask, I'm sure; he
has his lesson, and cannot miss me here, though in the
dark: which I have purposely designed, as a remedy
against my blushing gallant's modesty; for young lovers,
like game-cocks, are made bolder by being kept without
light.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>, <i>as from a journey.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Where is she? Darkness everywhere? [<i>Softly.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What! come before your time? My soul! my
life! your haste has augmented your kindness; and let
me thank you for it thus, and thus&mdash;[<i>Embracing and
kissing him.</i>] And though, my soul, the little time since
you left me has seemed an age to my impatience, sure it
is yet but seven&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> How! who's that you expected after seven?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ha! my husband returned! and have I been
throwing away so many kind kisses on my husband, and
wronged my lover already? [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Speak, I say, who was't you expected after seven?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] What shall I say?&mdash;oh&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Why
'tis but seven days, is it, dearest, since you went out of
town? and I expected you not so soon.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No, sure, 'tis but five days since I left you.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Pardon my impatience, dearest, I thought 'em
seven at least.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Nay, then&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But, my life, you shall never stay half so long
from me again; you shan't indeed, by this kiss you
shan't.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_469" id="Page_469">[Pg 469]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No, no; but why alone in the dark?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Blame not my melancholy in your absence.&mdash;But,
my soul, since you went, I have strange news to tell
you: Manly is returned.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Manly returned! Fortune forbid!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Met with the Dutch in the channel, fought, sunk
his ship, and all he carried with him. He was here with
me yesterday.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> And did you own our marriage to him?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I told him I was married to put an end to his
love and my trouble; but to whom, is yet a secret kept
from him and all the world. And I have used him so
scurvily, his great spirit will ne'er return to reason it
farther with me: I have sent him to sea again, I
warrant.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> 'Twas bravely done. And sure he will now hate
the shore more than ever, after so great a disappointment.
Be you sure only to keep a while our great
secret, till he be gone. In the mean time, I'll lead the
easy, honest fool by the nose, as I used to do; and
whilst he stays, rail with him at thee; and when he's
gone, laugh with thee at him. But have you his cabinet
of jewels safe? part not with a seed-pearl to him, to keep
him from starving.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nor from hanging.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> He cannot recover 'em; and, I think, will scorn
to beg 'em again.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But, my life, have you taken the thousand
guineas he left in my name out of the goldsmith's hands?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ay, ay; they are removed to another goldsmith's.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ay, but, my soul, you had best have a care he
find not where the money is; for his present wants, as
I'm informed, are such as will make him inquisitive
enough.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> You say true, and he knows the man too; but
I'll remove it to-morrow.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_470" id="Page_470">[Pg 470]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> To-morrow! O do not stay till to-morrow; go
to-night, immediately.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Now I think on't, you advise well, and I will go
presently.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Presently! instantly! I will not let you stay a
jot.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I will then, though I return not home till twelve.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, though not till morning, with all my heart.
Go, dearest; I am impatient till you are gone.&mdash;[<i>Thrusts
him out.</i>] So, I have at once now brought about those
two grateful businesses, which all prudent women do
together, secured money and pleasure; and now all
interruptions of the last are removed. Go, husband, and
come up, friend; just the buckets in the well; the
absence of one brings the other. But I hope, like them
too, they will not meet in the way, jostle, and clash
together.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>, <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>treading softly and staying
behind at some distance.</i></p>

<p>So, are you come? (but not the husband-bucket, I hope,
again.)&mdash;Who's there? my dearest? [<i>Softly.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> My life&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Right, right.&mdash;Where are thy lips? Here, take
the dumb and best welcomes, kisses and embraces; 'tis
not a time for idle words. In a duel of love, as in
others, parleying shows basely. Come, we are alone;
and now the word is only satisfaction, and defend not
thyself.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How's this? Why, she makes love like a devil in
a play; and in this darkness, which conceals her angel's
face, if I were apt to be afraid, I should think her a devil.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What, you traverse ground, young gentleman!
[<span class="smcap">Fidelia</span> <i>avoiding her.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I take breath only.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Good Heavens! how was I deceived! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_471" id="Page_471">[Pg 471]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, you are a coward; what, are you afraid of
the fierceness of my love?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Yes, madam, lest its violence might presage its
change; and I must needs be afraid you would leave
me quickly, who could desert so brave a gentleman as
Manly.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, name not his name! for in a time of stolen
joys, as this is, the filthy name of husband were not a
more allaying sound.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> There's some comfort yet. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But did you not love him?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Never. How could you think it?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Because he thought it; who is a man of that
sense, nice discerning, and diffidency, that I should
think it hard to deceive him.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No; he that distrusts most the world, trusts
most to himself, and is but the more easily deceived,
because he thinks he can't be deceived. His cunning is
like the coward's sword, by which he is oftener worsted
than defended.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Yet, sure, you used no common art to deceive
him.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I knew he loved his own singular moroseness so
well, as to dote upon any copy of it; wherefore I feigned
a hatred to the world too that he might love me in
earnest: but, if it had been hard to deceive him, I'm
sure 'twere much harder to love him. A dogged, ill-mannered&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> D'ye hear, sir? pray, hear her. [<i>Aside to</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Surly, untractable, snarling brute! He! a mastiff
dog were as fit a thing to make a gallant of.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay, a goat, or monkey, were fitter for thee.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I must confess, for my part, though my rival, I
cannot but say he has a manly handsomeness in's face
and mien.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> So has a Saracen in the sign.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_472" id="Page_472">[Pg 472]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Is proper, and well made.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> As a drayman.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Has wit.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> He rails at all mankind.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> And undoubted courage.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Like the hangman's; can murder a man when
his hands are tied. He has cruelty indeed; which is no
more courage, than his railing is wit.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thus women, and men like women, are too
hard for us, when they think we do not hear 'em: and
reputation, like other mistresses, is never true to a man
in his absence. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> He is&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Prithee, no more of him: I thought I had
satisfied you enough before, that he could never be a
rival for you to apprehend. And you need not be more
assured of my aversion to him, than by the last testimony
of my love to you; which I am ready to give you. Come,
my soul, this way. [<i>Pulls</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But, madam, what could make you dissemble love
to him, when 'twas so hard a thing for you; and flatter
his love to you?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> That which makes all the world flatter and dissemble,
'twas his money: I had a real passion for that.
Yet I loved not that so well, as for it to take him; for
as soon as I had his money I hastened his departure like
a wife, who when she has made the most of a dying
husband's breath, pulls away his pillow.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damned money! its master's potent rival still;
and like a saucy pimp, corrupts itself the mistress it procures
for us. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But I did not think with you, my life, to pass
my time in talking. Come hither, come; yet stay, till I
have locked a door in the other room, that may chance
to let us in some interruption; which reciting poets or
losing gamesters fear not more than I at this time do. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_473" id="Page_473">[Pg 473]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Well, I hope you are now satisfied, sir, and will
be gone to think of your revenge?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, I am not satisfied, and must stay to be
revenged.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> How, sir? You'll use no violence to her, I hope,
and forfeit your own life, to take away hers? that were
no revenge.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, no, you need not fear: my revenge shall
only be upon her honour, not her life.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> How, sir? her honour? O Heavens! consider,
sir, she has no honour. D'ye call that revenge? can you
think of such a thing? But reflect, sir, how she hates
and loathes you.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, so much she hates me, that it would be a
revenge sufficient to make her accessory to my pleasure,
and then let her know it.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> No, sir, no; to be revenged on her now, were to
disappoint her. Pray, sir, let us begone. [<i>Pulls</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Hold off! What, you are my rival then! and
therefore you shall stay, and keep the door for me, whilst
I go in for you; but when I'm gone, if you dare to stir
off from this very board, or breathe the least murmuring
accent, I'll cut her throat first; and if you love her, you
will not venture her life.&mdash;Nay, then I'll cut your throat
too; and I know you love your own life at least.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But, sir; good sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Not a word more, lest I begin my revenge on
her by killing you.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But are you sure 'tis revenge that makes you do
this? how can it be?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Whist!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> 'Tis a strange revenge, indeed.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> If you make me stay, I shall keep my word, and
begin with you. No more.
[<i>Exit at the same door</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>went out by.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i></p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">O Heavens! is there not punishment enough</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_474" id="Page_474">[Pg 474]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">In loving well, if you will have't a crime,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But you must add fresh torments daily to't,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And punish us like peevish rivals still,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Because we fain would find a heaven here?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But did there never any love like me,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">That untried tortures you must find me out?</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Others at worst, you force to kill themselves;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But I must be self-murdress of my love,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet will not grant me power to end my life,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">My cruel life; for when a lover's hopes</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Are dead and gone, life is unmerciful.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Sits down and weeps.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I have thought better on't: I must not discover
myself now I am without witnesses; for if I barely should
publish it, she would deny it with as much impudence, as
she would act it again with this young fellow here.&mdash;Where
are you?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Here&mdash;oh&mdash;now I suppose we may be gone.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I will; but not you. You must stay and act
the second part of a lover, that is, talk kindness to
her.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Not I, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No disputing, sir, you must; 'tis necessary to
my design of coming again to-morrow night.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> What, can you come again then hither?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes; and you must make the appointment, and
an apology for your leaving her so soon; for I have said
not a word to her; but have kept your counsel, as I
expect you should do mine. Do this faithfully, and I
promise you here, you shall run my fortune still, and we
will never part as long as we live; but if you do not do
it, expect not to live.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> 'Tis hard, sir; but such a consideration will make
it easier. You won't forget your promise, sir?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, by Heavens! But I hear her coming.
[<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_475" id="Page_475">[Pg 475]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Where is my life? Run from me already! You
do not love me, dearest; nay, you are angry with me, for
you would not so much as speak a kind word to me
within: what was the reason?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I was transported too much.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> That's kind.&mdash;But come, my soul, what make
you here? Let us go in again; we may be surprised in
this room, 'tis so near the stairs.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> No, we shall hear the better here, if anybody
should come up.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Nay, I assure you, we shall be secure enough
within: come, come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I am sick, and troubled with a sudden dizziness;
and cannot stir yet.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Come, I have spirits within.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> O! don't you hear a noise, madam?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> No, no; there is none: come, come. [<i>Pulls her.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Indeed there is; and I love you so much, I must
have a care of your honour, if you won't, and go; but to
come to you to-morrow night, if you please.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> With all my soul. But you must not go yet;
come, prithee.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Oh!&mdash;I'm now sicker, and am afraid of one of
my fits.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What fits?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Of the falling sickness; and I lie generally an
hour in a trance: therefore pray consider your honour
for the sake of my love, and let me go, that I may return
to you often.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> But will you be sure then to come to-morrow
night?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Swear.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> By our past kindness!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Well, go your ways then, if you will, you naughty<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_476" id="Page_476">[Pg 476]</a></span>
creature you.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.] These young lovers, with
their fears and modesty, make themselves as bad as old
ones to us; and I apprehend their bashfulness more than
their tattling.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> O madam, we're undone! There was a gentleman
upon the stairs, coming up with a candle, which made me
retire. Look you, here he comes!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>, <i>and his</i> Servant <i>with a light.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> How, my husband! Oh, undone indeed! This
way. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ha! You shall not escape me so, sir.
[<i>Stops</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> O Heavens! more fears, plagues, and torments
yet in store! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Come, sir, I guess what your business was here,
but this must be your business now. Draw. [<i>Draws.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Sir&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No expostulations; I shall not care to hear of't.
Draw.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Good sir!</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> How, you rascal! not courage to draw; yet durst
do me the greatest injury in the world? Thy cowardice
shall not save thy life. [<i>Offers to run at</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> O hold, sir, and send but your servant down,
and I'll satisfy you, sir, I could not injure you as you
imagine.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Leave the light and begone.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> Servant.]
Now, quickly, sir, what have you to say, or&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I am a woman, sir, a very unfortunate woman.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> How! a very handsome woman, I'm sure then:
here are witnesses of't too, I confess&mdash;[<i>Pulls off her
peruke and feels her breasts; then aside</i>,] Well, I'm glad
to find the tables turned; my wife is in more danger of
cuckolding than I was.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_477" id="Page_477">[Pg 477]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Now, sir, I hope you are so much a man of
honour, as to let me go, now I have satisfied you, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> When you have satisfied me, madam, I will.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I hope, sir, you are too much a gentleman to
urge those secrets from a woman which concern her
honour. You may guess my misfortune to be love by my
disguise: but a pair of breeches could not wrong you,
sir.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I may believe love has changed your outside,
which could not wrong me; but why did my wife run
away?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I know not, sir; perhaps because she would
not be forced to discover me to you, or to guide me from
your suspicions, that you might not discover me yourself;
which ungentlemanlike curiosity I hope you will cease to
have, and let me go.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Well, madam, if I must not know who you are,
'twill suffice for me only to know certainly what you are;
which you must not deny me. Come, there is a bed
within, the proper rack for lovers; and if you are a
woman, there you can keep no secrets; you'll tell me
there all unasked. Come. [<i>Pulls her.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Oh! what d'ye mean? Help! oh!</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I'll show you: but 'tis in vain to cry out: no one
dares help you; for I am lord here.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Tyrant here!&mdash;But if you are master of this
house, which I have taken for a sanctuary, do not violate
it yourself.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No, I'll preserve you here, and nothing shall
hurt you, and will be as true to you as your disguise;
but you must trust me then. Come, come. [<i>Pulls her.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Oh! oh! rather than you should drag me to a
deed so horrid and so shameful, I'll die here a thousand
deaths.&mdash;But you do not look like a ravisher, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Nor you like one would put me to't; but if you
will&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Oh! oh! help! help!</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_478" id="Page_478">[Pg 478]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> Servant.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> You saucy rascal, how durst you come in?
When you heard a woman squeak, that should have been
your cue to shut the door.</p>

<p><i>Serv.</i> I come, sir, to let you know, the alderman
coming home immediately after you were at his house,
has sent his cashier with the money, according to your
note.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Damn his money! Money never came to any,
sure, unseasonably till now. Bid him stay.</p>

<p><i>Serv.</i> He says, he cannot a moment.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Receive it you then.</p>

<p><i>Serv.</i> He says he must have your receipt for it:&mdash;he is
in haste, for I hear him coming up, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Damn him! Help me in here then with this
dishonourer of my family.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Oh! oh!</p>

<p><i>Serv.</i> You say she is a woman, sir.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No matter, sir: must you prate?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Oh Heavens! is there&mdash;[<i>They
thrust her in, and lock the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Stay there, my prisoner; you have a short reprieve.</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">I'll fetch the gold, and that she can't resist,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For with a full hand 'tis we ravish best.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>

<hr class="chap" />

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_479" id="Page_479">[Pg 479]</a></span></p>




<h3>ACT THE FIFTH.</h3>


<h4>SCENE I.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Eliza's</span> <i>Lodgings.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Eliza</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Ah, cousin! nothing troubles me
but that I have given the malicious
world its revenge, and reason now to
talk as freely of me as I used to do of
it.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Faith, then, let not that trouble
you; for, to be plain, cousin, the world
cannot talk worse of you than it did before.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> How, cousin! I'd have you to know, before this
<i>faux pas</i>, this trip of mine, the world could not talk
of me.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Only that you mind other people's actions so
much that you take no care of your own, but to hide
'em; that, like a thief, because you know yourself most
guilty, you impeach your fellow-criminals first, to clear
yourself.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O wicked world!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> That you pretend an aversion to all mankind in
public, only that their wives and mistresses may not be
jealous, and hinder you of their conversation in private.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Base world!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> That abroad you fasten quarrels upon innocent
men for talking of you, only to bring 'em to ask your<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_480" id="Page_480">[Pg 480]</a></span>
pardon at home, and to become dear friends with them,
who were hardly your acquaintance before.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Abominable world!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> That you condemn the obscenity of modern
plays, only that you may not be censured for never
missing the most obscene of the old ones.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Damned world!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> That you deface the nudities of pictures, and
little statues, only because they are not real.<a name="FNanchor_124_124" id="FNanchor_124_124"></a><a href="#Footnote_124_124" class="fnanchor">[124]</a></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, fy! fy! fy! hideous, hideous! Cousin, the
obscenity of their censures makes me blush!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> The truth of 'em, the naughty world would say
now.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span> <i>hastily.</i></p>

<p><i>Let.</i> O, madam! here is that gentleman coming up
who now you say is my master.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, cousin! whither shall I run? protect me, or&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Olivia</span>
<i>runs away, and stands at a distance.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Nay, nay, come&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, sir, forgive me!</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Yes, yes, I can forgive you being alone in the
dark with a woman in man's clothes: but have a care of
a man in woman's clothes.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What does he mean? he dissembles only to get
me into his power: or has my dear friend made him
believe he was a woman? My husband may be deceived
by him, but I'm sure I was not. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Come, come, you need not have lain out of your
house for this; but perhaps you were afraid, when I was
warm with suspicions, you must have discovered who she
was.&mdash;And, prithee, may I not know it?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> She was!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I hope he has been deceived:<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_481" id="Page_481">[Pg 481]</a></span>
and since my lover has played the card, I must not
renounce.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Come, what's the matter with thee? If I must not
know who she is, I'm satisfied without. Come hither.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Sure you do know her; she has told you herself,
I suppose.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No, I might have known her better but that I
was interrupted by the goldsmith, you know, and was
forced to lock her into your chamber, to keep her from
his sight; but, when I returned, I found she was got
away by tying the window-curtains to the balcony, by
which she slid down into the street. For, you must
know, I jested with her, and made her believe I'd ravish
her; which she apprehended, it seems, in earnest.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And she got from you?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And is quite gone?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Yes.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I'm glad on't&mdash;otherwise you had ravished her,
sir? But how durst you go so far, as to make her
believe you would ravish her? let me understand that,
sir. What! there's guilt in your face, you blush too:
nay, then you did ravish her, you did, you base fellow!
What, ravish a woman in the first month of our marriage!
'tis a double injury to me, thou base, ungrateful man!
wrong my bed already, villain! I could tear out those
false eyes, barbarous, unworthy wretch!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> So, so!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Prithee hear, my dear.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I will never hear you, my plague, my torment!</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I swear&mdash;prithee, hear me.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I have heard already too many of your false oaths
and vows, especially your last in the church. O wicked
man! and wretched woman that I was! I wish I had
then sunk down into a grave, rather than to have given
you my hand, to be led to your loathsome bed. Oh&mdash;Oh&mdash;[<i>Pretends
to weep.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_482" id="Page_482">[Pg 482]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> So, very fine! just a marriage-quarrel! which
though it generally begins by the wife's fault, yet, in the
conclusion, it becomes the husband's; and whosoever
offends at first, he only is sure to ask pardon at last. My
dear&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> My devil!&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Come, prithee be appeased, and go home; I have
bespoken our supper betimes: for I could not eat till I
found you. Go, I'll give you all kind of satisfactions; and
one, which uses to be a reconciling one, two hundred of
those guineas I received last night, to do what you will
with.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What, would you pay me for being your bawd?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Nay, prithee no more; go, and I'll thoroughly
satisfy you when I come home; and then, too, we will
have a fit of laughter at Manly, whom I am going to find
at the Cock in Bow-street, where I hear he dined. Go,
dearest, go home.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> A very pretty turn, indeed, this! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Now, cousin, since by my wife I have that honour
and privilege of calling you so, I have something to beg
of you too; which is not to take notice of our marriage
to any whatever yet a while, for some reasons very important
to me. And, next, that you will do my wife the
honour to go home with her; and me the favour, to use
that power you have with her, in our reconcilement.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> That I dare promise, sir, will be no hard matter.
Your servant.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.]&mdash;Well, cousin, this, I
confess, was reasonable hypocrisy; you were the better
for't.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What hypocrisy?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Why, this last deceit of your husband was lawful,
since in your own defence.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What deceit? I'd have you to know I never
deceived my husband.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> You do not understand me, sure: I say, this
was an honest come-off, and a good one. But 'twas a<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_483" id="Page_483">[Pg 483]</a></span>
sign your gallant had had enough of your conversation,
since he could so dexterously cheat your husband in
passing for a woman.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What d'ye mean, once more, with my gallant
and passing for a woman?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> What do you mean? you see your husband took
him for a woman.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Whom?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Heyday! why, the man he found you with,
for whom last night you were so much afraid; and who
you told me&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Lord, you rave sure!</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Why, did you not tell me last night&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> I know not what I might tell you last night, in a
fright.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Ay, what was that fright for? for a woman?
besides, were you not afraid to see your husband just
now? I warrant only for having been found with a
woman! Nay, did you not just now, too, own your
false step, or trip, as you called it? which was with a
woman too! fy, this fooling is so insipid, 'tis offensive!</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And fooling with my honour will be more
offensive. Did you not hear my husband say he found
me with a woman in man's clothes? and d'ye think he
does not know a man from a woman?</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Not so well, I'm sure, as you do; therefore I'd
rather take your word.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> What, you grow scurrilous, and are, I find, more
censorious than the world! I must have a care of you,
I see.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> No, you need not fear yet, I'll keep your secret.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> My secret! I'd have you to know, I have no
need of confidants, though you value yourself upon being
a good one.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> O admirable confidence! you show more in
denying your wickedness, than other people in glorying
in't.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_484" id="Page_484">[Pg 484]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Confidence, to me! to me such language! nay,
then I'll never see your face again.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I'll quarrel
with her, that people may never believe I was in her
power; but take for malice all the truth she may speak
against me.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] Lettice, where are you! Let us
be gone from this censorious ill woman.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Nay, thou shalt stay a little, to damn
thyself quite.&mdash;[<i>Aloud.</i>] One word first, pray, madam;
can you swear that whom your husband found you with&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Swear! ay, that whosoever 'twas that stole up,
unknown, into my room, when 'twas dark, I know not,
whether man or woman, by Heavens! by all that's good;
or, may I never more have joys here, or in the other
world! Nay, may I eternally&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Be damned. So, so, you are damned enough
already by your oaths; and I enough confirmed, and
now you may please to be gone. Yet take this advice
with you, in this plain-dealing age, to leave off forswearing
yourself; for when people hardly think the better of
a woman for her real modesty, why should you put that
great constraint upon yourself to feign it?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O hideous, hideous advice! let us go out of the
hearing of it. She will spoil us, Lettice.</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span> <i>at one door</i>, <span class="smcap">Eliza</span>
<i>at the other.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE II.&mdash;<i>The Cock in Bow Street. A table and
bottles.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How! saved her honour by making her husband
believe you were a woman! 'Twas well, but hard enough
to do, sure.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> We were interrupted before he could contradict
me.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_485" id="Page_485">[Pg 485]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But can't you tell me, d'ye say, what kind of
man he was?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I was so frightened, I confess, I can give no other
account of him, but that he was pretty tall, round-faced,
and one, I'm sure, I ne'er had seen before.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But she, you say, made you swear to return to-night?</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But I have since sworn, never to go near her
again; for the husband would murder me, or worse, if he
caught me again.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, I will go with you, and defend you to-night,
and then I'll swear, too, never to go near her again.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nay, indeed, sir, I will not go, to be accessory to
your death too. Besides, what should you go again, sir,
for?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No disputing, or advice, sir, you have reason to
know I am unalterable. Go therefore presently, and write
her a note, to inquire if her assignation with you holds;
and if not to be at her own house, where else; and be
importunate to gain admittance to her to-night. Let
your messenger, ere he deliver your letter, inquire first if
her husband be gone out. Go, 'tis now almost six of the
clock; I expect you back here before seven, with leave
to see her then. Go, do this dextrously, and expect the
performance of my last night's promise, never to part
with you.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Ay, sir; but will you be sure to remember that?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Did I ever break my word? Go, no more replies,
or doubts. [<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p>Where hast thou been?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> In the next room with my Lord Plausible and
Novel.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay, we came hither, because 'twas a private
house; but with thee indeed no house can be private,
for thou hast that pretty quality of the familiar fops of<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_486" id="Page_486">[Pg 486]</a></span>
the town, who, in an eating-house, always keep company
with all people in't but those they came with.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I went into their room, but to keep them, and
my own fool the squire, out of your room; but you shall
be peevish now, because you have no money. But why
the devil won't you write to those we were speaking of?
Since your modesty, or your spirit, will not suffer you to
speak to 'em, to lend you money, why won't you try 'em
at last that way?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Because I know 'em already, and can bear want
better than denials, nay, than obligations.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Deny you! they cannot. All of 'em have been
your intimate friends.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, they have been people only I have obliged
particularly.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Very well; therefore you ought to go to 'em the
rather, sure.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, no. Those you have obliged most, most
certainly avoid you, when you can oblige 'em no longer;
and they take your visits like so many duns. Friends,
like mistresses, are avoided for obligations past.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Pshaw! but most of 'em are your relations;
men of great fortune and honour.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes; but relations have so much honour as to
think poverty taints the blood, and disown their wanting
kindred; believing, I suppose, that as riches at first make
a gentleman, the want of 'em degrades him. But damn
'em! now I am poor, I'll anticipate their contempt, and
disown them.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> But you have many a female acquaintance whom
you have been liberal to, who may have a heart to refund
to you a little, if you would ask it: they are not all
Olivias.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn thee! how couldst thou think of such a
thing? I would as soon rob my footman of his wages.
Besides, 'twere in vain too: for a wench is like a box in
an ordinary, receives all people's money easily, but there<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_487" id="Page_487">[Pg 487]</a></span>
is no getting, nay, shaking any out again; and he that
fills it is sure never to keep the key.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, but noble captain, would you make me
believe that you, who know half the town, have so many
friends, and have obliged so many, can't borrow fifty or
a hundred pounds?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Why, noble lieutenant, you who know all the
town, and call all you know friends, methinks should not
wonder at it; since you find ingratitude too. For how
many lords' families (though descended from blacksmiths
or tinkers) hast thou called great and illustrious? how
many ill tables called good eating? how many noisy coxcombs
wits? how many pert cocking<a name="FNanchor_125_125" id="FNanchor_125_125"></a><a href="#Footnote_125_125" class="fnanchor">[125]</a> cowards stout?
