how many tawdry affected rogues well-dressed? how
many perukes admired? and how many ill verses
applauded? and yet canst not borrow a shilling. Dost
thou expect I, who always spoke truth, should?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Nay, now you think you have paid me; but
hark you, captain, I have heard of a thing called grinning
honour, but never of starving honour.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, but it has been the fate of some brave
men; and if they won't give me a ship again, I can go
starve anywhere with a musket on my shoulder.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Give you a ship! why, you will not solicit it.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> If I have not solicited it by my services, I know
no other way.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Your servant, sir; nay, then I'm satisfied, I must
solicit my widow the closer, and run the desperate fortune
of matrimony on shore. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> How!&mdash;Nay, here is a friend indeed; and he
that has him in his arms can know no wants.
[<i>Embraces</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Dear sir! and he that is in your arms is secure
from all fears whatever: nay, our nation is secure by<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_488" id="Page_488">[Pg 488]</a></span>
your defeat at sea, and the Dutch that fought against you
have proved enemies to themselves only in bringing you
back to us.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Fy! fy! this from a friend? and yet from any
other 'twere insufferable: I thought I should never have
taken anything ill from you.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> A friend's privilege is to speak his mind, though
it be taken ill.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But your tongue need not tell me you think too
well of me; I have found it from your heart, which
spoke in actions, your unalterable heart. But Olivia is
false, my friend, which I suppose is no news to you.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> He's in the right on't. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But couldst thou not keep her true to me?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Not for my heart, sir.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But could you not perceive it at all before I
went? Could she so deceive us both?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I must confess, the first time I knew it was three
days after your departure, when she received the money
you had left in Lombard-street in her name; and her
tears did not hinder her, it seems, from counting that.
You would trust her with all, like a true generous lover.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> And she like a mean jilting&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Traitorous&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Base&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Damned&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Covetous&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Mercenary whore.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I can hardly hold
from laughing.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay, a mercenary whore indeed; for she made
me pay her before I lay with her.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> How!&mdash;Why, have you lain with her?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Nay, she deserves you should report it at least,
though you have not.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Report it! by Heaven, 'tis true!</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> How! sure not.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_489" id="Page_489">[Pg 489]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I do not use to lie, nor you to doubt me.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> When?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Last night, about seven or eight of the clock.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ha!&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Now I remember, I thought she
spake as if she expected some other rather than me. A
confounded whore, indeed!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But what, thou wonderest at it! nay, you seem
to be angry too.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I cannot but be enraged against her, for her
usage of you: damned infamous, common jade!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, her cuckold, who first cuckolded me in my
money, shall not laugh all himself: we will do him reason,
shan't we?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ay, ay.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But thou dost not, for so great a friend, take
pleasure enough in your friend's revenge, methinks.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Yes, yes; I'm glad to know it, since you have
lain with her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou canst not tell who that rascal, her cuckold,
is?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> No.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> She would keep it from you, I suppose.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Yes, yes.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Thou wouldst laugh, if thou knewest but all
the circumstances of my having her. Come, I'll tell
thee.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Damn her! I care not to hear any more of her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Faith, thou shalt. You must know&mdash;</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span> <i>backwards, endeavouring to keep out</i>
<span class="smcap">Novel</span>, Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible, Jerry Blackacre</span>, <i>and</i>
Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>, <i>who all press upon him.</i></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I tell you he has a wench with him, and would
be private.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Damn 'em! a man can't open a bottle in these
eating-houses, but presently you have these impudent,
intruding, buzzing flies and insects in your glass.&mdash;Well,<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_490" id="Page_490">[Pg 490]</a></span>
I'll tell thee all anon. In the mean time prithee go to
her, but not from me, and try if you can get her to lend
me but a hundred pounds of my money, to supply my
present wants; for I suppose there is no recovering any
of it by law.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Not any: think not of it. Nor by this way
neither.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Go try, at least.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I'll go; but I can satisfy you beforehand it will
be to no purpose. You'll no more find a refunding
wench&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Than a refunding lawyer; indeed their fees
alike scarce ever return. However, try her; put it to
her.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ay, ay, I'll try her; put it to her home with a
vengeance. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nay, you shall be our judge, Manly&mdash;Come,
major, I'll speak it to your teeth; if people provoke me
to say bitter things to their faces, they must take what
follows; though, like my lord Plausible, I'd rather do't
civilly behind their backs.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, thou art a dangerous rogue, I've heard,
behind a man's back.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> You wrong him sure, noble captain; he
would do a man no more harm behind his back than to
his face.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I am of my lord's mind.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, a fool, like a coward, is the more to be,
feared behind a man's back, more than a witty man; for
as a coward is more bloody than a brave man, a fool is
more malicious than a man of wit.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> A fool, tar,&mdash;a fool! nay, thou art a brave sea-judge
of wit! a fool! Prithee when did you ever find
me want something to say, as you do often?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, I confess thou art always talking, roaring,
or making a noise; that I'll say for thee.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well, and is talking a sign of a fool?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_491" id="Page_491">[Pg 491]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Yes, always talking, especially too if it be loud
and fast, is the sign of a fool.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Pshaw! talking is like fencing, the quicker the
better; run 'em down, run 'em down, no matter for
parrying; push on still, sa, sa, sa! No matter whether
you argue in form, push in guard or no.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Or hit or no; I think thou always talkest
without thinking, Novel.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Ay, ay; studied play's the worse, to follow the
allegory, as the old pedant says.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> A young fop!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I ever thought the man of most wit had been
like him of most money, who has no vanity in showing it
everywhere, whilst the beggarly pusher of his fortune has
all he has about him still only to show.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Well, sir, and make a pretty show in the world,
let me tell you; nay, a better than your close hunks. A
pox, give me ready money in play! what care I for a
man's reputation? what are we the better for your
substantial thrifty curmudgeon in wit, sir?</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Thou art a profuse young rogue indeed.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> So much for talking, which, I think, I have
proved a mark of wit; and so is railing, roaring, and
making a noise; for railing is satire, you know; and
roaring and making a noise, humour.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>; <i>she takes</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>aside, and shows
him a paper.</i></p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> The hour is betwixt seven and eight exactly: 'tis
now half an hour to six.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, go then to the Piazza, and wait for me:
as soon as it is quite dark, I'll be with you. I must stay
here yet a while for my friend.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.] But is
railing satire, Novel?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And roaring and making a noise, humour?</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> What, won't you confess there's humour in
roaring and making a noise?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_492" id="Page_492">[Pg 492]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Nor in cutting napkins and hangings?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, sure.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Dull fops!</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> O rogue, rogue, insipid rogue!&mdash;Nay, gentlemen,
allow him those things for wit; for his parts lie only that
way.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Peace, old fool! I wonder not at thee; but that
young fellows should be so dull, as to say there's no
humour in making a noise, and breaking windows! I
tell you there's wit and humour too in both; and a wit
is as well known by his frolic as by his smile.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Pure rogue! there's your modern wit for you!
Wit and humour in breaking of windows: there's mischief,
if you will, but no wit or humour.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Prithee, prithee, peace, old fool! I tell you,
where there's mischief, there's wit. Don't we esteem the
monkey a wit amongst beasts, only because he's mischievous?
and, let me tell you, as good-nature is a sign
of a fool, being mischievous is a sign of a wit.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> O rogue, rogue! pretend to be a wit, by doing
mischief and railing!</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Why, thou, old fool, hast no other pretence to
the name of a wit, but by railing at new plays!</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Thou, by railing at that facetious noble way of
wit, quibbling!</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Thou callest thy dulness gravity; and thy dozing,
thinking.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> You, sir, your dulness, spleen; and you talk
much and say nothing.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Thou readest much, and understandest nothing, sir.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> You laugh loud, and break no jest.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> You rail, and nobody hangs himself; and thou
hast nothing of the satire but in thy face.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> And you have no jest, but your face, sir.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> Thou art an illiterate pedant.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Thou art a fool with a bad memory.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_493" id="Page_493">[Pg 493]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Come, a pox on you both! you have done like
wits now: for you wits, when you quarrel, never give
over till ye prove one another fools.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And you fools have never any occasion of laughing
at us wits but when we quarrel. Therefore let us be
friends, Oldfox.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> They are such wits as thou art, who make the
name of a wit as scandalous as that of bully: and signify
a loud-laughing, talking, incorrigible, coxcomb, as bully a
roaring hardened coward.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> And would have his noise and laughter pass for
wit, as t'other his huffing and blustering for courage.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Gentlemen, with your leave, here is one I would
speak with; and I have nothing to say to you.
[<i>Puts all out of the room except</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I told you 'twas in vain to think of getting money
out of her. She says, if a shilling would do't, she would
not save you from starving or hanging, or what you
would think worse, begging or flattering; and rails so at
you, one would not think you had lain with her.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> O, friend, never trust for that matter a woman's
railing; for she is no less a dissembler in her hatred than
her love; and as her fondness of her husband is a sign
he's a cuckold, her railing at another man is a sign she
lies with him.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> He's in the right on't: I know not what to trust
to. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But you did not take any notice of it to her, I
hope?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> So!&mdash;Sure he is afraid I should have disproved
him by an inquiry of her: all may be well yet. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What hast thou in thy head that makes thee
seem so unquiet?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Only this base impudent woman's falseness; I
cannot put her out of my head.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_494" id="Page_494">[Pg 494]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> O, my dear friend, be not you too sensible of
my wrongs; for then I shall feel 'em too with more pain,
and think 'em unsufferable. Damn her, her money, and
that ill-natured whore too, Fortune herself! But if thou
wouldst ease a little my present trouble, prithee go borrow
me somewhere else some money. I can trouble thee.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> You trouble me, indeed, most sensibly, when you
command me anything I cannot do. I have lately lost a
great deal of money at play, more than I can yet pay; so
that not only my money, but my credit too is gone, and
know not where to borrow: but could rob a church for
you.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] Yet would rather end your wants by
cutting your throat.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, then I doubly feel my poverty, since I'm
incapable of supplying thee. [<i>Embraces him.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> But, methinks, she that granted you the last
favour, (as they call it,) should not deny you anything.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> [<i>Looking in.</i>] Hey, tarpaulin, have you done?
[<i>Retires again.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I understand not that point of kindness, I confess.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, thou dost not understand it, and I have not
time to let you know all now; for these fools, you see,
will interrupt us: but anon, at supper, we'll laugh at
leisure together at Olivia's cuckold, who took a young
fellow, that goes between his wife and me, for a woman.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ha!</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Senseless, easy rascal! 'twas no wonder she
chose him for a husband; but she thought him, I thank
her, fitter than me, for that blind bearing office.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> I could not be deceived in that long woman's
hair tied up behind, nor those infallible proofs, her
pouting swelling breasts: I have handled too many sure
not to know 'em. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> What, you wonder the fellow could be such a
blind coxcomb?</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Yes, yes&mdash;</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_495" id="Page_495">[Pg 495]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> [<i>Looking in again.</i>] Nay, prithee, come to us,
Manly. Gad, all the fine things one says in their company,
are lost without thee.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Away, fop! I'm busy yet. [<span class="smcap">Novel</span> <i>retires.</i>]
You see we cannot talk here at our ease: besides, I must
be gone immediately, in order to meeting with Olivia
again to-night.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> To-night! it cannot be, sure&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> I had an appointment just now from her.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> For what time?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> At half an hour after seven precisely.</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Don't you apprehend the husband?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> He! snivelling gull! he a thing to be feared! a
husband! the tamest of creatures!</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Very fine! [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But, prithee, in the mean time, go try to get me
some money. Though thou art too modest to borrow
for thyself, thou canst do anything for me, I know. Go;
for I must be gone to Olivia. Go, and meet me here,
anon.&mdash;Freeman, where are you? [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Ay, I'll meet with you, I warrant; but it shall be
at Olivia's. Sure, it cannot be: she denies it so calmly,
and with that honest modest assurance, it cannot be true&mdash;and
he does not use to lie&mdash;but belying a woman
when she won't be kind, is the only lie a brave man will
least scruple. But then the woman in man's clothes,
whom he calls a man&mdash;well, but by her breasts I know
her to be a woman&mdash;but then again, his appointment
from her, to meet him again to-night! I am distracted
more with doubt than jealousy. Well, I have no way to
disabuse or revenge myself, but by going home immediately,
putting on a riding-suit, and pretending to my
wife the same business which carried me out of town
last, requires me again to go post to Oxford to-night.
Then, if the appointment he boasts of be true, it's sure to
hold, and I shall have an opportunity either of clearing
her, or revenging myself on both. Perhaps she is his<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_496" id="Page_496">[Pg 496]</a></span>
wench, of an old date, and I am his cully, whilst I think
him mine; and he has seemed to make his wench rich,
only that I might take her off his hands. Or if he has
but lately lain with her, he must needs discover by her
my treachery to him; which I'm sure he will revenge
with my death, and which I must prevent with his, if it
were only but for fear of his too just reproaches; for I
must confess, I never had till now any excuse but that of
interest, for doing ill to him. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Come hither; only, I say, be sure you mistake
not the time. You know the house exactly where Olivia
lodges, 'tis just hard by.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Yes, yes.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well then, bring 'em all, I say, thither, and all
you know that may be then in the house; for the
more witnesses I have of her infamy, the greater will be
my revenge: and be sure you come straight up to her
chamber without more ado. Here, take the watch; you
see 'tis above a quarter past seven; be there in half an
hour exactly.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> You need not doubt my diligence or dexterity;
I am an old scourer, and can naturally beat up a
wench's quarters that won't be civil. Shan't we break
her windows too?</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, no; be punctual only. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE III.&mdash;<i>A Room in the same.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>, <i>and two</i> Knights of the Post,<a name="FNanchor_126_126" id="FNanchor_126_126"></a><a href="#Footnote_126_126" class="fnanchor">[126]</a>
<i>a</i> Waiter <i>following with wine.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Sweetheart, are you sure the door was shut
close, that none of those roysters saw us come in?</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_497" id="Page_497">[Pg 497]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Wait.</i> Yes, mistress; and you shall have a privater
room above, instantly. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> You are safe enough, gentlemen; for I have
been private in this house ere now, upon other occasions,
when I was something younger. Come, gentlemen; in
short, I leave my business to your care and fidelity: and
so here's to you.</p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> We are ungrateful rogues if we should not
be honest to you; for we have had a great deal of your
money.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> And you have done me many a good job for't;
and so, here's to you again.</p>

<p><i>2nd Knight.</i> Why, we have been perjured but six times
for you.</p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> Forged but four deeds, with your husband's
last deed of gift.</p>

<p><i>2nd Knight.</i> And but three wills.</p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> And counterfeited hands and seals to some
six bonds; I think that's all, brother?</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Ay, that's all, gentlemen; and so, here's to you
again.</p>

<p><i>2nd Knight.</i> Nay, 'twould do one's heart good to be
forsworn for you. You have a conscience in your ways,
and pay us well.</p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> You are in the right on't, brother; one
would be damned for her with all one's heart.</p>

<p><i>2nd Knight.</i> But there are rogues, who make us forsworn
for 'em; and when we come to be paid, they'll be forsworn
too, and not pay us our wages, which they promised
with oaths sufficient.</p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> Ay, a great lawyer that shall be nameless
bilked me too.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> That was hard, methinks, that a lawyer should
use gentlemen witnesses no better.</p>

<p><i>2nd Knight.</i> A lawyer! d'ye wonder a lawyer should
do't? I was bilked by a reverend divine, that preaches<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_498" id="Page_498">[Pg 498]</a></span>
twice on Sundays, and prays half an hour still before
dinner.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How! a conscientious divine and not pay people
for damning themselves! sure then, for all his talking, he
does not believe damnation. But, come, to our business.
Pray be sure to imitate exactly the flourish at the end of
this name. [<i>Pulls out a deed or two.</i></p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> O, he's the best in England at untangling
a flourish, madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> And let not the seal be a jot bigger. Observe
well the dash too, at the end of this name.</p>

<p><i>2nd Knight.</i> I warrant you, madam.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Well, these and many other shifts, poor widows
are put to sometimes; for everybody would be riding a
widow, as they say, and breaking into her jointure. They
think marrying a widow an easy business, like leaping the
hedge where another has gone over before. A widow is
a mere gap, a gap with them.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> Major <span class="smcap">Oldfox</span>, <i>with two</i> Waiters. <i>The</i> Knights
of the Post <i>huddle up the writings.</i></p>

<p>What, he here! Go then, go my hearts, you have your
instructions. [<i>Exeunt</i> Knights of the Post.</p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Come, madam, to be plain with you, I'll be fobbed
off no longer.&mdash;[<i>Aside.</i>] I'll bind her and gag her but she
shall hear me.&mdash;[<i>To the</i> Waiters.] Look you, friends, there's
the money I promised you; and now do you what you
promised me: here my garters, and here's a gag.&mdash;[<i>To
the</i> Widow.] You shall be acquainted with my parts, lady,
you shall.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Acquainted with your parts! A rape! a rape!&mdash;what,
will you ravish me?
[<i>The</i> Waiters <i>tie her to the chair, gag her, and exeunt.</i></p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Yes, lady, I will ravish you: but it shall be
through the ear, lady, the ear only, with my well-penned
acrostics.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_499" id="Page_499">[Pg 499]</a></span></p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman, Jerry Blackacre</span>, <i>three</i> Bailiffs, <i>a</i>
Constable, <i>and his</i> Assistants <i>with the two</i> Knights
of the Post.</p>

<p>What, shall I never read my things undisturbed again?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> O la! my mother bound hand and foot, and
gaping as if she rose before her time to-day!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> What means this, Oldfox? But I'll release you
from him; you shall be no man's prisoner but mine.
Bailiffs, execute your writ. [<i>Unties her.</i></p>

<p><i>Old.</i> Nay, then, I'll be gone, for fear of being bail,
and paying her debts without being her husband. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>1st Bail.</i> We arrest you in the king's name, at the suit
of Mr. Freeman, guardian to Jeremiah Blackacre, esquire,
in an action of ten thousand pounds.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How, how, in a choke-bail action! What, and
the pen and-ink gentlemen taken too!&mdash;Have you confessed,
you rogues?</p>

<p><i>1st Knight.</i> We needed not to confess; for the bailiffs
have dogged us hither to the very door, and overheard
all that you and we said.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Undone, undone then! no man was ever too
hard for me till now. O Jerry, child, wilt thou vex again
the womb that bore thee?</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, for bearing me before wedlock, as you say.
But I'll teach you call a Blackacre bastard, though you
were never so much my mother.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Well, I'm undone! not one trick left?
no law-mesh imaginable?&mdash;[<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>.] Cruel sir, a
word with you, I pray.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> In vain, madam; for you have no other way to
release yourself but by the bonds of matrimony.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> How, sir, how! that were but to sue out a
habeas-corpus, for a removal from one prison to another.&mdash;Matrimony!</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, bailiffs, away with her.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> O stay, sir! can you be so cruel as to bring me<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_500" id="Page_500">[Pg 500]</a></span>
under covert-baron<a name="FNanchor_127_127" id="FNanchor_127_127"></a><a href="#Footnote_127_127" class="fnanchor">[127]</a> again, and put it out of my power to
sue in my own name? Matrimony to a woman is worse
than excommunication, in depriving her of the benefit of
the law; and I would rather be deprived of life. But
hark you, sir, I am contented you should hold and enjoy my
person by lease or patent, but not by the spiritual patent
called a licence; that is, to have the privileges of a husband,
without the dominion; that is, <i>Durante beneplacito</i>.
In consideration of which, I will out of my jointure secure
you an annuity of three hundred pounds a year, and pay
your debts; and that's all you younger brothers desire to
marry a widow for, I'm sure.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Well, widow, if&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> What! I hope, bully-guardian, you are not making
agreements without me?</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> No, no. First, widow, you must say no more that
he is a son of a whore; have a care of that. And, then, he
must have a settled exhibition of forty pounds a year, and
a nag of assizes, kept by you, but not upon the common;
and have free ingress, egress, and regress, to and from
your maids' garret.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Well, I can grant all that too.</p>

<p><i>Jer.</i> Ay, ay, fair words butter no cabbage: but guardian,
make her sign, sign and seal; for otherwise, if you
knew her as well as I, you would not trust her word for a
farthing.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I warrant thee, squire.&mdash;Well, widow, since thou
art so generous, I will be generous too; and if you'll
secure me four hundred pounds a year, but during your
life, and pay my debts, not above a thousand pounds, I'll
bate you your person, to dispose of as you please.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> Have a care, sir, a settlement without a
consideration is void in law; you must do something
for't.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> Prithee, then let the settlement on me be called
alimony; and the consideration, our separation. Come;<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_501" id="Page_501">[Pg 501]</a></span>
my lawyer, with writings ready drawn, is within, and in
haste. Come.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> But, what, no other kind of consideration, Mr.
Freeman? Well, a widow, I see, is a kind of sinecure,
by custom of which the unconscionable incumbent
enjoys the profits, without any duty, but does that still
elsewhere. [<i>Exeunt.</i></p>


<h4>SCENE IV.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Olivia's</span> <i>Lodging.</i></h4>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>with a candle in her hand.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> So, I am now prepared once more for my
timorous young lover's reception. My husband is gone;
and go thou out too, thou next interrupter of love.&mdash;[<i>Puts
out the candle.</i>] Kind darkness, that frees us lovers from
scandal and bashfulness, from the censure of our gallants
and the world!&mdash;So, are you there?</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>, <i>followed softly by</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>.</p>

<p>Come, my dear punctual lover, there is not such another
in the world; thou hast beauty and youth to please a
wife; address and wit, to amuse and fool a husband;
nay, thou hast all things to be wished in a lover, but
your fits. I hope, my dear, you won't have one to-night;
and that you may not, I'll lock the door, though there be
no need of it, but to lock out your fits: for my husband
is just gone out of town again. Come, where are you?
[<i>Goes to the door and locks it.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Well, thou hast impudence enough to give me
fits too, and make revenge itself impotent; hinder me
from making thee yet more infamous, if it can be.
[<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Come, come, my soul, come.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Presently, my dear, we have time enough sure.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> How, time enough! True lovers can no more<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_502" id="Page_502">[Pg 502]</a></span>
think they ever have time enough, than love enough.
You shall stay with me all night; but that is but a lover's
moment. Come.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> But won't you let me give you and myself the
satisfaction of telling you how I abused your husband
last night?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Not when you can give me, and yourself too,
the satisfaction of abusing him again to-night. Come.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Let me but tell you how your husband&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O name not his, or Manly's more loathsome
name, if you love me! I forbid 'em last night: and you
know I mentioned my husband but once, and he came.
No talking, pray, 'twas ominous to us.&mdash;[<i>A noise at the
door.</i>] You make me fancy a noise at the door already,
but I'm resolved not to be interrupted. Where are you?
Come, for rather than lose my dear expectation now, though
my husband were at the door, and the bloody ruffian
Manly here in the room, with all his awful insolence, I
would give myself to this dear hand, to be led away to
heavens of joys, which none but thou canst give.&mdash;[<i>The
noise at the door increases.</i>] But what's this noise at the door?
So, I told you what talking would come to. Ha!&mdash;O
Heavens, my husband's voice!&mdash;[<i>Listens at the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>Aside.</i>] Freeman is come too soon.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> O, 'tis he!&mdash;Then here's the happiest minute lost
that ever bashful boy or trifling woman fooled away! I'm
undone! my husband's reconcilement too was false, as
my joy all delusion. But come this way, here's a back
door.&mdash;[<i>Exit, and returns.</i>] The officious jade has locked
us in, instead of locking others out: but let us then escape
your way, by the balcony; and whilst you pull down the
curtains, I'll fetch from my closet what next will best
secure our escape. I have left my key in the door, and
'twill not suddenly be broken open. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p class="center">[<i>A noise as if people were forcing the door.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Stir not, yet fear nothing.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Nothing but your life, sir.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_503" id="Page_503">[Pg 503]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> We shall know this happy man she calls husband.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Re-enter</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Oh, where are you? What, idle with fear?
Come, I'll tie the curtains, if you will hold. Here take
this cabinet and purse, for it is thine, if we escape;&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Manly</span>
<i>takes them from her</i>]&mdash;therefore let us make
haste. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> 'Tis mine indeed now again, and it shall never
escape more from me, to you at least.
[<i>The door is broke open, enter</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span> <i>with a dark-lantern
and a sword, running at</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>, <i>who
draws, puts by the thrust, and defends himself,
whilst</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span> <i>runs at</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span> <i>behind.</i></p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> So, there I'm right, sure&mdash;[<i>In a low voice.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>Softly.</i>] Sword and dark-lantern, villain, are
some odds; but&mdash;</p>

<p><i>Ver.</i> Odds! I'm sure I find more odds than I expected.
What, has my insatiable two seconds at once? but&mdash;[<i>In
a low voice.</i></p>

<p class="center">[<i>Whilst they fight</i>, <span class="smcap">Olivia</span> <i>re-enters, tying two
curtains together.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Where are you now?&mdash;What, is he entered then,
and are they fighting? O do not kill one that can make
no defence!&mdash;[<span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>throws</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span> <i>down and disarms
him.</i>] How! but I think he has the better on't. Here's
his scarf, 'tis he. So, keep him down still: I hope thou
hast no hurt, my dearest? [<i>Embracing</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span>.</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Freeman</span>, Lord <span class="smcap">Plausible, Novel, Jerry
Blackacre</span>, <i>and</i> Widow <span class="smcap">Blackacre</span>, <i>lighted by
the two</i> Sailors <i>with torches.</i></p>

<p>Ha!&mdash;what! Manly! and have I been thus concerned
for him! embracing him! and has he his jewels again
too! What means this? O, 'tis too sure, as well as my
shame! which I'll go hide for ever.
[<i>Offers to go out,</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>stops her.</i></p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_504" id="Page_504">[Pg 504]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> No, my dearest; after so much kindness as has
passed between us, I cannot part with you yet.&mdash;Freeman,
let nobody stir out of the room; for notwithstanding your
lights, we are yet in the dark, till this gentleman please
to turn his face&mdash;[<i>Pulls</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span> <i>by the sleeve.</i>] How,
Vernish! art thou the happy man then? thou! thou!
speak, I say; but thy guilty silence tells me all.&mdash;Well,
I shall not upbraid thee; for my wonder is striking me as
dumb as thy shame has made thee. But what? my little
volunteer hurt, and fainting!</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> My wound, sir, is but a slight one in my arm; 'tis
only my fear of your danger, sir, not yet well over.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> But what's here? more strange things&mdash;[<i>Observing</i>
<span class="smcap">Fidelia's</span> <i>hair untied behind, and without a peruke,
which she lost in the scuffle.</i>] What means this long
woman's hair, and face! now all of it appears too beautiful
for a man; which I still thought womanish indeed!
What, you have not deceived me too, my little volunteer?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Me she has, I'm sure. [<i>Aside.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Speak!</p>

<p class="center"><i>Enter</i> <span class="smcap">Eliza</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Lettice</span>.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> What, cousin, I am brought hither by your
woman, I suppose, to be a witness of the second vindication
of your honour?</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> Insulting is not generous. You might spare me,
I have you.</p>

<p><i>Eliza.</i> Have a care, cousin, you'll confess anon too
much; and I would not have your secrets.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Come, your blushes answer me sufficiently, and
you have been my volunteer in love. [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> I must confess I needed no compulsion to follow
you all the world over; which I attempted in this habit,
partly out of shame to own my love to you, and fear of a
greater shame, your refusal of it; for I knew of your
engagement to this lady, and the constancy of your
nature; which nothing could have altered but herself.</p>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_505" id="Page_505">[Pg 505]</a></span></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Dear madam, I desired you to bring me out of
confusion, and you have given me more. I know not
what to speak to you, or how to look upon you; the
sense of my rough, hard, and ill usage of you, (though
chiefly your own fault,) gives me more pain now 'tis over,
than you had when you suffered it: and if my heart, the
refusal of such a woman&mdash;[<i>Pointing to</i> <span class="smcap">Olivia</span>]&mdash;were not
a sacrifice to profane your love, and a greater wrong to
you than ever yet I did you, I would beg of you to
receive it, though you used it as she had done; for
though it deserved not from her the treatment she gave
it, it does from you.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Then it has had punishment sufficient from her
already, and needs no more from me; and, I must confess,
I would not be the only cause of making you break
your last night's oath to me, of never parting with me; if
you do not forget or repent it.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Then take for ever my heart, and this with it;&mdash;[<i>Gives
her the cabinet</i>] for 'twas given to you before, and
my heart was before your due: I only beg leave to dispose
of these few.&mdash;Here, madam, I never yet left my
wench unpaid.
[<i>Takes some of the jewels, and offers them to</i>
<span class="smcap">Olivia</span>; <i>she strikes them down</i>: Lord
<span class="smcap">Plausible</span> <i>and</i> <span class="smcap">Novel</span> <i>take them up.</i></p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> So it seems, by giving her the cabinet.</p>

<p><i>L. Plau.</i> These pendants appertain to your most
faithful humble servant.</p>

<p><i>Nov.</i> And this locket is mine; my earnest for love,
which she never paid: therefore my own again.</p>

<p><i>Wid.</i> By what law, sir, pray?&mdash;Cousin Olivia, a word.
What, do they make a seizure on your goods and chattels,
<i>vi et armis</i>? Make your demand, I say, and bring your
trover, bring your trover. I'll follow the law for you.</p>

<p><i>Oliv.</i> And I my revenge. [<i>Exit.</i></p>

<p><i>Man.</i> [<i>To</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>.] But 'tis, my friend, in your consideration
most, that I would have returned part of your<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_506" id="Page_506">[Pg 506]</a></span>
wife's portion; for 'twere hard to take all from thee, since
thou hast paid so dear for't, in being such a rascal. Yet
thy wife is a fortune without a portion; and thou art a
man of that extraordinary merit in villany, the world and
fortune can never desert thee, though I do; therefore be
not melancholy. Fare you well, sir.&mdash;[<i>Exit</i> <span class="smcap">Vernish</span>
<i>doggedly.</i>] Now, madam, I beg your pardon [<i>Turning to</i>
<span class="smcap">Fidelia</span>] for lessening the present I made you; but my
heart can never be lessened. This, I confess, was too
small for you before; for you deserve the Indian world;
and I would now go thither, out of covetousness for
your sake only.</p>

<p><i>Fid.</i> Your heart, sir, is a present of that value, I can
never make any return to't.&mdash;[<i>Pulling</i> <span class="smcap">Manly</span> <i>from the
company.</i>] But I can give you back such a present as
this, which I got by the loss of my father, a gentleman of
the north, of no mean extraction, whose only child I
was, therefore left me in the present possession of two
thousand pounds a-year; which I left, with multitudes of
pretenders, to follow you, sir; having in several public
places seen you, and observed your actions thoroughly,
with admiration, when you were too much in love to take
notice of mine, which yet was but too visible. The
name of my family is Grey, my other Fidelia. The rest
of my story you shall know when I have fewer auditors.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, now, madam, you have taken from me all
power of making you any compliment on my part; for I
was going to tell you, that for your sake only I would
quit the unknown pleasure of a retirement; and rather
stay in this ill world of ours still, though odious to me,
than give you more frights again at sea, and make again
too great a venture there, in you alone. But if I should
tell you now all this, and that your virtue (since greater
than I thought any was in the world) had now reconciled
me to't, my friend here would say, 'tis your estate that hast
made me friends with the world.</p>

<p><i>Free.</i> I must confess I should; for I think most of our<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_507" id="Page_507">[Pg 507]</a></span>
quarrels to the world are just such as we have to a handsome
woman; only because we cannot enjoy her as we
would do.</p>

<p><i>Man.</i> Nay, if thou art a plain dealer too, give me thy
hand; for now I'll say, I am thy friend indeed; and for
your two sakes, though I have been so lately deceived in
friends of both sexes,&mdash;</p>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">I will believe there are now in the world</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Good-natured friends, who are not prostitutes,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And handsome women worthy to be friends;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Yet, for my sake, let no one e'er confide</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">In tears, or oaths, in love, or friend untried.</span><br />
</p>

<p>[<i>Exeunt.</i></p>




<hr class="chap" />
<h3>EPILOGUE.</h3>

<h4>SPOKEN BY THE WIDOW BLACKACRE.</h4>

<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To you the judges learned in stage-laws,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our poet now, by me, submits his cause;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For with young judges, such as most of you,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">The men by women best their business do:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And, truth on't is, if you did not sit here,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">To keep for us a term throughout the year,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">We could not live by'r tongues; nay, but for you,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Our chamber-practice would be little too.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And 'tis not only the stage-practiser</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Who by your meeting gets her living here:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For as in Hall of Westminster</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Sleek sempstress vents amidst the courts her ware;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">So, while we bawl, and you in judgment sit,</span><br />
<span class="pagenum"><a name="Page_508" id="Page_508">[Pg 508]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 2em;">The visor-mask sells linen too i' th' pit</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">O, many of your friends, besides us here,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Do live by putting off their several ware.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Here's daily done the great affairs o' th' nation</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Let love and us then ne'er have long-vacation.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">But hold; like other pleaders I have done</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Not my poor client's business, but my own.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Spare me a word then now for him. First know,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Squires of the long robe, he does humbly show,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">He has a just right in abusing you,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Because he is a Brother-Templar too:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For at the bar you rally one another;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Nay, fool and knave, is swallowed from a brother:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">If not the poet here, the Templar spare,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And maul him when you catch him at the bar.</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">From you, our common modish censurers,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Your favour, not your judgment, 'tis he fears:</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Of all love begs you then to rail, find fault;</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">For plays, like women, by the world are thought,</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">When you speak kindly of 'em, very naught.</span><br />
</p>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_7_7" id="Footnote_7_7"></a><a href="#FNanchor_7_7"><span class="label">[7]</span></a> From Macaulay's Essay on <i>The Comic Dramatists of the
Restoration.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_8_8" id="Footnote_8_8"></a><a href="#FNanchor_8_8"><span class="label">[8]</span></a> Daniel Wycherley, Esq., of Clive or Cleve, in Shropshire,
about seven miles north of Shrewsbury.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_9_9" id="Footnote_9_9"></a><a href="#FNanchor_9_9"><span class="label">[9]</span></a> The dates assigned by Macaulay to the first representations of
Wycherley's plays are in every case incorrect. See the Introduction
to each play.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_10_10" id="Footnote_10_10"></a><a href="#FNanchor_10_10"><span class="label">[10]</span></a> Macaulay's version of the above story is derived from Spence's
<i>Anecdotes.</i> It differs entirely from Dennis's version, which is
evidently the correct one, as the former totally misses the point,
and makes the Duchess guilty merely of a piece of unmeaning
rudeness. Dennis's account is as follows.&mdash;"The writing of that
Play [<i>Love in a Wood</i>] was the Occasion of his becoming acquainted
with one of King Charles's Mistresses after a very particular manner.
As Mr. Wycherley was going thro' <i>Pall Mall</i> towards <i>St. James's</i>
in his Chariot, he met the foresaid lady in hers, who, thrusting
half her Body out of the Chariot, cry'd out aloud to him, 'You,
Wycherley, you are a Son of a Whore,' at the same time laughing
aloud and heartily.... Mr. Wycherley was certainly very much
surpriz'd at it, yet not so much but he soon apprehended it was
spoke with Allusion to the latter End of a Song in the foremention'd
Play&mdash;
</p>
<p>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">'Great Wits and great Braves</span><br />
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">Have always a Punk to their Mother.'</span><br />
</p>
<p>
As, during Mr. Wycherley's Surprize, the Chariots drove different
ways, they were soon at a considerable Distance from each other,
when Mr. Wycherley, recovering from his Surprize, ordered his
Coachman to drive back, and to overtake the Lady. As soon as he
got over-against her, he said to her, 'Madam, you have been
pleased to bestow a title on me which generally belongs to the
Fortunate. Will your Ladyship be at the Play to-night?' 'Well,'
she reply'd, 'what if I am there?' 'Why, then I will be there to
wait on your Ladyship, tho' I disappoint a very fine Woman who
has made me an Assignation.' 'So,' said she, 'you are sure to disappoint
a Woman who has favour'd you for one who has not.'
'Yes,' reply'd he, 'if she who has not favour'd me is the finer
Woman of the two. But he who will be constant to your Ladyship,
till he can find a finer Woman, is sure to die your Captive.' The
Lady blush'd, and bade her Coachman drive away.... In short,
she was that Night in the first Row of the King's Box in 'Drury
Lane,' and Mr. Wycherley in the Pit under her, where he entertain'd
her during the whole Play." Dennis's <i>Familiar Letters</i>,
London, 1721.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_11_11" id="Footnote_11_11"></a><a href="#FNanchor_11_11"><span class="label">[11]</span></a> This anecdote is given by Leigh Hunt on the authority of
Voltaire's <i>Letters concerning the English Nation</i>. But Leigh
Hunt's memory appears to have played him false. The only
allusion, in Voltaire's <i>Letters</i>, to the connection between Wycherley
and the Duchess, is contained in the following words:&mdash;"Mr.
Wycherley, who was a long Time known publickly to be happy in
the good Graces of the most celebrated Mistress of King Charles the
Second."&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_12_12" id="Footnote_12_12"></a><a href="#FNanchor_12_12"><span class="label">[12]</span></a> Wycherley accordingly journeyed into France, about the
beginning of the winter of 1678, and returned, entirely restored, at
the end of the following spring. The King received him with the
utmost favour, and made choice of him as governor to his son. It
was immediately after this that Wycherley went down to Tunbridge
(in the summer of 1679), where he met the Countess of Drogheda,
whom he soon afterwards married.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_13_13" id="Footnote_13_13"></a><a href="#FNanchor_13_13"><span class="label">[13]</span></a> Mr. Leigh Hunt supposes that the battle at which Wycherley
was present was that which the Duke of York gained over Opdam,
in 1665. We believe that it was one of the battles between Rupert
and De Ruyter, in 1673.
</p>
<p>
The point is of no importance; and there cannot be said to be
much evidence either way. We offer, however, to Mr. Leigh Hunt's
consideration three arguments&mdash;of no great weight certainly&mdash;yet
such as ought, we think, to prevail in the absence of better. First,
it is not very likely that a young Templar, quite unknown in the
world&mdash;and Wycherley was such in 1665&mdash;should have quitted his
chambers to go to sea. On the other hand, it would have been in
the regular course of things that, when a courtier and an equerry,
he should offer his services. Secondly, his verses appear to have
been written after a drawn battle, like those of 1673, and not after
a complete victory, like that of 1665. Thirdly, in the epilogue to
<i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i>, written in 1673, he says that "all
gentlemen must pack to sea;" an expression which makes it
probable that he did not himself mean to stay behind. The
epilogue to <i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i> was probably written
about the end of 1671. See the Introduction to that play.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_14_14" id="Footnote_14_14"></a><a href="#FNanchor_14_14"><span class="label">[14]</span></a> There are no grounds whatever for this surmise.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_15_15" id="Footnote_15_15"></a><a href="#FNanchor_15_15"><span class="label">[15]</span></a> "He lost his memory (forty years before he died) by a fever, and
would repeat the same thought, sometimes in the compass of ten
lines, and did not dream of its being inserted but just before: when
you pointed it out to him, he would say, 'Gads-so, so it is! I
thank you very much: pray blot it out.'"&mdash;Pope, in Spence's
<i>Anecdotes.</i>
</p>
<p>
Elsewhere Pope states that he was forty years of age when the
illness occurred. It is possible that this illness may have been the
fever before mentioned, from which he sought recovery by travel, in
the winter of 1678; though Dennis certainly describes him as
returning "entirely restored," both in body and mind.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_16_16" id="Footnote_16_16"></a><a href="#FNanchor_16_16"><span class="label">[16]</span></a> This assertion is wholly without foundation.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_17_17" id="Footnote_17_17"></a><a href="#FNanchor_17_17"><span class="label">[17]</span></a> I can find no authority for this observation. It may have been
spoken in a moment of peevishness, but it is certainly very far from
conveying Wycherley's real estimate of his friend's genius.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_18_18" id="Footnote_18_18"></a><a href="#FNanchor_18_18"><span class="label">[18]</span></a> This "strange friendship" only terminated, as has been already
shown, with Wycherley's death.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_19_19" id="Footnote_19_19"></a><a href="#FNanchor_19_19"><span class="label">[19]</span></a> Our information respecting the closing scene of Wycherley's
life is too scanty for the formation of a definite judgment. We are,
however, under no necessity of believing the circumstances which
attended it to have been in any way scandalous. Pope's letter, on
this occasion, to Mr. Blount is here subjoined.</p>

<blockquote>
<p>"Jan. 21, 1715-16.</p>

<p>"I know of nothing that will be so interesting to you at
present, as some circumstances of the last act of that eminent comic
poet, and our friend, Wycherley. He had often told me, as I
doubt not he did all his acquaintance, that he would marry as soon
as his life was despaired of. Accordingly, a few days before his
death, he underwent the ceremony: and joined together those two
sacraments, which, wise men say, should be the last we receive:
for, if you observe, matrimony is placed after extreme unction in
our catechism, as a kind of hint of the order of time in which they
are to be taken. The old man then lay down, satisfied in the
conscience of having by this one act paid his just debts, obliged a
woman, who, he was told, had merit, and shown an heroic resentment
of the ill-usage of his next heir. Some hundred pounds,
which he had with the lady, discharged those debts: a jointure of
four hundred a year made her a recompense; and the nephew he
left to comfort himself as well as he could, with the miserable
remains of a mortgaged estate. I saw our friend twice after this
was done, less peevish in his sickness than he used to be in his
health; neither much afraid of dying, nor (which in him had been
more likely) much ashamed of marrying. The evening before he
expired, he called his young wife to the bedside, and earnestly
entreated her not to deny him one request, the last he should make.
Upon her assurances of consenting to it, he told her, 'My dear, it
is only this, that you will never marry an old man again.' I cannot
help remarking, that sickness, which often destroys both wit and
wisdom, yet seldom has power to remove that talent which we call
humour. Mr. Wycherley shewed his, even in this last compliment;
though I think his request a little hard, for why should he
bar her from doubling her jointure on the same easy terms.
</p>
<p>
"So trivial as these circumstances are, I should not be displeased
myself to know such trifles, when they concern or characterise any
eminent person. The wisest and wittiest of men are seldom wiser
or wittier than others in these sober moments. At least, our friend
ended much in the character he had lived in: and Horace's rule for
a play may as well be applied to him as a play-wright:
</p>
<p>'&mdash;&mdash;<i>Servetur ad imum</i><br />
<i>Qualis ab incepto processerit, et sibi constet.</i>'<br />
</p>
<p>
"I am, &amp;c."</p></blockquote>
<p>
It is stated that the lady's name was Jackson, and that she
brought Wycherley a fortune of £1,500. The following additional
particulars are given, on the authority of Pope, in Spence's <i>Anecdotes</i>,
"Wycherley's nephew, on whom his estate was entailed (but with
power to settle a widow's jointure) would not consent to his selling
any part of it; which he wanted much to do, to pay his debts,
about a thousand pounds. He had therefore long resolved to marry,
in order to make a settlement from the estate, to pay off his debts
with his wife's fortune, and 'to plague his damned nephew,' as he
used to express it.... After all, the woman he did marry
proved a cheat; was a cast mistress of the person who recommended
her to him; and was supplied by him with money for her wedding
clothes." This last assertion is hardly to be reconciled with the
assumption that Wycherley paid his debts with his wife's fortune.
From an allusion to his nephew's "ill-carriage" to him, in a letter
to Pope, dated Aug. 11, 1709, we gather that the quarrel between
them was of old standing; of its origin we are completely ignorant.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_20_20" id="Footnote_20_20"></a><a href="#FNanchor_20_20"><span class="label">[20]</span></a> It is difficult to understand in what the impropriety of these
speeches is supposed to consist. They are both placed in the mouth
of Sparkish, an affected fop, whose utmost ambition is to be recorded
a wit, and to whom no sacrifice would seem excessive for
the sake of a smart saying. His indifference to the young lady in
question occasions his loss of her in the end.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_21_21" id="Footnote_21_21"></a><a href="#FNanchor_21_21"><span class="label">[21]</span></a> Wycherley's "slowness" has been denied by both Pope and
Lansdowne. The former declares that "he was far from being
slow in general, and, in particular, wrote <i>The Plain Dealer</i> in
three weeks." And Lansdowne observes, "If it had been a
trouble to him to write, I am much mistaken if he would not have
spared himself that trouble." It seems certain, however, that he
revised and altered his plays before committing them to the public,
and he by no means belonged to the class of so-called Easy Writers,
with respect to whom a <i>bon-mot</i> of his is recorded in the ninth
<i>Tatler</i>. "The town has for half an age been tormented with
insects called Easy Writers, whose abilities Mr. Wycherley one
day described excellently well in one word: 'That,' said he,
'among these fellows is called Easy Writing, which anyone may
easily write.'"&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_22_22" id="Footnote_22_22"></a><a href="#FNanchor_22_22"><span class="label">[22]</span></a> A remarkably free translation, one would say; and the "whole
scene" is, in fact, but a small portion of a scene. But see, for
Wycherley's plagiarisms, the Introductions to the plays.&mdash;<span class="smcap">Ed.</span></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_23_23" id="Footnote_23_23"></a><a href="#FNanchor_23_23"><span class="label">[23]</span></a> Democritus excludes sane poets from Helicon.&mdash;<i>De Art Poet.</i> 296-7.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_24_24" id="Footnote_24_24"></a><a href="#FNanchor_24_24"><span class="label">[24]</span></a> See the <a href="#THE_GENTLEMAN">Introduction to <i>The Gentleman Dancing-Master</i></a>.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_25_25" id="Footnote_25_25"></a><a href="#FNanchor_25_25"><span class="label">[25]</span></a> <i>Some Account of the English Stage</i>, vol i. p. 135.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_26_26" id="Footnote_26_26"></a><a href="#FNanchor_26_26"><span class="label">[26]</span></a> The Mulberry Garden was situated at the further extremity of
the Mall in St. James's Park, upon the site now occupied by
Buckingham Palace and its grounds. Its name was derived from a
plantation of mulberry trees which James I. caused to be made
there. Later, the spot was converted into a public garden, with
shrubberies, walks, arbours, and a house of refreshment, and was
much frequented by persons of fashion as well as citizens. Pepys
found it "a very silly place, worse than Spring-garden," but "a
wilderness here that is somewhat pretty." The following extract
from Sedley's <i>Mulberry Garden</i> gives an idea of the doings at this
place. The scene is laid in the Garden:&mdash;
</p>
<p>
"<i>Wildish.</i> What, is there store of game here, gentlemen?
</p>
<p>
<i>Modish.</i> Troth, little or none; a few citizens that have brought
their children out to air 'em, and eat cheesecakes.
</p>
<p>
<i>Wildish.</i> I thought this place had been so full of beauties, that
like a pack of hounds in a hare warren, you could hunt one for
another: what think you of an arbor and a bottle of Rhenish?"</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_27_27" id="Footnote_27_27"></a><a href="#FNanchor_27_27"><span class="label">[27]</span></a> A gull; a courtesan's dupe; "one who may be easily led by
the nose or put upon."&mdash;<i>Bailey's Dict.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_28_28" id="Footnote_28_28"></a><a href="#FNanchor_28_28"><span class="label">[28]</span></a> Fegue or feague. "To beat, to whip, to drive."&mdash;<i>Wright
Dict. of obsolete and provincial English.</i> Hence our word <i>fag.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_29_29" id="Footnote_29_29"></a><a href="#FNanchor_29_29"><span class="label">[29]</span></a> Cheated of his portion.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_30_30" id="Footnote_30_30"></a><a href="#FNanchor_30_30"><span class="label">[30]</span></a> Whetstone's Park was the name of the district lying between
Lincoln's Inn Fields and Holborn. The character of its inhabitants
had given it at this time an ill reputation. In Crowne's comedy of
the <i>Country Wit</i> (1675) occurs the following allusion to Whetstone's
Park: "After I had gone a little way in a great broad street, I
turned into a Tavern hard by a place they call a Park; and just as
our Park is all Trees, that Park is all Houses. I asked if they had
any Deer in it, and they told me, not half so many as they used to
have; but that if I had a mind to a Doe, they would put a Doe
to me."</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_31_31" id="Footnote_31_31"></a><a href="#FNanchor_31_31"><span class="label">[31]</span></a> Strumpet.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_32_32" id="Footnote_32_32"></a><a href="#FNanchor_32_32"><span class="label">[32]</span></a> A prostitute.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_33_33" id="Footnote_33_33"></a><a href="#FNanchor_33_33"><span class="label">[33]</span></a> The present Pall Mall, so called from the game of Pall Mall
formerly played there with ball and mallet. In Wycherley's time
Pall Mall was already a street of houses, and the game was then
played at the Mall in St. James's Park, also called Pall Mall.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_34_34" id="Footnote_34_34"></a><a href="#FNanchor_34_34"><span class="label">[34]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> The New Exchange, a long building, erected upon the
site of the stables of Durham House, on the south side of the
Strand, and nearly opposite Bedford Street. Opened in 1609, it
became a fashionable lounge after the Restoration, and was pulled
down in 1737. "It was erected partly on the plan of the Royal
Exchange, with vaults beneath, over which was an open paved
arcade; and above were walks of shops, occupied by perfumers and
publishers, milliners and sempstresses."&mdash;<i>Timbs' Curiosities of
London.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_35_35" id="Footnote_35_35"></a><a href="#FNanchor_35_35"><span class="label">[35]</span></a> Strumpet.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_36_36" id="Footnote_36_36"></a><a href="#FNanchor_36_36"><span class="label">[36]</span></a> Bulk. "A stall before a shop."&mdash;<i>Bailey.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_37_37" id="Footnote_37_37"></a><a href="#FNanchor_37_37"><span class="label">[37]</span></a> Or Ferrandine: a stuff made of silk and wool.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_38_38" id="Footnote_38_38"></a><a href="#FNanchor_38_38"><span class="label">[38]</span></a> In 1577, William Lamb (formerly a gentleman of the chapel to
Henry VIII.) caused to be constructed, in the fields where now
stands Lamb's Conduit Street, a reservoir and a conduit by which
the water was conveyed to Snow Hill. These fields formed a place
of resort for the inhabitants of the adjoining districts. The conduit
was restored, from a design by Sir Christopher Wren, in 1667.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_39_39" id="Footnote_39_39"></a><a href="#FNanchor_39_39"><span class="label">[39]</span></a> "Cross or pile": equivalent to our "heads or tails." A cross
was usually on the reverse of old English coins; the obverse was
called the "pile," from the pile or punch with which the impression
was struck.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_40_40" id="Footnote_40_40"></a><a href="#FNanchor_40_40"><span class="label">[40]</span></a> The New Spring Garden, at Vauxhall; afterwards under the
name of Vauxhall, the most famous place of resort of that kind in
the metropolis. It was first opened about 1661, when Evelyn describes
it as "a pretty-contriv'd plantation," and was closed in
1859. Pepys has an interesting entry concerning it, under date
of May 28, 1667; "I by water to Fox-hall, and there walked in
Spring-garden. A great deal of company, and the weather and
garden pleasant: and it is very pleasant and cheap going thither,
for a man may go to spend what he will, or nothing, all as one.
But to hear the nightingale and other birds, and here fiddles and
there a harp, and here a Jew's trump, and here laughing, and there
fine people walking, is mighty divertising."&mdash;The Neat-house was
a place of entertainment at Pimlico.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_41_41" id="Footnote_41_41"></a><a href="#FNanchor_41_41"><span class="label">[41]</span></a> A powdering-tub means properly a tub in which meat is salted,
to sprinkle with salt being an occasional sense of the verb "to
powder." Hence the name of powdering-tub was applied to places
where persons afflicted with a certain disease were cured. Compare
Shakespeare, <i>Measure for Measure</i>, iii. 2; "Troth, sir, she hath
eaten up all her beef, and she is herself in the tub." Also <i>King
Henry V.</i>, ii. 1.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_42_42" id="Footnote_42_42"></a><a href="#FNanchor_42_42"><span class="label">[42]</span></a> The Mortlake tapestry was of some note at this time. The
works had been founded under the patronage of James I., and
Rubens and Vandyck subsequently lent their services to the undertaking.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_43_43" id="Footnote_43_43"></a><a href="#FNanchor_43_43"><span class="label">[43]</span></a> The angel was worth 10<i>s.</i>, and the piece 22<i>s.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_46_46" id="Footnote_46_46"></a><a href="#FNanchor_46_46"><span class="label">[46]</span></a> Mother Clifford was a noted procuress, who is mentioned in

<p><a name="Footnote_52_52" id="Footnote_52_52"></a><a href="#FNanchor_52_52"><span class="label">[52]</span></a> Punchinello had a booth at Charing Cross in 1666; this was

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_59_59" id="Footnote_59_59"></a><a href="#FNanchor_59_59"><span class="label">[59]</span></a> The saraband was a slow and stately dance.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_60_60" id="Footnote_60_60"></a><a href="#FNanchor_60_60"><span class="label">[60]</span></a> A farcical personage of the Italian stage, in the character of a
military braggart. Tiberio Fiurelli, the creator of this part, was
acting in Wycherley's time at the Italian Theatre in Paris. Angel
and Nokes were eminent comic actors of the day, and this scene
must have been sufficiently diverting if, as Genest supposes, the part
of Monsieur de Paris was actually played by Nokes, and that of Don
Diego by Angel.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_61_61" id="Footnote_61_61"></a><a href="#FNanchor_61_61"><span class="label">[61]</span></a> <i>Gavanho</i> in former editions, but there is no such word in the
Spanish language. I venture to substitute <i>gabacho</i>, a term of contempt
applied to a Frenchman.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_62_62" id="Footnote_62_62"></a><a href="#FNanchor_62_62"><span class="label">[62]</span></a> The <i>golilla</i> was a collar of pasteboard, covered with white
muslin, starched and plaited. It was at this time generally worn in
Spain, but later only by lawyers.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_63_63" id="Footnote_63_63"></a><a href="#FNanchor_63_63"><span class="label">[63]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i>, To bow in the Spanish fashion.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_64_64" id="Footnote_64_64"></a><a href="#FNanchor_64_64"><span class="label">[64]</span></a> Scarlet. A new method of dyeing scarlet was brought to
England in 1643 by a German, who established his dye-house at
Bow; hence Bow-dye came to signify scarlet. It is also used as a
verb: "Now a cup of nappy ale will bow-dye a man's face."</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_65_65" id="Footnote_65_65"></a><a href="#FNanchor_65_65"><span class="label">[65]</span></a> Cudden or cuddy; a clown; a silly fellow.</p></div>

<p><a name="Footnote_66_66" id="Footnote_66_66"></a><a href="#FNanchor_66_66"><span class="label">[66]</span></a> Blot.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_67_67" id="Footnote_67_67"></a><a href="#FNanchor_67_67"><span class="label">[67]</span></a> The "Checkers" was a common sign of public houses; from
the game of checkers, or draughts.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_68_68" id="Footnote_68_68"></a><a href="#FNanchor_68_68"><span class="label">[68]</span></a> Jump: a short coat.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_69_69" id="Footnote_69_69"></a><a href="#FNanchor_69_69"><span class="label">[69]</span></a> I am out of patience when anything is blamed, not because it is thought
coarsely and inelegantly composed, but because it is new: when for the ancients
not indulgence, but honour and rewards are demanded.&mdash;<i>Epist.</i> II. i. 76-8.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_70_70" id="Footnote_70_70"></a><a href="#FNanchor_70_70"><span class="label">[70]</span></a> Charles Hart, grandson of Shakespeare's sister, Joan Hart, was
one of the most distinguished actors of his time. He excelled
chiefly in tragedy, and it was said of him that he "might teach any
king on earth how to comport himself." He retired from the stage
in 1682, and died in the following year.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_71_71" id="Footnote_71_71"></a><a href="#FNanchor_71_71"><span class="label">[71]</span></a> A character in Ben Jonson's comedy, <i>The Alchemist</i>.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_72_72" id="Footnote_72_72"></a><a href="#FNanchor_72_72"><span class="label">[72]</span></a> <i>Sir Martin Mar-all</i> is the title of a comedy by Dryden, first
produced in 1667. In the scene referred to, Sir Martin serenades
his mistress, going through the motions of singing and accompanying
himself with the lute, while the actual performance is that of his
man, who is concealed behind him. The lady discovers the imposition,
through Sir Martin's failing to leave off at the right time.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_73_73" id="Footnote_73_73"></a><a href="#FNanchor_73_73"><span class="label">[73]</span></a> Chatelain's was a famous French ordinary in Covent Garden,
much frequented by wits and men of fashion. It is mentioned by
Pepys, and often referred to by Shadwell in his plays. The Cock
Tavern was in Bow Street, near where Wycherley and his first wife,
the Countess of Drogheda, lodged; and it was here that the
windows had to be left open when Wycherley frequented it, that the
countess might see there were no ladies in the company.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_74_74" id="Footnote_74_74"></a><a href="#FNanchor_74_74"><span class="label">[74]</span></a> See <a href="#Footnote_34_34">note 34</a>.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_75_75" id="Footnote_75_75"></a><a href="#FNanchor_75_75"><span class="label">[75]</span></a> "Covent Garden Drolery, Or a Colection of all the Choice
Songs, Poems, Prologues, and Epilogues (Sung and Spoken at
Courts and Theaters) never in Print before. Written by the refined'st
Witts of the Age. And Collected by R[ichard] B[rome]
Servant to His Majestie. London, Printed for James Magnes neer
the Piazza in Russel-Street, 1672."&mdash;<i>Tarugo's Wiles, or the Coffee
House</i>; a comedy by Sir Thomas St. Serle, produced in 1668.&mdash;<i>The
Slighted Maid</i>, a comedy by Sir Robert Stapleton, produced in
1663.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_76_76" id="Footnote_76_76"></a><a href="#FNanchor_76_76"><span class="label">[76]</span></a> A sweet-scented powder.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_77_77" id="Footnote_77_77"></a><a href="#FNanchor_77_77"><span class="label">[77]</span></a> Carefully.</p></div>

<p><a name="Footnote_78_78" id="Footnote_78_78"></a><a href="#FNanchor_78_78"><span class="label">[78]</span></a> Succeeds.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_79_79" id="Footnote_79_79"></a><a href="#FNanchor_79_79"><span class="label">[79]</span></a> Romp; tomboy.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_80_80" id="Footnote_80_80"></a><a href="#FNanchor_80_80"><span class="label">[80]</span></a> A well frequented ordinary near Charing Cross, on the site of
Drummond's Bank.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_81_81" id="Footnote_81_81"></a><a href="#FNanchor_81_81"><span class="label">[81]</span></a> In Wycherley's time the square of Covent Garden must have
presented an elegant appearance. The Piazza, designed by Inigo
Jones, extended, like the modern piazza, along the northern and
eastern sides; on the west stood St. Paul's Church, built by the
same famous architect, and on the south the square was bordered
by the gardens of Bedford House. "The area was inclosed with
railings, at sixty feet from the buildings; and in the centre was a
dial, with a gilt ball, raised upon a column." <i>Timbs' Curiosities of
London.</i> In 1671 the market was established, but was held, originally,
only on the southern side of the square, under the wall of
Bedford Gardens. The houses within the Piazza were then occupied
by persons of rank and fashion.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_82_82" id="Footnote_82_82"></a><a href="#FNanchor_82_82"><span class="label">[82]</span></a> Paw, adj. naughty. An affected word fashionable in the
latter half of the seventeenth century.&mdash;<i>Wright.</i></p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_83_83" id="Footnote_83_83"></a><a href="#FNanchor_83_83"><span class="label">[83]</span></a> "Lanterloo" or "langteraloo" was the name of a game at

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_87_87" id="Footnote_87_87"></a><a href="#FNanchor_87_87"><span class="label">[87]</span></a> It cannot have been earlier than the latter year, as <i>Le Misanthrope</i>,

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_88_88" id="Footnote_88_88"></a><a href="#FNanchor_88_88"><span class="label">[88]</span></a> Dryden.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_89_89" id="Footnote_89_89"></a><a href="#FNanchor_89_89"><span class="label">[89]</span></a> <i>Letters concerning the English Nation.</i> London, 1733.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

<p><a name="Footnote_90_90" id="Footnote_90_90"></a><a href="#FNanchor_90_90"><span class="label">[90]</span></a> It is, to say the least, doubtful if <i>Les Plaideurs</i> were written
before <i>The Plain Dealer</i>. The former was produced in 1668. This
supposed discovery of a non-existent coincidence appears to have
arisen from a misinterpretation of Voltaire's words in the French
edition of his <i>Letters concerning the English Nation</i>: "On a encore
lardé cette piece (<i>The Plain Dealer</i>) d'une Comtesse de Pimbesche,
vieille plaideuse." But Voltaire clearly employs the title of
"Comtesse de Pimbesche" only as a generic term for a litigious
female.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">
